DTEK is the largest private investor in the Ukrainian energy sector, employing 70 thousand people. DTEK Group generates electricity at solar, wind and thermal power plants, distributes and supplies electricity to end consumers, provides energy efficient solutions, develops a network of EV charging stations, as well as producing coal and natural gas. DTEK aspires to achieve carbon neutrality by 2040 across all its businesses.
We welcome the initiatives of the European Commission to set out the European Green Deal, a new growth strategy that aims to transform the EU into an economy with zero net GHG emissions by 2050. We also appreciate its commitment to ensure a level playing field for all market players and to lead the way globally in achieving carbon neutrality.

In this context, we would like to highlight our support for the strategic policy of the President and of the Government of Ukraine to gradually align with EU legislation on energy and climate and to continuously implement commitments under the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement and the Energy Community Treaty. In January 2020, the Government of Ukraine launched a Green energy transition process aiming to achieve carbon neutrality.

Regarding the inception impact assessment of the initiative on the 2030 Climate Target Plan, we would like to emphasize that the EU ambition to reduce GHG emissions by 50 or 55% by 2030 will have a direct impact on neighboring countries, especially on the contracting parties of the Energy Community, who aspire to integrate their energy markets with the European one.

The role of the EU as a global climate leader would consider such challenges and support for economies that are also committed to carbon neutrality but have less resources to achieve it at such an accelerated pace. Such considerations should cover the risk of a deepening gap between the EU and neighboring countries as the EU has larger capacities and resources to achieve these ambitious targets.

Therefore, we believe that the assessment should thoroughly examine the international impact of this initiative and suggest practical recommendations aiming to assist neighboring countries on their paths to climate neutrality. The assessment should consider the unintended consequences of the EU’s climate ambition on less mature electricity markets, such as the emerging Ukrainian electricity market. This could also envisage the extension of the analysis of the potential impact of the higher 2030 Climate Target on the situation around energy poverty and energy affordability in such countries.

I am Norris Whiston.  I live in Earltown Nova Scotia. I have a BSc in Engineering from the University of Rhode Island and a MEd from Acadia University.  I have written many histories, nature guides, and given talks. 
Having seen what disasters are soon to happen, right now we need to fully understand the complexities of what sequesters carbon and its first, but not only assistant, nitrogen, we need to use the best carbon sequestering means that the Earth can muster, and we need to secure and keep cool the carbon that had taken centuries to put into our soils.  We certainly shouldn’t pretend, by absurd reasoning that putting any more carbon into atmosphere justifies ruining the best ways of sequestering carbon and losing carbon that took so long to get. 
Some of the thoughts (and there are many more) that should go into avoiding the impending calamity are:
1. “Forests that are structurally variable and contain multiple layers of leaves outperform structurally simple forest with a single concentrated band of vegetation.” (Mcneill, Brian Virginia Commonwealth University 12 August 2019 Phys.org News) from (Gough et al. 9 August 2019 Ecology)
2. “In reality, biodiversity-challenged plantations are a far less reliable carbon sink than forests. Plantations can sequester only a quarter of the CO2 that functioning woodlands can, and converting forests to plantations actually releases carbon trapped in soil.” (Graber-Stiehl 3 March 2016 Pacific Standard Magazine) 
3. “Researchers found that in Europe, trees grown since 1750 have actually increased global warming. The scientist believe that replacing broadleaved species with conifers is a key reason for the negative climate impact.” “Removing trees in an organized fashion tends to release carbon that would otherwise remain stored in forest litter, deadwood and soil.” (McGrath 5 February 2016 BBC News) from (Naudts et al. 5 February 2016 Science)  
4. A study of 673,046 trees worldwide organized by the US Department of the Interior found the oldest trees sequester best. Spokesman N. Stephenson indicated that it was like the star player was a 90 year old instead of the 20 year. (Stephenson et al. 6March 2014 Nature 90-93) 
5. The presence of trees that fix nitrogen can double the amount of carbon a forest stores in its first 30 years of regrowth.  (Cary institute of Ecosystem Studies 13 February 2020 Phys.Org News)
6. Soil are vulnerable to warmth.  “Soils from colder regions and those with greater amounts of carbon were seen to emit more as temperatures went up.” (McGrath 3 Sept. 2014 BBC News) from (Karhu et al. 3 Sept. 2014 Nature)
7. Soil holds four times as much carbon stores as plant biomass. (Karhu 2014 Nature)
8. “As soon as we shovel the ground we are releasing greenhouse gas emissions.” (Kinver 18 October 2016 BBC News) 
9.  Soils are still losing carbon 15 years after clear cutting.  A 15 yr old stand released to the atmosphere 5 tonnes of CO2 per hectare annually. (Black, Andrew January 2006 Biocap).
To sum up: The best forests and trees to sequester carbon are older trees, hardwoods, are in structurally complex layers, and have natural nitrogen fixing capabilities within them.  Older natural forest needs to be protected and soils should be exposed as little as possible, certainly not by clearcuts, fragmentation or overdoing highway shoulders.
Where I live I am presently surrounded by clearcuts and listen and watch trucks pass my home with logs of various sizes on their way to chipping mills.  At one such mill in Sheet Harbor, Nova Scotia, I was able to take pictures of old large logs awaiting chipping and piles of chips that were about to be shipped across the Atlantic for biomass fuel.  Those digitals are dated and located.  All my digitals are done that way.  Some have been used by other Naturalists. You are welcomed for copies if you wish.
Yours truly,
Norris Whiston

Following up to date climate science consensus it is apparent, that your goal of becoming carbon neutral by 2050 does not protect us sufficiently from a global temperature increase above 1.5 degrees.
If we are serious about this, we need a more realistic and ambitious target to avoid the very likely catastrophic demise of civilisation with a warming atmosphere above 1.5 degrees.

We commend the EU for its interest in climate change mitigation. It is our sincere hope that the EU will lead the world in a more sustainable direction. 

In our rapidly warming and changing climate, it’s undeniable that  “business as usual” is no longer acceptable. The United Nations states, “Climate Change is the defining issue of our time and we are at a defining moment […] Without drastic action today, adapting to these impacts in the future will be more difficult and costly.” 

Burning forest wood for so-called ‘green’ energy controverts the undeniable reality of climate change. If burning biomass is designated ‘zero-carbon,’ then our environment will continue to pay in lost carbon sinks, habitats, and biodiversity.

Clearcutting has disastrous effects. Here in Nova Scotia, it has led to younger forests with smaller trees, less high-quality trees, and less species variety. This has created “a forest that is more susceptible to the stresses of climate change, such as insects and weather damage; less able to provide the ecosystem services required by society; and less economically valuable.” (William Lahey, An Independent Review of Forest Practices in Nova Scotia) 

Forests are a naturally stabilizing force for the climate. But their role is two-fold: they can act as both a cause and a solution for greenhouse gas emissions. (The International Union for Conservation of Nature, Forests and climate change)

The world cannot afford to lose the ecological benefits that healthy forests provide. “Forests are one of the most important solutions to addressing the effects of climate change. Approximately 2.6 billion tonnes of carbon dioxide, one-third of the CO2 released from burning fossil fuels, is absorbed by forests every year. […] Increasing and maintaining forests is therefore an essential solution to climate change.” (IUCN)

“Forestry can make a very significant contribution to a low-cost global mitigation portfolio that provides synergies with adaptation and sustainable development. However, this opportunity is being lost in the current institutional context and lack of political will to implement and has resulted in only a small portion of this potential being realized at present.” (Nabuurs et al, Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change)

“The biggest natural sink of terrestrial carbon lies in our forests and trees,” says Steve Running, a forest ecologist at the University of Montana. 
“And the biggest natural source of carbon on land is also the forest. So one of the most important things we can do for understanding the carbon budget is to get a better inventory of the carbon we have in our trees.” (NASA Earth Observatory, Seeing Forests for the Trees and the Carbon)

Clearcutting and burning harvested trees actively worsens climate change. When trees are felled or burned, the carbon dioxide they store escapes into the air, adding to greenhouse gas emissions. 

“There is more carbon in forest ecosystems – in the living and dead biomass of trees and in soils – than there is currently in the atmosphere, and in fact more than in all known oil and coal reserves combined. The Amazon forest alone stores so much carbon that if it were all released through deforestation, global warming would exceed the 1.5°C threshold, even if we stopped using fossil fuels.” (IUCN, Primary forests: our most valuable nature-based solution). 

Data from Drax Power Station in the U.K. demonstrate that burning pellets emits more CO2 than coal per unit energy. Burning wood cannot be “taken for zero for solid and gaseous biomass.”

We fully support the EU’s goal to cut greenhouse gas emissions by 50-55% for 2030. But supporting the use of biomass for energy would lead to the continued clearcutting of forests, an even further decline in carbon sink levels, and heightened emissions. Our natural ecosystems are our greatest weapons in the fight against climate change. We must protect and restore our forests.

Sincerely,

Lindsay Lee

Nelfo represents the electrical contractors in Norway. 

As member of the EuropeOn, representing the European electrical contracting sector, we welcomes the initiative of raising the intermediary climate targets, strongly needed for a climate neutral and competitive Europe. If the long-term objective of climate neutrality by 2050 is to be achieved, a much higher level of ambition is needed in the short-term.

As the Covid-19 pandemic has halted European economies, recovery packages have the potential to be a tipping point for climate action. The choices made now in response to this health crisis will determine the strength and pace of future growth in the green economy, and subsequent uptake of emissions-reducing solutions. We therefore urge the EU and its Member States to fully integrate the Green Deal and the upcoming stimulus packages. Similarly, the new 2030 targets should aim and account for a green recovery, thus channelling capital streams towards sustainable activities.

Electrification is the most efficient pathway to climate neutrality, and should be incentivised as part of the upcoming smart sector integration strategy. Electric technologies have now matured enough to cover sectors such as heating or transport. Crucially, electric technologies are zero-emissions technologies, and should take precedence in an ambitious climate plan.
An integrated approach, focusing on electric technologies and maximising their efficiency, should underpin the formulation of decarbonisation policies. An efficient combination of direct and indirect electrification is the most cost-effective and just pathway to climate neutrality for the EU.

Economic & Social Impacts

With the European Green Deal, the Commission has rightfully presented its energy transition plan as a growth strategy. Indeed, a well managed transition can make Europe more competitive and bring economic prosperity to its citizens, on top of a cleaner environment and air to breathe.

While some sectors will inevitably decline (i.e. fossil sectors), others, such as the electrical contracting sector, are poised to grow tremendously. Our sector is already expanding as a result of the ongoing shift to clean technologies and digitalization. Electrical contracting businesses, who already employ around 1.8 million professionals, currently report many open vacancies, full order books and, critically, difficulties recruiting professionals skilled in areas such as digitalization, renewables, energy efficiency and more.

As enablers of the energy transition, electrical contractors play a crucial role in the rollout of climate mitigating technologies. Their difficulties recruiting personnel with a future-proof skillset has the potential to considerably hamper their aforementioned role and create bottlenecks in the switch to a clean economy. Just considering passenger road transport, we can estimate that about 1.000 public charging points will need to be installed every day for the next 10 years to meet 2030 targets. For solar, this rises to 3.000 PV installation per day. Such a workload relies on the availability of enough qualified personnel, which is not the case at the moment.

Policies supporting employment and training in the green economy have to be implemented immediately to ensure that the workforce of tomorrow is equipped with the adequate skills to meet the growing demand for clean energy solutions. Education reforms must take place to adapt to the fast-paced evolutions in the clean energy sector with dynamically updated training curricula and up- and re-skilling strategies. Private sector stakeholders are in the best position to provide guidance on training needs of the labour market.

A just and competitive energy transition is within our grasp. With strong political commitments and objectives for climate neutrality and matching governmental support for all sectors, the green economy can thrive and lead Europe in a new era of sustainable growth.

La visión recogida en el documento está lejos de expresar la urgencia y profundidad de la transición ecológica imprescindible para realizar el cambio sistémico necesario para abordar la crisis climática. El documento contiene algunas declaraciones incorrectas:
1 – AUMENTO DE LA DEUDA ECOLÓGICA
«En la actualidad, nuestros sistemas económicos están empleando el fraudulento esquema de la pirámide de Ponzi con nuestro planeta. Estamos consumiendo recursos naturales más rápidamente de lo que pueden regenerarse; estamos utilizando los recursos de las próximas generaciones para operar en el presente y nos estamos hundiendo cada vez más en la deuda ecológica. La prosperidad sólo puede perdurar si asumimos los límites de nuestro planeta. Esto nos permitiría construir una economía que funcione para siempre. Sin embargo, ignorarlos conduce a una economía finita y limitada en el tiempo que erosiona constantemente el planeta del que depende».
Fuente: Global Footprint Network (https://www.footprintnetwork.org/about-us/our-history/ )
2 – COLAPSO ECOLOGICO VS. LOS «GASES»
¿Es la emergencia ecológica principalmente un problema de emisión de gases? El Plan del objetivo climático se centra en las emisiones de gases de efecto invernadero provinientes del sector energético. Sin embargo, el cambio del uso del suelo ha tenido el impacto negativo relativo más grande en el colapso ecológico. Estos dos aspectos no pueden ser abordados de manera separada, ya que las estrategias de transición energéticas son intensivas en términos de uso del suelo y explotación minera.
El 75% del medio ambiente terrestre ha sido severamente alterado por la población humana, extraemos aproximadamente 60 mil millones de toneladas de recursos cada año, el doble que en 1980. Más del 85% de los humedales existentes en 1700 desaparecieron antes del 2000. La cubierta forestal mundial alcanza sólamente el 68% de los niveles pre-industriales y existen aproximadamente 17.000 minerías de gran escala en el mundo. El cambio climático todavia no es el factor más significativo de la destrucción de la naturaleza. Eso significa que el problema que abordamos no es simplemente cómo «limpiar» nuestras fuentes de energía, sino más bien cómo podemos reducir nuestro consumo global de energía para salvar al planeta.

La UE sigue negociando puntos porcentuales en el «presupuesto de carbono» los cuales resultan, dudosos  y difíciles de calcular. El nivel de incertidumbre que acarrea este presupuesto es excesivo y lo convierte en infructuoso; necesitamos un enfoque mucho más directo como pueden ser altas restricciones al uso de la energía y de los materiales, la conservación de la naturaleza por encima de los beneficios económicos, una transición agrícola hacia la agroecología, etc. Además, de acuerdo con el «Informe sobre Calentamiento Global de 1,5ºC» del IPCC, el objetivo de mantener el calentamiento global por debajo de 1,5ºC requeriría de un descenso drástico de emisiones antes de 2030. Stand.earth commends the EU on its efforts to significantly reduce greenhouse gas emissions over the next decade. In order to effectively reduce emissions and achieve climate-neutrality, any amendment to the European Climate Law must address the risk of a growing biomass energy sector.

The integrity of any plan to significantly reduce carbon emissions by 2030 and achieve carbon neutrality by 2050 is seriously jeopardized by the continued growth of biomass energy. Biomass continues to be sourced from primary forest regions, namely in the United States and Canada. Protecting forests for natural and carbon values is a vital component of a successful global climate strategy. Maintaining older, biodiverse forests, draws down carbon levels and helps buffer at-risk ecosystems against the impacts of climate change. Protecting intact forests also makes nearby communities more resilient to climate impacts such as drought, floods, and wildfire. Writing to the European Union in 2018, 796 scientists stated that supplying an additional 3% of global energy with biomass would require logging rates of global forests to be doubled.

European demand for forest-sourced biomass, such as wood pellets, to burn for energy is having a direct impact on some of the most carbon-rich forests on the planet, including the Canadian boreal and the inland rainforests in British Columbia. Despite evidence proving that biomass energy produces more carbon dioxide at the stack than coal, stack emissions are not accounted for. Harvest-side emissions are also not fully accounted for, creating a serious carbon debt.

When forests are logged and burned for energy, the carbon they accumulated over many years is instantaneously transferred into the atmosphere. Many forests may never re-capture the amount of carbon they once stored. Classifying forest bioenergy as a “renewable” resource alongside wind and solar falsely assumes that sourcing regions will recover within a single lifetime. Some of the planet’s most carbon-dense forests are found in British Columbia, and it will take centuries for these forests to regain carbon storage potential comparable to pre-logging levels.
Wood pellet production risks further legitimizing wasteful and destructive logging practices, rather than incentivizing meaningful forestry reform that protects carbon-rich and ecologically important forests. Destructive practices like clearcutting further diminish a forest’s ability to begin recovering its carbon storage potential. Research in BC has shown that following a clearcut, there’s a minimum 13 year window where the logged and replanted area no longer sequesters carbon: this analysis suggests that clearcutting is preventing forests in BC from removing an additional 26.5 million tonnes of carbon dioxide per year from the atmosphere. The combined figure is equivalent to the annual emissions from almost 15 million passenger vehicles.
As part of this process, we encourage the European Commissions to: require accounting of stack emissions from bioenergy facilities, and account for additional emissions associated with forest impacts; ensure that biomass from primary forest regions is not classified as renewable or carbon neutral, and discourage subsidies to the sector accordingly; and account for the importance of intact forests in achieving climate goals.

The point of departure of the 2030 Climate Target Plan is the right one: the 40% greenhouse gas (GHG) emission reduction target of the EU is completely inadequate to stay below 1.5 degrees of Global Heating, so a revised target is essential to tackle the climate crisis. However, a GHG reduction target amounting to 50-55%, remains inadequate for the task. The IPCC clearly stated in its 1.5 Special Report that in order to stay below 1.5 degrees of Heating, "global net anthropogenic CO2 emissions decline by about 45% from 2010 levels by 2030 (40–60% interquartile range), reaching net zero around 2050" (IPCC Chapter 2, p.95). While on face value the proposed EU targets appear to meet these requirements, they fail to acknowledge that the IPCC is referring to "global" emission reduction. As a signatory to the Paris Agreement, the EU has endorsed the principle of "common but differentiated responsibilities". This means that Annex I countries have higher mitigation responsibilities than countries of the developing world. Developed states not only have a strong historic responsibility given their large carbon footprints, but also the technical and financial capacities to reduce emissions, while developing states often find themselves in very vulnerable economic situations. In order to comply with its "fair share", the EU therefore has to urgently increase its ambition. Not only is this required by its commitments under the Paris Agreement, but also by the EU's human rights obligations. Already at the current 1 degree of warming, we are witnessing substantive human rights violations of the socio-economically most vulnerable and marginalised communities. To honour its commitments and stand by its values, the EU has to increase its ambition.

A couple of reflections and questions for consideration with respect to appropriate new 2030 targets
1. With respect to the inception impact assessment Ref. Ares(2020)1631599 - 18/03/2020
Towards the end, on p.6, the text states: "... the EC will look ... extending the scope of emissions trading (e.g. to road transport, maritime transport and buildings) ..."
This raises questions:
a. Why only specific sectors and not all, society-wide energy use? A kg CO2 is a kg CO2, independent of its origin, so why not tax them all equally in order to set a price signal for all CO2 emissions, and thus facilitate an overall societal cost optimum mix of measures?
b. Why only look at extending the ETS? Why not also/equally analyse the reverse option, namely to extend the ETD to the present ETS energy use (replacing over time the ETS)? If the on-going initiative to renew the ETD is successful, the ETD could be more effective than the ETS because it guarantees predictable carbon prices, which is a necessary precondition for investments. Reportedly, for this reason even some industrialist would be asking for a fixed carbon price trajectory.
c. Why not also consider energy taxes (as in the 2011 ETD draft) to stimulate moderation of demand, instead of mere fuel switching (risking to cause new investment needs in lower carbon, but not zero carbon infrastructure).

2. Skip CCS, leapfrog to BECCS: a great opportunity?
Climate projections seem to indicate that in the future negative emissions will to a greater or lesser extent (depending on the scenario) be needed. Then, why not start right now? BECCS is one of the large-scale options (and among the cheapest).
The ports of Rotterdam (NL), Antwerp & Ghent (BE) state that they will systematically apply CCS (apparently based on fossil fuels) by 2025-2030, with off-shore sequestration in depleted gas fields. Why not investigate whether they could immediately apply BECSS? This would "double" the positive climate impact, and allow for more rapid progress in the short term, by 2030.
Rather than setting up a collection network of CO2 from all plants, could the ports maybe convert biomass into CO2 (for sequestration) and H2. The hydrogen can then be delivered to all the plants at the price of natural gas (including ETS carbon price), so that they then all don't need to worry about the carbon capture or competitiveness. All extra costs (more expensive biomass, conversion, capture, ...) could be borne by the society as a whole, notably from energy and carbon tax revenues. What would be the surplus cost per tonne CO2 avoided?
This concept could be rolled out relatively quickly in all EU ports with significant industrial CO2 emission. What would be the total potential?
Also all new coastal (back-up) power plants could be located in these ports, thus further boosting the benefits.
The scheme would also relatively quickly reduce natural gas consumption, so that (stranded) investments in new gas infrastructure could be avoided, even if its consumption would still (provisionally) rise elsewhere. In this manner investments would be most productive (directly BECCS, rather than nat'l gas).
Could this approach allow for a 55% 2030 target, rather than 50%?
IPCC reports that worldwide 100 EJ could sustainable be harvested. Present global energy use is about 600 EJ. So the scheme could probably be applicable to most industrial harbours around the world, if available biomass is preferentially dedicated to this use.
It would establish permanent long term negative emissions.

ENTSO-E welcomes the EC initiative for the 2030 climate target plan and the need for a relevant impact assessment to prepare the transition towards climate neutrality by 2050. TSOs are committed to play their role in enabling this transition. According to the latest TYNDP scenarios, carbon neutrality must be achieved by 2040 in the electricity sector and by 2050 in all other sectors to comply with the 1.5° C target of the Paris Agreement. This will require the replacement of fossil fuels by carbon free primary sources, development of flexibility, including demand side response, digital solutions, system integration, investments in physical and digital infrastructure and closer TSO-DSO cooperation, all while keeping the balance of affordability, security and sustainability for EU citizens and industries.
A holistic approach to planning the energy system is needed in order to assess the impact of new targets on energy infrastructure. ENTSO-E deliverables (TYNDPs, joint scenarios, MAF) provide a substantial database for further analysis on the power system needs, the pathways to 2040, the infrastructure requirements to meet climate ambitions, or the cost of ‘no grid’ options. The MAF reveals the need for increased flexibility, and for fully exploiting the flexibility potential of new resources, in order to balance a power system with greater share of variable RES. 
The electricity transmission grid plays a pivotal role to ensure adequacy in Europe. ENTSO-E’s TYNDP is a solid basis for the infrastructure investments needed for the energy transition. However, ensuring adequate and timely development of infrastructure in pace with RES deployment requires to simplify and speed-up permitting processes. 
The 2030 climate target plan should take into account the significant potential of smart sector integration to facilitate decarbonisation efforts through a holistic approach. Different sector integration technologies and solutions will be key to decarbonise various sectors by capitalizing on complementarities and synergies, and providing best use of most efficient cross-sectoral flexibilities, while maintaining the reliability and resilience of the power system. In addition, system security and energy efficiency should be criteria in the assessment of all policy options.
An appropriate governance framework is important to support the climate agenda. NECPs shall provide consistent and structured pathways towards this. This framework should count on strong European cooperation, with an important role for regions and a strong European leadership in research and innovation. 
Implementing the cyber-physical grid will enable efficiency gains and new functionalities for the whole power system. Digitalization drives innovation leading to new services, solutions, products and markets. The 2030 climate target plan should assess the contribution of digitalization, coming from efficiency gains in grid operation and planning, removing market access barriers, ensuring transparency for consumers, and creating new market opportunities  from a system perspective, while maintaining operational security and minimizing costs and risks for the system.
An enabling framework for R&D&I will be key to achieve the climate objectives: more research and innovation in techniques and processes enabling market integration, coordination and automation will be required to meet challenges stemming from greater energy cross-border exchanges, the development of local markets and active customers’ participation in the power system. As renewables provide more system services in the future, more innovative assets and solutions will be vital for the secure grid operation. A “one system” perspective that includes decentralization of generation, sectorial integration, active consumers, digitalization and new technologies, coupled with the market design delivering the right investment signals and incentives for innovation will be key for a future-proof European energy system.

Ich finde die Bemühungen der einzelnen Regierungen und auch der EU noch viel zu gering.
Lange Zeit, jahrzehntelan, wurde uns immer wieder vorgebetet, dass ein schnelleres Handeln nicht möglich wäre. Stattdessen wurde es nicht nur nicht besser sondern sogar schlimmer mit dem Ausstoß von CO 2 durch die Verbrennugn fossiler Rohstoffe.
Nun reichen die Maßnahmen, die man im Jahr 1990 angepeilt hat, längst nicht mehr aus, denn der menschengemachte Klimawandel ist viel schneller vorangeschritten, als erwartet und vorherberechnet. Umso wichtiger sind nun auch drastischere und konsequentere Maßnahmen als die vor 30 Jahren vereinbarten Regelungen um eine Erderwärmung und damit einen für uns Menschen lebensbedrohlichen Klimawandel noch abzuwenden.

In the context section of the inception impact assessment, it is observed that "the world is currently not on track to achieve the Paris Agreement objective on limiting temperature change below 2°C, let alone 1.5°C". And while further it is noted that "While the EU cannot solve climate change on its own, [...] it is nevertheless the first major economy willing to do what it takes to become climate neutral, to [...] lead by example." Both are statements, that as a conscious European citizen, an environmental engineer by training, and a sustainability researcher by profession, I can wholeheartedly agree. Although climate change is a slow process that cannot be predicted in all certainty while considering all cross-effects, it is important to understand that the question is not, wheather the scenario is good or bad, but rather how bad. The warnings have been there for 50 years and the exact number failing to be fully accurate should not mislead us into thinking the problem will not hit humanity hard.

With all that being said, two aspects need to be considered for moving European politics forward in a more sustainable way: Is continued pollution for the next 30 years really the ambition, a "leader by example" should display? And, will the European policy continue to shift the problem "out of our borders" by making industry produce in international markets to avoid strict European legislation - not solely on environmental aspects, but the pattern here is as clear as in any field.

Additionally, in my view the document heavily revolves around one specific topic - energy. However, it is commonly agreed that GHG emissions originate from a wide set of human activities. This type of name-dropping too often leads to pointing fingers and some sort of "easy-going" attitude for thos contributing less to the occuring pollution. From my working experience, however, I know that the smallest shares are sometimes the ones that can be erased with very little effort. Therefore, I propose a more balanced wording, as a lot of other relevant topics are scratched in the document but fail to leave the same impression as "energy.

Lastly, the research and the evidence for the disastrous path we are walking is there - what we need now is ambitous and probably challenging targets combined with the will and stamina to really meet them as a collective. Hereby the European Union should bring out its best and encourage a joint (not synchronised) approach rather than letting nations fight over which is "the most pressing" problem. Each state has their specific challenges and is likely to have different resources for solving them. What is most crucial now is finding the synergies to compensate national shortcomings in one sector and overperformance (e.g. negative netto emissions) with a matching counterpart.

This feedback is submitted on behalf of the Swedish company Oatly (www.oatly.com), which produces and distributes oat-based foodstuffs. 

Oatly warmly welcomes that the Commission sets a more ambitious target for the 2030 Climate Target Plan by cutting greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions by at least 50% to 55% by 2030 from 1990 levels. 

Many lives have already been impacted by global warming and Oatly strongly believes that it is time for the EU to lead the way in increasing the EU’s GHG emission reductions target for 2030 to at least 50% (from 1990 levels). Oatly acknowledges that solving the climate crisis is not merely up to the EU (responsible for 10% of global emissions) but does believe that the EU needs to show its leadership and demonstrate that it is possible to establish a gradual and fair trajectory from 2020 to 2050 which includes all sectors, including the food system. As a food company, Oatly wants to highlight the correlation between the global climate crisis and the way in which food is produced and land is managed at present (as rightfully highlighted by the Roadmap of the Farm to Fork Strategy). 

Establishing the 2030 GHG emission reduction target will impact all sectors and can stimulate innovation and the deployment of clean technologies in the food sector, relating to each step of the food chain; from the use of  fertilisers for organic farming and cultivation (with nutrient recycling); to the processing, packaging and distribution of foodstuffs. The food industry is responsible for 25% of all global emissions.  Against the background of the global climate crisis and diet-related non-communicable diseases, Oatly wants to highlight the rate at which the market of innovative and sustainable plant-based foodstuffs has been growing in the past years, providing  a response to the beforementioned problems. The plant-based food sector is an example of a sector offering solutions and growth opportunities. Looking at food sector-specific European policies, including the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP), the need for a transition to a sustainable food system in Europe is however yet to be completely reflected in policy.

We see that many consumers today, especially among the younger generations, change their diets to reduce their climate footprint. 
We know that an increasing number of consumers want to be able to make informed choices when consuming foodstuffs. As a food producer, Oatly strongly believes in transparency and  facilitating for the consumers to make informed choices by giving them access to the climate  footprint information of the foodstuffs they are buying. For this reason, Oatly provides its products with a climate declaration (based on calculations by a third party, Carbon Cloud ), that declares the climate footprint of products in carbon dioxide equivalents (CO2e).  The climate declaration is a concrete way of helping and empowering consumers to match their call for climate action with what they consume. Oatly believes that a mandatory common standard for how to calculate a foodstuff’s climate footprint, separate from its nutritional content, could lead to innovation and to lowering the climate impact of the food sector. For this to happen, it will be crucial that the information is given to the consumer in full transparency and thus in absolute and comparable numbers CO2e. This is also the only way to empower the consumers and let them understand and measure the climate impact of their consumption. Furthermore, we believe it is crucial to increase the knowledge of the enormous effects our food choices have on the climate and make it easier for consumers to make those informed and sustainable choices to tackle climate change.

Wild Europe feedback on
European Commission Roadmap: EU 2030 Climate Target Plan

Wild Europe warmly welcomes the more ambitious 2030 Climate Target plan to reduce the EU’s GHG emission “for 2030 by at least 50% and towards 55%”. However, the EU and its Member States should recognise that the realistic implementation of such an ambitious target will be at risk if burning wood-based biomass for bioenergy remains considered as a renewable, carbon zero solution.

There has been a succession of scientific reports on the negative consequences of wood burning for bioenergy, including a clear warning from the European Academies’ Science Advisory Council in June 2018 against classifying forest biomass as a renewable, carbon neutral solution (see list of reports in attachment). They confirm that wood burning for bioenergy aggravates climate change, destroys biodiversity, is energy-inefficient and misspends billions of euro annually in taxpayer and consumer subsidies. 

Wood burning for bioenergy undermines all eight main elements of the EU’s Green Deal (also in attachment).

Promoting wood bioenergy - despite its clear negative impacts - risks eroding the global credibility of the EU as a well-respected proponent of best environmental practice.

There are major problems with burning wood-based biomass for bioenergy:

1. Economic

•	The practice is energy inefficient and produces greater emissions per unit of energy than other means of generation - including coal and gas
•	Current subsidies supporting it divert investment from genuine renewable technologies, improved energy efficiency and better insulation - all of which make a positive contribution to mitigating climate change.
•	Payment of these subsidies is a burden on productive business and personal livelihoods. As economies slowly rebuild post COVID-19, proponents of wood bioenergy subsidy will not be lightly forgiven for supporting the wastage of scarce capital on an expensive myth of renewable energy that worsens the climate change it claims to mitigate.

2. Social - Health  

Studies have shown that high levels of pollution with fine particles is caused inside houses using wood stoves. This can create respiratory problems. External pollution is also worsened.

3. Environment

•	Climate change is worsened: wood burning is not carbon-neutral, the ‘pay-back’ period of offset from tree regrowth is far too long – many decades – to justify ignoring the emissions from burning 
•	Carbon storage: the main mitigation benefit of forests derives from the size and longevity of their ecosystem carbon stocks and not their annual rate of sequestration. Carbon stocks in primary forests are greater than in production forests even at harvest maturity. Felling forests, particularly old growth and primary, to mitigate climate change through increased sequestration is an unscientific fallacy.
•	Biodiversity: logging wood for bioenergy, even merely removing deadwood, has a significant negative impact on biodiversity – degrading and destroying forest ecosystems and their dependent species

Key recommendations:

1)	The Renewable Energy Directive should urgently be revised to exclude wood biomass as a renewable solution. If this step is taken, wood burning will not be eligible for public subsidies. These subsidies should be redirected to genuine renewable energy sources, improved energy use efficiency and insulation.

2)	LULUCF regulation must guarantee that forests carbon stocks in Europe increase in all EU member states. This can be achieved not only through sustainable forest management, but also - more cost-effectively - through strictly protecting and restoring at least 10% of Europe’s forests, with special attention to old growth/primary forests.

Das vorgeschlagene 2030 Ziel der EU Kommission von 50-55% geht von einem zu hohen CO2 Budget aus für die Mitgliedsstaaten der Europäischen Union. Wir bei “Friday For Future Austria” argumentieren mit “listen to the science”. Nach unseren Beratungen mit Klimaforscher*innen braucht es eine Reduktion der THG von -80% bis 2030 gegenüber 1990 und bis 2035 die Klimaneutralität, damit wir eine höhere Wahrscheinlichkeit haben das 1.5°C Ziel einhalten zu können. Gerechnet wurde hier mit dem 420 Gt CO2  Budget ab dem Jahr 2018 (IPCC SR15), und einer equal-per-capita Verteilung. 1. BirdLife Europe welcomes the assessment of climate and energy policies to accommodate the increase in climate ambition in the EU for 2030 and beyond. The next 5 to 10 years are crucial for climate action and emissions reductions in order to reduce the future impact of climate change and make 2020 the first step on a pathway to limit global warming to 1.5°C, while protecting and restoring our environment and biodiversity. It is crucial that this assessment moves beyond the existing framework to reflect the broader ambition of the European Green Deal to cut pollution, restore biodiversity and create a healthy and just society for European citizens. 

Throughout the impact assessment, the cost of inaction needs to be continuously considered. There will be economic and social impacts from swift and immediate climate action that will negatively affect some sectors and regions, however such findings should not dilute ambition, rather identify areas where transition plans and support are needed and which could lead the way into a regenerated economy supportive of climate and environmental recovery.

Modelling by the European Climate Foundation (2019) has shown that addressing demand-side drivers of climate change will allow a 65% reduction compared to 1990 levels to be achieved by 2030 whilst reducing pressure on biodiversity. While a Solar Power Europe’s study shows that a 100% renewable energy system enables the EU to become climate neutral before 2050 in the most cost-effective manner and will lead to sharpest decline in GHG emissions, down to zero by 2040. Such ambition should be assessed during this process. 

During the modelling of scenarios it is crucial that the Commission makes its assumptions open and transparent. Many areas for which an assumption may be made, e.g. on future consumption, availability of biomass; it may be necessary to complete an individual impact assessment in order to determine a path that is cohesive with increased climate ambition, and which can drive policy reform in those sectors. 

The key environmental objective of this initiative is to address the issue of climate change and enhance the EU’s global leadership role in the fight against climate change. Co-benefits, synergies and potential trade-offs with air pollution, waste management, resource efficiency / circular economy and biodiversity also exist and deserve attention - All of which, if considered in the European Green Deal ‘do not harm’ context regarding the environment, will also contribute to climate change mitigation and emissions reductions. 

It is important that the assessment recognises the need to address the environmental impact of land-use hence the importance of the roadmap to 1) assess the CO2 and environmental impact of bioenergy and 2) expand beyond climate and energy legislation to sustainably achieve the EU’s carbon neutrality goal through actions that enhance the biodiversity and resilience of forests.

The environmental impacts of this initiative should address the issue of the twin biodiversity and climate crisis and the fight against it. Therefore it needs to consider joint solutions for mutual benefit. Furthermore it should also address destructive practices that damage ecosystem functioning and reducing both the ecosystems ability to sequester carbon, but also resilience and adaptability to potential climatic changes. 

Comment on objectives and policy options to be assessed from the INCEPTION IMPACT ASSESSMENT text are included in the attached file.

The Climate Target Plan focuses on greenhouse gas emissions, mainly from energy. However, land use change has had the largest relative negative impact on ecological collapse. The two aspects cannot be addressed separately as proposed energy decarbonisation strategies are land and mining intensive. In fact, the document is not realistic in terms of the actual level of true costs of “renewable” energy sources and electrification in terms of mining, land and materials use. Such sources cannot be assumed to be a source of growth due to their physics, as they are much less energy dense and dependable on fossil fuels, while they are more material and land-intensive. Widely available renewable energy technologies (wind and photovoltaic) depend on mining, inter-continental imports, fossil fuels for transport and maintenance, long-distance electrical connections and storage capacity and create serious decomissioning issues. They produce electricity while most energy consumption is thermal energy (heat). They are far from representing a solution in a growing economy, but, once realistically modelled, can be part of the solution in a post-growth society.

Climate change is not yet the most significant driver of nature’s destruction. Seventy-five percent of the terrestrial environment has been severely altered by humans, who extract about 60 billion tons of resources every year, double the amount in 1980. More than 85% of the wetlands present in 1700 have been lost by 2000. Forest cover world-wide is only 68% of pre-industrial levels and there are about 17 000 large scale mining sites in the world. This means that the most urgent question is not how “clean” our energy sources are but rather how much can we reduce overall energy consumption in order to save the planet. 

Would you board a plane that has a 50% chance of falling? This is what the EU is asking their citizens by negotiating percentage points of a dubious and difficult to calculate “carbon budget”. The level of uncertainty around such a budget is excessive and fruitless: we need much more direct approaches such as hard caps on energy and materials use, maximisation of nature conservation, a transition of agriculture to agroecology, etc. Moreover, following the 2018 IPCC report "Global Warming of 1.5ºC", the goal of keeping global warming below 1.5°C would require a dramatic decrease in emissions by 2030. This implies a greater effort than the EU's 45% target.

Europe has not decoupled economic growth from its ecological footprint, and a wide range of studies now suggest that through 'sustainable growth' the absolute reduction in material consumption will not be achieved. Reductions in the footprint as measured by the EU are only due to a greater reliance on Asian material imports and to a slowdown in economic growth following the 2008-2009 financial crisis. “The constantly increasing ecological footprint [of the EU-28] has resulted in an ever larger biocapacity deficit”, European Environment Agency (https://www.eea.europa.eu/data-and-maps/indicators/ecological-footprint-of-european-countries-1/assessment)

Not only is the ecological footprint of the EU steadily rising: the benefits of unsustainable consumption go to the rich and the costs are borne by the poor, indigenous people and minority communities! For a just transition, the Climate Target Plan should (1) mainly look at the link between energy, material consumption and wealth distribution, and (2) also look at any target from an historical, and global perspective so that the EU’s ecological debt is recognised

Die Grundausrichtung der Initiative ist richtig, weil sie sich an den wissenschaftlichen Erkenntnissen zur Klimaveränderung und dem Schutz der Lebensmöglichkeit zukünftiger Generationen orientiert. 

Wenn im Jahre 2050 Klimaneutralität weltweit erreicht sein soll, kann es aber nicht nur um die in Europa getätigten Emissionen gehen, denn große Teile der außereuropäischen Emissionen dienen unmittelbar dem nicht-nachhaltigen Lebensstil europäischer Konsumenten (Beispiel China als Werkbank der Welt). Europa ist für wesentlich mehr Emissionen verantwortlich als in Europa ausgestoßen werden. 

Europäische Politik muss von jetzt an die Reduzierung der weltweiten Gesamtemissionen im Blick haben und notfalls auch bilateral und multilateral durchsetzen. Dies wird aber nur gelingen, wenn Europa gleichzeitig glaubwürdig ausstrahlt, zu einer nachhaltigen Lebens- und Wirtschaftsweise transformiert zu sein, also ein echtes Vorbild vorleben kann. Zusätzlich werden für Indien, Afrika und Südamerika erhebliche Technologietransfers von Europa zu leisten sein.

Aus dieser Perspektive folgt, dass Europa schon zwanzig Jahre früher, also bereits im Jahre 2030, den Umbau zu einer klimaneutralen Wirtschaft weitgehend abgeschlossen haben muss, um international wirksam werden zu können.

Die Dringlichkeit des Umbaus kann sogar zunehmen, wenn neuere Studien zeigen, dass der beschleunigte Zusammenbruch sehr vieler Ökosysteme die Lebensgrundlagen menschlicher Existenz bedroht [1]. Da diese Entwicklung eher einen abrupten Verlauf nehmen wird, der für viele Menschen schwer vorstellbar ist, weil er nicht den bisherigen Alltagserfahrungen entspricht, sind Aufklärung der Bevölkerung und Abkehr von Beschwichtigungspolitik erste wesentliche Schritte. 

Die Ernsthaftigkeit der Diskussion (mit voller Berücksichtigung wissenschaftlicher Erkenntnis) und die Dringlichkeit politischen Handelns im Zuge der Coronavirus-Pandemie sowie die besonnene Verhaltensweise der Bevölkerung können als Leitbild dienen. In der Klimakrise wird es wesentlich darauf ankommen, dass Europa eine Führung durch die europäischen Institutionen erfährt. Der Green Deal ist, wenn er der Dringlichkeit seines Anliegens angepasst wird, ein guter Anfang, der zu einem umfassenden Umbau zu nachhaltigem Wirtschaften weiterentwickelt werden kann.

Hochachtungsvoll, Kristin Wolgast

Unfortunately it is not enough to be climate-neutral by 2050. The EU is rich and has the strength to do even more. To do what is necessary! Please consider also CO2 taxes for everything and duties on climate unfriendly produced products at EU borders. Also very important is the agricultural sector. It imports a lot of soy for the animals which leads to deforestation. Agroecology could and should be the new way of farming.

Liebe EU-Kommission, das reicht bei Weitem nicht! Sabemos desde la publicacion de los "límites del crecimiento' en 1972 que estamos en una encrucijada. Como ciudadano estoy dispuesto a renunciar a cualquier actividad o producto que no sea sostenible. Sabemos que el crecimiento sostenible es una entelequia, un oximoron. Sabemos que sobrepasamos en 1980 la capacidad de carga de la tierra. Debemos frenar. Crear tejido social, escuchar a los cientificos. Sabemos cuales son los puntos donde intervenir en un sistema: paradigmas, objetivos, reglas, informacion y lazos de realimentacion de lo que aprendemos que un individuo no piese sumar y que la UE sin coordinacion internacional tampoco. No se cuales son vuestras competencias pero eso es independiente del problema, necesitamos una opinión publica con información correcta y a ser posible una visión sistemica y colaboracion internacional
The goal of 50 to 55% reduction in GHG emissions is for sure NOT ENOUGH. We must aim to a much stronger reduction, at least 70/80%.

2050 is far too late to secure a liveable planet for our kids and all coming generations! We need to achieve zero emissions much much earlier!!! Please acknowledge this existential crisis we face and act accordingly! Be HEROES not cowards.

As a member of Klimadelegation e.V.  I want to emphasis our position and underline the demand of a higher GHG-reduction target which has to be in line witch a maximum global warming of 1.5 °C and the current state of research. We need to undertake our global responsibility, we can not let the poorest on this earth with the devastating consequences.

After carefully studying your outlined draft for the impact assessment we came to the conclusion that it does not reflect the current state of needs nor the current state of scientific knowledge in respect to climate change. As we already know global warming must be limited to a maximum of 1.5 Degree Celsius to avoid the worst impacts on younger generations in the future. Already today vulnerable groups suffer from the impacts of climate change and lives are harmed. Therefore we want to emphasize that from our point of view the current efforts of the EU in aiming to raise the emission reduction target to 50-55% is not at all aligned with this principle of international law, nor is this proposed impact assessment as of now a valid base for increased efforts in this direction. From our point of view it is necessary to analyze the climate impacts including tipping points, planetary boundaries and the current and future harm that climate will pose. The IPCC and further scientific studies already analyzed these impacts on a global scale, we would recommend a similar analysis and also stocktake for the European context. In our view this assessment poses the essential starting point for any further analysis in this context. Only if this is taken into account will the result of the evaluation will offer a complete, long term and comprehensive picture of  the economic, social and environmental impacts which ensures that the rights of all humans today and in the future are respected, protected and fulfilled.
In concrete terms this means:
1. The EU's globally fair contribution to meeting the 1.5 degree target in 2030 would be to limit CO2 emissions below 804 MtCO2e/yr in 2030 (excl. LULUCF). This level of reduction equates to emissions cuts of 86% below 1990 levels (excl. LULUCF). As explained above, this “fair share” contribution includes both domestic emission reductions and contributions to assisting poorer countries reduce their emissions. Excluding contributions to assisting poorer countries reduce their emissions the EU’s domestic reduction alone needs to account for a minimum of 65% of emissions cuts. By 2040 the EU needs to be climate neutral to avoid overstepping dramatic tipping points and planetary boundaries. The IPCC states that under a 1.5°C scenario the thresholds for around 20% of these tipping points are crossed; but under a 2°C scenario that figure rises to 50%.
2. We demand that the term clean technologies must be clarified and that natural gases, nuclear power and geo-engineering technologies are strictly excluded from this defined set of technologies.

3. Economic Impacts: not only analyze challenges, also a focus on benefits (mid- and long-term); analyze economic harm and losses  without a transition → make a business case for the transition! In reality the transition economically makes sense.

4. Social Impacts: analysis needs to equally consider short-term, mid-term and long-term challenges of a transition AND benefits. Right now the listed benefits aren’t fully depicted. What would be the effects and consequences if we did NOT reduce these emissions.
- Effects on human health
- Impact on freedom
- Impact on the free movement of people
- Impact on human safety
- Impact on the human habitat

5. Environmental Impacts:
-  climate risk analysis for EU, tipping points, planetary boundaries
- draw back connection and interlinkages to social and economic impacts and also give ecosystem services attention and value in this respect

Abordar de manera eficaz el problema de la crisis climática sin cambiar las prioridades económicas y comerciales es absolutamente imposible:
El crecimiento implícito a nuestro sistema económico actual es el principal factor que provoca la perdida de biodiversidad y el cambio climático. No es posible mantener ese crecimiento sin aumentar continuamente el consumo de recursos naturales y de materias primas, el aumento de emisiones de gases de todo tipo, de agentes contaminantes y de residuos. El "crecimiento sostenible" no deja de ser un oxímoron, la única forma de reducir el impacto medioambiental de nuestro sistema económico requiere estancamiento, incluso decrecimiento.

Las emisiones GEI que provocan el Cambio Climático no son el único reto urgente que debemos afrontar: También la generación de todo tipo de residuos, la pérdida de biodiversidad, de recursos naturales (como grandes masas forestales, agua potable, materias primas, etc.) -seguimos consumiendo recursos naturales más rápidamente de lo que pueden regenerarse-, son problemas, como poco, tan peligrosos e importantes como el Cambio Climático producido por esas emisiones de gases. 

Una transición energética eficaz no es posible si no se toman decisiones políticas drásticas contrarias a la ideología imperante, ideología que define el comercio y la inversión de capitales como prioridad número 1. Estas medidas pasan, por ejemplo, por derogar (o salir de forma ordenada) de tratados de comercio e inversión, como el Tratado de la Carta de la Energía, o similares, puesto que estos tratados permiten herramientas coercitivas contra la capacidad legislativa de los gobiernos de los países miembros, como son los tribunales de resolución de controversias entre inversor y Estado (ISDS o ICS), tribunales a través de los cuáles, grandes multinacionales, ya han demandado a países por medidas en defensa del medio ambiente (como el caso Vattenfall contra Alemania de 2009 o Rockhopper contra Italia en 2016).
The goal of 50 to 55% reduction in GHG emissions is for sure NOT ENOUGH. We must aim to a much stronger reduction, at least 70/80%

1 – AUMENTO DE LA DEUDA ECOLÓGICA
«En la actualidad, nuestros sistemas económicos están empleando el fraudulento esquema de la pirámide de Ponzi con nuestro planeta. Estamos consumiendo recursos naturales más rápidamente de lo que pueden regenerarse; estamos utilizando los recursos de las próximas generaciones para operar en el presente y nos estamos hundiendo cada vez más en la deuda ecológica. La prosperidad sólo puede perdurar si asumimos los límites de nuestro planeta.».
2 – COLAPSO ECOLOGICO VS. LOS «GASES»
El Plan del objetivo climático se centra en las emisiones de gases de efecto invernadero provenientes del sector energético. Sin embargo, el cambio del uso del suelo ha tenido el impacto negativo relativo más grande en el colapso ecológico. A tener en cuenta porque las estrategias de transición energéticas son intensivas en el uso del suelo y explotación minera.
El problema que abordamos no es simplemente cómo «limpiar» nuestras fuentes de energía, sino más bien cómo podemos reducir nuestro consumo global de energía para salvar al planeta.
3 – MARCO DEL PRESUPUESTO DE CARBONO
La UE sigue negociando puntos porcentuales en el «presupuesto de carbono» los cuales resultan, a nuestro entender, dudosos y difíciles de calcular. El nivel de incertidumbre que acarrea este presupuesto es excesivo y lo convierte en infructuoso; necesitamos un enfoque mucho más directo. Además, de acuerdo con el «Informe sobre Calentamiento Global de 1,5ºC» del IPCC, el objetivo de mantener el calentamiento global por debajo de 1,5ºC requeriría de un descenso drástico de emisiones antes de 2030. Esto implica un mayor esfuerzo que el 45% de reducción que propone la UE en su plan.
4 – CRECIMIENTO ECONÓMICO
Europa no ha desvinculado el crecimiento económico de su huella ecológica. Diversos estudios demuestran que mediante el «crecimiento sostenible» no se logrará una reducción absoluta en el consumo de materiales.
5 – CRECIMIENTO ECONÓMICO, JUSTICIA GLOBAL Y COLONIALISMO
Los ricos siguen acumulando los beneficios del consumo insostenible mientras que los pobres, los indígenas y las minorías cargan con los costes. En el Plan de Objetivo Climático se debe fijar una transición justa que debe poner en el punto de mira la relación existente entre los consumos de energía y materiales respecto a la distribución de la riqueza.
6) SER REALISTAS SOBRE LAS RENOVABLES
El documento no es realista en términos de cuál es el verdadero coste de las energías «renovables». Hay que tener en cuenta que para conseguir que las tecnologías de energía renovable sean ampliamente accesibles (eólica y fotovoltaica) significa depender de la minería, las importaciones inter-continentales, los combustibles fósiles (para el transporte de dichos materiales y el mantenimiento de las instalaciones), de las conexiones eléctricas de larga distancia, la capacidad de almacenamiento y que además crean graves problemas de desmantelamiento. Además producen electricidad, cuando la mayor parte del consumo energético es en forma de calor. Están lejos de ser una solución en una economía en contínuo crecimiento, pero después de ser modeladas de forma realista, pueden ser, claramente, parte de la solución en una sociedad post-crecimiento.

Ich finde es ja schön, dass sich einer deutlichen Reduzierung der Treibhausgase endlich angenommen wird. Nur wird diese Reduzierung, wenn es bei den bisherigen Plänen bleiben sollte, mit vollem Wissen um die Konsequenzen viel zu gering ausfallen. Der Klimawandel und das Artensterben sind die globalen Herausforderungen, denen wir uns stellen müssen. Deshalb bis spätestens 2030 klimaneutral und auf dem Weg dahin eine realistische CO2-Bepreisung.

"The EU aims to become climate-neutral (net zero climate gas emissions) by 2050." So weit, so lobenswert. Bei einer Reduktion der Treibhausgasemissionen bis 2030 um 50-55% im Vergleich zu 1990 wird am Ende aber - sollte nicht doch noch ein Wunder geschehen - im Zeugnis stehen: hat sich bemüht. 
Denn diese 55% sind nichts weiter als eine klägliche Selbstinszenierung als - nun ja, als was eigentlich? Der IPCC wurde 1988 gegründet, Forschung zum Klimawandel gibt es seit mehr als 40 Jahren, viele der Folgen sind bereits heute schon sichtbar - auch ohne akademischen Hintergrund oder empfindliche Messinstrumente. Ich will hier nur mal die Arktis als Beispiel aufführen, deren Schmelzen schneller voranschreitet, als wissenschaftliche Prognosen das vorhergesagt haben. 

Und trotzdem vertrödeln Sie wertvolle Zeit! Mag sein, dass wir (und ich nehme mich da selbst mit ein, Jahrgang '92) nicht mehr erleben, wie die Systeme der Erde nach und nach kollabieren, da wir auch trotz all der Forschung viele Zusammenhänge immer noch nicht verstehen, die das Gleichgewicht auf der Erde erhalten. Unsere (eure) Kinder und Enkelkinder werden es aber erleben, und viele Menschen erleben es bereits heute schon. Und das ist für mich das schlimmste - der Klimawandel (das Klima, falls man es sich als etwas abstraktes vorstellen mag) unterscheidet nicht zwischen denen, die dafür verantwortlich sind, und denen, die (weil sie auf der "falschen" Seite einer Grenze geboren wurden, in die "falsche" Familie, die "falsche" Geselllschaft - nennen Sie es wie Sie wollen) gar nicht erst die Möglichkeit haben, jemals einen so großen CO2-Fußabdruck zu hinterlassen wie wir in der westlichen, industrialisierten Welt. Bereits heute fordert der Klimawandel hunderttausende Opfer, und da sind noch nicht einmal die unzähligen nicht-menschlichen Spezies dabei, die wir mit in den Abgrund reißen. 

Ich könnte hier auch Zahlen und Statistiken und Paper heranziehen, aber da gibt es glaube ich in/im Umfeld der EU-Komission geeignetere Menschen, um Ihnen den wissenschaftlichen Hintergrund zu vermitteln. Falls Sie das überhaupt anzweifeln, das will ich Ihnen nicht unterstellen. Mich würde nur interessieren, ob Sie nachts gut schlafen. Wie Sie das alles von sich schieben können? Wie Sie so eiskalt sein können, unser aller Zukunft (vielleicht nicht das Überleben an sich, aber das Leben in einer Gesellschaft, so wie wir sie kennen) aufs Spiel zu setzen? 
Ich schäme mich wirklich für diese (meine, obwohl ich mir das nicht ausgesucht habe) Spezies. Und ich befürchte, dass auch bei mir am Ende stehen wird "hat sich bemüht". Aber ich weiß, dass ich wirklich alles getan habe... nur manche Menschen sind eben unbelehrbar, und es sind oft die, die am längeren Hebel sitzen. Da bleibt mir nur zu sagen: "Es tut mir Leid, ihr Menschen von morgen. Wir wussten es besser, aber wir haben es nicht geschafft, rechtzeitig das Notwendige zu tun, um euch diese Welt zu erhalten. Es tut mir Leid, ihr ausgestorbenen und aussterbenden und überlebenden Spezies. Wir haben euch abgehängt, irgendwo in diesem Wettkampf ums Überleben auf diesem Planeten, und wir haben euch nicht mal die Chance gegeben, uns aufzuholen. Es tut mir so unendlich Leid!"

50% cut in CO2 by 2030 is not enough, 70% would be more ideal. 
Further, this target should but doesn't account for 'grey' emissions generated outside of the country to produce many of the goods and services we depend on from overseas. This key climate target is also reductionist, since CO2 is not so bad per se and is needed by plants and forests, other GHG gases are also toxic, such as methane. More ambitious, holistic targets triggering more positive impacts rather than just 'doing less bad' would include circular economy targets ensuring materials are kept in the economy for as long as possible, thereby cutting external and domestic emissions also through transport, cutting gasoline subsidies and reforming the CAP, bringing in KPIs for farmers linked to soil quality, use of toxic fertilisers which threaten soil and consumers, and promoting less use of livestock, but more polyculture and permaculture, to name a few.

Sehr geehrte Damen und Herren,
wie wir in der aktuellen Pandemiesituation sehen, sind die Bürger Europas bereit den Empfehlungen der Wissenschaft zu folgen, wenn sie transparent und ausreichend informiert werden. Auch in der Klimakrise können und müssen wir den Erkenntnissen der Wissenschaft folgen. Bessern Sie deshalb  bitte den 2030 Climate Target Plan in diesem Sinne nach und setzen Sie ihn dann rasch und transparent um, damit wir alle gemeinsam das in Paris vereinbarte Ziel erreichen die Erderwärmung auf unter 1,5 Grad zu halten. Nur so können wir die Klimakrise noch eindämmen.
Ich bedanke mich für Ihre Bemühungen!

The goal of 50 to 55% reduction in GHG emissions is for sure NOT ENOUGH. We must aim to a much stronger reduction, at least 70/80%!

Measured against accepted scientific findings, the draft of 4 March 2020 does not do justice to the objectives formulated by the EU Commission and in the Paris Agreement. The proposed measures fall far short of what is scientifically necessary. The EU is thus failing to take the leadership role that is required – and claimed – for successful global climate protection, and is failing to set the course for a strong position in the coming transformation process.
The 2030 target must not be concretised in September, but must be tightened up considerably now. Moreover, it must not be made dependent upon an impact study that attaches new conditions to compliance with the Paris Agreement.
The EU must not rely on very uncertain future possibilities for removing CO2 from the atmosphere. This will shift the consequences of the expected negative climate impact onto children, future generations, and the most vulnerable populations.
The draft does not constitute the crucial contribution to fairness and social justice as stipulated in the Paris Agreement.
In particular, there is a lack of binding and scientifically based controls by independent review and advisory mechanisms.
The regulation is to be geared towards the goal of significant reductions in greenhouse gas emissions over the next ten years. This will require well over 55 percent reductions in GHG emissions by 2030 (compared with 1990). According to the IPCC, only a minimal emissions budget remains to limit global warming to as little as 1.5 degrees, as ensured by the Paris Climate Change Convention. Without a very large reduction by 2030, this budget will be exhausted well before 2050, with massive irreversible socio-ecological consequences.
This highlights the scale of the current challenge, which is a transformation of society as a whole. To this end, more far-reaching measures must be adopted, and all economic sectors must be examined for their climate impact and committed to reduction targets.
This includes:
the establishment of an independent body for scientific oversight;
recognising the urgency of the situation and setting it as a benchmark for action;
indicating the associated greenhouse gas emissions for all proposed measures and taking the associated GHG emissions into account in all further decisions;
ensure socially equitable burden sharing as a prerequisite for social stability and cohesion.

prinzipiell freue ich mich sehr darüber, dass der Weg zur Klimaneutralität eingeschlagen wurde und dass sich alle verpflichtet haben, ihn mit zu gehen. 
Nur bin ich der festen Überzeugung, dass wir keine Zeit bis 2050 dafür haben. Und dass die Menschen bereit sind, sich auf Vorgaben einzulassen, wenn es um das Allgemeinwohl geht, das zeigt die derzeitige Krise. Der Klimawandel wird noch viel schlimmere Szenarien für uns bereit halten und auch er wird nicht mit sich handeln lassen. Wir Menschen müssen das tun. 
Schon jetzt hat es bei uns in Dortmund wieder seit Wochen nicht wirklich geregnet und für die nächsten zwei Wochen sieht es auch nicht danach aus. Ich habe Angst!!!!!

Mit herzlichen Grüßen und voller Hoffnung, dass Sie handeln werden

P. S.: Leider kann ich hier von meinem Handy auf etwas nicht zugreifen, was ich gern angehängt hätte, aber vielleicht macht sich ja jemand die Mühe, es zu finden. Die Geschichte „Vom Mann auf der Insel“ von Franz Hohler. Ein wichtiger Gedankenanstoß!

Este plan no es lo suficientemente ambicioso. La reducción de emisiones de gases de efecto invernadero al 50% para 2050 nos expone a los peores escenarios de aumento de de temperatura global, con profundas consecuencias para las personas y los ecosistemas (https://www.ipcc.ch/sr15/chapter/spm/). Con una estimación del colapso de los ecosistemas para 2030 (https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-020-2189-9) debemos poner el foco en reducir el impacto negativo que tenemos sobre ellos. Las medidas deben ser muy ambiciosas, acorde con la emergencia que estamos viviendo: reducir nuestra huella ecológica cambiando a un modelo de consumo sostenible, abandonando el crecimiento infinito que nos llevará a colapso de nuestra civilización y, por supuesto, asegurando una transición justa para todos.

Please, don't opt for weak goals. We have the Paris agreement and now it's time to deploy all available instruments to put us on track for +1,5°C max. We discussed this in length and we decided on the most preferable scenario. Applying this scenario to real life and translating it into political measures, that will contribute the most (i.e. reduce GHG the most), is hard. But science has given us a pretty good idea, where to act most effectively, and we must ACT NOW! Every delay means a more dire future for my generation and the generations to come. Clearly, the proposed roadmap is too fainthearted.
So, be brave ;) We need to switch our energy supply to renewables. We need to reinvent the way we built, our cities, our countryside and the fabric in-between. We need to reimagine our place in nature, how we grow food, the way we consume and produce, to get away from the predominant mining mentality to a cultivating mentality. We need to promote eco-sufficiency, apply efficient technologies an boost further scientific research...among other things.
That requires changes in legislation, education, infrastructure, taxation, our economy... and probably society as a whole. We need to ask the uncomfortable questions, now.
There's a lot to be done and the EU climate targets for 2030, as presented here, are by far not enough. Worse, they leave the impression of not even trying. Small steps and business as usual other than that are not an option anymore. We've hesitated too long, already. Now, let's roll up our sleeves and get going!

Der vorgeschlagene Green Deal der Kommission ist ein kleiner Schritt in die richtige Richtung. Als EU-Bürgerin und Mutter von drei kleinen Kindern bin ich jedoch überzeugt, dass Ihr Plan nicht reicht. Klimaneutralität im Jahre 2050 ist als Ziel nicht ausreichend. Wir stehen in Deutschland möglicherweise gerade vor dem dritten heißen Dürrejahr in Folge mit ausgetrockneten Böden, kaputten Wäldern, sinkenden Grundwasserspiegeln, Hitzetoten. Im Süden Europas wird es Klimaforschern zufolge zukünftig noch trockener und heißer werden als in Deutschland. Nahrungsmittelmangel, Wasserprobleme,  Überschwemmungen, Verlust von vielen Arten, Flüchtlingsströme aus Teilen der Erde, die wir verwüsten lassen, werden die Folgen sein. Angesichts der drohenden gravierenden Auswirkungen auf uns Menschen weltweit wäre es unverantwortlich, in Europa noch dreißig weitere Jahre zu viel CO2 zu emittieren. Die europäischen Staaten haben in der Corona-Krise gezeigt, dass sie bei einem entsprechenden politischen Willen schnell Gefahren abwehren können. Sie sollten jetzt zeigen, dass sie auch für die Zukunft der Menschen zu schnellem und effektiven Handeln bereit sind. Ich möchte Sie daher bitten, Ihrer Verantwortung auch für meine Kinder gerecht zu werden und die Klimaneutralität Europas möglichst in der nächsten Dekade zu erreichen!

Eine Erhöhung des 2030 Ziels ist zwingend notwendig, um eine Chance darauf zu haben, die Ziel aus dem Paris Agreement einzuhalten. Es ist allerdings zu beweifeln, dass die Erhöhung auf 50%-55% Reduzierung ausreichend ist. Da die Reduzierung der ersten ~50% leichter sein wird als die  der zweiten Hälfte sollte mit einem sehr ehrgeizigen Ziel von ca. 80% Reduzierung bis 2030 gestartet werden. Die Coronakrise zeigt, dass entschlossenes und radikales bei Gefahr möglich und machbar ist. Zudem bietet die Coronakrise die große Chance, die geplanten Milliardenhilfen, die zur Stützung der Wirtschaft sowieso notwendig sind, im Sinne einer transformation zu einer nachhaltigen Wirtschaft zu nutzen. 
Es sollten dringend Kriterien definiert werden, nach denen die Hilfsgelder nur an Unternehmen vergeben werden, deren wirtschaftsweise mit dem angestrebten Reduktionsziel vereinbar sind. Diese Initiative ist mit äußerster Dringlichkeit voranzutreiben, da zu befürchten ist, dass sich das 'window of opportunity' sonst schnell schliesst, wenn die Gelder erstmal in falsche Projekte geflossen sind.  
Generell müssen auch die Subventionskriterien für die Agrarwirtschaft, grundlegend überarbeitet werden, so dass nur noch klimafreundliche Landwirschaft gefördert wird.

Trees possess a very unique and wonderful quality - they remove carbon from the air and sequester it!  These are one of our very best "weapons" in the fight against climate change!  So I implore you, please do not add to our already monumental problem of the deforestation happening here.  Yes, please reduce your carbon emissions but not at the cost of our wonderful trees!!!
Thank you :)

Furthermore, the European Union's Climate Target Plan should include the 4 demands brought forth in the European Citizens Initiative launched by Fridays For Future.
