We as Klimadelegation e.V. want to thank the EU Commission for a transparent and participatory consultation process. Following you can find our feedback: After carefully studying your outlined draft for the impact assessment we came to the conclusion that it does not reflect the current state of needs nor the current state of scientific knowledge in respect to climate change. As we already know global warming must be limited to a maximum of 1.5 Degree Celsius to avoid the worst impacts on younger generations in the future. Already today vulnerable groups suffer from the impacts of climate change and lives are harmed. Therefore we want to emphasize that from our point of view the current efforts of the EU in aiming to raise the emission reduction target to 50-55% is not at all aligned with this principle of international law, nor is this proposed impact assessment as of now a valid base for increased efforts in this direction. From our point of view it is necessary to analyze the climate impacts including tipping points, planetary boundaries and the current and future harm that climate will pose. The IPCC and further scientific studies already analyzed these impacts on a global scale, we would recommend a similar analysis and also stocktake for the European context. In our view this assessment poses the essential starting point for any further analysis in this context. Only if this is taken into account will the result of the evaluation will offer a complete, long term and comprehensive picture of  the economic, social and environmental impacts which ensures that the rights of all humans today and in the future are respected, protected and fulfilled. 

In concrete terms this means: 
1. The EU's globally fair contribution to meeting the 1.5 degree target in 2030 would be to limit CO2 emissions below 804 MtCO2e/yr in 2030 (excl. LULUCF). This level of reduction equates to emissions cuts of 86% below 1990 levels (excl. LULUCF). As explained above, this “fair share” contribution includes both domestic emission reductions and contributions to assisting poorer countries reduce their emissions. Excluding contributions to assisting poorer countries reduce their emissions the EU’s domestic reduction alone needs to account for a minimum of 65% of emissions cuts. By 2040 the EU needs to be climate neutral to avoid overstepping dramatic tipping points and planetary boundaries. The IPCC states that under a 1.5°C scenario the thresholds for around 20% of these tipping points are crossed; but under a 2°C scenario that figure rises to 50%. 

2. We demand that the term clean technologies must be clarified and that natural gases, nuclear power and geo-engineering technologies are strictly excluded from this defined set of technologies. 

3. Economic Impacts: not only analyze challenges, also a focus on benefits (mid- and long-term); analyze economic harm and losses  without a transition → make a business case for the transition! In reality the transition economically makes sense. 

4. Social Impacts: analysis needs to equally consider short-term, mid-term and long-term challenges of a transition AND benefits. Right now the listed benefits aren’t fully depicted. What would be the effects and consequences if we did NOT reduce these emissions.
- Effects on human health 
- Impact on freedom
- Impact on the free movement of people
- Impact on human safety
- Impact on the human habitat

5. Environmental Impacts: 
-  climate risk analysis for EU, tipping points, planetary boundaries
- draw back connection and interlinkages to social and economic impacts and also give ecosystem services attention and value in this respect

In conclusion: 
To make it possible to actually develop effective policy measures based on the impact assessment, we expect the EU to conduct the planned analysis on the basis of current scientific knowledge. We further expect the EU to consider the full set of challenges imposed by climate change and benefits posed by the transition.

Citizens’ Climate Europe appreciates the EU has set high ambitions to tackle global warming and embraces becoming CO2 neutral by 2050 as a clear climate objective. We support increasing the ambition of the 2030 climate targets.

The policy we advocate for, Carbon Fee & Dividend (CF&D), would support an efficient and socially fair transition in alignment with the EU’s increased ambition. According to several studies by IPCC, IMF, OECD, economy-wide carbon pricing is a key instrument in climate policy. Combining it with a dividend is expected to address many of its social and political consequences and to increase acceptance of carbon pricing.

Impact on economy:
* An economy-wide domestic carbon price creates equal economic pressure on every tonne of emissions. This applies throughout the value chain and leads to more efficient emission reductions by capturing as many abatement channels as possible.
* A steadily rising carbon price avoids a price shock in the near future, and facilitates effective decarbonisation in line with an increased ambition on 2030 targets.
* Implementing a rising, economy-wide carbon price provides investors with a clear signal regarding the direction of the EU economy, giving them the necessary confidence and price incentives to redirect investments into low-carbon technologies, spurring innovation and reducing the risk of stranded assets. The resulting private investment flows would leverage public funding.
* An economy-wide carbon price can be integrated with the existing ETS in a number of ways, the most straightforward being as a floor price. The floor price would give the EU a mechanism on which to base international discussions on carbon pricing and deliver a benchmark towards a carbon border adjustment mechanism.

Impact on society:
* Any serious decarbonisation policy will have an impact on the price of carbon-intensive products, whether through carbon pricing, regulation or direct reduction mandates. When that happens, distributional impacts will emerge as an important issue. Returning revenue to the public in the form of an equal dividend addresses this issue, ensuring energy affordability and connectivity for most members of society. Most households, typically vulnerable and mid-income ones, would be better off.
* Popular support for climate policy is crucial. Evidence from Canada shows good public communication secures majority public support. It should also provide a clear signal that the concerns of EU citizens on climate change are addressed and that everyone is part of the solution.
* Reflecting the carbon content of a product in its price is consumer-friendly. It avoids limiting consumer choice, but facilitates decision-making based on the always-used benchmark of price. Those who choose to consume more carbon-intensive goods will pay more to do so.

Impact on environment:
* A projection of the effects of CF&D for the US (reviewed by the World Bank) shows a reduction in emissions by 33% from baseline in the first 10 years [1].
* By achieving similar results, the EU would achieve 78% of the enhanced 2030 goal of 55%. 
* A CBA based on CF&D impacts consumption-based emissions and gives foreign producers exporting to the EU the same degree of price certainty as domestic firms.
* CF&D would be promoted to many countries world-wide, due to its ease of implementation and effectiveness impacting wider emissions.

The attached document and the references therein, in particular projections for the US economy [1], provide further details on CF&D and the expected impact on economy, society, and the environment.

In conclusion, CF&D is expected to be able to serve as a key component in a mix of policies that can both deliver on increased ambition and at the same time address the economic and social challenges that come with it.

[1] “The Economic, Climate, Fiscal, Power, and Demographic Impact of a National Fee-and-Dividend Carbon Tax”, https://citizensclimatelobby.org/remi-report/

As a biodiversity conservation practioner with a PhD in Zoology, I am extremely concerned with the increasing use of wood for biofuel. The declaration by the European Union that biofuels are carbon-neutral has generated a rapidly growing market for wood that is leading to greatly intensified clearcut harvesting of forests across the globe. This is a serious problem for at least two reasons. 

First, the biodiversity in forest habitats is in sharp decline, especially the species that live in mature and older forests. These species depend on maintenance of mature forest habitat, but most countries have been less than effective at conserving their forests, especially under economic pressures.  In many countries the loss of forests for biofuels is a growing problem of which most people are unaware. This is leading to large biodiversity losses in forested regions. One example is the widespread destruction of majestic bottom-land hardwood forests in the coastal plain of the southern USA, one of the last natural forest habitats left in the southern states. There, one of our Canadian boreal forest species-at risk, the Rusty Blackbird, spends the winter and relies on bottom-land hardwood forests to survive. This bird has declined by over 90% due to habitat loss. 

Second, the recent scientific research has shown that biofuels do NOT actually reduce carbon emissions, instead leading to increased emissions in the shorter term. Burning wood instead of coal for energy will actually result in a large increase in atmospheric CO2 for at least the next four decades. It may take a century until the carbon stored in the growing trees matches the carbon debt caused by their burning. Unless we change the trajectory of carbon emissions within the next 10-20 years, we will loose the opportunity to limit the effects of climate change.  By assuming biofuels are carbon neutral is very likely to lead to irreversible impacts of climate change before the potential, long-term benefits of biofuels accrue. Please change the EU policy so that carbon is properly counted when biofuels are burned. Forest biomass is NOT a zero-carbon fuel. We need to focus our efforts on growing as many large trees as possible, rather than cutting and burning them, and to make this shift immediately, to reduce carbon emissions and have a chance at a somewhat normal world. Please make the right decision.

Good evening,

In short, the reduction targets in the current proposal are just insufficient. Science is clear, and demands us to be more ambitious if we are to avoid the 1.5ºC target. Moreover, experience teach us that plans never go as well as we would like. Therefore, emission goals that are already insufficient may lead to numbers well below what is necessary. And here we can not apply traditional risk management, because the consequences of failure are catastrophic, both in human and economic terms.

Additionally, carbon markets have shown to be inefficient in reducing emissions. They are subject to market volatility, plus Europe is outsourcing most of its production to China. They should be replaced by a much more straightforward tax on carbon, both on products produced on EU or imported (at least charged for transport and estimated production emissions). This would both promote emission reductions in a more efficient way than the volatile price of carbon certificates, and hinder the outsourcing of production. In addition to reducing long-distance trade and its astronomical emissions, it would promote the re-localization of many industries, which can be of vital importance as the current coronavirus has shown, and boost the EU economy. Note: to be effective, such carbon tax should not be negligible, so it has a real impact.

Such carbon tax would discourage highly contaminant activities, forcing them to either evolve or disappear, and would provide economic resources to the EU to fund much more ambitious investment programs on sustainable economy. It could be argued that it may make European businesses less competitive. But they would be equally competitive inside the European market, and even more, they will have a competitive advantage as long distance trade is discouraged. Also, it can be argued that this would go against free trade. And it is true. But we have to choose between the "free market" (which only benefits big corporations) and salvation. Looking at history, we see that the current free trade standard is just a few decades old, and the world has been under many different paradigms. Free trade as a dogma can, and should be, abolished. It is just a matter of political will. You have to choose, free trade for corporations, or a future for us and future generations.

Another note: for its political sustainability, the transition has to be social. It must empower communities, not fund mega-projects of big corporations or cover their losses. People get revenue from these initiatives in order to support them politically and prevent the current trend towards nationalism and populism that, if not prevented, will destroy the EU.

As a final note, for very long the development of countries has been measured with GDP. An index that does not distinguish if the generated goods are guns or respirators for COVID. Moreover, it has been proven that the current production suffices for covering the needs of all the population, if we renounce to our absurd level of hyperconsumption (something we will have to do, either voluntarily or due to lack of material resources). Therefore, it is time to switch to other indicators for the economy, that focus on well-being and sustainability, and not on just mere increase of production without taking into account the huge externalities caused by the climate crisis.

It is a moment to be brave and dareful. We have been complacent for too long, we have made deals with corporations and used market mechanisms (with little result, compared to what is really needed). We are already late, very late. Please, do not lose time in bargaining with corporations and lobbies. Do what it is necessary, as the science says, and let the lobbies know that they either jump in and find new opportunities, or stay out and lose them. But no more bargaining. We need decisive action, and if we are to fall on either side, better cut too much on emissions than too little. Too much is at risk.

The Inception Impact Assessment on the 2030 Climate Pact must align the EU’s climate efforts to a pathway compatible to limiting global temperatures to 1.5°C and to a just transition which leaves no one behind. 
 
The Commission’s impact assessment proposes to assess the impact of increasing the 2030 climate target from 40% to at least 50% and towards 55% in a responsible way. But the latest scientific evidence shows that this target range is clearly inadequate to limit global temperatures to 1.5°C as agreed by the European Union under the Paris Agreement.
 
As the UNEP Emissions Gap Report 2019 makes clear, global emissions need to be cut by 7.6% per year, starting now, in order to limit global warming to 1.5°C. For the EU – even without taking into account equity-related issues such as per capita emissions or responsibility for historical emissions – this means a cut of 68% by 2030 relative to 1990 levels. WWF’s position is that the EU should be aiming to cut emissions by 2030 by at least 65%, and to review this target following the global stocktake under the Paris Agreement in 2023. WWF therefore calls for the Inception Impact Assessment to assess the impacts of increasing the 2030 EU GHG reductions target to 65%. 
 
Increasing the pace of decarbonisation in light of the Paris Agreement’s objective to limit global temperatures to 1.5°C is also in line with the principle of a just transition which leaves no one behind.
 
Ensuring a just transition does not equate to slowing the transition nor reducing its ambition. Indeed, in many cases, higher ambition accompanied by a managed, supported and planned transition can bring more benefits to communities and the most vulnerable than by taking a slower route to climate neutrality. This is for 2 principle reasons: first, climate change most negatively impacts the most vulnerable and least able to adapt in society and second, it locks communities into a longer transition. So-called bridging technologies such as fossil gas require significant investments which can take up to 30 years to be recuperated and the infrastructure is of little to no use in a fully-climate neutral system. The burden of the climate impacts and the costs of potentially stranded assets are paid by taxpayers rather than the polluters.
 
When setting ambition, it is therefore essential to consider the need for decisive, substantial and consistent financing of investments to enable a faster and more direct transition. Investments in energy efficiency accelerate the transition and represent no regret solutions generating many jobs and simultaneously addressing energy poverty. Likewise, significant, early and direct support to renewables heating systems including notably by subsidising a direct switch from coal to heat pumps or other renewable heat sources will assist vulnerable and poorer communities and reduce the overall cost of the transition.
 
A just transition means that the transition to climate neutrality leaves no one behind. Costs are equitably shared and benefits spread equally. Put another way, it means that inequalities do no increase, or may even be decreased by the transition. The costs of the transition should be considered over the long term and any public support should be targeted at no regret options in the transition that place the wellbeing and empowerment of people first.

The Commission intends to propose increasing the EU’s economy-wide GHG emission reductions target for 2030 “in line with the ‘do no harm’ principle”. Reducing emissions with 50-55% by 2030 is, however, not in line with such a principle. The more ambitious 2030 Climate Target plan to reduce the EU’s GHG emission “for 2030 by at least 50% and towards 55%” is warmly welcomed. However, the EU and its member states should recognise that the realistic implementation of such an ambitious target is at risk if burning wood-based biomass continues to be considered as renewable, carbon zero solution.
Since the clear warning of European Academies’ Science Advisory Council (EASAC) in 2018 against classifying forest biomass as renewable, carbon neutral solution, there have been successive waves of scientific evidence of the negative consequences of wood burning for bioenergy. It aggravates climate change, destroys biodiversity, is energy-inefficient and misspends billions of euro annually in subsidies and thus undermines all key elements of the EU’s Green Deal.
Burning wood for bioenergy as a renewable, carbon zero solution is false, because this practice is (a) not carbon zero (EASAC states that “(t)he concept of all bioenergy being carbon-neutral is too simplistic and does not offer any general context-independent justification to increase forest utilisation. Carbon neutrality involves a ‘payback’ period (the time taken for forests to reabsorb the carbon dioxide emitted during biomass combustion), which ranges from decades to hundreds of years", (b) is environmentally inefficient, as Biomass power plants emit more carbon pollution per megawatt-hour than coal plants, and offsetting those emissions takes decades (PFPI, 2016), (c) Wood burning is not good for human health. According to EASAC (2018), carbon emissions per unit of electricity generated from forest biomass exceed those from coal, (d) economically inefficient way to tackle climate breakdown because divert investment away from real renewable technologies and improving energy efficiency including better insulation that make a positive contribution to mitigating climate change.
However, I would like to focus my feedback on the negative impact of wood-based bioenergy on biodiversity in Europe and beyond. logging wood for bioenergy, and even merely removing wood debris or deadwood, will have a significant negative impact on biodiversity. Such practice causes direct negative impact on saproxylic species, which depend on dead and decaying wood for at least part of their lifecycle, and are involved in decomposition processes and the recycling of nutrients in natural ecosystems! IUCN reported in 2018 almost a fifth (18%) of European saproxylic beetles are at risk of extinction. Bouget C. et al 2012 also found logging of natural forest destroys soil, has chemical and physical damage to wildlife, which impacts the base of food chain especially of forest dwelling species.
The European Environmental Agency reported in 2015 that “(o)nly 26 % of forest species and 15 % of the forest habitats were found to be in favourable conservation status”. The EEA also found that the EU-28 Member States report forest practices as one of the main causes of unfavourable and bad conservation status of forest habitats and species under the Habitats Directive.
Logging mature forests and replace them with plantations hence is a false solution to climate change. Mackey et al 2020 found that “the main mitigation benefit of forests derives from the size and longevity of their ecosystem carbon stocks and not the annual rate of sequestration.” Carbon stocks in primary forests are greater than in production forests even at harvest maturity.
The full impact assessment of 2030 Climate Target plan should take these into account and help to revise the Renewable Energy Directive (burning wood for bioenergy is not renewable and so not eligable for any public subsidy) and guarantee that carbon sink in forests in increased in EU MSs through effective protection of at least 10% of our forests.

The scope of the 2030 Climate Target Plan is very impressive -- as is the EU's global leadership on reaching high-mitigation targets.

One question regarding the Plan is the nature of the Target.  It does not appear that the parameters / boundaries associated with a 'net zero EU in 2050' target have been precisely defined.  The target could be defined territorially; it could reflect a per-capita or percent-of-global-GDP share of the remaining GLOBAL carbon budget to stay on <2degree C pathways.

This may be significant in terms of how the EU accounts for 'net zero' effort.  As a result of a series of recommendations made at the IPCC and then adopted by the UNFCCC in relation to carbon accounting, emissions from burning biomass are not counted in the energy sector.  All combustion emissions in power sector are counted, properly, as energy-related.  Woody biomass is the sole exception; it is counted in the AFOLU section of reporting (LULUCF section of UNFCCC accounting) to stay consistent with the 'change in forest stock' approach that undergirds AFOLU.

In practice, however, that has meant that a globally-significant source of emissions is not being counted.  We refer to emissions from biomass burning within the European Union.  If those emissions come from domestic (EU) sources, then they only show up as changes in forest stock, and thus the actual volume of emissions associated with biomass burning are recorded only as a 'memo item' and not a reporting category with specific implications for the 'net zero' target.  

But the EU is increasingly dependent on foreign sources of woody biomass to fuel its power and heating sectors. EU demand for imported wood pellets now comprises two-thirds of total EU consumption and looks set to increase further.

This has created two types of dangerous dependency.  One is the obvious financial and supply chain risks associated with dependence on feedstocks at great distance from the point of combustion.  Such supply chain risks have become very apparent in the current moment of dealing with the COVID-19 crisis.

The other type of dependency is more subtle, but creates real risks for achieving the 'net zero' target.  That dependency relates to the EU's increasing reliance on imported woody biomass to reach net zero -- because as noted above woody biomass is treated in current accounting rules unlike all other fuel sources for energy production. It isn't counted against the 'net zero' target, and thus creates a 'sham' benefit that is NOT reflected in actual carbon levels in the atmosphere.  Here we can see in particular the significance of the EU taking more seriously a 'net zero' approach that does not rely on accounting tricks related to bioenergy (or related to forest-based offsets for that matter), and one that would properly reflect ambition in the spirit of the Paris Agreement, with its focus on achieving globally pathways toward <2 degrees.

The obvious solution is to fix the accouting rules.  The RED II should be reopened and made clear that all smokestack emissions are counted and reflected in accounting toward the 'net zero' target.  We acknowledge that reporting to the UNFCCC would still need to reflect IPCC guidance -- but what we are arguing here is simply to use the 'memo item' re: biomass emissions in accounting toward the EU's decarbonization goals -- so that emissions from biomass burning DO show up meaningfully as a reporting category with significance toward achieving net zero by 2050.

Emissions from biomass burning need to be counted, whether they come from domestic or imported sources.  No 'emissions free pass' for the EU based on the import of wood pellets -- that compromise forest sinks in the US southeast and northwest, Canada, and increasingly Brazil.

Sehr geehrte Damen und Herren,

Das Reduktionsziel der Treibhausgas-Emissionen bis 2030 gegenüber 1990 von 40% auf 50-55% zu erhöhen ist definitiv ein Schritt in die richtige Richtung, aber nach aktuellem Stand der Wissenschaft ein viel zu kleiner Schritt.

Das New Climate Institue hat in einer vom Bundesumweltministerium beauftragten und im September 2019 veröffentlichten Studie ( https://newclimate.org/2019/09/23/a-possible-2050-climate-target-for-the-eu/ ) berechnet, dass die EU, um einen fairen Beitrag zum 1,5°-Ziel zu leisten, schon zwischen 2030 und 2040 klimaneutral sein müsste, also deutlich vor 2050.
Auch Stefan Rahmstorf kam im März 2019 bei einer Berechnung des verbleibenden Traibhausgas-Budgets darauf, dass Klimaneutralität (für Deutschland) bis 2035 erreicht werden müsste, um einen fairen Beitrag zum 1,5°-Ziel zu leisten.

In einer im Juni 2019 in Nature erschienenen Studie (https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-019-1368-z) schlagen Klimaforscher eine neue Systematik zur Berechnung des CO2-"Restbudgets" vor, die Faktoren wie z.B. Kipppunkte einbezieht.
Unter Anwendung dieser Systematik kommt man zu dem Schluss, dass um das 1,5°-Ziel mit einer Wahrscheinluchkeit von 66% zu erreichen, sogar die Welt bereits 2030 klimaneutral sein müsste (https://www.klimareporter.de/erdsystem/klimaneutralitaet-kommt-2050-zwei-jahrzehnte-zu-spaet) . Hier ist nicht einbezogen, dass Industrienationen im Sinne der Klimagerechtigkeit früher klimaneutral werden müssten, um Entwicklungs- und Schwellenländern die Chance zu geben, auf unseren Wohlstand aufzuschließen.
Laut diesen Berechnungen würde bei globaler Klimaneutralität bis 2050 das 1,5°-Ziel nur mit einer Wahrscheinlichkeit von 33% erreicht.

Seit der Unterzeichnung des Pariser Klimaschutzabkommens hat die Wissenschaft viele neue Erkenntnisse gewonnen, und leider deuten diese insgesamt daraufhin, dass der Klimawandel viel schneller voranschreitet als zuvor erwartet, und somit sämtliche zu dieser Zeit gesetzten Ziele deutlich zu niedrig angesetzt waren.

Mit einer Zielsetzung von 50-55% Emissions-Reduktion bis 2030 nimmt die EU also keine Führungsrolle auf dem Weg zum 1,5°-Ziel ein, sondern hinkt dem Notwendigen deutlich hinterher. Damit die EU ihren eigenen Ansprüchen gerecht wird, erwarte ich daher eine Zielsetzung von 100% Reduktion bis spätestens 2035, alles andere würde zukünftigen Generationen keinen lebenswerten Planeten hinterlassen.

Ich appelliere an Sie: Hören Sie auf die Wissenschaft!

Mit demokratischen Grüßen,
Thomas Pfeiffer

Der gesamte zivile Verkehr, also Autos, Motorräder, Lastwagen, Flugzeuge, Schiffe und Bahn - reduziert bloß um die beim Transport für Bauen und Fleischwirtschaft entstehenden - verursacht einen vergleichsweise geringen Anteil an den weltweiten CO2-Emissionen. This feedback identifies grave logical inconsistencies within the initiative, and it raises important questions.
 
I kindly request the responsible units to resolve the inconsistencies and to answer the questions.
 
 
A) INCONSISTENCY:
The initiative emphasizes the importance of the 1.5 °C goal
while the Comission's target of GHG neutrality is not in line with this goal.
 
The Commission’s target year of 2050 is much more likely to be in line with a pathway that leads to a global warming of approx. 2.4 °C. [see attachment]
Reasons for this discrepancy:
- incorrect transfer of the IPCC 1.5°C pathway from the global level to the EU level
- negligence of feedback processes in the earth climate system
- usage of outdated climate models
 
This contradiction must be resolved 
* either by choosing a year between 2030 and 2040 as target for GHG neutrality (in line with the Paris Agreement [see attachment])
* or by clearly pointing out that the Commission’s target year of 2050 is not in line with the Paris Agreement
* or by explaining why the Commission thinks that the target year of 2050 is still in line with the Paris Agreement on the one hand as well as with ecological and social sustainability on the other hand. (The large-scale use of BECCS technologies is not ecologically and socially sustainable.)
 
 
B) INCONSISTENCY:
The document under review emphasizes that ‘the initiative also needs to ensure … that it is a socially fair and just transition’
while the Commission’s target year of 2050 is neither socially fair nor just.
 
Due to the incorrect transfer of the IPCC 1.5 °C pathway from the global level to the EU level, the goal of the Paris Agreement would only be achievable, if other countries with lower current emission rates would be granted a remaining GHG budget that is much lower than the remaining budget granted to the EU. [see attachment]
 
This contradiction must be resolved
* either by choosing a year between 2030 and 2040 as target for GHG neutrality (socially fair w.r.t. to the EU’s ‘fair share’ [see attachment])
* or by clearly pointing out that the Commission’s target year of 2050 is neither socially fair nor just on a global scope
* or by clearly pointing out that the Commission’s target year of 2050 is not in line with the Paris Agreement.
 
 
C) QUESTION:
The document under review says that ‘the initiative will assess … how this increase of 2030 climate target relates to the pathway beyond 2030’. Will this include an assessment of the suitability of the 2030 Climate Target Plan for fulfilling the Paris Agreement in a way that is in accordance with the EU’s fair share of a global GHG reduction pathway?
 
If this is the case: How will the Commission react, if the assessment concludes that the 2030 Target Plan does not meet these criteria?
 
 
D) QUESTION:
According to the document under review, the initiative plans to perform impact analyses. Will these include an analysis of the catastrophic consequences that are likely to arise from the 2050 target's insufficiency to limit global warming to 1.5 °C?
 
The Commission’s targeted GHG neutrality in 2050 is likely to be in line with a pathway that leads to a global warming of approx. 2.4 °C [see attachment].
 
In contrast to a global warming to 1.5 °C, a global warming of 2.4 °C leads to several catastrophic consequences including
- drastic amplification of extreme weather events [SchellnMart14]
- complete loss of warmwater coral reefs [IPCC18]
- doubling of the number of species that loose more than 50 % of their natural habitat [IPCC18]
- quadruplication of the number of people suffering from absolute water scarcity [Schewe13]
- increase of outbreak probability of civil war in Africa by ~40 % [Hsiang13]
 
[SchellnMart14]: Schellnhuber, Martin: Pontifical Academy of Sciences, Extra Series 41, 2014.
[IPCC18]: IPCC: Special Report on 1.5 °C, 2018.
[Schewe13]: Schewe at al.: Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA, 111 (9), 2013.
[Hsiang13]: Hsiang et al.: Science 341, 2013.

2 2 - EL COLAPSO ECOLOGICO VERSUS EL PROBLEMA DE "GAS"
Es la emergencia ecológica principalmente un problema de "gas"? El Plan del objetivo climático se centra en las emisiones de gases de efecto invernadero, mayoritariamente en cuanto a la energía. Sin embargo, el cambio del uso del suelo ha tenido el impacto negativo relativo más grande en el colapso ecológico. Esos dos aspectos no pueden ser abordados de manera separada, ya que las estrategias energéticas de descarbonización son intensivas en términos de uso del suelo y de explotación minera.
El setenta y cinco por ciento del medio ambiente terrestre ha sido severamente alterado por la población humana, quién ha extraído aproximádamente 60 mil millones de toneladas de recursos cada año, el doble que en 1980. Más del 85% de los humedales existentes en 1700 han desaparecido antes del 2000. La cubierta forestal mundial alcanza sólamente el 68% de los niveles pre-industriales, y existen aproximadamente 17 000 minerías de gran escala en el mundo. El cambio climático no es todavia el factor más significativo de la destrucción de la naturaleza. Eso significa que la cuestión urgente no es cómo "limpiar" nuestras fuentes de energía, sino más bien cómo podemos reducir nuestro consumo global de energía para salvar al planeta.

2020 marks a halfway point for the EU as it will be 30 years since the first IPCC report, and 30 years to when the EU aims to be net-zero economy, fully decarbonised, more specifically by 2050. We are half-way in time, but with 2018 GHG emissions at 24-5% below 1990 levels – we are only around a quarter of the way there in effort. The EU is backloading action on climate change. 

At the same time, the EU has met its overall reduction target for 2020 already back in 2014, 6 years earlier, indicating that the target was far from an ambitious one or even one that harnessed the European economy's potential. This further shows that the targets the EU have been setting politically are disconnected from the rate at which emissions reductions are actually feasible, the rates at which technology costs drop once given an initial push and is in fact cutting us short of reaching more emissions reductions faster. There is a cost effectiveness element that a relevant target ensures, more specifically by adding a certain degree of pressure on the reduction trajectories, it ensures that the reductions happen where they are cheapest and encourages deployment across the space of the Union. In the absence of stringency from the targets, some economic benefit is lost, as is the the fact that postponing emission reductions feasible today for later only increases the bill for the last decades and the reductions end up happening where there are either extra funds for them or where there is additional regulation requiring it, increasing the overall long-term cost of decarbonisation. 

The current target for 2030 is not compatible with the Paris Agreement, nor is it in tune with what is already in our legislation. A year ago Sandbag launched a report that brought good news: the EU in 2019 already had the policies in place it needs to halve its emissions by 2030 at least, compared to 1990. We modeled all the policies already in place like those of the Clean Energy Package, the mobility packages and announced coal phaseouts and our results show this would deliver a cut of at least 50% in GHG emissions. This is more than the Commission’s Longterm Strategy modelling of 2018 indicated (a mere 45%), in a large part because our report also modeled coal phaseouts that had been agreed since 2018.
This means discussion on Europe’s climate ambition in 2030 changes from “at least 40%”, to become “at least 50%”. This was before the NECPs, which now take us beyond this level, assuming implementation. With the EU's new Industrial Strategy and Circular Economy Action Plan, in which the need to have deep reductions in the next decade already is clearly highlighted as a key priority, we can assume the EU will reach at least -55% by 2030. The EU target needs to reflect at minimum this level of ambition, as to ensure stringency of the target which leads to implementation at a lowest cost. 

A EU target of -60% by 2030 would be advisable from the perspective of reaching the Paris Agreement levels and of inspiring others to follow. This would require a redrawing of the two EU carbon budgets, which would in any case be required given the departure of the UK from the EU. Last but not least, targets for the future need to assume innovation and build it in through a higher level of the overall target. 

See attached our analysis for more details on how a relevant target for the EU for 2030 can be achieved, a target above -55% on 1990, which is the minimum level for the target to be labelled as ambitious. While the EU has only 10% of the world's emissions, its carbon footprint is much larger and it has the responsibility to lead on this front at the global level and inspire third parties to follow suit. The measures which aim to make EU trade more sustainable, such as by introducing border carbon adjustments to avoid distorsions between the EU market and other markets with higher carbon intensity will be necessary.

Wir brauchen ein nachhaltiges Wirtschaftssystem, dass nicht auf Wachstum ausgerichtet ist. Unbegrenztes Wachstum auf einem Planeten mit begrenzten Ressourcen kann es nicht dauerhaft geben. Wir haben bereits lange genug die sozialen und ökologischen Kosten externalisiert - und damit auf die Gesellschaft, andere Länder und nachfolgende Generationen abgewälzt. 
Bitte bitte endlich die schädlichen EU-Agrarsubventionen anpassen! Wir brauchen kleinbäuerliche, regionale Strukturen mit Ökolandbau und Permakultur. Wir brauchen eine flächengebundene Tierhaltung - es dürfen nur so viel Tiere gehalten werden, wie es der Boden und das Grundwasser verträgt. Europa ist der Kontinent der kurzen Wege - wir brauchen dringend massive Investitionen in ein europaweites, flächendeckendes Radwegenetz, allen voran in den Städten. Genauso brauchen wir massive Investitionen in einen europaweiten, grenzüberschreitend guten ÖPNV und attraktives, flächendeckendes Carsharing. Massive Reduktion des europäischen Fleischkonsums; langlebige, reparierbare Produkte; echtes Energiesparen statt Rebound Effekte usw. 
Wie wäre es mit einer Gemeinwohl-Ökonomie?

„Kapitalbildung ist nicht Selbstzweck, sondern Mittel zur Entfaltung der Volkswirtschaft.“ (Bayrische Verfassung, Art. 157)

Copa and Cogeca represent 22 million farmers and their family members as well as 22,000 cooperatives that are dedicated to providing 446 million EU citizens with safe, nutritious, high-quality and affordable food every day. Copa and Cogeca welcome the European Climate Law proposal, which delivers a legal framework to achieve climate neutrality by 2050 in line with the Paris Agreement objectives. Farmers, forest owners and their cooperatives are committed to the Paris Agreement and to contributing to the Sustainable Development Goals.

Article 3 of the proposed climate law broadly ignores the international position on climate action when it comes to food production. The Paris Agreement clearly states in article 2.1.b that climate targets must be achieved ‘in a manner that does not threaten food production’. This paramount issue should be addressed in the proposed climate law, given that food security remains a real geo-political risk, with the world currently having just over three months’ stocks of cereals. The special and strategic role of agriculture should be highlighted even more in the Climate Law by including the entire article 2.1b. “Increasing the ability to adapt to the advance impacts of climate change and foster climate resilience and low greenhouse gas emissions development, in a manner that does not threaten food production.’

The EU’s proposed climate law seeks to deliver climate-neutrality by 2050. There are significant issues regarding how this ‘climate neutrality’ will be determined. At present, the way methane is accounted for does not reflect the up to date science and farmers are not getting credit for the carbon sequestrated in soil and biomass. It is essential that these issues are addressed, to ensure that all emissions emitted and sequestered by the sector are to be correctly and fully accounted when defining carbon neutrality.

The EU’s Green Deal as the strategic framework,  and Farm to Fork Strategy and proposed Climate Law as implementing tools seek to address all the climate and environmental emergency in Europe declared by the European Parliament. However, addressing this emergency is lacking the necessary resources in the current MFF and CAP budget discussions. The current proposal of the European Commission to seek to drive increased climate ambition while at the same time proposing to cut the CAP budget by 14% is a complete contradiction. Farmers cannot be expected to do more with less.

Further research and innovation should be supported to find technical solutions as much as possible to reduces greenhouse gas emissions in agriculture. A significant part of agricultural emissions are due to natural processes. Understanding these processes is crucial to mitigate emissions.

The impact assessment should investigate possibilities for enhanced GHG sinks in agricultural soils and forest, including the necessary legislative framework and investments for Bioenergy with Carbon Capture and Storage, and in which the role of sinks can contribute to increase the 2030’s climate ambition. The special role of agriculture in climate action, as laid out in the Paris Agreement, has to be recognised in carbon crediting schemes. It is of crucial importance that farmers, forest owners and their cooperatives have an economic incentive to contribute to climate action. The opportunity to create additional income for farmers through carbon farming measures and privately funded carbon crediting schemes, might have the possibility to sustainably increase farm productivity in line with climate and soil biodiversity goals.

It has to be noted that agriculture and forestry can majorly help to substitute fossil fuels through the use of by-products. The RED II Directive is lacking in ambition in terms of promoting access to the organic carbon market for biomass originating in European agriculture and forestry. It therefore undermines the achievement of the EU’s climate, energy, bioeconomy and circular economy objectives.

We welcome the opportunity to provide our position on the Initial Impact Assessment on 2030 Climate Target Plan. Please find it attached. Despite we are not opposing the EU long-term climate neutrality vision, we cannot support the increased 2030 climate target at this stage, at least unless the points mentioned in the attached document are fully taken into account or met.

We need a 2030 target of at least (!) 65% reduction of GHG in comparison to 1990 (best 80%) to be on track with the Paris agreement. We need an independent scientific advisory board to veto every decision/vote. We need climate taxes for imports, so that emissions will not be outsourced abroad (ofc the EU cannot tax the countries but it has an important advisory role). We need solely free trade agreements with counties on track for the 1,5˚C target. We need free educational material on the effects of the climate crisis for everyone.
WE NEED NET ZERO BY 2040!

This 2030 Climate Target Plan is not good enough. Listen to the scientists! There is barely time left to fight climate change. We cannot leave action to the people who will live in 50 years from now. They will suffer but cannot reverse climate change. Please act responsibly NOW.

Das Klimaziel muss bereits 2030 erreicht werden. Die Coronakrise muss genutzt werden, die Wirtschaft nur unter dem Aspekt des Klimaschutzes  zu unterstützen. Sämtliche Subventionen klimaschädlicher Wirtschaftszweige müssen sofort gestoppt werden. Alle Bereiche des öffentlichen Lebens müssen auf ihre Klimaverträglichkeit geprüft und ggf. umgebaut/ geändert werden. Klimaschonendes Verhalten muss belohnt werden. Wir brauchen eine funktionierende CO2-Bepreisung (mind. 80€/t).

Es ist gut dass es diesen Plan gibt.
Allerdings sind die Ziele für 2030 immer noch nicht ambitioniert genug. Klimaneutralität bis 2050 reicht (vielleicht) im weltweiten Maßstab, aber von hochentwickelten Industrieländern muss eine schnellere Reduktion kommen als von Entwicklungsländern.

Liebe EU-Kommission,

noch ZEHN JAHRE lang bloß WENIGER SCHÄDLICH für die Bewohnbarkeit unseres Planeten zu sein reicht nicht. Es müssen DRASTISCHE Maßnahmen beschlossen werden, die eine akzeptable Wahrscheinlichkeit dafür bieten, dass wir keine Kipppunkte mehr überschreiten, und so den unwiederbringlichen Verlust unseres derzeitigen gemäßigten Klimas in Kauf nehmen müssten:
Wir müssen die zehn Jahre bis 2030 dazu nutzen, die weltweit größten Treinhausgas-Emittenten (Gebäude, industrielle Landwirtschaft, Militär und erst an vierter Stelle der gesamte sonstige Verkehr) derart umzustellen, dass wir auf den Verbrauch von nicht kreislauffähigen Brennstoffen VOLLSTÄNDIG verzichten können:

Gebäude verursachen durch Betrieb (Heizung, Warmwasser und Elektrizität), Produktion und Transport der Baustoffe sowie durch die eigentlichen Bauprozesse ca. 40% des weltweiten CO2-Ausstoßes. Das bedeutet:
- Bauprojekte dürfen ab 2030 nur noch genehmigt werden, wenn die dafür benötigten Baumaterialien entweder aus NACHWACHSENDEN ROHSTOFFEN oder aus wiederverWENDeten Bauprodukten stammen. Bis dahin ist stufenweise darauf hinzuwirken, dass die Bauwirtschaft dieses Ziel erreicht, z.B. indem die eingesetzten Bauprodukte KREISLAUFFÄHIG HERGESTELLT UND VERBAUT werden.
- Ab 2030 dürfen für den Betrieb von Gebäuden KEINE fossilen Brennstoffe oder AKW mehr verwendet werden. Eine gute Alternative ist die Verbrennung von Wasserstoff, der zuvor durch dezentrale Photovoltaik-Anlagen vor Ort hergestellt wurde.

Ab 2030 brauchen wir eine wirklich andere Politik für eine Gesellschaft, die wirklich anders funktioniert. Unser Wirtschaftssystem, das derzeit zwecks Gewinnmaximierung schnellstmöglich aus wertvollen Quellen giftige Abfallsenken macht, muss von seiner linearen Funktionsweise auf eine kreislauffähige umgestellt werden.
DAFÜR müssen JETZT die Weichen gestellt werden! Vielen Dank für Ihre Aufmerksamkeit. Ich vertraue darauf, dass Sie sich für unser aller Zukunft einsetzten werden!

I appreciate the efforts being taken by the EU to prevent climate change, however, in my opinion, the regulations are not strict enough and we need to act now to succeed, so at a much faster speed than we are doing now. There is more than enough scientific evidence and warnings that were expressed by scientists worldwide to prove this. 

Also, I feel that the current focus (to fight climate change) lies very much on reducing emission from the transport sector- whereas those from the fashion industry and other products industries as well as the animal agricultural sector are much bigger. There must especially be regulations implemented for these. Methane, produced by cattle in the animal agriculture industry is for example potentially 28 times more harmful than carbon dioxide in terms of its global warming potential, while nitrous oxide, also produced by these animals, is 265 times as potent. This shows that we must not only talk about CO2 reduction, but adress these other emissions, respectively this industry with special focus. A solution would be transitioning to a plant-based food system.

Further on, very important oxygen sources such as the rainforests are destroyed for animal farming and growing plants to feed animals for the meat and dairy industry. Moving towards a plant-based food system, where much (!) less land is used and where the land is used to directly grow food for human consumption (without feeding an animal first), would save precious forests that we urgently need for oxygen. Also, this transition should not be difficult as there are plenty of plant-based meat and dairy and even egg replacing products tasting exactly the same. This would also have positive effects on the health of the EU’spopulation and would reduce the world hunger drastically as more food will beavailable for everyone.
Of course the most important source for our oxygen is the ocean. By creating dead zones here through the animal industry, by plastic pollution and by the fishing industry itself, we are destroying this source as well. 

So I am urgently asking to please consider these sectors named here! Otherwise, we will definitely not make it and will face the 6th massextinction of our planet. If we manage to implement strict regulations and slowdown economical activities to save lives from the corona virus, this shows that we as the EU are definitely able to take similar and appropriate actions to prevent the much bigger catastrophe of climate change which is costing many more than a few hundred thousands deaths! Thank you for giving me/us the chance to express an opinion on this matter!

COGEN Europe, the European Association for the Promotion of Cogeneration, supports the European Commission’s initiative to develop a robust impact assessment on 2030 energy and climate targets, as part of a comprehensive and predictable legislative framework. The cogeneration (CHP) sector is committed to the creation of a resilient, decentralised and carbon neutral European energy system by 2050 with CHP as its backbone. CHP empowers European citizens and industry to generate efficiently reliable and affordable clean heat and power locally, thus representing a “no regrets” solution for delivering EU’s energy and climate objectives both in the medium and long term. 

To trigger industry commitment towards carbon neutrality, EU's climate and energy framework for 2030 must create a level playing field to foster a stable and positive investment environment for solutions that ensure a smooth and cost-effective transition between now and 2050. To achieve this, COGEN Europe recommends putting in place a robust and inclusive process to revise the 2030 GHG target, with a view to:
1. preserve the competitiveness of existing investments; 
2. identify efforts required to deliver the additional ambition; 
3. propose effective measures to foster the uptake of clean future-proof solutions, including cogeneration, cost-effectively contributing towards the additional carbon reductions required

As concerns the contribution of CHP towards the 2030 climate and energy objectives and beyond, the following principles should be be considered:
1. Account for the marginal power mix, when estimating the electricity displaced by cogeneration. Similarly, fully account for carbon budget impacts of emissions caused by inefficient and non-renewable electrification of end use (https://www.ffe.de/attachments/article/797/EU%20Displacement%20Mix.pdf)
2.Take an integrated systems approach to energy, fully maximising energy efficiency, renewable energy and flexibility across electricity, heat and gas systems. This entails that the energy infrastructure and its operation should be cost-optimised to accommodate for the right mix of power-to-x, cogeneration (as the most efficient thermal generation solution), demand response, storage to complement end-use electrification. 
3. Pay special attention to the cost-effective decarbonisation of heat, to ensure both industrial competitiveness and to tackle energy poverty. For industrial users, continuous supply of medium and high grade heat must be ensured. For buildings, the assessment should not ignore the challenge of expensive winter power peaks associated with high electrification rates, even when maximising renovation rates and demand response (https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0360544217312124)

CHP today
- CHP efficiently generates 11% of EU’s electricity and 15% of its heat, reducing CO2 emissions in the EU by more than 200 million tons per year, eq to 60 mil petrol cars being removed from roads. 
- It is used as best available technology in many key industries: pulp and paper, alumina, chemicals, ceramics, glass, textiles, food & drink. 
- Across Europe, 90 million European households get local electricity and efficient heating, hot water and cooling thanks to CHP via district heating
- Over 100,000 active energy consumers (homes, hospitals and SMEs) self-generate their heat and power with distributed CHP facilities, including via fuel cell micro-CHP. 

CHP potentials in 2030 (http://www.code2-project.eu/) 
- EU project CODE2 estimates that in 2030 CHP could generate 20% of the EU’s electricity highly efficiently on a range of increasingly renewable fuels. The CODE2 projections estimate that new and upgraded CHP beyond 2012 would further reduce total inland energy consumption by 870 TWh and additionally reduce CO2 emissions by 350 Mt in 2030.
- Realising these potentials  could secure up to 1/3 of the additional emissions required to reach a 50-55% reduction of GHG compared to '90.

1 – AUMENTO DE LA DEUDA ECOLÓGICA
«En la actualidad, nuestros sistemas económicos están empleando el fraudulento esquema de la pirámide de Ponzi con nuestro planeta. Estamos consumiendo recursos naturales más rápidamente de lo que pueden regenerarse; estamos utilizando los recursos de las próximas generaciones para operar en el presente y nos estamos hundiendo cada vez más en la deuda ecológica. La prosperidad sólo puede perdurar si asumimos los límites de nuestro planeta. Esto nos permitiría construir una economía que funcione para siempre. Sin embargo, ignorarlos conduce a una economía finita y limitada en el tiempo que erosiona constantemente el planeta del que depende».

2 – COLAPSO ECOLOGICO VS. LOS «GASES»
¿Es la emergencia ecológica principalmente un problema de emisión de gases? El Plan del objetivo climático se centra en las emisiones de gases de efecto invernadero provinientes del sector energético. Sin embargo, el cambio del uso del suelo ha tenido el impacto negativo relativo más grande en el colapso ecológico. Estos dos aspectos no pueden ser abordados de manera separada, ya que las estrategias de transición energéticas son intensivas en términos de uso del suelo y explotación minera.
El 75% del medio ambiente terrestre ha sido severamente alterado por la población humana, extraemos aproximadamente 60 mil millones de toneladas de recursos cada año, el doble que en 1980. Más del 85% de los humedales existentes en 1700 desaparecieron antes del 2000. La cubierta forestal mundial alcanza sólamente el 68% de los niveles pre-industriales y existen aproximadamente 17.000 minerías de gran escala en el mundo. El cambio climático todavia no es el factor más significativo de la destrucción de la naturaleza. Eso significa que el problema que abordamos no es simplemente cómo «limpiar» nuestras fuentes de energía, sino más bien cómo podemos reducir nuestro consumo global de energía para salvar al planeta.

3 – MARCO DEL PRESUPUESTO DE CARBONO
La UE sigue negociando puntos porcentuales en el «presupuesto de carbono» los cuales resultan, a nuestro entender, dudosos y difíciles de calcular. El nivel de incertidumbre que acarrea este presupuesto es excesivo y lo convierte en infructuoso; necesitamos un enfoque mucho más directo como pueden ser altas restricciones al uso de la energía y de los materiales, la conservación de la naturaleza por encima de los beneficios económicos, una transición agrícola hacia la agroecología, etc. Además, de acuerdo con el «Informe sobre Calentamiento Global de 1,5ºC» del IPCC, el objetivo de mantener el calentamiento global por debajo de 1,5ºC requeriría de un descenso drástico de emisiones antes de 2030. Esto implica un mayor esfuerzo que el 45% de reducción que propone la UE en su plan.

4 – CRECIMIENTO ECONÓMICO
Europa no ha desvinculado el crecimiento económico de su huella ecológica. Diversos estudios demuestran que mediante el «crecimiento sostenible» no se logrará una reducción absoluta en el consumo de materiales. La reducción de la huella ecológica, según los cálculos de la UE, se deben únicamente a una mayor dependencia de las importaciones de materiales de Asia y a una desaceleración del crecimiento económico tras la crisis financiera de 2008-2009. «La huella ecológica en constante aumento [de la UE-28] ha dado lugar a un déficit de biocapacidad cada vez mayor".

5 – CRECIMIENTO ECONÓMICO, JUSTICIA GLOBAL Y COLONIALISMO
No sólo sigue creciendo la huella ecológica de la UE: los ricos siguen acumulando los beneficios del consumo insostenible mientras que los pobres, los indígenas y las minorías cargan con los costes. Por tanto en el Plan de Objetivo Climático se debe fijar una transición justa que debe poner en el punto de mira la relación existente entre los consumos de energía y materiales respecto a la distribución de la riqueza, y así enfocar cualquier objetivo del plan partiendo de una perspectiva histórica y global, obligando a la EU a reconocer su deuda ecológica.

6) SER REALISTAS SO
The goal of 50 to 55% reduction in GHG emissions is for sure NOT ENOUGH. We must aim to a much stronger reduction, at least 70/80%.
The goal of 50 to 55% reduction in GHG emissions is for sure NOT ENOUGH. We must aim to a much stronger reduction, at least 70/80%.
This plan ist too small, too uncouragious, too much favour for the "old" industries and companies. Give stronger and more ambitious goals a go! Do it for our all future!

Bitte halten Sie die Klimaziele von Paris ein und setzen sie konkrete Maßnahmen, die von der Wissenschaft angeraten sind, um! Es gibt keinen zweiten Planeten und alles, was an Geld in die Erforschung des Weltraumes investiert wird, muss ab sofort für unsere Erde eingesetzt werden! Wir haben eine Verantwortung unseren Kindern und Kindeskindern gegenüber. Jetzt ist es noch möglich die Ziele zu errreichen , aber nur mit konsquentem Handeln!
The goal of 50 to 55% reduction in GHG emissions is for sure NOT ENOUGH. We must aim to a much stronger reduction, at least 70/80%.

Dear EU Commission,

unfortunately I have only heared about this feedback possibility now and thus I have little amount of time left to go through all the targets of the initiative and give my feedback. 

However, what I would like to ask from you is to base your decisions and regulations on sound scientific findings and not common opinions. It is especially true for agricultural regulations, as in the past many of these were not in line with the latest state of knowledge. To name some: (I know you are rather the executive organ, but nonetheless I think this is important also in your decision making)

- the EU legislation on GMOs basically prohibiting any cultivation of GMO - including gene edited plants - due to the fact that a registration is made artificially costly by the European institutions, so that it becomes unaffordable for most plant breeding companies. This is despite the fact that GMOs have various environmental and health benefits ( you can check basically any study on GMOs for that) 

- subsidies for organic farming despite the fact, that it is not more environmentally friendly than conventional farming (see Meemken and Qaim 2018 “Organic Agriculture, Food Security, and the Environment“ in Annual Review of Resource Economics) 

I as a European citizen vote for the EU institutions to make decisions to lead and improve our society. And I trust you to make these decisions based on all the knowledge there is and not based on public opinion. 

Thank you for that and best regards,
Hannah

Ich bin der Meinung, dass bis 2030 mindestens 55% Reduktion der Treibhausgase erreicht werden müssen. Das halte ich nach Kenntnis der Forschung der Wissenschaftler für absolut überlebensnotwendig. Unsere Gesellschaft hat seit den 70er Jahren genug Wissen über den menschengemachten Klimawandel und hat es verdrängt, die Klimakrise zu bekämpfen. Wir haben jetzt keine Zeit mehr zu verlieren. Wir brauchen einen Systemwandel. Raus aus den Fossilen, raus aus der Tierlandwirtschaft wie sie momentan besteht, raus aus der Duldung von profitgetriebener Naturzerstörung auf dem ganzen Globus! Jakob Schäuffelen von den Parents4Future Berlin

Es ist gut, dass die Notwendigkeit zur Nachbesserung bei den Klimazielen erkannt wurde. Allerdings ist der 2030 Climate Target Plan in der aktuellen Form noch vollkommen unzureichend. Jedes weitere Zehntelgrad Klimaerhitzung steigert die Wahrscheinlichkeit eines galloppierendes Klimawandels enmor. Das muss unbedingt verhindert werden, wenn wir wollen, dass heute geborene Kinder auch zukünftig noch in einer Welt leben, in der sie die Vorraussetzungen für ein würdiges, menschliches Leben vorfinden. Ein guter Plan wäre es, die Emissionen bereits bis 2030 auf Nettonull oder wenigstens um 95 % zu reduzieren. Es ist möglich. Und die aktuelle Coronakrise zeigt, zu welch drastischen Veränderungen unsere Gesellschaft fähig ist

Es ist wissenschaftlicher Konsens, dass 50% CO2-Einsparung nicht reichen werden um die Klimakatastrophe abzuwenden. 80% bis 2030 und/oder 100% bis 2035 wie fridays for Future es fordert wären nötig und auch machbar mit einer klaren Politik und vor allem einer deutlichen Kommunikation, welche die Krise adressiert, wie es in der coronakrise geschehen ist. Gerade wir als reiche Industriegesellschaft sollten voranschreiten und haben aufgrund von Postkolonialismus und bereits emittierter Emissionen eine Verantwortung. Außerdem haben wir als große Staatengemeinschaft die Möglichkeit strenge Maßnahmen ohne Konkurrenzverlust am Markt durchzusetzen und gleichzeitig ein Vorbild zu sein für andere Industrienationen.
The goal of 50 to 55% reduction in GHG emissions is for sure NOT ENOUGH. We must aim to a much stronger reduction, at least 70/80%.

organization: AGPM - Association Générale des Producteurs de Maïs
feedback:
L'AGPM et ses partenaires des filières biocarburants en France (AGPB, CGB, FOP, SNPAA, ESTERIFRANCE) estiment que le relèvement de l'objectif de réduction de GES à 50%-55% en 2030 doit être l'occasion de décarboner encore plus les transports grâce à la bioéconomie agricole européenne.

Au regard de l’importance du secteur des transports dans les émissions de gaz à effet de serre (GES), la stratégie de l’énergie de l’Union Européenne doit y être particulièrement volontariste pour en réduire son impact sur le Climat. Elle devra maintenir aussi un équilibre dans la répartition des efforts de réduction de GES entre les différents secteurs concernés notamment les carburants routiers, non routiers, aériens et maritime, mais également les combustibles pour les bâtiments, chauffages et plus particulièrement agriculture.

L’agriculture ne doit pas, et ne peut pas, servir à compenser les efforts que les autres secteurs ne fourniraient pas ou leur moindre contribution à l’atteinte de cet objectif communautaire. Le secteur des transports devra donc participer significativement. 

Afin de concrétiser son ambition, l’Union Européenne doit donc tirer avantage de ses biocarburants, issus d’une agriculture européenne innovante, encadrée par une politique agricole commune qui prend en compte la protection des sols, la biodiversité, les enjeux agronomiques et environnementaux. Les filières biocarburants apportent des solutions pour, tout à la fois, contribuer à la sécurité alimentaire et aux préoccupations environnementales de l’Europe ; accroître sa souveraineté énergétique et protéinique ; participer à la décarbonation du secteur des transports et répondre aux nouvelles demandes en matériaux biosourcés dans le cadre d’une bioéconomie créatrice d’emplois ruraux. 

L'AGPM et ses partenaires souhaitent que l'analyse et les propositions formulées dans le document ci-joint participeront à une évaluation plus complète des leviers à mobiliser pour répondre à la nouvelle ambition GES européenne pour 2030. Nos organisations souhaitent poursuivre ce dialogue avec la Commission européenne. La lutte contre le réchauffement climatique ne peut pas attendre.

feedback: SVOL vítá iniciativu Evropské komise navrhnout plán pro realizaci klimatických změn do roku 2030 v souladu s cílem dosažení uhlíkové neutrality do roku 2050 a domnívá se že je nutné koordinovat postupy k dosažení tohoto cíle. SVOL zdůrazňuje, že evropské lesy a lesnický sector hrají v tomto procesu v souladu s rostoucími sociálními potřebami a související politickými cíly v oblasti klimatu, životního prostřeví, ekonomiky a energetiky klíčovou roli. Plán označuje oblast využití půdy včetně lesů jako klíčovou pro snižování obsahu CO2. Toto je možné zajistit aplikací trvale udržirtelného hospodaření (TUH), které je velkým přínosem pro ovlivnění klimatu včetně velkého potenciálu pro zmírnění jeho změn. Ohospodařování evropských lesů trvale udržitelným a aktivním způsobem přispěje k zvýšené absorbci CO2 z atmosféry . TUH není omezeno jen na absorbci uhlíku. ožňuje nabídnout obnovitelnou a pro změny klimatu příznivou surovinu pro výrobu produktů ze dřeva, které v sobě ukládají uhlík a mohou být náhradou za materiály a paliva z fosilních zdrojů. Tyto tři užitky (absorbce, ukládání a náhrada) přispívají ke snížení emisí CO2 uvolňovaného do atmosféry a zároveň zajišťují, že lesy stale přirůstají a zajišťují mnohé další celospolečeské služby. EU musí pro dosažení uhlíkové neutralizy posílit své ambice k vytvoření životaschopného oběhového hospodářství. Takový vývoj může také pozitivně přispět venkovským oblastem nabídkou ekonomického rozvoje, novými pracovními  příležitostmi, zastavením  úbytku obyvatel na venkově stejně jako posílením konkurenceschopnosti EU. Vítáme I další opatření, která by propagovala výrobu EU a mobilizaci biomasy v souladu s lokálními možnostmi a potřebami. Evropské lesy si potřebují udržet svén zdraví a vitalitu v kontextu adaptace na klimatické změny, proto musí musí I nadále poskytovat komplexní spectrum ekosystémových služeb jako např. absorbci CO2 a zajišťování biodiverzity. Proto potřebují být uhlíkové ambice EU doprovázeny novou Strategií EU adaptace klimatu, která by měla nabídnout další poznatky, jak přizpůsobit a zlepšit hospodaření v lesích klimatickým změnám. Z našeho pohledu by měl Klimatický plan EU 2030 zdůraznit klíčovou roli TUH, jak je doposud implementováno a směřovat k dosažení cílů 2050 holistickou cestou zaměřenou na asorbci a ukládání uhlíku a náhradu neobnovitelných surovin. K tomuto cíly by měly být stanoveny pevné reference s Lesnickou strategií EU 2020, která by měla sloužit jako hlavní politický rámec pro lesnická témata v souvislostech s ostatními s lesem  souvisejícími iniciativami EU (např. Strategie biodiversity, Akční plán pro oběhové hospodářství, …). Pokud nastavujeme záměry pro cíle 2030, měli bychom zmínit, že EU v směrnici LULUCUF však nejsou implementovány situace, k jaké může  dojít současnénsituaci v důsledku  oslabení vitality lesů v České republice. Probíhající velkoplošná kůrovcová kalamita a usychání porostů ostatních dřevin a při jejich zpracování přesáhnou národní referenční kritéria nastavená směrnicí LULUCF pro nejbližší období. Přestože Česká republika a vlastníci lesů  vynaloží obrovské finannční prostředky na její zpracování a obnovu kalimatickou změnou zničených lesních poorostů, hrozí ji od EU finanční postihy místo potřebnén podpory na uryclenou obnovu takto zničených lesních porostů. SVOL by chtěl zdůraznit, že jakékoliv budoucí parametry EU, které nebudou v souladu s principy TUH, např. v oblasti trvale udržitelných kritérií ochrany přírody, mohou být kontraproduktivní. Pro sociální, ekologické a ekonomickou živatoschopnost lesnictví a s lesem souvisejících odvětví a zastavit rozvoj oborů klíčových pro dosažení uhlíkové neutrality EU a dosažení cílů Evropské Zelené dohody. SVOL se domnívá, že výše zmíněná témata by měla být vzata v úvahu při definování aktivit a politik nezbytných pro uhlíkovou neutralitu EU a mohou přispět tak k úspěšnému dosažení vytýčeného cíle.

our current Covid19 crisis shows that we can take decisive action, handle restrictions and act with compassion for the most vulnerable in our societies. Die in diesem Entwurf beschriebenen Ziele zur Reduktion sind nicht ausreichend. Der EU-28-steht bemessen ihres Anteils an der Weltbevölkerung (6,9%) ein Restbudget von 28.980 bzw. 55.200 Mio. t. CO2e zu. Dieses Budget ist einem linearen Trend folgend 2030 bereits weit überschritten.
Gerade in dieser seltsamen Zeit sieht man, welche Maßnahmen die Politik und die Gesellschaft ergreifen können, um auf das Ziel der größtmöglichen Unversehrtheit der Bevölkerung hinzuarbeiten. Deswegen wird hier auch gehandelt, wenn auch an einigen Stellen zu spät und in Deutschland gerade ein bisschen zu spät aber noch im Rahmen. - es dürfen kein Freihandelsabkommen mit Partnerländern unterzeichnet werden, die keinen 1,5° kompatiblen Weg verfolgen

Hinzu kommt, dass es keine stichhaltigen Beweise dafür gibt, dass Wirtschafts- und Ressourcenwachstum voneinander entkoppelt werden können. Deshalb sollte ein Umbau des Sytems hin zu einer Post-Wachstums-Gesellschaft angestrebt werden.

Diese Maßnahmen klingen drastisch, aber wir sind es denjenigen Menschen, die schon derzeit unter den Folgen des Klimawandels leiden und den kommenden Generationen schuldig.

Der Klimawandel gilt als eine der drängendsten Herausforderungen unserer Zeit. Die Dekarbonisierung steht dabei als Leitmotiv für einen umfassenden Strukturwandel, der die gesamte Gesellschaft und alle Wirtschaftssektoren betrifft. Der Bundesverband Wirtschaft, Verkehr und Logistik (BWVL) und seine Mitgliedsunternehmen aus der Transport- und Logistikwirtschaft bekennen sich zu ihrer Verantwortung und sind bestrebt, den ihrerseits maximal möglichen Beitrag zur Reduktion der CO2-Emissionen und zur Erreichung der Pariser Klimaschutzziele zu leisten. Dabei muss die Klimaneutralität - unter den Voraussetzungen von Sicherheit und Verfügbarkeit umweltneutraler, bezahlbarer Energien - mit dem Erhalt und dem Ausbau von Wohlstand und Versorgungssicherheit in Einklang gebracht werden.
 
Als Verband, der überwiegend Industrie- und Handelsunternehmen mit eigenen Transport- und Logistikkapazitäten vertritt, erhoffen wir von der Kommission eine starke Orientierung an realistischen und damit erreichbaren Ziel- und Umsetzungsvorgaben. Nur dann kann das die Umsetzung der Reduktionsziele auch als gesamtgesellschaftlicher Auftrag zum Erhalt der logistischen Lebensadern für die Wirtschaft und die Versorgung der Gesellschaft erfolgreich sein.

Die Abkehr von der Nutzung mit konventionell-fossilen Kraftstoffen betriebenen Transportmitteln hängt ganz wesentlich von der Verfügbarkeit adäquater alternativer Antriebe ab. Adäquat sind die Antriebe dann, wenn sie gegenüber den heute verwendeten Systemen eine - tank-to-wheel bemessene - Verringerung der THG- sowie Schadstoffemissionen erreichen und dabei weder in Konkurrenz zur Nahrungserzeugung stehen, noch zu anderweitigem Ressourcenverbrauch bzw. Raubbau führen. Adäquat alternative Antriebe müssen sodann verfügbar sein. Die dazugehörige Infrastruktur ist eine wesentliche Voraussetzung für die Anwendbarkeit in der Praxis.

Sowohl der Einsatz funktionierender alternative Antriebstechnologien als auch deren Verfügbarkeit werden sich schneller im Rahmen bestehender Wirtschafts- und Gesellschaftssysteme durchsetzen, je wirtschaftlicher sie sind. Nur bei ausreichender Wirtschaftlichkeit der Alternativen Antriebssysteme ist davon auszugehen, dass sie von den Adressaten in möglichst breitem Umfang angenommen werden. Das bedeutet zum einen, dass ein für die erforderlichen Investitionen verlässlicher Planungshorizont geschaffen werden muss. Zum andern sollten die Aufwendungen für die umfangreich erforderlichen Investitionen mit Hilfe von Förderstrategien für die Neuanschaffungen von energieeffizienten Nutzfahrzeugen begleitet werden.

Als wirksames Mittel zur Reduktion von Treibhausgasemissionen betrachtet der BWVL auch einen europäischen CO2-Zertifikatehandel.  Zudem sollten die aus den Klimaschutzmaßnahmen im Verkehrssektor zusätzlich generierten Einnahmen grundsätzlich dort reinvestiert werden. 
Die skizzierten Empfehlungen sollten nicht nur verkehrsträgerunabhängig gelten, sondern auch insgesamt wettbewerbsneutral zur Umsetzung gebracht werden. 

Für den Transformationsprozess gilt es, technologische, gesellschaftliche und wirtschaftliche Rahmenbedingungen zu schaffen. Deren Balance wird über den Erfolg der Einhaltung der Klimaschutzziele und den Preis, der dafür zu zahlen ist, entscheiden.

Reduction of greenhouse gas emission until 2030 to -50% or -55% compared to the level of 1990 and climate neutrality in 2050 is far too less ambitious.

Making Europe a leading role in preventing total global ecosystem collapse, and taking into account that not all countries will act in time, Europe needs to act quicker.

Therefore greenhouse gas emissions must be reduced to -50% compared to the level of 1990 already by 2025 and climate neutrality must be achieved by 2030.

Included in the calculations of the emissions must also be "imported" emissions, i.e. emissions which occur in other countries for products and services we consume in Europe but produce elswhere.

"By necessity, this will require profound change in how energy, food and other material-intensive services are supplied. These systems of provision are entwined with the preferences, actions and demands of people as consumers, citizens and communities. Deep-rooted shifts in values, norms, consumer culture and underlying worldviews are inescapably part of the necessary sustainability transformation.

Such transformations are disruptive and cannot be achieved through an accumulation of incremental and gradual improvements" (Quote from the UN Emissions Gap Report 2019).


Regards,
M.B., Physicist, Germany.

Buenos días:

Mis sugerencias para la política climática en Europa son las siguientes.

-Creación de un fondo económico común para la protección del medio ambiente.

-Destinación del dinero de dichos fondos a: 
1. Conservación de especies vegetales y animales autóctonas de cada país y región.
2. Ayudas públicas para empresas y particulares que quieran instalar en sus negocios o viviendas paneles solares.
3. Inversión europea en energías limpias y renovables, especialmente energía solar en aquellos países que por su climatología pueden convertirse en fuente productora de dicha energía.

-Cumplimiento de una normativa estricta respecto a emisiones de CO2, residuos urbanos y vertidos a ríos y mares.

-Creación de plantas eficientes de reciclado de residuos (incluyendo tetrabricks).

-Legislación contra la obsolescencia programada de aparatos electrónicos y la utilización de materiales altamente contaminantes en su fabricación.

-Prohibición de la fabricación y uso de los plásticos más contaminantes.

-Inversión en la reforestación masiva de Europa con especies autóctonas de cada región.

-Inversión y ayudas a la agricultura ecológica en todos los países europeos, respetando las especies vegetales que estos han producido históricamente.

-Implementación de planes para autoabastecimiento energético de los edificios gubernamentales.

-Ayudas económicas para el urbanismo ecológico, con la creación de jardines verticales y zonas verdes que purifiquen el aire en las ciudades.

-Planificación de sistemas de compostaje municipal en pueblos y ciudades (por barrios) y facilitación de sistemas de compostaje domésticos para la reducción de residuos.

-Inclusión de la educación medioambiental como materia curricular en los planes de estudio de las escuelas públicas.

(Desde España, Patricia Pascual Auqué).

The target plan needs a clear commitment to enforce an end to all environmentally damaging subsidies in the member states. That includes ending tax benefits for airlines (VAT and jet fuel tax need to be imposed), tax benefits for commuters, subsidies for buying cars, etc.

Particularly climate-damaging products such as cement, meat, air travel, cars, gasoline, should either become subject to a direct environmental tax, or a significant CO2 prize without exceptions (also for e.g. airlines) needs to be imposed.

Citizen assemblies or similar demarchy-like concepts should be instituted for implementing details.

Selbstverständlich können die Klimaschutzmaßnahmen nicht umfangreich genug sein. Völlige Klimaneutralität sollte schon bis 2030 erreicht werden. Die Maßnahmen des EU Parlamentes müssen entsprechend ausgestaltet werden. Globaler Klimaschutz ist das größtmögliche Friedensprojekt der Weltgemeinschaft. Wirtschaftsinteressen einzelner Nationen oder Nationengemeinschaften über den Erhalt des globalen Lebensraumes zu stellen, würde die Völker gegeneinander aufbringen.

Liebe EU-Kommission,

Weitere ZEHN JAHRE lang WENIGER SCHÄDLICH für die Bewohnbarkeit unseres Planeten zu sein reicht uns und sollte auch Ihnen nicht reichen. Es müssen DRASTISCHE Maßnahmen beschlossen werden, die eine akzeptable Wahrscheinlichkeit dafür bieten, dass wir keine Kipppunkte mehr überschreiten, und so den unwiederbringlichen Verlust unseres derzeitigen gemäßigten Klimas in Kauf nehmen müssten:
Wir müssen die zehn Jahre bis 2030 dazu nutzen, die weltweit größten Treinhausgas-Emittenten (Gebäude, industrielle Landwirtschaft, Militär und erst an vierter Stelle der gesamte sonstige Verkehr) derart umzustellen, dass wir auf den Verbrauch von nicht kreislauffähigen Brennstoffen VOLLSTÄNDIG verzichten können:

Die Bepreisung von Produkten und Konsumgütern muss in Zusammenhang mit deren sozialen, gesamtvolkswirtschaftlichen und selbstverständlich umwelt bzw. Klimatischen Auswirkungen gestellt werden. Denn nur so ist eine Verbesserung auf die breite Masse im bestehenden System ohne Verbote und demokratische Einschränkungen übertragbar. 

Dies gilt sowohl für landwirtschaftliche Produkte, als auch für Produkte aus rohstoffen jeglicher Art. 

Besonders Gebäude verursachen durch Betrieb (Heizung, Warmwasser und Elektrizität), Produktion und Transport der Baustoffe sowie durch die eigentlichen Bauprozesse ca. 40% des weltweiten CO2-Ausstoßes. Das bedeutet:
