France Nature Environnement salue la réalisation de l'évaluation des politiques climatiques et énergétiques pour répondre à l'augmentation de l'ambition climatique. Il est essentiel que cette évaluation dépasse le cadre existant pour refléter l'ambition plus large du "Green Deal" européen de réduire la pollution, de restaurer la biodiversité et de créer une société saine et juste pour les citoyens européens. 

Cela est particulièrement important pour évaluer l'impact des politiques climatiques et énergétiques sur les forêts, qui ont des impacts à la fois sur le CO2 et sur la biodiversité. L'augmentation des prélèvements, sans mettre une meilleure préservation de la biodiversité et sans la mise en œuvre de pratiques sylvicoles avec de moindres impacts a des impacts négatifs sur la biologie des forêts, sur leur biodiversité et sur le climat. 
Bien que le couvert forestier augmente, la capacité des forêts de l'UE à éliminer le dioxyde de carbone (CO2) diminue considérablement depuis 2015 et cette tendance devrait se poursuivre. Dans le même temps, les émissions de CO2 provenant de la biomasse ont augmenté de 160 % depuis 1990. 

L'évaluation de la feuille de route devrait donc accorder une attention particulière à l'ajustement des éléments suivants :
-	Les synergies et les compromis entre les préoccupations sociales et environnementales telles que la biodiversité, l'utilisation des ressources, la pollution ou la sécurité alimentaire". Cela est particulièrement pertinent lorsque l'on examine les impacts des bioénergies et les possibilités offertes par "l'augmentation du rôle des puits naturels". Une attention particulière devrait être accordée à la compatibilité avec les directives "Oiseaux" et "Habitats". 
-	Les avantages d’adopter des approches parallèle et complémentaire pour adaptation et l’atténuation notamment en terme de préservation et de renforcement des puits de carbone des écosystèmes viables à long terme qui permettent la résilience climatique et contribuent à d'autres objectifs environnementaux ; 
-	La combustion de la biomasse à des fins énergétiques n'est pas "neutre en carbone" et les émissions réelles de gaz à effet de serre devraient être évaluées pour évaluer l'efficacité réelle des bioénergies. Sur la base de cette évaluation, il est impératif que la Directive relative aux énergies renouvelables (RED) fasse l'objet d'une révision. Il est également important que tout objectif relevant de l'utilisation des terres, du changement d'affectation des terres et de la foresterie reste distinct de ceux associés aux réductions des émissions provenant des combustibles fossiles, afin de garantir que les activités menées dans l'un de ces domaines respectifs n'entraînent pas un manque de mesures, ni ne masque un manque d’ambition dans l'autre.

Le lien entre la dégradation de l'environnement et la perte de biodiversité et l'économie réelle est absent. Les critères devraient mentionner explicitement "comment inverser la perte de biodiversité" comme un élément clé de l'adaptation au climat et de l'atténuation de ses effets.
Impacts probables :
Il est important que l'évaluation reconnaisse la nécessité de traiter l'impact environnemental de l'utilisation des terres, d'où l'importance de la feuille de route pour 1) évaluer l'impact des bioénergies sur le CO2 et l'environnement et 2) aller au-delà de la législation sur le climat et l'énergie pour atteindre durablement l'objectif de neutralité carbone de l'UE par des actions qui renforcent la biodiversité et la résilience des forêts.

Nous sommes heureux d'avoir l'occasion de faire connaître notre point de vue. Compte tenu de la grande diversité des effets du changement climatique, il est important d'élargir la diversité des parties prenantes qui sont consultées, afin de garantir des solutions équilibrées résultant de l'inclusion d'un éventail d'expertises

Het verbond van Belgische ondernemers (VBO FEB) wil volgende aandachtspunten doorgeven naar aanleiding van de inception impact assessment over de 2030 reductiedoelstelling:
1.	Een verhoging van de reductiedoelstelling voor broeikasgassen van 40% naar 50% of 55% zal normaal gezien aanleiding geven tot een nieuwe ETS- en non-ETS-reductiedoelstelling. VBO is van mening dat die verdeling op de meest kostenefficiënte wijze moet gebeuren om zo de concurrentiepositie van de Europese industrie niet in het gedrang te brengen. Daartoe moeten binnen het ETS-systeem ook voldoende vrije uitstootrechten beschikbaar blijven omdat er een aanhoudend risico op carbon leakage is als gevolg van het lagere ambitieniveau buiten de EU.
2.	Een nieuwe non-ETS-reductiedoelstelling zal normaal gezien aanleiding geven tot een verhoging van de reductiedoelstelling voor elke lidstaat. Het VBO is van mening dat de verdeling van die nieuwe reductiedoelstelling naar doelstellingen per lidstaat – dus een nieuwe effort sharing decision – niet mag gebeuren op basis van het BNP/capita maar zou moeten gebeuren rekening houdende met het technisch-economische potentieel van elk van de lidstaten. Om het evenwicht tussen de armere en rijkere lidstaten te herstellen bestaan er andere mechanismen zoals het moderniseringsfonds en het just transition fonds. De effort sharing decision dient daar dus niet voor aangewend te worden.
3.	De Europese Commissie moet transparant zijn over de CO2-prijs die ze binnen haar modellen naar voor schuift om een reductiedoelstelling van 50% of 55% te realiseren. Als de verdeling van een nieuwe reductiedoelstelling gebaseerd is op het technisch-economisch potentieel van elk van de lidstaten zou elke lidstaat een zelfde CO2-prijs moeten krijgen. Als de verdeling op een andere basis gebeurt (wat we als VBO niet eerlijk zouden vinden), moet de Europese Commissie de CO2-prijs voor elke lidstaat afzonderlijk bekend maken.
4.	De Europese Commissie geeft in deel A van het document over de inception inpact assessment (“Context, Problem definition and Subsidiarity Check”) aan dat het realiseren van de huidige 32%-doelstelling voor hernieuwbare energie en de 32,5%-doelstelling voor energie-efficiëntie aanleiding zou geven tot een broeikasgasreductie van 45%. Om die reden is het VBO er absoluut geen voorstander van om samen met (of naast) een eventuele beslissing tot verhoging van de reductiedoelstelling voor broeikasgassen ook de doelstellingen voor hernieuwbare energie en energie-efficiëntie te verhogen. Daarenboven zijn de lidstaten de energie-efficiëntie richtlijn en de richtlijn inzake hernieuwbare energiebronnen nog aan het omzetten in nationale wetgeving en moeten ondernemingen zich nog aanpassen aan het nieuwe regelgevende kader. Als toch beslist zou worden om de doelstellingen voor hernieuwbare energie en/of energie-efficiëntie te verhogen, mag op deze manier zeker geen hogere reductiedoelstelling (hoger dan de nieuwe 50%- of 55%-doelstelling) doorgedrukt worden.
5.	Als de Europese Commissie zou beslissen om de reductiedoelstelling voor broeikasgassen te verhogen van 40% naar 50% of 55% vindt het VBO dat de wijzigingen aan het huidige regelgevende kader verankerd moeten worden rond het principe dat investeringen in koolstofarme technologieën en oplossingen bevorderd worden. Daarbij mag zeker niet uit het oog verloren worden dat alle industriële sectoren gekenmerkt worden door lange investeringscycli en 2030 als investeringshorizon al heel dichtbij ligt.
6.	Het VBO stelt voor dat in opvolging van een eventuele beslissing om de reductiedoelstelling voor broeikasgassen te verhogen, de Europese Commissie een investeringsplan en een plan om de innovatie te stimuleren zou uitwerken. Volgens het VBO is het aangewezen dat die plannen op een grotere schaal dan nu worden opgemaakt, met een opdeling per sector (staal, cement, chemie…) en met uitgewerkte acties. De plannen mogen dus zeker niet beperkt blijven tot een aantal algemene principes.

The Natural Resources Defense Council’s response focuses on ensuring that 2030 EU climate protection measures deliver the best possible outcomes for climate and nature, whilst ensuring the highest cost-effectiveness.

In particular, we urge you to end billions of Euros in subsidies for replacing fossil fuels with biomass from forests, which are counterproductive to these aims.

Burning forest biomass releases large amounts of climate-warming pollution into the atmosphere and destroys crucial carbon-capturing ecosystems, setting us back decades in the fight against climate change. As such, continued EU support for this form of bioenergy directly threatens the tightened GHG reduction targets proposed in the 2030 EU Climate Target Plan. 

In an open letter to the EU Parliament, more than 800 leading scientists have called for urgent action to restrict forest bioenergy schemes, as has the European Academies Science Advisory Council (EASAC). Forest biomass also diverts scarce investment resources from low-cost, low-risk and readily available clean energy alternatives, such as solar and wind, and is incompatible with the EU’s ‘do no harm’ principle.

A key problem of EU flagship climate policies to date has been their failure to distinguish between forms of energy generation that do not rely on combustion and therefore, are genuinely free of GHG emissions (e.g. wind, solar, wave, tidal), and forms of energy generation that are based on the combustion of raw materials, which result in significant GHG emissions and subsequently rely on theoretical re-sequestration of CO2 by plants to offset their emissions (e.g. various forms of bioenergy).

This has led to the perverse situation where the majority (approximately 60%) of the EU’s Renewable Energy Target is now met by forms of combustion energy, which emit significant GHG emissions.

Burning wood in power stations to produce electricity worsens climate change just like coal and other fossil fuels. Per unit of electricity, biomass power plants emit more CO2 from their smokestacks than coal plants do. Forest regrowth takes decades, during which atmospheric CO2 is higher than it would be otherwise. The EU Commission’s own report titled “Carbon impacts of biomass consumed in the EU” showed that EU energy scenarios that reduce the use of bioenergy, instead relying more on solar and wind, result in the lowest carbon emissions.

Additionally, EU incentives to harvest wood for electricity production undermine local efforts to protect biodiversity in the regions where forests are being cut to supply biomass. Independent media reporting has exposed the unsustainable logging practices used to source wood for pellets exported to Europe, including sourcing from clearcuts of mature hardwood forests in the Southeastern U.S., damaging biodiversity in the North American coastal plain—a region designated as a global biodiversity hotspot.

Continued state-support for biomass energy can no longer be justified on climate or environmental grounds. However, a recent assessment of government subsidies and other forms of financial support offered to biomass energy producers in the European Union found that in 2017, the 15 member states most heavily reliant on bioenergy spent more than €6.5 billion to subsidise its production. [Trionomics - Financial support for electricity generation & CHP from solid Biomass- attchd].

Some countries have already started to change course: e.g. the UK government has announced that coal-to-biomass will be excluded from future Contracts for Difference (CFD) auctions, and stated that “all support for biomass conversions ends in 2027”.

Given the significant financial expenditures now required to mitigate the economic impacts of the COVID19 pandemic, it is more important than ever that the EU’s Climate Target Plan to 2030 puts an end to billions in wasteful bioenergy subsidies and instead redirects this investment toward truly clean and renewable energy sources like solar and wind.

Outokumpu welcomes the opportunity to provide feedback to the Inception Impact Assessment of Climate Target Plan 2030. 

Global CO2 emissions need to be reduced significantly during the next decade to avoid irreversible damage from climate change. The emissions in the EU have EU have reduced continuously. At the same time, global CO2 emissions continue to grow. 

Climate change mitigation needs strong global actions. Countries will provide their final NDCs submissions according to the Paris Agreement to the UNFCC by the end of 2020. It is necessary to evaluate and take into account the level of commitments of the third countries. It is also necessary to assess the full impact of the ongoing COVID-19 outbreak.

Preliminary assessments indicate that with the existing burden sharing between ETS/non-ETS sectors, an increased ambition to 50...55% would have a significant impact on the EU ETS market, with a respective reduction in available allowances by 1.2…1.8 billion. In the absence of further adjustments, that could mean a reduction of free allowances respectively by 500M…750M. This would more than nullify the 3% auctioning/free allocation shares’ flexibility agreed in the recent ETS revision. According to, carbon prices would rise to levels around 50…75€/tCO2 by 2030 for ambition at 50...55%.

A comprehensive analysis of carbon leakage measures is needed. Carbon leakage measures need to remain commensurate to and effective for the high level of pursued climate ambition.

The increased climate ambition would require that carbon leakage provisions are strengthened. The proposed Carbon Border Adjustment mechanism is needed as a complementary measure to reduce carbon leakage, and not as an alternative to existing ones, i.e. free allocation and indirects compensation. Also, Carbon Border Adjustment mechanism should take into account the whole carbon footprint, not only direct emissions. This would further strengthen EU’s role as a global climate leader. A broader approach is also needed to avoid further outsourcing of emissions to supply chain.

The carbon leakage assessment needs to have a forward-looking approach instead of historical evidence as mentioned in the Inception Impact Assessment. The assessment of the techno-economic potential needs to take into account the external factors - the enabling regulatory framework and the relevant energy and raw materials - that would allow to overcome the barriers and materialise such potential.  Hence, the plan needs to include concrete proposals on the enabling regulatory framework and the abatement potential should not be used as an argument for reducing carbon leakage protection, since it would make EU companies more vulnerable in the decisive time when compliance costs are complemented by the abatement costs of the implementation of the breakthrough technologies. 

The initiative aims to assess what would be required to have a more balanced reduction pathway from 2020 to 2050. However, innovation does not follow a linear path and especially disruptive breakthrough technologies that are needed for the long-term climate neutrality objective will require sufficient time for being developed, upscaled and commercialized. Thus, an accelerated pathway post 2030 could well be achievable when such technologies reach a sufficient level of maturity. 

The most cost-efficient and internationally sound burden sharing between ETS and non-ETS should be applied when the target is set. We welcome the statement that all sectors of the economy and society will need to contribute to the transition. There is a large potential for example in the buildings, agricultural and transport sector.
The goal of 50 to 55% reduction in GHG emissions is for sure NOT ENOUGH. We must aim to a much stronger reduction, at least 70/80%.

-50/-55% Treibhausgas-Emissionen bis 2030 im Vergleich zu 1990 sind zu wenig - wir bräuchten mindestens -80% bis 2030. Die Ausbauziele für erneuerbare Energien müssen entsprechend angehoben werden. Erneuerbare Energien zu fördern, hat auch wirtschaftliche Vorteile. In fast ganz Europa wäre es möglich, sich auf allen Ebenen (kommunal, regional, national) autark mit Hilfe von erneuerbaren Energien mit Strom zu versorgen (https://timtroendle.github.io/possibility-for-electricity-autarky-map/). Dies verringert die Abhängigkeit von Ölpreisen und den ölfördernden Staaten.

Die EU investiert immer noch viel zu viel in Erdgas(infrastruktur), zu wenig in Stromnetze. Erdgas kann eine kurzfristige Brückentechnologie sein, um Emissionen schnell zu reduzieren. Sie sind aber keine Lösung, um mittelfristig Netto-Null Emissionen zu erlangen, da bisher nicht gezeigt wurde, dass der Methanschlupf bei Importen wirksam reduziert werden kann (mittelfristig auf nahe null). Da die Investitionen auf 50 Jahre angelegt sind, ist die starke Investition in Erdgasinfrastruktur eine immense Fehlinvestition, welche mit bereits bestehenden Klimazielen nicht vereinbar ist.

Eine Investition in den Ausbau lokaler erneuerbarer Energien (PV-Anlagen auf Hausdächern - auch und vor allem in Städten, Wärmepumpen, Solarthermie etc.) wäre eine wesentlich effektivere Maßnahme die Emissionen langfristig zu senken, die Energieversorgung durch eine dezentrale Erzeugung resilienter zu machen und langfristig massiv Geld zu sparen (Ausgaben für importiertes Erdgas, Öl und Kohle). 

Solaranlagen und Windkraftanlagen produzieren bei heutigen Strompreisen nach ca. 3-10 Jahren fast kostenlosen Strom. Der anschließende Gewinn könnte bspw. den Kommunen zu Gute kommen.

1. AUMENTO DE LA DEUDA ECOLÓGICA
«En la actualidad, nuestros sistemas económicos están empleando el fraudulento esquema de la pirámide de Ponzi con nuestro planeta. Estamos consumiendo recursos naturales más rápidamente de lo que pueden regenerarse; estamos utilizando los recursos de las próximas generaciones para operar en el presente y nos estamos hundiendo cada vez más en la deuda ecológica. La prosperidad sólo puede perdurar si asumimos los límites de nuestro planeta. 

2. COLAPSO ECOLOGICO VS. LOS «GASES»
El Plan del objetivo climático se centra en las emisiones de gases de efecto invernadero provenientes del sector energético. Sin embargo, el cambio del uso del suelo ha tenido el impacto negativo relativo más grande en el colapso ecológico. Estos dos aspectos no pueden ser abordados de manera separada, ya que las estrategias de transición energéticas son intensivas en términos de uso del suelo y explotación minera.
El 75% del medio ambiente terrestre ha sido severamente alterado por la población humana, extraemos aproximadamente 60 mil millones de toneladas de recursos cada año, el doble que en 1980. Más del 85% de los humedales existentes en 1700 desaparecieron antes del 2000. La cubierta forestal mundial alcanza sólamente el 68% de los niveles pre-industriales y existen aproximadamente 17.000 minerías de gran escala en el mundo.  Eso significa que el problema que abordamos no es simplemente cómo «limpiar» nuestras fuentes de energía, sino más bien cómo podemos reducir nuestro consumo global de energía para salvar al planeta.

3. MARCO DEL PRESUPUESTO DE CARBONO
La UE sigue negociando puntos porcentuales en el «presupuesto de carbono» los cuales resultan, a nuestro entender, dudosos y difíciles de calcular. El nivel de incertidumbre que acarrea este presupuesto es excesivo y lo convierte en infructuoso; necesitamos un enfoque mucho más directo como pueden ser altas restricciones al uso de la energía y de los materiales, la conservación de la naturaleza por encima de los beneficios económicos, una transición agrícola hacia la agroecología, etc. Además, de acuerdo con el «Informe sobre Calentamiento Global de 1,5ºC» del IPCC, el objetivo de mantener el calentamiento global por debajo de 1,5ºC requeriría de un descenso drástico de emisiones antes de 2030. Esto implica un mayor esfuerzo que el 45% de reducción que propone la UE en su plan.

4. CRECIMIENTO ECONÓMICO
Europa no ha desvinculado el crecimiento económico de su huella ecológica. Diversos estudios demuestran que mediante el «crecimiento sostenible» no se logrará una reducción absoluta en el consumo de materiales. La reducción de la huella ecológica, según los cálculos de la UE, se deben únicamente a una mayor dependencia de las importaciones de materiales de Asia y a una desaceleración del crecimiento económico tras la crisis financiera de 2008-2009. «La huella ecológica en constante aumento [de la UE-28] ha dado lugar a un déficit de biocapacidad cada vez mayor», Agencia Europea del Medio Ambiente 

5. CRECIMIENTO ECONÓMICO, JUSTICIA GLOBAL Y COLONIALISMO
No sólo sigue creciendo la huella ecológica de la UE: los ricos siguen acumulando los beneficios del consumo insostenible mientras que los pobres, los indígenas y las minorías cargan con los costes. Por tanto en el Plan de Objetivo Climático se debe fijar una transición justa que debe poner en el punto de mira la relación existente entre los consumos de energía y materiales respecto a la distribución de la riqueza.

6. SER REALISTAS SOBRE LAS RENOVABLES
 Para conseguir que las tecnologías de energía renovable sean ampliamente accesibles (eólica y fotovoltaica) significa depender de la minería, las importaciones inter-continentales, los combustibles fósiles, de las conexiones eléctricas de larga distancia, la capacidad de almacenamiento y que además crean graves problemas de desmantelamiento.
Un saludo,

EREF welcomes the increase of the climate target for 2030. The planned reduction of CO2 emissions by 2030 from 40% to 50-55% is another indication that the EU recognizes the international commitment from the Paris Agreement and the effects of the climate crisis.
However, setting the target between 50-55% lacks ambition and does not reflect the scientific knowledge available. A binding reduction target of at least 55% for 2030 is necessary. Also, the Commission should consider that there are already calls for a 65% reduction in 2030. In order to achieve the goals of the Paris Agreement, a binding reduction target of at least 75-80% is necessary for 2040. The targets should be defined early and clearly so that the EU can enter the COP26 negotiations with tangible domestic commitments. Postponing these decisions with a subsequent higher objective for 2040/2050 would be dangerous and counterproductive for scientific, technical, socioeconomic and practical reasons.
The Special Report of the IPCC on Global Warming has shown that missing the 1.5°C temperature target entails severe additional damages to the ecosystem and increases the chances of hitting tipping points that could spiral global heating out of control. It is vitally important that all possible measures are taken now to avoid the tipping points. At a later stage only limited damage control is possible.
Some of the measures will have to be quite drastic in the short term. In order to better cushion these effects and facilitate a just transition, measures should be initiated immediately so that they can be better distributed over time – while we still have options for climate mitigation and are not restricted to climate change adaptation. Numerous measures need considerable lead time for planning and construction (e.g. for infrastructure). It is therefore necessary to lay the framework and act now.
Studies show that early and ambitious action is more effective and less costly. Any measure stimulating investment takes time to be defined and implemented. Additionally, authorities, companies or private persons need time to adapt and derive appropriate steps and projects to fulfil the criteria. Decisive and quick action is the only way for EU businesses to benefit from first mover advantages and gain in competitiveness globally. Those actions can and should be linked to a EU recovery plan from the COVID-19 crisis, facilitating a green transition. 
In order to avoid gambling on carbon capture technologies which might be available in the future, the reduction of GHG emissions must be a priority. The plan should focus on avoiding emissions instead of removing them from the atmosphere. Natural GHG sinks and/or existing or hoped for technologies for separation, storage or processing should only be considered for unavoidable emissions. They can only be a supplement to the accelerated expansion of renewable energies.
Climate Action needs energy transition. The transition will be most effective, if it is decentralized and based on renewable energies and energy efficiency. This approach reduces costs as well as dependencies and should preferably be pursued. For the Climate Target Plan (CTP), shorter intervals of 5 years should be considered for setting GHG reduction targets.
EREF welcomes the approach to analyse the NECPs for the assessment. The CTP needs to go hand in hand with a clear framework for binding targets for each Member State. A strong framework and trajectory for accelerated use of renewable energy in all sectors, for phasing out and ending the import of fossil fuels as well as investment incentives for a GHG-neutral industry are crucial. However, the process so far has highlighted many weaknesses, e.g. NECPs not covering all necessary issues, lacking ambition or not being submitted on time. Once established and accepted, the full implementation of the NECPs should become mandatory and subject to infringement procedures and penalties.

Jordens Vänner Sverige ser positivt på initiativet om Europas “Green Deal”, där en bindande EU-lagstiftning om klimatneutralitet till senast 2050 är ett grundläggande fundament. 

Det är dock viktigt att betona att fundamentala ekosystem inom atmosfären, haven eller skogarna inte har ställt sig bakom ytterligare 30 år av nettoutsläpp av växthusgaser. Ingen representant från djur- eller växtriket har klivit fram och sagt att 30 år till är en väl genomtänkt avgränsning som de klarar att hantera. Vi ser inte heller någon entusiastisk uppslutning från bönder runt om i världen som de senaste åren har sett hur de initiala klimatförändringarna kraftigt påverkar möjligheterna att försörja sig själva och sina familjer, eller från den grupp äldre människor som inte har ekonomiska möjligheter att fly långvariga värmeböljor med luftkonditionering eller semesterutflykter till svalkande badorter. 
Den resilience som finns inbyggd i större ekosystem har utsatts för extremt hårda påfrestningar de senaste 70 åren och det finns inga som helst garantier för att de åtgärder som nu föreslås håller sig inom gränserna för vad jordens livsavgörande ekosystem klarar. Tvärtom varnar allt fler forskare för en ständigt ökad risk för att vi når punkter där självgenererande och ostoppbara uppvärmningsprocesser triggas igång, vilka snabbt kan bryta sönder viktiga ekosystem och förstöra livsmöjligheterna för en stor del av alla levande varelser, inklusive mänskligheten. Vi ser därför ett stort behov av att omedelbart och radikalt börja ställa om samhället för snabbt minska utsläppen av klimatpåverkande gaser. Med utgångspunkt i detta ser vi med stor oro på den svaga start som föreslås i Europas Green Deal, och förordar skärpta utsläppsmål till 2030 som gör det möjligt att klara högst 1,5 graders temperaturhöjning. 
Det innebär att utsläppen av växthusgaser behöver minska med 65-70% till 2030, jämfört med de nu föreslagna 50-55%. Det högre målet ligger i linje med EU:s åtagande i Parisavtalet. 

Vi ser också med stor oro på att Europas Green Deal fortfarande tar utgångspunkt i ett tillväxtsamhälle, där det finansiella systemet som bygger på uppblåsta krediter kräver ständig expansion för att inte kollapsa. I programmet för Europas gröna omställning krävs tydliga gränsdragningar kring framtida expansion, där endast åtgärder som harmoniserar väl inom ramen för de planetära gränserna  kan tillåtas. 
I den planetära kris vi befinner oss i är vi positiva till fortsatt forskning och stöd till konkreta projekt för att fånga och lagra koldioxid. Vi vänder oss dock mot att redan idag räkna in dessa än så länge ytterst osäkra tekniker som en framtida del av Europas utsläppsminskningar. Det är idag många gånger billigare för de stora anläggningar och branscher som ingår i Europas handelssystem för utsläppsrätter att släppa ut koldioxid i atmosfären än att omvandla och lagra den. Det kommer att krävas kraftigt höjda priser på utsläppsrätter för att denna teknik ska kunna bli ett reellt inslag för minskade utsläpp. 

I linje med detta vill vi inom ramen för Europas Green Deal se en översyn och skärpning av de mål som handeln med utsläppsrätter styr emot, där nya skärpta mål för utsläppsminskningar till 2030 behöver vara styrande. Med ambitionen att använda handelssystemet för att snabbt få ner utsläppen ställer vi oss positiva till att låta systemet omfatta fler sektorer. I linje med detta anser vi att ambitionen i Europas Green Deal om att införa “gränsavgifter” på importvaror från länder med lägre klimatkrav är helt avgörande. 
Vi ställer oss också positiva till den omställningsfond för att stötta regioner som riskerar att förlora många jobb i omställningen från ett fossilbaserat samhälle till ett hållbart. Men med den snabba omställning som kommer att krävas till 2030 behöver mer resurser tillföras.

According to IPCC the next 5 to 10 years are crucial in emission reduction and climate action. 2020 needs to be the turning point to deliver on emission reductions and to keep global warming limited to 1,5°C. 

A 50 - 55 per cent reduction, as proposed in the Communication of the European Green Deal, will not be enough to fill the large emission gap of 15 TgCO2 in order to meet the Paris Agreement target and keep global warming at 1,5°C (UNEP, 2019). Furthermore, modelling by the European Climate Foundation (2019) has shown that addressing demand-side drivers of climate change will allow a 65% reduction to be achieved whilst reducing pressure on biodiversity. NABU advocates for extending the assessment of increasing the 2030 EU GHG reductions target to 60 – 65 % below 1990 levels without offsetting. Europe is one of the top greenhouse gas emitters worldwide, and with historical responsibility needs to act faster than other countries in the world. However, Europe cannot save the world alone. It needs to ensure increasing its efforts well before the postponed COP26, to encourage third countries to step up efforts, too.

NABU asks for the assessment to include: 
-	Impacts of energy sufficiency and energy efficiency and nature compatible infrastructure needs from RES, considering the role of a healthy, resilient ecosystems against fighting climate change and considering cumulative impacts of human activities on nature
-	how the 2030 climate target can  keep global warming limited to 1,5 °C, through a pathway for 2040 and climate-neutrality well before 2050
-	the impact consumption and land uses have on climate, energy, transportation and industry 
-	how the EU can increase CO2-absorptions in a short period of time, including investing in natural sinks, nature based solutions and the restoration, protection and maintenance of ecosystems and how to limit the role of biomass-based products. 
-	the scale of investment required, looking at how to avoid lock-in and stranded assets, such as fossil gas infrastructure
-	macro-economic implications of the costs of inaction

The environmental impacts of this initiative should address the issue of the twin biodiversity and climate crisis and the fight against it. Therefore it needs to measure only joint solutions. Nature Based Solutions for greener cities

One of the biggest societal challenges is climate change. We more and more experience the consequences of sea level rise, heavy rainfall and drought that lead to financial, economic and social damage. In 2030 about 60% of our population will live in the city and this percentage will grow further in the future. On a relatively small surface lots of functions have to be combined. This challenge can not only be solved by technical solutions. For sure, they are more effective when a combination with the nature based solutions is made. 

Greenery is no longer to be considered as decoration. We are, based on scientific research,  aware of the values and benefits of greenery linked to climate change, biodiversity, health of people and in the circular economy. A few years ago the European Commission developed, supported by VHG, the Nature Based Solutions in renaturing the city Strategy under Horizon 2020. It made clear that greenery can no longer be left out as an option in creating liveable cities and it is important to involve greenery at the beginning of the planning and design process. Meanwhile new coalitions have been formed on national and local level in which specific policies and innovative best-practices are developed.

Green solutions
How can we make a liveable green environment and green sustainable buildings? VHG, the Dutch Landscape Contractors Association with 1.100 members and member of the European association ELCA, has developed the concepts of The Living Garden and The Living Building. Both concepts contribute to a sustainable and healthy living environment. In The Living Garden, based on 18 elements of sustainability, new ideas are offered for the design, creation an maintenance of private gardens, schoolyards, gardens at health institutions, commercials areas and in public spaces. For every target group there is a mind map which indicates precisely what the benefits of greenery are for them. We know for example that children learn better after that they have plaid at a green schoolyard. Research has shown that patients recover better in a hospital where they have a view on greenery. 

In the concept of The Living Building there is a lot of inspiration on how to make buildings greener. We can add greenery on the roof, at the façade or indoors. This concepts contains 19 elements of sustainability. The 19th is Energy. Roofs are a perfect place to set up electricity. When we place the solar panels on a green roof, they deliver more energy and last longer. The concept of The Living Building offers good opportunities and inspiration for different types of buildings and multifunctional usage of roofs. The urgency and depth, as well as the need for systemic change to address the climate crisis, is not conveyed.
INCREASING ECOLOGICAL DEBT
"Today, our economic systems are employing the fraudulent Ponzi scheme with our planet. We are consuming natural resources faster than they can be regenerated; we are using the resources of the next generations to operate in the present and we are sinking deeper and deeper into ecological debt. Prosperity can only endure if we embrace the limits of our planet. This would allow us to build an economy that works forever. However, ignoring them leads to a finite, time-bound economy that constantly erodes the planet on which it depends.
ECOLOGICAL COLLAPSE VS. THE "GASES"
Is the ecological emergency mainly a problem of gas emissions? The Climate Target Plan focuses on greenhouse gas emissions from the energy sector. However, land use change has had the greatest relative negative impact on ecological collapse. These two aspects cannot be addressed separately, as energy transition strategies are land use and mining intensive.
Seventy-five percent of the Earth's environment has been severely altered by the human population; we extract approximately 60 billion tons of resources each year, twice as much as in 1980. More than 85% of the wetlands that existed in 1700 disappeared before 2000. Global forest cover is only 68% of pre-industrial levels, and there are approximately 17,000 large-scale mines worldwide. Climate change is not yet the most significant factor in the destruction of nature. That means that the problem we are addressing is not simply how to "clean up" our energy sources, but rather how we can reduce our global energy consumption to save the planet.
CARBON BUDGET FRAMEWORK
The EU continues to negotiate percentage points in the carbon budget' which we find dubious and difficult to calculate. The level of uncertainty involved in this budget is excessive and makes it unproductive; we need a much more direct approach such as high restrictions on the use of energy and materials, nature conservation over economic benefits, an agricultural transition towards agro-ecology, etc. Furthermore, according to the IPCC's "1.5°C Global Warming Report", the goal of keeping global warming below 1.5°C would require a dramatic decrease in emissions by 2030. This implies a greater effort than the 45% reduction proposed by the EU in its plan.
ECONOMIC GROWTH
Europe has not decoupled economic growth from its ecological footprint. Studies show that "sustainable growth" will not achieve an absolute reduction in material consumption. The reduction of the ecological footprint, according to EU calculations, is only due to an increased dependence on material imports from Asia and a slowdown in economic growth following the 2008-2009 financial crisis. "The [EU-28's] ever-increasing ecological footprint has resulted in a growing biocapacity deficit", European Environment Agency (https://www.eea.europa.eu/data-and-maps/indicators/ecological-footprint-of-european-countries-assessment)
ECONOMIC GROWTH, GLOBAL JUSTICE AND COLONIALISM
Not only does the EU's ecological footprint continue to grow: the rich continue to reap the benefits of unsustainable consumption while the poor, indigenous and minorities bear the costs. The Climate Target Plan must therefore set out a just transition that must focus on the relationship between energy and material consumption with respect to the distribution of wealth, and thus approach any target in the plan from a historical and global perspective, forcing the EU to recognise its ecological debt.
BE REALISTIC ABOUT RENEWABLES
The document is not realistic in terms of what the real cost of "renewable" energy is. It should be borne in mind that making renewable energy technologies widely accessible (wind and photovoltaic) means relying on mining, inter-continental imports.

Die deutsche Chemie unterstützt das globale 2-Grad Ziel 2050 und trägt auch mit ihren Produkten aktiv dazu bei. Die VCI-Studie „Roadmap Chemie 2050“ zeigt auf, dass es für die Branche technologisch möglich ist 2050 treibhausgasneutral zu produzieren. Der Pfad hierzu wird aber nicht linear sein. Zudem steigt damit der Bedarf an wettbewerbsfähigem Strom aus erneuerbaren Energien für die chem. Industrie in Deutschland sowie der zusätzliche Investitionsbedarf (elffacher Strombedarf bis 2050, mindestens 628 TWh Erneuerbaren Strom zu einem Preis von 4 Cent/KWh und 45 Mrd. € Investitionsmittel) sehr stark an. Seitens der Politik müssen die dafür erforderlichen geeigneten Rahmenbedingungen geschaffen werden. 

Zusätzliche Emissionsminderungen bis 2030 über bestehende Vorgaben hinaus nicht möglich 
Die EU-Kom. verfolgt mit der Verschärfung des Klimaschutzziels 2030 von 40 % auf mindestens 50 % und angestrebte 55 % gegenüber 1990 sehr ambitionierte Ziele. Diese Zielsetzungen führen zwangsläufig zu Verschärfungen von Minderungszielsetzungen in bestehenden Instrumenten, wie z.B. dem EU-ETS. Diese neuen Ziele können wiederum nicht von der chem. Industrie begleitet werden, da die dafür erforderlichen treibhausgasneutralen Produktionsverfahren frühestens ab Mitte der 2030er Jahre zu Verfügung stehen (vgl. VCI-Studie). Dabei muss auch bedacht werden, dass aus wirtschaftlichen Gründen viele Anlagen erst deutlich nach 2030 in Betrieb genommen werden können. Darüber hinaus entwickeln sich Produktionsverfahren und Technologien nicht nach einem linearen Pfad, sondern stets unterschiedlich. 

Die Erhöhung des Reduktionsziels 2030 wird den Druck auf das EU-ETS und sowohl die bestehenden nationalen als auch europ. Zielsetzungen deutlich erhöhen. EU-ETS-seitig wird dies zu einer Verschärfung des linearen Reduktionsfaktors und ggf. zu der Notwendigkeit eines sektorübergreifenden Korrekturfaktors führen, den die EU-Kom. in der derzeitigen RL zur 4. Handelsperiode bewusst verhindert hat. Daneben muss das bestehende Effort Sharing neu verhandelt werden. Die hieraus resultierenden Mehr- sowie Doppelbelastungen der im intern. Wettbewerb und auch in Wertschöpfungsketten stehenden Unternehmen müssen zwingend durch auskömmliche Carbon Leakage-Schutzmechanismen ausgeglichen werden (kostenlose Zuteilung im EU-ETS und im besonderen Maße die Strompreiskompensation).

Keine Ausweitung EU-ETS
Sowohl die Industrie als auch die Energiewirtschaft sind mit dem größten Teil ihrer Emissionen vom EU-ETS erfasst. Nach Ablauf der dritten Handelsperiode, im Jahre 2020, werden die an das EU-ETS gestellten Ziele übererfüllt sein. Das Ergebnis zeigt, dass das Handelssystem funktioniert. Die Ausweitung des bestehenden EU-ETS auf die bisher nicht erfassten Non-ETS-Sektoren könnte zu massiven Preiserhöhungen bei den Zertifikaten führen und damit zu Wettbewerbsproblemen, die die Carbon Leakage-Gefahr für die heimischen Industrien erhöhen werden. Grund dafür sind stark unterschiedliche CO2-Vermeidungskosten und Preiselastizitäten der verschiedenen Sektoren. Es sollten zunächst sektoral eigene Systeme entwickelt werden. Mehr- und Doppelbelastungen sind dabei zu vermeiden. Derzeitige Carbon Leakage-Maßnahmen würden nicht mehr ausreichen, um die Zusatzbelastung auszugleichen. 
Im EU-ETS sind Carbon Leakage-Maßnahmen weiterhin erforderlich und müssen bei einer Zielerhöhung sogar verstärkt werden. Grenzausgleichsmaßnahmen z.B. sind kein Ersatz, da diese keinen adäquaten Schutz leisten können. 

Effektiver Klimaschutz kann nur global erreicht werden und erfordert ein globales Klimaschutzregime, mind. G20-Ebene, mit gleichen Regeln und Belastungen für alle. Unterschiedliche Anforderungen infolge von Alleingängen einzelner Regionen führen zu Wettbewerbsverzerrungen zulasten der europ. Industrie und bergen die Gefahr der indirekten Förderung einer treibhausgas-intensiveren Produktion außerhalb der EU. Um dies zu verhindern, muss die EU stärker er auf eine global einheitliche Lösung hinwirken.

EIGA supports Europe’s climate ambitions. The Green Deal recognizes that energy-intensive industries such as industrial gases are - as solution providers to multiple value chains - indispensable for Europe’s transition. Achieving Europe’s ambitions means going through a deep transformation within as few as two investment cycles. The industrial gases sector will play its part as an important element of the transition to a climate neutral and circular economy.

By procuring renewable electricity, air separation units - for the production of oxygen and nitrogen - are in principle straightforward to make climate-neutral.  However, to do so requires that sufficient reliable and affordable renewable electricity be available to industry; unfortunately this is not currently the case so more renewable energy will have to become available to achieve the EU 2030 Climate Target. The industrial gases sector will then be able to increase the share of renewable electricity in its energy mix and make the adaptations necessary in the design of air separation units to meet the changed features of electricity markets.

Disruptive technologies for low-carbon production of hydrogen already exist.  The production of renewable hydrogen is technically feasible, however limited again by the availability of reliable and affordable renewable electricity and by low demonstrated production capacities. “Blue” hydrogen – fossil-based hydrogen with CCS – is already technically demonstrated at scale and, with the appropriate support, is ready for roll-out. Both technology paths will help the EU to achieve its 2030 Climate Target.  

The impact assessment should also take into account different sectors’ ability to achieve significant GHG emission reductions during the period up to 2030, including the various investment steps - from innovation to implementation – that will inevitably result in non-linear impacts on emissions. Further, the industrial gases sector has long investment cycles, so investments that will impact its emissions profile in 2030 may have been taken already.

Tightening the EU 2030 Climate Target can facilitate a smoother trajectory towards 2050.  However, this major endeavor will not happen without a significant increase in production costs; policymakers should remain aware of the need to protect energy-intensive industries from carbon leakage.  Finally, policies should be crafted to avoid intersectoral market distortions e.g. inequality for outsourced production of industrial gases, which is broadly recognized for the environmental & economic benefits it provides.

Feedback of the DKV on the Roadmap for the 2030 Climate Target Plan

Deutscher Kälte- und Klimatechnischer Verein (German Society of Refrigeration and Air Conditioning) DKV e.V. is the only German technical-research society for individuals. The organisation was founded 1909 in Berlin and has recently more than 1600 members in Germany and foreign countries. Since then it has served as a non-profit academic organisation in the fields of cryogenics, refrigeration, air conditioning and heat pumps and related science and technology. – The DKV objectives are: Advance the arts and science and research of refrigeration, heating and air conditioning. 

Based primarily on the data from Germany, the DKV sets the following statements:
•	Around 56 % of final energy consumption is thermal energy /1/
•	The largest part are space heating, domestic hot water and process heat
•	So far, the majority is covered by burning fossil fuels.

The DKV sees realistic potentials by replacement of heat generation based on the combustion of fossil fuels by: 
•	Heat pumps for space heating as an existing and already industrialized technology
•	Heat pumps for domestic hot water as an existing and already industrialized technology 
•	Heat pumps for process heat which is to a limited extend an already existing technology (up to approx. 150 °C), and requires a certain level of R&D&I activities
•	Thermal storage as an existing and already industrialized technology to be able to use volatile renewable energies 
•	Waste heat recovery from commercial and industrial processes (in Germany the annual amount of waste heat from refrigeration and air/conditioning systems alone corresponds to approx. 40 % of the energy required annually for space heating)

CO₂ emissions correspond to approx. 74 % (globally) respectively 82 % (Germany) of all greenhouse gas emissions /2/. Thus, they are crucial. 

The DKV sees the target of a reduction of CO₂ emissions by 55 % compared to the base from 1990 to be achieved by 2030 – thus within a decade – as feasible if the potential of refrigeration, air conditioning and heat pump technology is used to the full extent /3/. 
For this, existing and already industrialized technologies can be used today.

Fast action on climate change has never been more necessary. Rapid global warming is bringing us perilously close to reaching critical climate tipping points; self-reinforcing feedback processes which further exasperate warming.
Assessment of the EU’s 2030 climate target must recognise our responsibility and capacity to avoid passing climate tipping points. Allowing anthropogenic emissions to set off a domino effect of tipping points that leaves us struggling to stabilise the climate risks catastrophic environmental, economic and social consequences. 
Despite the Paris agreement goal to limit the increase in the global average temperature to well below 2°C and to pursue efforts to limit to 1.5°C above preindustrial levels, current pledges take us on a pathway towards a 3-3.2°C increase by the end of the century.   In 2019 the UNEP emissions gap report estimates that to meet the 1.5°C target global annual emissions need to drop by almost 60% between 2018 and 2030.  Any meaningful attempt to meet the Paris agreement needs an increased focus on urgent near-term emission reduction measures. 
The 2019 UNEP emissions gap report warns that we must reduce global greenhouse gas emissions by 60% from 2018 levels by 2030 in order to limit warming to 1.5°C target.
If the EU were to align with this and reduce its emissions by 60% from 2018 levels by 2030 this would equate approximately to a 70% reduction from the 1990 baseline by 2030.  However, the notion of common but differentiated responsibilities, means that as a developed country the EU should adopt more ambitious measures, therefore the climate target of 70% should be committed to as a very minimum.
Meaningful action to keep global temperature increases to 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels requires the timeline for reaching net-zero-emissions to be bought forward to 2040 or earlier, in line with the EU’s historic contribution to the climate crisis and the global justice imperative. Current climate and energy targets for 2030 and the full implementation of the relevant legislation would enable EU emission reductions of around 45% by 2030 compared to 1990. The continuation of these policies and measures would only lead to around 60% GHG reduction by 2050, therefore increasing the target by just 5 or 10% over the next decade is clearly not enough to meet a net zero 2050, let alone net zero 2040.  
As evidenced by the coronavirus pandemic, societies are willing to make big changes to accommodate near-term threats. Recent events have demonstrated our ability to enact rapid behavioural and economic changes in order to mitigate those threats. Framing climate action as a near term threat is not only scientifically accurate but essential to ensure political and public buy-in. An ambitious 2030 climate target of 70% reflects the need for urgent action to avoid climate tipping points and also communicates the scale of climate emergency we are facing with the wider public. The proposed target of 50-55% simply does not match the urgency of action required to avoid catastrophic climate tipping points.
To enable near-term emission reductions requires further action on Short Lived Climate Pollutants (SCLPs) such as hydrofluorocarbons, methane and black carbon. Action on these super pollutants offers huge potential to avoid tipping points, as their short-life spans (often less than a decade or two) means that eliminating them has potent near-term cooling effects and could help buy us some much-needed time. Avoiding deforestation is also a key fast action climate mitigation strategy.
Consideration of the economic impacts of an ambitious climate target must not just consider the costs of action but also the huge costs associated with acting too slowly to avoid the threats posed by climate change. Addressing SCLPs also brings significant economic, health and social co-benefits, through improvements in air quality.

We, in the Swedish forest-based industry, are strongly convinced that, with the help of the new European Green Deal, we can offer solutions needed to transform society to climate neutrality while continuing to reduce our impact on climate change and increasing production in Europe. Our industry has therefore a strategic interest in being at the forefront of the decarbonisation efforts for 2050. We are an integral part of the circular bioeconomy and we operate several strategic elements of the forest-based industry value chain.
1. Promote biobased products and fibre-based solutions as well as circular economy
Biobased and fibre-based products have a tremendous role to lower the carbon footprint of end-user products. Policies should aim at fostering their market penetration. This is also in line with the Circular Economy Action Plan where the Commission aims to ensure the sustainability of renewable bio-based materials, including through actions following the Bioeconomy Strategy and Action Plan.
2. Strike the right balance between ETS and non-ETS sectors 
An increase of the 2030 target must strike the right balance between ETS sectors on one hand and non-ETS sectors on the other hand. There are good reasons for the non ETS sectors to take on the main part of an increased 2030 target and to maintain the level of ambitions in the ETS sector. The development in the ETS sector is dependent on the length of investment cycles, exposure to global competition and their role in delivering emission reductions along value-chains. In addition, any changes to the ETS followed by changes to the 2030 target must be combined with a global approach for European companies exporting outside of the EU with strengthened safeguards to stop carbon leakage, also taking into account indirect costs for industry of a higher electricity price since electrification is key for many sectors in the green transition. Furthermore, a large part of the emissions from the heating and transport sectors are expected to move to the ETS sector through electrification. In addition, many Member States already have national climate targets that exceed their EU target for non ETS sectors.
Both the development of existing technologies and a shift to new technologies and processes will be required for industry to become climate neutral. A linear trajectory therefore risks being contra productive for several sectors. A stepped approach taking into account technology shifts for different sectors is crucial. Investments in research and development for fossil-free production processes and CCS, including test and demonstration facilities, is important. Finally, to get the incentives right to benefit the first movers, not punishing them, is crucial.
3. Preserve regulatory stability
New legislative provisions introduced by the recently agreed Renewable Energies and Energy Efficiency Directives should not be subject to revision. Member States are still in the process of transposing them into national legislation and operators are still in the process of adjusting to the agreed regulatory framework. Re-opening these provisions will create regulatory instability for several years, having a negative impact on investments.
4. Role of the forests.
The carbon sink of forests should be seen as a part of a forest system which acts as a carbon sink, while storing carbon in products and substituting fossil-based materials, products and fuels. For this reason, forests must not be seen as carbon sinks or as an offset for emissions from other sectors: this would miss much of their full potential as sustainable source of fibers for renewable and recycled products, while bearing the risk of forests becoming a source of emissions in the long run. The objective should be to encourage secure investments into sustainable forest management to grow European forests further, adapt them to climate change and restore them where they are already affected by it.

Glass Alliance Europe, the European Alliance of Glass Industries, welcomes the opportunity to comment on the draft 2030 Target Climate Plan. The association has decided to submit a joint contribution, together with 11 other energy industries, to highlight a number of key elements that would need to be considered for an increase in the GHG emission reductions target for 2030 (in attachment).
Glass Alliance Europe wishes to stress that a number of enabling conditions are required for a swift reduction of manufacturing emissions; e.g. availability of disruptive technology, enabling infrastructures, carbon neutral energy, and financing. The assessment should therefore consider if these conditions are available (in practice and not theoretically) for further increasing the contribution of energy intensive sectors by 2030 compared to the current target.
Glass Alliance Europe shares the European Commission views when it states that the mitigation potentials between the different sectors of the economy differ strongly. Studies show that the mitigation potential in the building and transport sectors are particularly high. Therefore, the European Commission should consider in its impact assessment increasing significantly the GHG emission reduction effort in these sectors where solutions are available on the short term.
Finally, a possible increase of EIIs’ carbon leakage exposure should be assessed alongside the revision of the 2030 climate targets. Should the emission reductions target for energy intensive being reviewed in 2021, this will inevitably impact the carbon leakage exposure of the energy intensive sectors.

The agriculturural sector was, is and remains willing to participate in the 2030 climate efforts, but on the basis of a correct distribution of efforts and taking into account the potential and capacity of the sector
- Correct distribution: agriculture has decreased its greenhouse gasses already with around 20% since 1990, on the opposite the transport sector just increased its emissions since 1990. So the most efforts have to be made in the traffic sector. 
- The potential is lower than in other sectors due to natural processes with are the cause of greenhouse gas emissions in agriculture
- A fair price for food is a precondition for making additional efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

Further research and innovation is needed to find technical solutions as much as possible to reduces greenhouse gas emissions in agriculture, because natural processes are the cause of emissions in the agricultural sector and we still do not fully understand these processes.

Agricultural soils can store carbon indeed. But this requires additional efforts from farmers, they have been compensated for this. This is possible through CAP, but has also be rewarded outside the CAP, f.e. by carbon markets which can be facilitated by governements.

In context of several nation states (for example the country which I am a Citizens of, Germany) not being willing to take proper steps to keep the paris agreement, I'm happy that the EU Commission wants to take this topic forward and give it a higher salience. On the other hand I'm worried that while in the Document it is stated that the EU wants to do "whatever it takes" to uphold the paris agreement and become emission neutral, the plans to reduce the emissions by 50-55% till the year 2030 are not enough. If we want to have a 50/50 chance of staying under the 1.5°C goal, then we need to be emission neutral by 2038 (the world). For a 66% chance we should be neutral by 2030. If we keep hold of the neutral by 2050 goal as the world, we only have a 33% chance. (german link: https://www.klimareporter.de/erdsystem/klimaneutralitaet-kommt-2050-zwei-jahrzehnte-zu-spaet) This is all forgetting the historic duty we have as Europe, which has produced around 25% of all greenhousegas emissions so far (https://ourworldindata.org/co2-and-other-greenhouse-gas-emissions#cumulative-co2-emissions). In this context to give other countries a fair chance, we need to be climate neutral much earlier than 2050, and for that to happen we need larger reduction goals by 2030, somewhere in the realm of 70-85%. This is all in the consideration that we will have continued sinking of emissions from today on, globally (which is not the case).

Why is the 1.5°C goal so important? (Trajectories of the Earth System in the Anthropocene - https://www.pnas.org/content/115/33/8252)
There are some things which are out of human control, for example Biogeophysical Feedbacks and tipping points/cascades. Please check the above scientific paper to be informed of these. Maybe things will be okay if we reach 1.75°C, but maybe they won't be. In this context we need to be on the safe side - rather safe than sorry.

The possible increase of the 2030 climate target is one of the milestones of the European Green Deal that put Europe on the path to climate neutrality in 2050. With this policy process the EU can continue to lead international efforts, as all Parties of the Paris Agreement are required to review their objectives in line with the ambition mechanism. 

It is crucial that Member States and the European Parliament are able to take an informed decision on the 2030 climate target and the path to climate neutrality. This should be based on an objective and coherent analysis.  Therefore the 2030 climate target plan and the accompanying impact assessment must consider all possible solutions pragmatically and without prejudice.
 
It is furthermore important to ensure that climate action in the EU is always affordable, feasible and cost-effective. This should be the case for both citizens and businesses in each Member State and economic sector. Sectors which are subject to international competition should be protected against the risk of carbon leakage. The objective - as stated in the inception impact assessment - to make the climate transition contribute to sustainable growth, strengthening competitiveness and modernizing companies is more important than ever.
 
In addition, the EU's role as a leader and catalyst in global action on climate change should lead to effective results . As EU, we depend on cooperation with other major trading blocs. When increasing our European climate ambition, we must assess how the other regions are taking responsibility.
 
We expect the European Commission to thoroughly analyze the elements above in the communication and the accompanying impact assessment, identifying at least the following:
 
•	A well- substantiated and well-advised assessment of the possible climate targets for 2030, in which various options are explored with an open mind. It is premature to examine only two options ex-ante, i.e. - 50% or - 55%. The options between -40% and -50%, and between -50% and -55% should also be evaluated.

•	A thorough assessment of any additional climate efforts of the other major trading blocs and an estimate of :
      o	the potential incentive effect of raising the 2030 climate ambition on the ambitions of other major trading blocs ;
      o	The impact of increasing the European climate target 2030 on global emissions and achieving the necessary global emission reductions;
      o	The impact on trade flows

•	The assessment of the use of international flexibility to achieve the increased 2030 climate target , which is elaborated under Article 6 of the Paris Agreement while avoiding double counting;

•	A full update of the EU Reference scenario, taking into account the latest policy plans of the Member States. The inception impact assessment indicates that it will only be available by the end of 2020. However, it is imperative that the reference scenario is fully available for the 2030 climate target plan and the impact assessment. 

•	A detailed modeling, in which the cost-effective contribution of each Member State and sector (also per Member State) and the macro-economic impact for member states and sectors and quantified.

•	The possible impact of the Corona crisis on the available resources for achieving the 2030 climate targets.

The EU is applauded for strong action to mitigate climate change and the continual development of strategies, such as the 2030 Climate Target Plan, which are significant in leading the world in policies to reduce emissions and importantly to decouple them from economic growth and link them to reversing environmental degradation. Developing an energy system, but also commodity production, that reverses environmental degradation is essential for sustaining human activity on the planet.
Mitigation actions require both reducing emissions to the atmosphere and increasing stocks of carbon in the biosphere. Actions should be assessed in terms of their impact on both the magnitude and longevity of carbon stocks. The EU’s land use sector is currently assessed as a net annual sink (although a declining sink). The more important fact is that the land sector, and particularly forests, stores large amounts of carbon in a stable form. Maintaining this carbon and avoiding its loss as emissions should be the highest priority mitigation action in the land sector. This pool of carbon could be increased greatly by changing land management, and hence removing carbon from the atmosphere.
Biomass-based products for energy or commodities are not carbon neutral. Biomass may be used as substitutes for other more GHG-intensive products, but will always result in a loss of carbon stocks from the biosphere and increase in carbon in the atmosphere. Utilisation of biomass means foregone storage of carbon in the biosphere and this opportunity cost must be included in carbon accounts. The assumption of carbon neutrality is based on assessment of current emissions being offset by future removals by forest regeneration. However, the removals take many decades to achieve this offset. This time factor must be taken into account in prioritising mitigation actions for the next decade. 
Prioritising nature-based solutions should be based on the total carbon storage in the land sector, with decreasing order of activities as follows:
1.	Protection – primary forests with high biomass carbon stocks, managed for conservation, with strong legal protection and enforcement.
2.	Proforestation and restoration – ceasing harvesting in native forests and allowing secondary forests to continue regrowing, with management for restoration.
3.	Reforestation – planting native tree species on previously cleared land and allowing trees to continue growing.
4.	Plantations – industry re-adjustment to source wood products from plantations.
These activities should be designed in the context of systematic landscape conservation planning to optimise spatial placement of forest-based interventions and improve connectivity between existing and restored natural ecosystems.
Policies for mitigation actions and reversing environmental degradation should be completely synergistic. Maintaining stable carbon stocks in the land sector is dependent on maintaining biodiversity and natural ecological processes. Biodiversity should not be considered as just a co-benefit. Transformations in the zoning of land use will be an important action, particularly in increasing the area and protection status of forest lands.
Environmental impacts should consider both negative and positive impacts. Negative impacts of using biomass for energy and commodity production include: continued and future loss of biodiversity and ecosystem integrity; competition of land for food production; reduction in the quality and quantity of fresh water supply; air pollution and health impacts. Positive impacts of protecting and restoring ecosystems as carbon stores include: enhancing ecosystem services provided by biodiversity; improved water supply; improved recreational and ecotourism opportunities.
Mitigation actions that merely reduce the rate of emissions against an historic reference level are insufficient. Rather, actions are needed that explicitly avoid emissions as well as enabling ongoing sequestration.

En la actualidad, nuestros sistemas económicos están empleando el fraudulento esquema de la pirámide de Ponzi con nuestro planeta. Estamos consumiendo recursos naturales más rápidamente de lo que pueden regenerarse; estamos utilizando los recursos de las próximas generaciones para operar en el presente y nos estamos hundiendo cada vez más en la deuda ecológica. La prosperidad sólo puede perdurar si asumimos los límites de nuestro planeta. Esto nos permitiría construir una economía que funcione para siempre. Sin embargo, ignorarlos conduce a una economía finita y limitada en el tiempo que erosiona constantemente el planeta del que depende. 
El Plan del objetivo climático se centra en las emisiones de gases de efecto invernadero provinientes del sector energético. Sin embargo, el cambio del uso del suelo ha tenido el impacto negativo relativo más grande en el colapso ecológico. Estos dos aspectos no pueden ser abordados de manera separada, ya que las estrategias de transición energéticas son intensivas en términos de uso del suelo y explotación minera.
El 75% del medio ambiente terrestre ha sido severamente alterado por la población humana, extraemos aproximadamente 60 mil millones de toneladas de recursos cada año, el doble que en 1980. Más del 85% de los humedales existentes en 1700 desaparecieron antes del 2000. La cubierta forestal mundial alcanza sólamente el 68% de los niveles pre-industriales y existen aproximadamente 17.000 minerías de gran escala en el mundo. El cambio climático todavia no es el factor más significativo de la destrucción de la naturaleza. Eso significa que el problema que abordamos no es simplemente cómo «limpiar» nuestras fuentes de energía, sino más bien cómo podemos reducir nuestro consumo global de energía para salvar al planeta.
La UE sigue negociando puntos porcentuales en el «presupuesto de carbono» los cuales resultan, a nuestro entender, dudosos y difíciles de calcular. El nivel de incertidumbre que acarrea este presupuesto es excesivo y lo convierte en infructuoso; necesitamos un enfoque mucho más directo como pueden ser altas restricciones al uso de la energía y de los materiales, la conservación de la naturaleza por encima de los beneficios económicos, una transición agrícola hacia la agroecología, etc. Además, de acuerdo con el «Informe sobre Calentamiento Global de 1,5ºC» del IPCC, el objetivo de mantener el calentamiento global por debajo de 1,5ºC requeriría de un descenso drástico de emisiones antes de 2030. Esto implica un mayor esfuerzo que el 45% de reducción que propone la UE en su plan.
Europa no ha desvinculado el crecimiento económico de su huella ecológica. Diversos estudios demuestran que mediante el «crecimiento sostenible» no se logrará una reducción absoluta en el consumo de materiales. La reducción de la huella ecológica, según los cálculos de la UE, se deben únicamente a una mayor dependencia de las importaciones de materiales de Asia y a una desaceleración del crecimiento económico tras la crisis financiera de 2008-2009. «La huella ecológica en constante aumento [de la UE-28] ha dado lugar a un déficit de biocapacidad cada vez mayor»
No sólo sigue creciendo la huella ecológica de la UE: los ricos siguen acumulando los beneficios del consumo insostenible mientras que los pobres, los indígenas y las minorías cargan con los costes. Por tanto en el Plan de Objetivo Climático se debe fijar una transición justa que debe poner en el punto de mira la relación existente entre los consumos de energía y materiales respecto a la distribución de la riqueza, y así enfocar cualquier objetivo del plan partiendo de una perspectiva histórica y global, obligando a la EU a reconocer su deuda ecológica.
Hay que tener en cuenta que para conseguir que las tecnologías de energía renovable sean ampliamente accesibles (eólica y fotovoltaica) significa depender de otras industrias que sí contaminan.
Están lejos de ser una solución en una economía en contínuo crecimiento.

AFEP, the French Association of Large Companies, welcomes the consultation of the European Commission on an Inception Impact Assessment for a 2030 Climate Target Plan. 

This consultation is of utmost importance for companies as the goal is to assess the feasibility of more stringent greenhouse gases emissions targets for 2030 at EU level through an amendment of the proposed climate law. 

The current COVID-19 pandemic clearly shows the difficulties to react to unexpected events at the global level. In this context, companies consider that the ten next years will be crucial to provide solutions to address the expected risk of climate change while taking into account social acceptance and economic and competitivity constraints.

The impact assessment will be a huge challenge as it will examine many policies (eg: Effort Sharing Directive, Emissions Trading Directive, Renewable Energy Directive, Energy Efficiency Directive...) covering a wide number of sectors.

AFEP member companies support the target of the Paris Agreement by respecting regulations and taking voluntary commitments to lower their GHG emissions where they operate, generally at a worldwide scale.

Given the economic effects of the current pandemic and its possible impacts in the longer term, it is important to define in the impact assessment under what conditions the current 2030 energy and GHG emissions targets will be reached. In this context, companies wish for this impact assessment to determine how the EU and all Member States could strike the right balance between GHG emissions constraints, with the current or additional set of legislation, and more significant support to sustain low carbon solutions inside the EU - from the R&D until their rollout.

Companies wish for the Commission to assess the feasibility of each GHG emissions reduction scenario (40%, 45 %, 50% and 55%) by 2030 compared to 1990 within the EU in regard to the various enabling factors among which: improvement of EU competitiveness and attractiveness through the possible use of carbon footprint target and related provisions, the rise of low carbon investments given constraints on investments cycles, and acceptable targets sharing between ETS and non-ETS sectors considering energy intensity/exposure to international trade while maintaining carbon leakage measures/compensation of indirect costs provisions.

The pdf document attached to this feedback develops the association’s comments in more details and lists all the enabling factors that will for companies be key to assess the feasibility of each GHG emissions reduction scenario.

Konkret: Es wird in der EU noch immer viel zu viel in Erdgas-Infrastruktur investiert, und zu wenig in Stromnetze und -speichermöglichkeiten. Wind- und Sonnenenergie sind viel klimafreundlicher als Erdgas. Dass bei dem Letzteren der Methanschlupf wirksam reduziert werden kann (mittelfristig auf nahe Null), ist bisher nicht belegt. Währenddessen wird an den Küsten viel Windstrom produziert, das aber leider nicht genutzt werden kann: Um Überlastung der Stromnetze zu vermeiden, müssen betriebsbereite Windräder zeitweise angehalten werden und still stehen... organization: Cefic - The European Chemical Industry Council
feedback:
Cefic supports Europe’s ambition to become climate neutral by 2050. The Green Deal recognises that energy-intensive industries, such as chemicals, are indispensable for Europe’s transition, as solution providers to multiple value chains. Climate neutrality by 2050 means going through a deep transformation within just one or two investment cycles. The EU chemical industry intends to grasp the opportunities arising from the transition to a climate neutral and circular economy.

Changing the 2030 target can secure a balanced reduction pathway towards 2050 and redistribute in time the transition effort towards climate neutrality. Pathways are however not linear. The impact assessment should consider the different sectors’ and Members States’ ability to achieve significant GHG emissions reduction until 2030 and investment cycles, including different investment steps from innovation to implementation. This means part of the investment decisions determining our GHG emissions profile in 2030 have been taken already.

Main disruptive technologies that would allow the Chemical Industry to make a step change are not yet available or still need to be demonstrated on a full industrial scale and become competitive vis-à-vis conventional production. Modelling tools should also take into consideration total investment costs, variable costs (including loss of efficiency due to new processes or alternative feedstock) and interactions between sectors of the economy (e.g. impact of the renovation wave on demand for basic materials).

Based on the current effort-sharing between sectors of the economy, an increase of the 2030 GHG target up to -55% could result in more than a doubling of the ETS Linear Reduction Factor applying to industry. It makes sense to consider a redistribution of the effort between sectors (split between ETS and non-ETS sectors) based on marginal abatement cost, technology readiness and exposure to global competition e.g. by increasing the level of ambition in the building sector.

We need a coordinated EU-wide response to the threat of climate change as nationalisation of climate policy and fragmented action will distort the internal market. The EU ETS should keep playing this role by ensuring an EU-wide approach for power and industry. If similar approaches are considered for e.g. road transport or buildings, it must be done via a separate trading scheme, as these sectors currently have different elasticities to carbon cost.

The Commission should also take due account of the international dimension and the negative impact of fragmented action on a global level. An increase of the 2030 ambition must be accompanied by reinforced protection against the risk of carbon leakage addressing direct and indirect carbon costs, imports and exports, and securing an adequate amount of free allocation available for industry. As the cost of emitting or investing into low-carbon technologies becomes higher, it will be important that these costs can be shared across society and that the payback for investing into new processes is sufficient. As auctioning revenues have gone up it becomes all the more important that these are reinjected into innovation in our sectors, in line with our investment challenge.

Last but not least, we urgently need an enabling framework creating the necessary conditions for investments, as identified in the Industrial Transformation Master Plan. This calls for a tangible regulatory framework which not only puts climate ambition into law but also the necessary pre-conditions. Industry will only be able to start a deep transformation once the necessary infrastructure is in place, once it has access to abundant climate-neutral resources and energy at competitive cost and once new markets for low-carbon circular products justify the investment.

Please also read our joint Alliance of Energy Intensive Industries answer here: https://cefic.org/app/uploads/2020/04/Joint-Alliance-submission15-04-20.pdf
