The use of woody biomass for energy (beyond internal use in the forest sector) has been increasing in British Columbia (BC) over the past two decades.  Most BC wood pellets are exported to Europe and Asia. In BC, bioenergy from wood can make economic sense as a secondary by-product industry, where there is ‘waste’ from existing processing facilities, such as sawmills.  Pellet production from harvest residues could also help reduce the air pollution caused by slashburning, but it won’t help reduce anthropogenic emissions of CO2 to the atmosphere by 2040 or 2050.  Large-scale production of bioenergy from forest biomass is not GHG neutral, nor is it sustainable or environmentally friendly.

Yes, logged forests can be renewed but carbon neutrality for forest biomass means that all emissions from the harvesting, transport, processing, and burning of trees and wood products are offset by future carbon stores. That is unlikely and would take many years—in BC perhaps 70 to 400+ years, if at all.  Some logged, old-growth temperate rainforests may never recover their original carbon storage capacity.
Yes, wood is renewable in the long term; wood bioenergy uses carbon that is already within the biosphere; and wood biofuel can substitute for fossil fuel.  But wood typically has one-third to one-quarter the specific energy (MJ/kg; aka energy density) of coal or other hydrocarbons. This means that, to get a unit of energy, you need to burn more wood relative to fossil fuels and more CO2 will be put into the atmosphere with wood than with fossil fuels.  Thus, wood burning results in greater initial CO2 emissions.  Pellets have greater specific energy than some unprocessed wood but still less than fossil fuels. 

In principle, wood pellets can be used to displace fossil fuels in the generation of electricity.  It happens in the EU,  where wood pellets have ill-advisedly  been deemed carbon neutral, thereby ignoring the CO2 emitted during processing and shipping and the losses of carbon stock from forests harvested in North America.  This is an example of ‘leakage’; the European offsetting results in CO2 emissions elsewhere, effectively exporting the emissions.   Producing wood pellets in BC and shipping them to Europe can account for about 25% of the total carbon emissions from the use of wood pellets in European power plants.   Under international rules, these emissions are assigned to BC.  Exporting pellets from BC thus results in increased reported emissions in BC.  Marine transportation (typically by freighters burning very dirty bunker fuel) is a major contributor to negative environmental impacts.
 
Burning wood or wood products from mature and old forests won’t help reduce anthropogenic emissions of CO2 to the atmosphere by 2030 or 2050.  It takes time to regain the carbon storage on the landscape – i.e., to pay off the ‘carbon debt’.   Moreover, if the imperative is to avoid carbon emissions now and reduce emissions 80% or achieve net zero emissions by 2050, it’s the amount not the origin of the atmospheric CO2 that really matters for the next few decades.  The atmosphere can’t discriminate between molecules of carbon dioxide.  CO2 is CO2 whether it comes from a tailpipe or a ‘carbon neutral’ stack.

As a primary industry with a continual demand for fibre, additional pressure falls on natural forests to supply fibre during shortages of  mill residues.   Grinding up healthy, young and mature forests for pellets is an ill-advised use of wood.  Logging old forests (including irreplaceable old growth) solely to produce pellets makes no sense economically, ecologically, or in terms of carbon stewardship.  High-grading decay-rich old forests to retrieve only the 10-25% best sawlogs for milling or whole log export, while producing pellets from the mountains of bush residue, is also a bankrupt approach. Large-scale production of bioenergy from forest biomass is not GHG neutral, nor is it sustainable or environmentally friendly.

The EU’s global leadership in the fight against climate change is invaluable. Increasing the 2030 EU GHG reductions target from 40% to 50% or 55% is essential. But stronger climate action must not come at the expense of forests.

To date, EU Renewable Energy Directives (RED) intended to reduce GHG emissions have classified the burning of biomass for energy as “zero carbon.” Far from being zero carbon, wood-fired electricity and heating-units using green wood chips for fuel emit more CO2 per unit of energy output than fossil-fired units. For example, in 2016 at the Drax Power Plant in the UK, burning coal produced 873 kilotons (kt) of CO2 per terawatt hour of electricity(TWH). Burning biomass produced 902 kt CO2 per TWH.

Under current RED, biomass, particularly wood and wood-waste, is the biggest source of renewable energy in the EU. In 2019 the Drax power station burned 7.05 million tonnes of wood pellets. 65% of those wood pellets came from the USA.

Harvesting this volume of wood for biomass is devastating already stressed forests on both sides of the Atlantic. Here in Canada, our forests now sequester 30% less carbon than in 1990. In Annapolis County, Nova Scotia, they have seen a 15% reduction in forest cover between 2000 and 2018. This is due to harvesting, the majority of it in its least sustainable, most damaging form: clearcutting.

When a forest is clearcut, while trees may in time regrow and begin to sequester carbon again, they will take a minimum of ten years to do so in any significant way, and far longer to fully replace the carbon sink capacity of the forest that was removed. This is time we don’t have. Also, more carbon is stored in the top metre of soil in a natural forest than is contained in all the woody material above ground. When sunlight hits that newly exposed forest floor, the soil releases most of the carbon it has been storing. The only forestry we should be practicing in a climate and biodiversity emergency is closed canopy, ecological forestry. This kind of forestry would not, could not and should not produce the quantity of wood currently required by plants burning pellets for the generation or co-generation of electricity.

In Nova Scotia, citizens have repeatedly declared that they want an end to clearcutting but the government department responsible for monitoring forestry industry activities is staffed by veterans of that industry. Public consultations are organised by government then ignored while the industry continues to cut as much ‘fibre’ as it can. This is decimating what little remains of the rich, biodiverse, uneven aged Acadian forest that once covered Nova Scotia. Between 1958 and 2003 the proportion of forest in Nova Scotia aged more than 61 years fell from 59% to 13.5%. Since 2003 the pace of clearcutting has increased.

This year, Northern Pulp, a sawmill that contaminated an Indigenous community’s land for 50 years, was finally closed down. This cut demand for fibre in our province and might offer an opportunity to start restoring our forests. Instead our provincial government, hand in glove with industry, is searching for an export market. They already export biomass to the UK and Europe and are eager to export more. Make no mistake, these are NOT sustainably sourced woodchips. Please, please do not encourage further destruction of our forests by continuing with the travesty of burning biomass for “green” energy.

The biodiversity crisis is inseparable from the climate crisis. Forests offer a natural solution for both crises. We need a climate policy that puts forests first. Please stop classifying the burning of biomass as “zero carbon.” End all subsidies for biomass harvesting and burning. Instead channel that money into protecting and restoring forests in the EU. That will give us a chance to protect and restore our forests too. This is a global emergency. We must work together to solve it.

To whom it may concern,

Overall, I am happy to see attempts by the EU to take climate action and I want to encourage you to not lose track of these goals, even if there is other, additional, crises currently demanding our attention. There are several aspects of the 2030 Climate Target Plan that I would like to provide feedback on:

- The goals stated in the plan are not compatible with the 1.5°C target. The IPCC report demands a reduction of emissions of around 45% between 2010 and 2030. Please listen to the science and act accordingly!

- Considering that you state that "strong leadership" is necessary to finally effectively meet the goals of the Paris Agreement, I ask the EU members to show this strong leadership and finally work together in order to meet their contributions to achieve the 1.5°C target.

- According to your Climate Target Plan, the EU is "willing to do what it takes to become climate neutral" - please do act accordingly! - Please put a stronger emphasis on the fact that there will be huge impacts on fundamental rights of humans (especially vulnerable groups) if sufficient action to become climate neutral is delayed. Europe needs to act exemplarily in this case - and be a role model for other high emitters that are not yet willing to commit themselves to serious climate action such as the USA, Australia or the BRIC states.

This crisis is not a bargain but simply the question of future livelihood on this planet. The goals stated in the 2030 Climate Target Plan are good, but still far from being ambitious enough. We need to set higher goals and reduce emissions as fast as possible!

I demand, that the EU protects live on this planet and preserves our planet for all humans in and outside of Europe and for future generations.

Thank you for your effort and please keep in mind that an ambitious 2030 Climate Target Plan is in the interest of all citizens - of the EU and the world - no matter which party they identify with, no matter who they have voted for. And please, please listen to the scientists!

We face the biggest threat to our existence with the interwoven issues of climate crisis and accelerating loss of biodiversity. Reviewing the current legislation and goals for a more ambitious response is essential. 

What is hugely problematic about the goals is that the proposed solutions to achieve them are based on misinformation and misleading accounting. Mary Jean Chisholm

Is the ecological emergency primarily a “gas” problem? The Climate Target Plan focuses on greenhouse gas emissions, mainly from energy. However, land use change has had the largest relative negative impact on ecological collapse. The two aspects cannot be addressed separately as proposed energy decarbonisation strategies are land and mining intensive.

Seventy-five percent of the terrestrial environment has been severely altered by humans, who extract about 60 billion tons of resources every year, double the amount in 1980. More than 85% of the wetlands present in 1700 have been lost by 2000. Forest cover world-wide is only 68% of pre-industrial levels and there are about 17 000 large scale mining sites in the world. Climate change is not yet the most significant driver of nature’s destruction. This means that the most urgent question is not how “clean” our energy sources are but rather how much can we reduce overall energy consumption in order to save the planet.

Die Initiative versucht, die bestehenden EU-Regelungen dahingehend anzupassen, dass die Treibhausgasemissionen bis zum Jahr 2050 etwa linear auf null reduziert werden sollen. Was dabei keine Berücksichtigung findet, ist, dass es sich bei der Überführung der EU in eine klimaneutrale Gesellschaft um ein sehr komplexes Vorhaben handelt. Die Erfahrung zeigt, dass sich große, komplexe Projekte bei gleichbleibendem Aufwand asymptotisch (in Form einer exponentiell Abfallenden Kurve) ihrem Ziel nähern. Oft wird dies als Paretoprinzip bezeichnet - 80% der Zielerreichung wird mit 20% der Bemühungen erreicht. 

Jeder realistische Treibhausgasemissions-Reduktionspfad muss folglich einer exponentiellen Abnahme folgen. Bei einem linearen Reduktionspfad müssten die Anstrengungen dagegen exponentiell zunehmen, was heute zwar bequem ist, sehr bald jedoch vollkommen unrealistische Maßnahmen erfordern würde. Entsprechend ist in dem in der Initiative vorgesehenen Reduktionspfad das Scheitern schon fest eingebaut. Um realistisch 99,9% Klimaneutralität bis 2050 zu erreichen müssen die Treibhausgasemissionen jedes Jahr um ca. 20% bezogen auf das Vorjahr sinken. Bezogen auf das Jahr 1990 muss die 50% Reduktion bereits im Jahr 2022 erreicht werden. 2030 liegen die Emissionen dann unter 9% bezogen auf 1990. Nur mit einer solchen jährlichen 20%-Abnahme ist das Ziel einer Treibhausgasneutralität bis 2050 tatsächlich realistisch erreichbar. Bezogen auf 1990 sähe ein realistischer Pfad folglich so aus:
2022: 50%
2024: 32%
2026: 21%
2028: 13%
2030:  8,6%
2035:  2,9%
2040:  1,0%
2045:  0,3%
2050:  < 0,1%

Hier zeigt sich die Tücke exponentieller Verläufe, wie wir sie auch bei der derzeitigen Corona-Pandemie erleben. Wir müssen jetzt wesentlich entschlossener handeln als es unsere linear denkende Intuition suggeriert. Anderenfalls ist das Scheitern in zehn Jahren aber unausweichlich. Die Folgen wären dabei wesentlich schlimmer als eine unkontrollierte Ausbreitung von SARS-CoV-2, bei der wir derzeit bereit sind, sie mit sehr viel drastischeren Maßnahmen zu verhindern.

Fazit:

Um realistisch Klimaneutralität bis 2050 erreichen zu können, muss das Zwischenziel für 2030 auf höchstens 9% Treibhausgasemissionen bezogen auf 1990 angepasst werden. Offensichtlich ist die Aufstellung nur dieses einen Zwischenziels zur Einhaltung des notwendigen Reduktionspfades nicht geeignet. Ein geeignetes Mittel ist dagegen das Festlegen einer jährlichen prozentualen Reduktion der Treibhausgasemissionen von 20% jeweils bezogen auf das Vorjahr. Die Einhaltung des Zieles muss überwacht werden, damit bei Überschreitung automatisch und zeitnah (innerhalb weniger Monate) zuvor festgelegte, starke Gegenmaßnahmen aktiv werden. 

Wie bereits viele Kommentatoren angemerkt haben, ist der in der Initiative vorgeschlagene lineare Reduktionspfad nicht mit dem 1,5°C-Ziel vereinbar. Wie ich hier dargelegt habe, ist er auch vom Prinzip her nicht umsetzbar und sein Scheitern daher unausweichlich. Ich rege an, statt festen Zwischenzielen eine jährliche prozentuale Reduktion der Treibhausgasemissionen festzulegen. 

Sollte es bei den vorgeschlagenen viel zu geringen Zielen bleiben, rege ich wenigstens an, den Text der Initiative entsprechend anzupassen und offen zuzugeben, dass die Maßnahmen nicht ausreichen, um einen fairen Beitrag Europas zum Erreichen des 1,5°C-Zieles zu liefern. Auch die dadurch billigend in Kauf genommenen Konsequenzen bis hin zum möglichen Ende unserer hochtechnologisierten Zivilisation sollten offen genannt werden und im Abschnitt "Likely economic impacts" Berücksichtigung finden. Zudem sollte erwähnt werden, dass der vorgesehene lineare Reduktionspfad eine exponentielle Zunahme der Bemühungen erfordert und somit sicher scheitern wird.

2050 is much too late. We already see tipping points triggering (arctic ice, permafrost). We are living at the expense of future generations, our children. We have to listen to our scientists and follow their advice. Stop subsidizing fossil fuels, stop extracting fossil fuels. We have to find sustainable ways to live, including the environment. Nature won't wait for us, we have to act now. We cannot fix it once it's broken and we have no other planet to live on. Our lives depend on a stable climate. Tax carbon at ~200€ per tonne (roughly the estimate of what it's harmful effects cost society) or do whatever it takes so we don't lose control, before the heating of our atmosphere becomes self-accelerating.

As the Target Plan has stated, we as humans are not taking the required measures to reduce the global warming to 2°C, which is the absoulute least of a goal we must set, since the 'right' goal - as stated in the Paris climate agreement and in various IPCC reports - should be to reduce the global warming to 1.5°C. 

In my opinion, the plan to raise the reduction of the green house emissions compared to 1990 from 40% to 50-55% is a step in the right direction, but still clearly not enough to reach the goals stated above. The IPCC report regarding the 1.5°C goal sees a reduction of 45% compared to 2010 as appropiate, and even in this and other reports, the factual foundation is presented quite embellished, since they stride to match the scientific consensus. 
So even the 45%-recommendation of the IPCC has to be taken as an absoulute minimum of measure for a Climate Target Plan that could really be taken seriously.

I often try to imagine myself in the position of one of the politicians that, at the end of the day, makes a consequent decision towards the goals that will safe our planet in the long run and has to face various complaints from people with high economic power, such as e.g. big company CEOs. Even if they don't express these complaints directly to me, they express them and I - sooner or later - will hear them and feel the pressure, since the power of this complaint is high. 
But, with all reasoning, I would still listen to the broad european population, to the people, rather than to one person with much money, since I was raised in a democracy, where every opinion, be it from a young university student, a construction worker or a high class CEO, matters to the same amount. 
And I would listen to the people dedicating their lives to research and environmental science, since they are the people that know the best how to act in favour of our planet, as a large group, as a conscientious species, as human beings. 
I demand a consequent strategy that will actually be able to maintain the goals that are so important to us and to following generations. 
I ask the European Union to take a leading role as the one global player that actually cares and listens and makes decisions that can change our habits to the better. For us and for the planet. 

What I also miss is the fact that we as the European Union, a comparably rich society with a more severe history regarding green house emissions, have to act in a stricter way as others.
To ensure that more challenged countries and unions can follow up until 2050, we have to take a higher responsobility and do more work, in the common sense of climate justice.
Not to mention the fact that our lifestyle is a result of high emissions in places all over the world, which should also be considered.
I demand a stricter consideration of the various areas regarding climate justice for the Climate Target Plan

 'Whatever it takes' is the answer to the question what should be done to face the climate crisis. Seeing the current measures, I must say that 'whatever it takes' is simply not the truth. We can do better!

 A reduction of green house emissions to net zero until 2025 for the economically strong european countries and until 2030 for the economically challenged european countries is, in my opinion, the right way towards a healthy planet for us and many generations to come.

Kurzversion: Klimaneutralität bis 2050 ist nach wissenschaftlichem Stand nicht sinnvoll. Als Ziel sollten 2025 oder 2030 angesetzt werden.

Wir wissen dank zahlreichen Wissenschaftlern, dass die jetzigen Vorgaben des Pariser Abkommens, vermutlich zu einer Erderwärmung von ungefähr 3°C führen würden. Bei dieser Temperatur sind mit hoher Wahrscheinlichkeit bereits einige Kipppunkte erreicht, die die Erwärmung weiter vorantreiben und zu weiteren Kipppunkten führen, bis zum Dominoeffekt.
3°C Erwärmung führen also vermutlich zum Aussterben der Menschheit und mit Sicherheit zum zivilen Kollaps und Milliarden Toten.

Technologien zur Kohlenstoffbindungen dürfen in keinen Plänen enthalten sein. Selbst wenn sie wundersamer Weise plötzlich großtechnisch zur Verfügung stehen, würden sie Unmengen an Energie brauchen, die wir in den nächsten Jahrzehnten nicht "grün" produzieren könnten. Die einzige funktionierende "Technologie" in dem Bereich ist die Photosynthese, von der wir durch Waldsterben, -bränden und -rodungen und dem Sterben des Phytoplanktons immer weniger haben.
Aufforstung ist zur Kohlenstoffbindung die einzige realistische Möglichkeit.

Als Aktivist von Extinction Rebellion stehe ich hinter der Forderung für Staaten wie Deutschland 2025 für die Klimaneutralität anzupeilen. Egal welches Ziel wir uns setzen, wir werden es verfehlen. Das liegt in der Natur der Sache. 
Beschließen wir jetzt schwerwiegende Maßnahmen, können wir starke Emissionssenkungen erreichen und die restlichen schwer umgänglichen Emissionen die verbleiben, über einen längeren Zeitraum bearbeiten.
Nur so können wir den wissenschaftlich belegten, akzeptablen Zeitpunkt von 2036 zur Klimaneutralität erreichen.

Schwerwiegende Maßnahmen sind der Bevölkerung schwierig zu vermitteln. Hier meine Vorschläge dazu:

1) Den Klimanotstand hat die EU schon ausgerufen. Sehr gut! Beziehen sie sich bei jeder Maßnahme auf ihn, um die Notwendigkeit zu betonen.
2) Die dritte Forderung von XR ist die Einführung von Bürgerversammlungen, bei denen ausgeloste Bürger von Experten beraten werden und dann Maßnahmen beschließen sollen (häufig Bürgerrat genannt; das Konzept ist Ihnen sicherlich bekannt).
Maßnahmen die unter Bürgerbeteiligung beschlossen werden, werden eher von den Bürgern akzeptiert. Außerdem können sich Politiker auf die Beschlüsse der Bürgerversammlung berufen, um Verantwortung von sich zu weisen und die eigene Wählbarkeit zu schonen und Lobbyisten weniger zu verärgern.
3) Nutzen sie die Coronakrise. Die Bürger haben jetzt eine kleine Krise erlebt und haben akzeptiert, dass diese zu Einschränkungen geführt hat. Es muss klar vermittelt werden, wie gewaltig die Klimakrise im Vergleich zum "Corona-Problemchen" ist. Milliarden Leben sind gefährdet statt zehn- oder huntertausenden.
4) Verwerfen wir die bisherige Umweltpsychologie, die das Problem kleinredet. "Tun sie etwas für die Umwelt und benutzen sie weniger Plastiktüten" oder "richtig heizen und die Umwelt schonen" sind kleine Beiträge, die schön für das eigene Wirksamkeitsgefühl sind, aber gegen die Gewaltigkeit der Klimakatastrophe verpuffen. Die Angst die Tatsachen auszusprechen wie sie sind, um die Menschen nicht zu lähmen, hat in den letzten Jahrzehnten zu keinen Ergebnissen geführt.
Stellen wir klar, dass sich das Leben jetzt stark ändern muss, weil es sich sonst, einige Jahre später, noch deutlich stärker ins negative ändern wird.
5) Nutzen wir psychologische Bildung. Man stelle sich den Steinzeitmenschen und seine Sorgen vor: Hunger, Gefahr durch Raubtiere, Tot durch Krankheiten, die man nicht versteht. Wenn ein Steinzeitmensch von einem Paradies geträumt hat, dann sehe es wohl wie die Gegenwart der meisten Europäer aus: 
Das Wissen morgen, nächste Woche, nächsten Monat und die nächsten Jahre nicht verhungern zu müssen.
Sicherheit vor Raubtieren oder anderen physikalischen Gefahren, wie dem Wetter.
Gesundheitsversorgung und Heilung vieler Krankheiten.


Folgen Sie der Wissenschaft! Klimaneutral bis 2030!

Firstly, thank you for opening up the debate on this immensely important topic, and for aiming at faster emission reduction.
Sadly though, the targets you set are dangerously careless. 
Climate neutrality by 2050 isn't nearly sufficient. What we need, is to aim for net neutrality by 2025. We are steering towards tipping points that will make climate change irreversible and create an earth uninhabitable and hostile to us humans. This is scientific consensus. 
So please, continue listening to the science as you have been with the COVID-19 crisis.
As we are seeing now, rapid change is possible - and necessary. A greater risk of pandemics is only one among the many disastrous consequences of climate change and wildlife destruction.
The relief schemes to rebuild the EU economy after COVID-19 thus offer an amazing opportunity which may very well be the last one we have left:
Please, spend the money well and use it to support climate and ecologically friendly industries. They are the ones that we'll need in the future. The care and medical sector is among them.
Say goodbye to an economic model of growth. It's impossible to decouple growth from carbon emissions. Our current system is destroying the very resources we all need to survive. There are many wonderful alternatives. 
The majority of the people is desperate in the face of the climate crisis and longing for big, structural change. We all want to have a future on this planet. We will support radical measures. 
So please, please, be brave.

Dear Sirs and Madames,
As has already been stated several times here: 2050 is too late. We need to achieve this goal faster which IMHO can not happen without significant change in the way we live now.
Comparable change has happened before and can be absolutely positive. To achieve the necessary goals without sacrificing our comfort we need to address several factors i.e.:
Renewable energy.
UBI/BGE
Work/income
Housing
Transport 
Changes in the way we work and build things need to be made.
Recent studies have shown that 60% of the work done today is basically "useless". 
Several other studies exist, showing that we can live as comfortable as now with everybody working 20 hours or less, if we cut the overhead of having to sell and buy more, produce more.... 
If we produce what we really need and make it last, including the ability to make repairs or get updates for as long as possible, we can save resources, energy and time and sacrifice nothing. A simple example are SmartPhones, which are often high quality and could be used much longer if repairs were possible and updates available. 
I noticed the EU was also pushing for more norms in things like cables and connectors, which is also a great move in the right direction, thanks for this.

We need to go back to building things to last.
Making these changes will save resources, energy, reduce waste and free up the creativity we need for interesting new solutions. 
Of course this will cut the profits of companies, to buffer this we need an UBI for the people. If what we are doing today is not for the good of everybody, to make our lives easier and comfortable, why should we do it? It's the people who need to profit.
Companies will continue to make money, just not the obscene amount of today. Companies also consist of people and it should be good for them, too, but the current race needs to stop if we really want to reach the 2 degree goal. I can't impress strongly enough how important this is. 

Automation and digitalisation will not only help produce things with less human work necessary but will either help us here or destroy our way of living once millions of people are no longer able to find work.  This also will make an UBI a good solution to buffer the effect of and time while we make a chance and also help everybody to profit from the existing technology.
There are huge chances in this and we can save a lot of the energy and resources we now waste for a unnecessarily ruinous way of living. This will help us reaching our goals and the climate targets as set in Paris.
I do hope you will consider this basic thoughts, (of course it's not possible to fit it all into a relatively short comment) and find ways to include it in the decision process. 
Thank you.

Based on reading and analyzing the hundreds of documents and research reports and extensive discussions with dozens of scientists and NGOs worldwide, we have prepared the following advice;
• Immediately end subsidies on the burning of woody biomass.
• Only stimulate truly sustainable solutions and the development of energy generation.
• Make every effort to prevent deforestation.
• Increase the planting of new varied forests as soon as possible.
• Make every effort to reduce the emission of harmful substances.
• Limit the influence of the paid pro-biomass lobby on the EU, our governments and organizations of which we depend on advice for determining policy.

Oxfam appreciates the initiative to increase the EU’s headline greenhouse gas reduction target, as the current 2030 target is not even remotely consistent with the goal of the Paris Agreement to pursue efforts to keep warming at below 1.5°C, nor does the current target allow the EU to be a leader in global climate action – contrary to what EU citizens expect from their governments, as polls regularly show.

Yet, to become a true climate leader, the EU should consider increasing its target to a minimum of 65 per cent reductions by 2030. This would at least be in line with the aggregate global emission cuts needed for staying below 1.5°C (based on the UNEP Emissions Gap report 2019 which finds that global emissions must fall 55% below 2018 levels by 2030 for consistency with a 1.5C pathway). It would also be closer to what most equity frameworks would consider an EU fair share.

Hence, the impact assessment should also include assessment of a potential increase of the EU 2030 target to 65 per cent reductions.

In order to assess fairness in any EU enhanced 2030 target, the initiative should also assess the impact that possible target levels (e.g. 50, 55 or 65 per cent reductions) would have on increases of global average temperatures if the ambition implied in such an enhanced target was the benchmark by which other countries were to set their own climate targets in a fair effort sharing that is rooted in the UNFCCC’s principle of common but differentiated responsibilities and respective capabilities. Such an assessment could be oriented around the available wide range on literature on equity and fairness in sharing the global effort to keep warming below 1.5°C/2°C, e.g. as applied by the Climate Action Tracker initiative (https://climateactiontracker.org/methodology/comparability-of-effort/) and as used by the IPCC AR5 (chapter 6 of WG III) or assessed by Höhne et al. (2014, Regional GHG reduction targets based on effort sharing: a comparison of studies. Climate Policy, 14(1), 122–147).

In its measuring economic and social impacts, the initiative should avoid one-dimensional cost-benefit analyses but also look at effects on policy-triggered investor expectations or technological learning processes across the economy, next to impacts on key indicators such as reduced air pollution and associated healthcare costs, employment, investment rates across the EU etc. It should furthermore fully integrate in its impact assessment the benefits of avoided economic, social and cultural damages from climate change, both in the EU and world-wide, including negative impacts from increased instabilities negatively affecting Europe in an interconnected world, based on temperature scenarios that can reasonably be associated with the proposed increased EU 2030 target (e.g. as per the previous paragraph above).

It is vital that the initiative also assesses undesired negative impacts from implementing a new EU 2030 target, e.g. negative impacts on global food security directly or indirectly linked to the use of land-based bioenergy or land-based carbon removals; as well as negative global impacts linked to increased demand for natural resources needed for the energy transformation (e.g. for energy storage capacities) especially where these resources are extracted in conflict-ridden regions or with low environmental and social safeguards, also taking into account indirect effects across markets and sectors; the initiative should explore options to minimise/eliminate these potential negative consequences.

Sehr geehrte Damen und Herren,

die von ihnen gesteckten Ziele sind nicht im Geringsten mit einer Erderwärmung deutlich unter 2 Grad Celsius bis Ende des Jahrhunderts vereinbar. Ich denke ich muss hier nicht weiter ausführen, warum das so ist und was auf dem Spiel steht. Mit diesen unambitionierten Zielen gefährden Sie das gesamte Leben auf dem Planeten. Die EU muss alles dafür tun („whatever it takes“), um so schnell und viel wie möglich Treibhausgase einzusparen, um möglichst bis 2025 Klimaneutralität zu erreichen. 

Ich baue sehr darauf, dass Sie sich ihrer unermeßlichen Verantwortung für den Erhalt unseres Planeten bewusst sind und allles dafür tun werden, um unsere Lebensgrundlage zu erhalten.

Herzlichen Dank.

The plan of the European Commission to cut greenhouse gas emissions by 50 or 55% by 2030 is insufficient to meet the targets set out in the Paris Climate Agreement (limiting average global temperatur rise to 1.5° Celsius by 2100) and unfortunately an insult to people who intent to live on this planet post 2050. Not only do we risk irreversible large-scale damage to our environment that will hamper our ability to live a good life and have a striving economy in Europe. We will also harm those who have contributed the least to global heating.

My counter proposal is to reduce greenhouse gas emissions to net zero by 2025. The rationale for this timeline is the precautionary principle and global justice so that less developed countries have a longer time to adjust their economies. We cannot afford to wait too long as we might reach tipping points very soon that will lead to run-away climate change.

As reaching net zero greenhouse gas emissions by 2025 requires a massive transformation of our economy, I suggest to convene a Citizens' Assembly (modelled on the Citizens' Assembly in Ireland on constitutional reform) and come up with a legislative proposal based on the decisions of the Citizens' Assembly. This way we can strengthen European democracy and ensure to create an economy based upon the will of the people and restrict the destructive tendencies of the fossil fuel industry. I am convinced that the vast majority of European citizens will support far-reaching measures to curb greenhouse gas emissions when they are presented with the evidence and the likely consequences of our current emission path. That's why a Citizens' Assembly with real democratic power is such an effective and legitimate tool.

The DDA is pleased to submit a response regarding the EU 2030 Climate Target Plan. See attached our full response.

Data centers form the bedrock of the European economy and fore runners in the energy transition and the use of green energy. Concentration of IT in data centers results also in efficiency. Despite the enormous growth in data for the last 10 years, energy consumption has remained stable worldwide. 

With the response we would like to ask the Commission to consider to take in account this specific -vital- industries in nowadays society to make the transition as effective as possible, and to make and step up significant investment to green energy when deciding on the 2030 Climate Targets.

Bold ambition is needed as the future is sustainable and digital with Europe being the forerunner.

Leider sind Ihre Ziele nicht vereinbar mit dem 1.5 °C Ziel (noch mit der "deutlich unter 2°C" Formulierungen des Pariser Klimaabkommens). In dem dazugehörigen Bericht des IPPC wird eine Reduktion der Treibhausgasemissionen um ungefähr 45% gegenüber dem Jahr 2010 bis 2030 gefordert.

Auch im IPCC Sonderbericht über das 1.5°C Ziel sind nicht alle Risiken des Klimasystems enthalten. Das kommt aus der Struktur des IPCC, wo es darum geht den wissenschafltichen Konsens zu präsentieren. Tatsächlich ist die Lage bereits viel dramatischer (Waldbrände im Amazonas, tauende Permafrostböden ...). 

Dies alles sind viel zu geringe Ziele, da es um den Erhalt unserer Lebensgrundlagen geht! Wir müssen uns also höhere Ziele setzen und sofort so schnell wie möglich Treibhausgasemissionen reduzieren. Darum fordere ich, dass wir eine Reduktion der Treibhausgasemissionen auf Netto-Null bis 2025 für die wirtschaftsstarken EU Staaten (z. B. Deutschland) und bis mindestens 2030 für die wirtschaftsschwächeren EU Staaten
anstreben. Dabei sollen auch durch die EU verursachte Emissionen in anderen Staaten mit einbezogen werden.

Die Corona Krise muss hier als Chance genutzt werden.

Dear European Commission, 

all climate goals need to be in accordance with the Paris Agreement. 

If we don't manage to limit global warming to 1,5°C there will be immense consequences.

Reducing carbon emission by 50-55% by 2030 is clearly not in accordance with the Paris Agreement. 

Please act now, act in accordance with science and act bravely. 

The EU and the world are watching

Bioenergy Europe welcomes the Roadmap on the 2030 Climate Target Plan and supports the upcoming impact assessment guiding informed policy design on (i) how to increase the ambition in a manner that best contributes to sustainable and inclusive growth, (ii) ensuring that the EU has access to a secure, affordable and sustainable energy system and (iii) that negative emission technologies (including nature-based and technology-based solutions) are promptly scaled up. Considering the insufficient progress towards Paris objectives, the EU needs to lead by example. In this context, climate targets for 2030 must be increased to prepare the EU for the transition towards carbon neutrality by 2050, achieving a more gradual annual GHG emissions reduction path and acceptable distribution of efforts. Bioenergy Europe is supportive of an at least -55% GHG emissions reduction by 2030. With energy currently accounting for more than 75% of total emissions in the EU, increasing the share of renewables in the energy mix is crucial. A 50% renewable energy target would deliver the right message to the market, for investments to flow towards renewable technologies. Energy efficiency will also play a key role in the achievement of the 2050 targets: the renewable energy target and the energy efficiency one need to be mutually reinforcing. With variable renewables being increasingly part of the EU electricity mix, the demand for flexibility services will also increase. Bioenergy is a reliable companion to variable renewables and market-ready to deliver the flexibility necessary to the security of the grid. For this reason, power generation based on solid biomass and sustainable bioliquids must be considered a crucial component of the mix beyond 2030. While increasing electrification is a reality, this is not the univocal solution to an effective energy transition. The EU Green deal's success depends also on the decarbonization of the heating and cooling sector, representing half of EU energy consumption. In this segment, the share of renewable energy sources has been growing at a slower pace than in the power sector. RES represents only 20% of energy used in this sector, with 16.9% provided by bioenergy alone. Strengthening the current article 23 of Renewable Energy Directive, including a binding renewable heat target would trigger much-needed investments in this area.  Reaching half of the heating and cooling sector powered by renewables by 2030 would be possible and sustainable. To get to this objective, Bioenergy Europe believes that the renewable heat target produced by the Member States should be a binding one and increased to 3.1 pp annually. Alignment of the current Energy Taxation Directive with current climate goals should also be envisaged. Energy taxation should be based on energy content and on CO2 emissions, providing a common framework for CO2 pricing in the internal market. Such measures would help to decrease fossil fuel import dependency, promoting the development and consolidation of EU local supply chains of renewable sources. To minimize the social impact of increased tax rates for fossil fuels in the heating sector, potentially worsening energy poverty, it is essential to develop a policy framework supporting the modernization of heating stock in Europe.  Similarly, biofuels will be instrumental in the much-needed decarbonisation of transports.  Increased targets for 2030 will promote the use of renewable energy solutions which in the case of bioenergy are for the majority, locally produced. As stressed by IPCC and by the 2018 in-dept analysis supporting the Commission’s vision for a climate-neutral economy, achieving carbon neutrality will be possible only if the EU can increase its CO2 emissions absorption capacity over time. A clear path is needed to support negative emissions technologies development together with an increase of sustainable use of bio-based products and nature-based solutions.

The Southern Environmental Law Center appreciates the opportunity to comment on the EU Commission’s impact assessment on the 2030 climate target plan. Our response focuses on the need to properly account for woody bioenergy emissions as the EU moves forward with its 2030 climate target plan. Additionally, the current assessment must move beyond the existing framework to reflect the broader ambition of the European Green Deal to cut pollution, restore biodiversity, and create a healthy and just society for European citizens. All of these goals are undercut by the continued reliance and subsidization of woody biomass for electricity. 
EU climate policies, and the national policies and subsidies that stem from them, incorrectly categorize all bioenergy as carbon neutral at the point of combustion. But leading scientists have shown that burning trees for electricity is as bad for the climate as coal. Even EASAC warned about the serious mismatch between bioenergy science and policy in the RED.
Per unit of energy, biomass  plants emit more carbon from their smokestacks than coal, and any carbon “benefit” is hypothetical and occurs, if at all, decades to a century later—and then only if forests are allowed to regrow and are not converted to plantations or recut for energy. In recognition of this, in 2018, the UK set a substantially lower limit on fossil-fuel lifecycle CO2 emissions from biomass fuels in order to qualify for renewable energy subsidies, a limit that appears impossible for wood pellets to meet. And, in 2020, the UK proposed to exclude new coal-to-biomass conversions from future rounds of its Contracts for Difference scheme.
A 2018 EU Commission report also highlighted that energy scenarios with reduced bioenergy use and greater reliance on wind and solar resulted in the lower carbon emissions. Support for biomass is therefore incompatible with the EU’s plan to drastically reduce GHG emissions by 2030 and reach climate neutral by 2050. The EU’s climate policies must be strengthened to accurately reflect the full lifecycle emissions of bioenergy feedstocks, taking into account both direct and indirect land-use change impacts. 
Not only does burning biomass emit large amounts of carbon, but cutting down trees for that process simultaneously reduces the ability of forests to sequester more carbon. Although the EU’s forests are a net sink of CO2, the forests’ capacity to remove carbon from the atmosphere has been significantly declining since 2015 and this trend is set to continue. The EU must focus on increasing natural sinks, by protecting and restoring natural forests and avoiding the additional pressures on these ecosystems from bioenergy demand.  
The EU incentives for woody biomass also undermine the EU’s broader efforts to protect biodiversity and the EU’s “do no harm” principle. A 2016 EU Commission report recognized the “direct negative ecological consequences” of much of the bioenergy sourcing occurring in the southeastern US. This sourcing has been shown to include clearcutting of highly biodiverse forests and the use of large-diameter whole trees. Biodiversity loss and climate change are inextricably linked. The EU must therefore consider what impacts its climate policies will have on global biodiversity and should set specific criteria on how to minimize and reverse biodiversity loss as a key component of climate adaptation and mitigation.  
Unfortunately, the 2018 REDII failed to introduce meaningful restrictions or safeguards for bioenergy. Continued support for bioenergy can no longer be justified on climate or environmental grounds. The EU’s must re-evaluate REDII’s continuing reliance on bioenergy in light of the climate, biodiversity, and other environmental harms from large-scale bioenergy use. The EU must end subsidization of this industry and focus instead on truly clean and renewable energy sources like wind and solar, as well as the protection and restoration of forests and other natural carbon sinks.

I am writing with respect to the proposed use of wood as a ‘zero carbon’ renewable energy source. It is simply not true, as many studies have shown and others have commented.
 I especially deplore industrial forestry using fast-growing species from areas such as the southern USA or countries such as Romania, Hungary and Slovakia, because of the negative impact on biodiversity and soil use in those places.
At this time, I specifically wish to address the importation of wood chips from eastern Canada: Nova Scotia. 
I am a lifelong resident of rural Nova Scotia and at the age of 79 have 5 generations of  local knowledge behind me. Nova Scotia was settled by the French in the 1600’s and subsequently the English took over: it is among the longest-colonized, and most destroyed,  parts of North America. The forests that the Native folks depended on were cleared, for dwellings, to grow crops, and for timber for European warships and trading ships. Soil cover over bedrock is scant over most of the province: the last glaciation pushed most of the soil into the Atlantic, forming the Scotian shelf. The remaining soil does not, and cannot, support successions of whole tree harvesting. It should support a diverse Acadian forest of many species; it is now showing large patches of bedrock; forest fires burn down into the remaining soils, and biodiversity is desperately limited. 
The indiscriminate removal of whole trees, as well as the slash from more responsible logging which should remain for fertility and cover, continues partly because the European Union has created a ‘market’.
 What is ‘zero carbon’ about uprooting every scrap of wood fibre from a forest, trucking it many kilometres to a facility that uses oil to chip it into tiny pieces, more oil to dry it, more oil to move it to a port and more oil to take it across an ocean to a giant plant to burn for energy?
This ridiculously wasteful equation holds just as true for the ‘forests’ of the Carolinas, and of the Eastern European countries.
Sadly it seems only the economically depressed areas that have this rape and pillage foisted on them in the name of ‘sustainable’ energy.
I am asking the EU to instead spend billions of euros on solar arrays, geo-thermal installations, wind-farms, and retro-fitting of buildings, all before it burns any more wood. 
I am asking the EU to put priority and incentives into protecting and restoring natural forests everywhere they exist, and returning upland cleared areas to forest -- which will also reduce flood damage as rainfalls increase.
If these policies are implemented and funded, I hope that my children and grandchildren can continue to travel in a restored Europe. Otherwise I have no intention of bringing my tourist dollars to the EU’s cities any longer.

Die Klimaziele der EU erfahren begründet eine große Zustimmung. Es steht außer Zweifel, dass eine Begrenzung des Temperaturanstieges und Klimastabilität ein Ziel für Wirtschaft und Gesellschaft sein muss, nicht nur in der EU. Eine wachsende Weltbevölkerung bei steigendem Wohlstandsanspruch führt parallel zu Emissionswachstum in anderen Regionen der Welt. Sofern die EU nicht nur für sich selbst die beschriebene Klimaneutralität erreichen will, muss dies gelingen, indem Wohlstand und Versorgungssicherheit auf hohem Niveau bewahrt werden - bei einem gleichzeitig attraktiven Preisgefüge. Erst die Kombination von hoher Sicherheit und Verfügbarkeit von Energie bei gleichzeitg attraktiven Prodduktions- und Nutzungskosten werden andere Regionen motivieren, ebenfalls den Weg zur Klimaneutralität einzuschlagen. Die Bemühungen der Bürger und der Gesellschaften in der EU wären andernfalls zwecklos.

Als Verband, dem überwiegend kleine und mittlere Unternehme nangeschlossen sind, appellieren wir an die Kommission, dabei die Machbarkeit der Umsetzung nicht aus dem Auge zu verlieren. Der kontinentale Transport empfindlicher Güter ist auf mittleren Strecken nur mit dem Fahrzeug zu bewältigen. Transporte mit der Bahn finden immer dann statt, wenn entsprechende Anschlussanlagen und Kapazitäten nutzbar und die Laufzeiten planbar sind. Vor- und Nachlauf müssen jedoch immer noch mit dem Fahrzeug, derzeit mit dem Kraftfahrzeug, erfolgen.

Die Unternehmen würden sich unmittelbar von der Nutzung konventionell mit fossilen Kraftstoffen betriebener Fahrzeuge lösen, sofern adäquate alternative Antriebe incl. der Möglichkeit zur Betankung / Beladung zur Verfügung stehen. Die Verbände der transportierenden Wirtschaft haben dies in der Vergangenheit immer wieder deutlich gemacht. Allerdings müssen alternative Antriebe zunächst verfügbar, zuverlässig und dauerhaft und letztendlich auch kostenmäßg vertretbar sein. Dies betrifft sowohl die "Hardware" als auch die Antriebsstoffe.

Eine sektorale Umsetzung der Reduktionsziele erscheint unter den aktuellen technischen Möglichkeiten für die Nutzer aus der transportierenden Wirtschaft nicht realistisch. Soll der Sektor "Transport" die Emissionen in dem von der EU geforderten Maßstab reduzieren, müssen entweder die Transportmengen in dem hochgradig arbeitsteiligen Europa massiv reduziert werden, oder emissionsarme, besser noch emissionsfreie, Transportmittel müssen zur Verfügung stehen. 

Dabei darf nicht der gleiche Fehler gemacht werden, wie bei der Einführung der Quote für Biokraftstoffe. Es war bereits damals absehbar, dass es zu einer Konkurrenz der Nahrungsmittelproduktion mit der Produktion für die Kraftstofferzeigung, incl. der problematischen Flächennutzung kommen wird. Insofern gilt es diesesmal perspektivisch eine Folgenabschätzung nicht nur des "Nichtstun", sondern auch des geplanten Weges zu berücksichtigen. 

Elektrisch angetriebene Fahrzeuge erfüllen diesen Anspruch heute nicht. Neben unverhältnismäßig hohen Kosten ist auch die Einsetzbarkeit nicht in dem erforderlichen Maß gegeben. Es ist auch zu berücksichtigen, dass die Stromerzeugung für Fahrzeuge in Konkurrenz tritt zur Stromerzeugung für dne Verbrauich in den privaten Haushalten und für die produzierende Wirtschaft. 

Schnell erreichbare Emissions-Reduktionspotenziale dürften in der Realisierung optimaler Fahrzeugnutzung liegen. Dazu gehört die Vermeidung von Staus, Leerlaufstrecken, nicht optimaler Rollwiderstände, sowie die Optimierung von Maßen und Gewichten unter Beachtung bautechnischer Restriktionen.

Ein gewisses Maß an Ressourceneffizienz dürfte auch in der Gestaltung optimaler Wege liegen. Eine Förderung der Techniken hierzu sollte nicht vergessen werden.

Ein "Change der Transportwirtschaft" wird nur gelingen, wenn er für die Transportwirtschaft finanzierbar ist. Sonst wären die Bürger und die Wirtschaft im Jahr 2050 womöglich immobil.

Please consider rethinking this plan as soon as possible: It is simply not ambitious enough. I understand, it's better than nothing - but as soon as it passes, please start working on revising this to give us a realistic chance of avoiding 1.5 degree warming, given the latest scientific findings.

The current corona crisis has changed everything, and we should use this second chance to finally put us on an audacious trajectory to have a realistic chance of avoiding "runaway" climate change and reversing the destruction of biodiversity.

Key to this is to stop telling ourselves that we can decouple growth from ecological degradation. There's no historical precedent for this, and we need to change this paradigm into one that realizes that the economy exists within the planet’s ecosystem, so there’s a physical limit to how big we can grow. Environmental economists have been raising this issue for years, perhaps refer to Tim Jackson's "Prosperity Without Growth", Herman Daly's concept of a steady-state economy, or more recently Kate Raworth's "Doughnut Economics".  Maybe growth was useful to get us here, but now we need a different paradigm.

Of course, it's imperative to protect the weakest members of society through such a shift, and this environmental shift needs to coincide with re-strengthening our social support, safety nets, and creating massive amounts of public goods.

First: Burning Biomass like wood is NOT Zero Emissions! 
- It may be counted zero in national statistics, because, in the case of wood, it is compared to net emissions from forest and therefore at a national level, net emissions would be counted for in the LULUCF sector of each country. But like in the case of biofuels, the burning of those are counted as emissions, even if lower than those of fossil fuels. Although also Sugarcane, Rapeseed and other biofuel plants have uptaken the carbon from the atmosphere before.  

Second: Forests shall also to be treated like "young fossil" carbon deposits.
- They store carbon for over hundred or more years. Although it is claimed, that burning firewood is "carbon neutral" because the carbon has been uptaken before - this is also the case for any fossil fuel. Only the time span is much bigger, but: in the case of climate change, this is an urgend task! Looking at the target 2030 or even at a "neutrality" target 2050, no tree can absorb the same amount of carbon, which has been released by the tree standing there before, within this extremely short period.

Third: Even so, burning wood as a limited resource is always an energy consumption and GHG emission.
- Acknowledging, that even "renewable" resources are limited and carbon release allowance is much more limited, we should avoid burning wood wherever we can. Material wood use is more efficient and in many cases does cause much less damage for the atmosphere, burning wood which otherwise could be used to replace more energy-intensive materials, is avoiding such better use and has negative impacts.

Fourth: For the coming decades, growing wood depots in forests are one important tool to store huge amounts of Greenhouse Gases. 
- Restoration of degraded areas, leaving forests to reach more mature stages, and preserving as many old growth forests as possible (or leaving degrared forests to become "old growth stands") are the most important means to contribute to the goals of carbon neutrality. Forest owners could be given support in order to reduce logging levels, if that really contributes to higher timber stocks for a long period. 

Fifth: Promoting more wood being used for energy production, poses all types of forests at risk.
- We already have seen many, even hundreds of cases where forests are heavily used for firewood production. With the support of EU Commissions targets, eliminating protected forests (e.g. in Romania), or overlogging forests in many other Member States, will  become even more profitable. We should also respect other countries´ domestic needs for healthy forest ecosystems and timber use, instead of promoting even more imports of biomass (e.g. from USA).

Sixth: Saving old forests is also supporting other important (EU-) policy goals: Local Climate, Biodiversity, Soil protection and others.
- More biomass and deadwood in forests are supporting their capabilities to resist climate change. Deadwood does not only contribute to healthy soils, but also stores much water, cooling down local forest climate. Biodiversity is a crucial means to maintain important forest functions and their resilience.

Seventh: Supporting more initiatives to reduce emissions of timber industries.
- Within timber use, it should be made public how many emissions per ton of product are caused during the whole processing chain. Especially pulp and paper, but also for other highly processed wood products, there should be a label which shows the energy intensity of the product. The aim is, to avoid or to reduce the production of short living and single use wood products (firewood, paper, packaging woods), and promoting the production of long living products like in construction or furniture. This would contribute to achieve a significant reduction of GHG emissions within the timber/wood sector. As an example: The production of one ton of celulose results in the same amount of GHG emissions, than the production of one ton of steel!

Thank you!

Thank you for permitting non-members to comment on the EU environmental regulations. The climate change problem is not one that respects borders. In parts of Canada, the temperature has already risen by an average 2.3 degrees Celsius and there have been massive forest fires. These events highlight both the emergency that we face and the importance of global forests in the climate change equation. 

Like many of the other commenters in this forum, I want to call attention to the unscientific and mistaken view that the use of wood products as fuel (e.g., biomass fueled electric power generation) is carbon neutral, and hence can be counted as a sustainable alternative to fossil fuels. It is true that, unlike coal, for example, forests do (under some conditions!) regrow, and hence, are a “renewable” resource. This does make some forestry practices sustainable. For example, the carbon in the lumber used in building houses is preserved within these structures for a significant length of time. 

However, forest products that are burned release their carbon into the air. They are harvested from forests that cannot “renew” their ability within the time that we have to stabilize the climate and avoid catastrophe. Even with the proposed changes to the EU regulations aimed at carbon reduction, biofuel (generally the burning of wood) is still classified as a net zero carbon source of energy.  EU countries are thus encouraged to substitute biofuels for fossil fuels, to subsidize biomass energy production, and to trade carbon credits in a way that allows for increased GHG production overall.

The research shows just how counterproductive the “zero carbon” status of biofuels is in the fight against climate change (references available on request). Here are a few of the main points:
•	Because biofuel is burned green, its carbon footprint per unit of power is worse than coal, the worst of the fossil fuels.
•	Whereas, of course, coal does not sequester carbon, trees do; so incentivizing the destruction of forests is doubly counterproductive. Studies show that EU countries as a whole have significantly degraded their forest’s ability to sequester carbon in the last decade. 
•	Harvesting trees has resulted in significant loss of biodiversity when more diverse natural forests are replaced (if they are replanted) by monocultures.
•	The heavy equipment used in biomass harvesting generally disturbs the forest soil (which contains several times more carbon than the forest itself) so that this becomes a significant additional source of atmospheric carbon.   

With its Green New Deal, the EU is positioning itself to be a global model in the fight against climate change. The idea that the forests are a resource that can be exploited in the battle to reduce planetary warming is one of the most damaging myths that exists today. We know that North America has a long way to go to catch up with the progress on GHG regulation that has been made in Europe. We need your help in setting targets that can make a difference.   

Dr. Nathan Brett (La Pêche Coalition for a Green New Deal)

The European woodworking industry is fully behind the objectives of the European Green Deal. This is clearly displayed in the Forest-based Industries 2050 Vision, in which the forest-based value chains commit to climate neutrality, circular bioeconomy, resource efficiency, economic growth and employment creation, and lay out pathways to reach those goals.

Therefore, we welcome the fact that the European Commission will assess, among other things, “how the EU can increase the absorptions of CO2 emissions over time, including in its natural sinks and the role of biomass-based products and nature based solutions” within a 2030 horizon. To this aim, CEI-Bois would like to put forward some remarks:

• The full climate mitigation potential of the forest sector is best achieved by taking into account both the action of forests and harvested wood products as a carbon sink and carbon stock, and the substitution effect of wood products. While anthropogenic emissions and removals in the forest are captured in the LULUCF accounting framework, it is more difficult to visualise the mitigation effect of forest-based substitution of fossil materials. This makes it complex to assess the climate benefit of circular bioeconomy in an integrated way and its “enabling” potential, as defined in the Taxonomy Expert Group Final report (Annex I, p.42). Such potential should be explicitly recognised in the relevant sectors, such as construction.

• Timber buildings are key allies in climate change mitigation strategies. The average impact of building with 1 ton of wood instead of 1 ton of concrete could lead to an average reduction of 2.1 tons of carbon dioxide emissions over the complete life cycle of the product (including use and disposal), as recognised in the 2018 EU Bioeconomy Strategy. According to a recent EFI briefing1, increasing the market share of wood construction from current level to 20% could lead to 100 Mt CO2 savings in Europe. The Impact Assessment should therefore evaluate the potential contribution of wood products in the construction sector at EU level, using embodied carbon metrics.

• Forest sinks should not be seen as a way to offset fossil emissions from other sectors. Leaving fossil materials into the ground is a guaranteed way to prevent CO2 emissions. In fact, ageing forests are vulnerable to climate change themselves, and active forest management is needed to prevent the ever-increasing damages caused by fires, storms, pests and other disturbances.

• Finally, the economic and social impact of climate policies should be carefully assessed when evaluating the role of forests and forest-based sector towards the 2030 climate goals, and especially in the light of the economic shock caused by the current Covid-19 sanitary crisis. Today the forest-based sector represents around 420.000 enterprises for a total turnover of over 520 billion euros and around 3,5 million workers; the woodworking industry alone includes 170.000 companies and employs 1 million workers. Recovery plans in Europe should conjugate the fight against climate change with safeguards to employment and competitiveness of businesses.

Dogwood Alliance appreciates the opportunity to input into the EU Commission’s impact assessment on the 2030 climate target plan. Our response centers on making sure that 2030 EU climate protection measures deliver the best possible outcomes for climate, impacted communities, and nature, whilst ensuring cost-effectiveness. We focus our submission on the role that wood pellet biomass plays in the current mix of subsidized renewable energy.

The EU’s climate policies must be strengthened to accurately reflect the full lifecycle emissions of bioenergy feedstocks, taking into account both direct and indirect land-use change impacts. Currently, subsidies going towards the burning of wood for energy are perversely creating reliance on bioenergy imports from our region of focus, the Southeastern United States. Chatham House, EASAC, the Southern Environmental Law Center, and Natural Resources Defense Council, among others, have all confirmed that burning wood for energy does not provide carbon benefits compared to fossil fuels and is degrading highly biodiverse natural forests.

In the Southern U.S., communities have been negatively impacted by the wood pellet industry, primarily through increased noise and dust pollution, threats to clean drinking water and health impacts from the release of particulate matter, such as asthma and allergies. Attorneys for Environmental Integrity Project have found that wood pellet mills systematically violate the Clean Air Act’s major source permitting requirements by failing to install the best available control technology. Numerous facilities emit VOCs well above the major source threshold but have not installed any controls to reduce VOC emissions, despite the Act’s clear mandate to do so.

Dating back to 2013, various mainstream media outlets have investigated and documented the changes brought about by increased demand from the EU for wood pellets. Loggers from the Southeast U.S. interviewed for a Washington Post article stated that the demand for wood to supply Enviva wood pellet mills was so high that “you can justify shovel-logging again [clear felling using roads of felled lumber in the swamp],” and that Enviva was “paying for some swamp logging.” 

Demand for wood pellet biomass is placing pressure on one of the most heavily disturbed forest landscapes in the world, according to Dr. Matthew Hansen’s Global Forest Change work at the University of Maryland. Over a decade, roughly one-third of the tree cover is either re-growing or cleared. Due to disturbance, the forest is on average younger and therefore holds less mass and carbon stock. Global Forest Watch animations from satellite images centered at Ahoskie, North Carolina, home to one of the biggest pellet plants in the United States display forest loss increasing relative to forest gain. This represents the turning of the landscape into a tree farm, driven by biomass demand. 

Additionally, the European Commission’s 2016 report on the environmental impacts of relying on biomass from the Southeast U.S. recognized the “direct negative ecological consequences” of increased harvesting of upland hardwood forests and the potential conversion of these forests to pine plantations.
 
Unfortunately, the 2018 Renewable Energy Directive (RED) recast failed to introduce meaningful restrictions or safeguards for bioenergy. Continued state-support of this form of energy can no longer be justified on climate or environmental grounds. It is more important than ever that the EU’s climate mitigation pathway to 2030 puts an end to squandering billions of euros on supporting the burning of wood for energy and instead redirects this financial support toward genuinely zero-emitting and renewable energy sources like solar and wind. We need climate policies that put forests, communities, and addressing climate change first.

EU Renewable Energy Directives (RED) intended to reduce GHG emissions have classified the burning of biomass for energy as “zero carbon.” This is erroneous and has had severe impacts on the biodiversity and carbon sink capacity of forests in Europe and North America. Far from being zero carbon, wood-fired electricity and heating-units using green wood chips for fuel emit more CO2 per unit of energy output than fossil-fired units. For example, in 2016 at the Drax Power Plant in the UK, burning coal produced 873 kilotons (kt) of CO2 per terawatt hour of electricity (TWH). Burning biomass produced 902 kt CO2 per TWH. 

Current regulations have led to perverse subsidies such that the Drax plant in the UK received, in 2019, £861.5 million (£2.36 million per day). The EU must end the “green” classification of biomass for energy that gave rise to such subsidies. Without subsidies it is unlikely plants burning biomass for energy would be economically feasible, especially as the cost of truly renewable energy continues to drop. 

Under current RED, though, solid and gaseous biomass, particularly wood and wood-waste, is the biggest source of renewable energy in the EU. It is used for the production of electricity, heating and cooling. In 2019 the Drax power station burned 7.05 million tonnes of wood pellets. 65% of those wood pellets came from the USA. 

Not only does burning biomass emit significant GHGs at the smokestack, the harvesting of wood for biomass is devastating forests on both sides of the Atlantic. In the name of supposedly “green” energy, this is damaging our carbon sinks when we need them the most. Unlike other forms of carbon capture, forests are a proven, low cost, high benefit “technology.”  They are sequestering carbon right now. They are also havens for biodiversity.  In addition, more carbon is stored in the top metre of soil in a natural forest than is contained in all the woody material above ground. When sunlight hits that newly exposed forest floor, the soil releases most of the carbon it has been storing. 

Biomass is not a “zero carbon” or “green” fuel.  Please, in the interest of the wellbeing of the natural world and all its inhabitants, change the Renewable Energy Directives to reflect this reality.

Answer to the inception impact assessment (roadmap) on the 2030 Climate Target Plan.

IMA-Europe manifests his willingness to contribute to the debate on the intermediate targets enabling to achieve climate neutrality by 2050.

IMA-Europe supports the EC proposal for the 2030 Climate Target Plan under the first European Climate Law. This legislation will set the intermediate pathway to achieve the 2050 climate neutrality target and ensure that once the 2030 goal is implemented in the European Climate Law, no step back is taken to undermine the credibility of the climate objective. IMA-Europe recognises the importance of the current discussion and wishes to participate actively as a notorious contributor.

OUR CALLS

A robust Impact assessment is necessary to evaluate the impact of the new climate target. The current European climate policy is based on a GHGs reduction target of 40% (compared with 1990 levels) by 2030. The EC  shall undertake a detailed and robust analysis of impact assessment and cost benefit analysis on EU industry competitiveness if an increase of this target to 50% or even up to 55% GHGs by 2030 is considered necessary to achieve climate neutrality by 2050 .The analysis should demonstrate that the EU industry remains competitive in the global context.

The 2030 Climate Target Plan must ensure carbon leakage protection for exposed sectors. An increased level of ambition on the GHG emission target reduction shall be accompanied by a similar increased level of industry protection. The increase of the target (if any) must be realistic and based on empirical cost-benefit analysis. As far as the risk of carbon leakage is still present, additional measures on top of the current system shall be set in parallel to address the issues. The European Commission, while leading by example, should encourage other countries to introduce similar GHG mitigation measures. 

The 2030 Climate Target Plan must recognise the potential impact of increasing climate ambition. It is imperative to highlight the consequences that increasing the GHGs target could trigger on different policy regulations such as EU ETS, ETD, RED II, IED, etc. Potential trade-offs on biodiversity loss and energy efficiency shall also take special consideration. Thus policy coherence should be assessed ex-ante. 

The 2030 Climate Target Plan must be an enabler for technological development for carbon removal. It is also essential to consider the non-linear trajectory of innovation. The challenge of transformation to deliver on climate objectives for the mineral sector requires significant investments in modernisation and innovation. We call the EC to strengthen the support of these instruments to enable decarbonisation.

In line with the Green Deal, Europe aims to become climate-neutral by 2050 and plans to increase its target for 2030 to ensure a smooth transition. However, according to the 2020 UN Report,  European society is facing pressing challenges regarding both water quantity and quality with direct impact on the whole society, particularly in the provision of safe, secured and sustainable energy. Climate neutrality measures taken without considering the effects on the availability and use of water resources run the risk of intensifying water crises, ultimately defeating their purpose. Climate neutrality goals and attention to water resources can however be developed in a mutually reinforcing way by achieving a Water Smart Society. The Water Europe Vision offers sensible solutions for an systemic (or intergrated) development of these two agendas:
 
•	Recognize and fully exploit the true value of water for the development of a circular water economy to improve water and energy efficiency. 
 
•	Exploit the value in water through the extraction and valorisation of energy and nutrients embedded in used water streams, it would offer new sources of energy in line with the zero-pollution strategy and increase the flexibility for the sector to provide safe, secure and sustainable energy.
 
•	Deploy digital solutions to monitor and prevent wastes, as well as improve the management capabilities – and therefore the resilience – of Europe’s ageing water infrastructure, preventing system failures.
 
•	Invest in water-related nature-based solutions to protect powerplants and cooling systems. They limit the impacts of climate change events such as droughts and floods, especially if they are implemented in synergy with environmental measures such as the Biodiversity Strategy 2030. 
 
•	Encourage Water-oriented Living Labs to apply all the measures above. These Labs are the right testbeds for all kinds of new solutions, implementing at the same time technological and non-technological innovations, energy-efficiency measures and renewable energy sources. They are a powerful tool to also scale up all these developments from idea to market at a national or regional level and achieve the 2030 and 2050 targets.
 
Through the Just Transition Fund, industrial and energy intensive regional efforts to create a Water Smart Society can be supported, thus forming a basis and a model for an Energy Smart Society. A number of accompanying reforms to help mobilize low-carbon finance and investment must be considered, especially through the EU’s Action Plan on Financing Sustainable Growth and the European Green Deal Investment Plan.

Water Europe (WE) is the voice and promotor of water-related innovation and RTD in Europe. WE is a membership-based multi-stakeholder organisation representing over 200 members from academia, technology providers, water users, water service providers, civil society, and public authorities. WE activities and positions are guided by its Water Vision “The Value of Water: Towards a Future-Proof European Water-Smart Society”.

Comment to the EU on burning biomass for energy 2020-04-09

I am writing from Nova Scotia Canada to provide essential information about unintended consequences of this proposal on forests in North America. 

When a forest is clearcut (or nearly clearcut), while trees may in time regrow and begin to sequester carbon again, they will take a minimum of ten years to do so in any significant way, and far longer to fully replace the carbon sink capacity of the forest that was removed. Further, forests are under increased stress due to warming temperatures, drought, wildfire and insect infestations - so protecting healthy forests should be a priority. In addition, more carbon is stored in the top metre of soil in a natural forest than is contained in all the woody material above ground. When sunlight hits that newly exposed forest floor, the soil releases most of the carbon it has been storing. The only forestry we should be practicing in a climate and biodiversity emergency is closed canopy, ecological forestry. This kind of forestry would not, could not and should not produce the quantity of wood currently required by plants burning pellets for the generation or co-generation of electricity.

Unfortunately, governments in North America, and in my province of Nova Scotia Canada in particular, have no policies promoting ecological forestry and practice clearcutting (and near clearcutting) of crown (public) forests and private woodlots. Our government is in search of export markets and it would continue clearcutting of our forests to export pellets to the EU. Thus, sound policy in the EU should consider the impact of biomass burning on the overall availability of healthy forests and the ability of those forests to sequester carbon. Only by considering the full impact of policy choices can the EU lead the world to a sustainable future.

Thank you very much for considering this comment.

THE IMPORTANCE OF TRANSPORT

Transport (including international aviation and shipping) is already the largest GHG emitter in the EU. Additionally, it is the only sector to have increased its emissions since 1990. Whatever target is agreed upon for 2030 would require a rapid and steep change in the emissions from the sector.

A T&E paper (attached to this consultation) has shown how transport can reduce its emissions to contribute to an overall target of -55%. Given the remaining carbon budgets and the Paris Agreement, -55% reduction is considered the very minimum. 

In order to meet the goals of the Paris Agreement, and to meet that agreement’s requirement for targets to be economy-wide, the 2030 target should make explicit that it includes emissions from both domestic and international aviation and shipping. 

Inclusion can be facilitated, in the case of shipping, through the use of Regulation 2015/757, known as Monitoring, Reporting and Verification (MRV) Regulation. This regulation provides the most accurate emissions data from shipping related to the EU, which is an independent third-party verified and certified.

For aviation, this can be facilitated through the inclusion of all kerosene sales within the EU, which are currently reported to the UNFCCC, which act as a proxy for emissions from all flights departing from the EU.

IMPROVING THE MODELLING WORK
