Gas Distributors for Sustainability (GD4S) comprises the leading natural gas distributors in France, Italy, Ireland, Spain, Portugal and Romania. Together, we represent 27.4m customers in Europe. GD4S welcomes this opportunity to provide feedback on the inception impact assessment of the 2030 Climate Target Plan. Overall, we support the Plan as part of the European Green Deal. 

Having reviewed the inception impact assessment, we make the following observations: 

We agree that raising the climate ambition between 2020 and 2030 is necessary to meet the objective of a net zero continent in 2050. Therefore, the renewable energy objectives in the renewable energy directive (RED II) and the energy efficiency objectives in the energy efficiency directive (EED) will need to be increased. As representative of the gas distribution sector, we would like to underline how our companies can help in meeting enhanced targets. 

A renewable gas target should be fixed at the EU level and adapted at national levels considering national features. This target, based on the injection of renewable gas into the grid will not only be useful to decarbonise the network, but also to better maximise production volumes and optimise end use. National Energy and Climate Plans should be aligned and based on a coherent approach. Those plans should provide the Commission with a view on renewable gas development in each of the EU Member States and how it will contribute to the objective of climate neutrality.  

We strongly agree with the Commission that the 2030 Climate Target Plan must “increase the ambition in a manner that best contributes to sustainable and inclusive growth, enhances economic competitiveness through accelerating innovation and modernising Europe’s enterprises”. Gas and renewable gas technologies fit this objective. Electrolysers and hybrid heat pumps can be easily produced in Europe and therefore be a vector of Europe’s competitiveness in the world. These technologies are participating to the coupling of gas and electricity sectors and will therefore reduce the need for additional infrastructures (reinforcement of electricity grid, electricity peak management technologies), which will be beneficial to energy affordability and security. 

We strongly agree with the Commission that “all sectors of the economy and society will need to contribute” to raising the targets. The gas sector has the advantage to reach different sectors. Biomethane can be injected in the grid easily and this renewable energy reduces agriculture and urban waste. It provides a substitute to chemical fertilizers – through digestate it co-produces – and brings additional revenues to farmers, consequently supporting rural areas. The use of sequential cropping in the process increases carbon capture in soils, while preserving land for food production. These biomass-based products play the role of natural sinks. Biomethane can also be used as a fuel to decarbonise mobility. BioNGV offers strong CO2 emissions reduction over its lifecycle. To consider this contribution in the Regulations setting CO2 standards for light-duty and heavy-duty vehicles, we urge for the adaptation of the lifecycle methodology at EU level to account for CO2 reduction emissions.    

GD4S remains at your disposal to further discussed the above points (contact@gd4s.eu).

Latvian Peat Association unites Latvian peat producers and entrepreneurs whose activities are related to the peat sector. On average, 1800 workers are employed in peat extraction, increasing to 2500 during the season. Jobs are in regions. LPA would like to express some concerns regarding proposed Climate Target Plan 2030. 
1)The planned revising and updating of climate policies and regulatory documents (many of them are quite new!) will create an unnecessary administrative burden both the European commission and the member states. For example, the LULUCF regulation 2018/841 is recently adopted and MS already have difficulties with its implementation. First let's look at how it works for a few years. 
2) Climate change should be mitigated, but economic aspects should also be taken into account. If too strict climate policy stops peat production in Europe, it will move to Russia. There will be much lower environmental requirements and for climate this can be worse than responsible extraction in EU countries. Peat and peat products are basis for food production and for growing of forest and decorative plants. 70% of growing media (substrates) used worldwide are peat based. Population of Planet is growing very fast and need for different growing media will grow in next 30 years for 415%. 
3) EU legislation should be based on correct (true) information which corresponds to real situation in the MS, EU and world. The emissions accounting methodology advised by IPCC should be significantly improved in order to correspond to local conditions especially regarding wetlands and peat extraction. In the IPCC Guidelines for National GHG Inventories (Wetlands) the default coefficients of GHG inventory guidelines are about two times higher than the actual emissions. For peat is used an instantaneous oxidation method, but it does not correspond to real situation. Extracted peat is used for horticulture (in Latvia 93%, in EU 37% y.2017, y.2019 more than 50% already, it’s increasing year by year), but in IPCC guidelines all peat is treated as energy peat. Use for horticulture means C sequestration by growing plants. EC should focus on improving IPPC methodology of GHG inventory, at least in LULUCF sector, and obtaining more accurate data and only then come with new initiatives.  
4) In the statistics about goods external sales, in accordance with the Combined nomenclature, Peat is classified as an energy product and is mentioned next to coal products: “Section 27. Mineral fuel, mineral oils and their distilled products; bitumen substances: mineral waxes”, code 2703. There is no other place for peat and peat products (substrates) in CN. For peat and peat product exporting companies, this is the only place to account for this export. Therefore, the EU statistics creates a completely incorrect conception about peat usage. Peat and peat substrates are exported only for use in agriculture and forestry. The peat extracted in Latvia is one third or 31% of the peat used in professional horticulture in the European Union. Unlike peat use for energy peat use for horticulture provides GHG sequestration. The risk that EC makes legislation using incorrect data is very high.   
6) Some MS and industries already made big changes, so, GHG emission reductions have already been made. If the agreed EU level targets 2030 will be revised, the Member States contributions made so far must be taken into account.

I am saddened that you are still not serious enough in your handling of the climate crisis. These proposed goals are not enough to stay below 1,5 degrees celsius or the goal of the Paris Climate Convention. As a young person I am very afraid of the future that lies ahead, if we continue down this path of valueing profits and short term economic growth more than the health of the planet. Still I know that living in Europe I will be in a very privileged  position, while the people in the global south will suffer the full extent of our recklessness today. 

These are all far too few goals, since the aim is to preserve our livelihoods! We must therefore set ourselves higher targets and immediately reduce greenhouse gas emissions as quickly as possible. That is why I call for a reduction in greenhouse gas emissions to net zero by 2025 for the economically strong EU countries and by at least 2030 for the economically weaker EU countries. BASF supports the Paris Agreement and sees climate protection as a key priority. We will do our share to support the European Union’s target of climate neutrality in 2050. Both for our products as for our production, innovation is our key asset to realize the transition towards a climate-neutral and circular economy. We strive for further substantial CO2 savings in our production processes by developing completely new technologies (e.g. Carbon Management program, ChemCycling project). 

In view of the challenging economic situation and outlook, sustainable recovery of the European economy and society depends on ensuring a competitive industry and working towards a long-term climate protection vision. The immediate priority is to get ‘back on track’, i.e. to protect the European assets, technologies and critical infrastructures provided by companies such as BASF. It is crucial that the current crisis does not diminish the ability to drive the required investments. BASF’s planned capital investments include renewable electricity integration and pilot plants to enable large-scale application of new technologies from 2030 onward. The 2030 target plan should therefore be tested for feasibility in this new context. 

The technological upgrades needed for a higher EU GHG target require the right enabling conditions. Key to improving industry’s transformation capabilities is its global competitiveness. This requires reinforced carbon leakage protection, support for first industrial deployment of new technologies, a significant increase of RES capacities and an improved regulatory framework. BASF considers the following aspects key for the 2030 target assessment:

1.	Global climate context. This includes assessing i) the impact of Brexit in terms of GHG on EU27 ii) CO2 costs for emission reductions and impact on competitiveness and iii) investment costs into low-carbon technologies vs 3rd countries. The speed of the EU energy transition is contingent on the ability and willingness of society to finance and sustain the conditions and investments, as such policy mechanisms for carbon cost internalization should be assessed.
2.	Effort sharing: EU ETS and non ETS sectors. Sectors with the most cost-effective reduction options and high social acceptance levels should be responsible for higher emissions reductions. Measures in the building sector to realise the EU’s ‘energy efficiency first’ mission and climate neutrality are therefore needed; this means actively increasing renovation rates (and depth) to address the existing building stock and raising this to ‘nearly zero energy buildings’ standards. 
3.	EU ETS and Indirect Cost Compensation should remain central pillars for industrial carbon leakage protection. A complete and transparent assessment of carbon and investment leakage risks is needed. It should not be based solely on historical evidence or direct carbon costs – this does not reflect the risk of leakage in the future, which increases with the rise in EUA price and respective energy prices. 
4.	CBAM is not a suitable carbon leakage protection measure for exporting industries. All policy instruments to strengthen carbon leakage protection should be part of the toolbox. This includes policies with a carbon cost internalization mechanism to facilitate CO2-neutral production (e.g. Carbon Contract for Difference; Green Dot-like system), enabling production of low carbon products that are competitive in EU and non-EU markets. 
5.	Transformation pathways require a sectoral assessment, and removal of regulatory bottlenecks for RES integration. New targets and legislation should take industry’s long-term investments into account as well as the role of competitive RES pricing. The removal of regulatory bottlenecks such as the renewable energy surcharges can unleash the potential of RES for large-scale industrial sites. The EEAG are instrumental to facilitate this within the 2030 period.

A detailed response is attached.

Dear Sirs/Mesdames
I am pleased to see that the EU is concerned about Greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions and is providing an opportunity for feedback on this initiative. One aspect of this plan is troubling to me and that is the proposed use of biomass for energy. Biomass is not a good solution for reducing GHG as the carbon footprint is extremely high. 

My home province of Nova Scotia has been providing biomass to Europe through the cutting down of forests, many of them old growth forests. This use of our forests is something that is disturbing to many people here. Forests sequester carbon in soil and in trees. Cutting down trees and disturbing soil releases this carbon and burning wood pellets for fuel further releases carbon. It takes years of new tree growth to replace the storage that has been lost - it is not as simple as planting new trees to replace those forests. Forests do not regenerate through the act of planting new trees. Much of the replanting that is done simply generates monocultures that are maintained through herbicide spraying and selective planting.

The business of cutting of forests and chipping and shipping of trees for biomass is not carbon neutral, but rather, it is carbon expensive as it requires the use of a great deal of fossil fuels. Additionally, cutting forests here and in other places serves only to reduce habitat, cause soil loss and decrease biodiversity. This is not something to do in a climate crisis. We should be increasing biodiversity and increasing forests all across the planet, not cutting them down.

 I urge you to consider the real footprint of biomass rather than see it as a renewable or green source of fuel. This is very misleading and not a good direction.

Kind regards
Jacqueline

I am writing on behalf of Global Forest Coalition and Biofuelwatch with a focus on the implications for bioenergy-related policies. However, we would also like to express wider concerns about the emphasis on economic growth and the claim that the EU has successfully decoupled economic growth from ghg emissions. This claim ignores the EU’s continuously growing ‘material footprint’ (tinyurl.com/vgfa92b) and the increased ghg emissions associated with imports from outside the EU, including in particular imports of high impact commodities like soy, beef and palmoil, and it relies on the assumption that EU bioenergy is carbon neutral. 
EU ghg emissions need to be reduced much faster than proposed if we want any chance of limiting global warming to 1.5 degrees. However, we are seriously concerned that increased targets could lead to increased use of bioenergy via the RED and EU-ETS (where bioenergy is classed as carbon neutral). Hundreds of scientists (tinyurl.com/sew8lad) as well as ESAC have pointed out that cutting down trees for energy results in carbon increases in the atmosphere over many decades that are incompatible with the goal of the Paris Climate Agreement. Similarly, biofuels have been widely shown to result in indirect land use change emissions which are commonly greater than those of the fossil fuels replaced (3x greater in the case of palm oil biofuels). There are similar concerns over other types of bioenergy, e.g. biogas from maize or grass silage. Bioenergy accounts for ~60% of all renewable energy in the EU (tinyurl.com/uaq4gw8). Unless it is excluded from the scope of the RED and ceases to be classified as carbon neutral under EU-ETS, more ‘ambitious’ climate and renewables targets will translate into more forest degradation, deforestation and other land-use change and lead to more land-grabbing. Sustainability and ghg standards for biofuels have been in place since 2010, and standards for solid biomass have existed in several member states for many years, but a recent analysis about such standards shows that they have not been an effective tool for avoiding or even reducing the negative impacts of biomass energy on the climate, forests, biodiversity and communities (tinyurl.com/usrp3sh).
The consultation rightly mentions the need for greater emissions reductions in all sectors, including the LULUCF sector (which should in fact be sequestering carbon). Across the EU-27, forests are being rapidly degraded, reducing and increasingly ending their ability to sequester carbon, and with devastating impacts on wildlife. It also impacts significantly on the communities which depend on and care for their forests and which see these forests damaged, destroyed, or replaced by monoculture conifer plantations. However, in like with its action plan on halting deforestation, the EU climate policy must equally address the severe impacts on forests outside the EU. If bioenergy demand remains as high as it is or, worse, rises further, greater safeguards for EU forests could well result in more imports of wood pellets from regions such as the Southeastern USA and Canada, woodchips from around the world, and soya and palm oil from developing countries for biofuels. The latter are associated with large-scale landgrabbing and human rights abuses, as well as dramatic deforestation rates. Biodiversity protection as well as climate and environmental justice require an end to subsidies and other incentives for bioenergy.
In this context, we note our concern that the consultation speaks about trade-offs between climate policy and biodiversity. Ever since life evolved, ecosystems have regulated and stabilised the Earth’s climate. Biodiversity loss worsens climate change and vice versa and “climate policies” that harm biodiversity, such as support for bioenergy, make climate change worse. We also note with concern that the consultation makes no mention of human rights impacts of EU climate policies, including in relation to bioenergy.

Dear EU Policy Makers and Legislators,

The present pandemic demonstrates our connection and interdependence on this planet. It also shows that we have to work together to fight such a global threat. The threat of Climate Change is no different. The decisions and policies on one continent affect the health and lives of people in other parts of the world.
The EU's new plan to cut emissions by 50 % or more below 1990 levels by 2030 is great news for everyone. BUT, PLEASE: don't mess up when deciding how to reach that goal.  We are talking about the (long ago) ill-conceived idea to replace fossil-fuels with biomass, in particular wood-chips derived from healthy trees that once made up a forest, then calling it "green energy and carbon neutral". The notion that CO2s emitted by burning wood-chips is equal to the CO2 captured by trees before they were cut down is FALSE. Research clearly shows that burning wood releases even more C02 than coal, as well as causing smog and at least as many health concerns. In fact, biomass produces approx. 50 % more C02 pollution per unit of energy than the coal it is replacing! Please, see the research by Mary S. Booth, PHD ecosystem scientist.
It is false to simply count CO2s released and captured, disregarding everything else.  This kind of balance sheet misses a lot of essential factors!  Not only does a forest capture and hold way more CO2s, it gives us other enormous benefits never considered in this accounting scheme. Forests clean the air, filter and hold water, keep the topsoil in place, provide shade, help with extreme temperature fluctuations, thereby providing important habitat for all kinds of creatures, guaranteeing the biodiversity and healthy ecology we all depend on. How anybody could have ever come up with such a loop-sided "first-grader math exercise", and then find governments implementing policies that subsidize the actual destruction of entire ecosystems, is beyond us.  Please, look at the pics of ha upon ha of clear-cuts in Eastern Europe, North-America and all over the world: entire mountainsides absolutely bare. Where did all that soil go in the next downpour? Where did all that water go? It was always kept in place by the trees in the forest, then released slowly.
Europe's idea to produce its electricity requirements by burning wood chips is not only increasing CO2 in the atmosphere, it fosters the elimination of natural carbon sinks, giving a green light to every other country that it's ok to destroy the lungs of the world and killing the creatures who depend on this habitat, bringing wildlife, bugs and viruses forever closer to humans. So far, you have chosen to ignore scientists worldwide, including your own advisers. We are asking you to go back to the science and research at hand.  The well-being of planet earth is at stake! 
We would also like to urge you to have a consultation with Kate Raworth, the economist who promotes a very different economic model. One that could help us to develop a sustainable economy. This is the chance of a lifetime to restore social integrity and find sustainable ways in our interactions with nature and in the use and exploration of natural resources. Let's not blow this chance again.  We MUST NOT go back to the "old normal".
While we live in Nova Scotia, Canada, we are writing to you as citizens of this world. Europe's policies on biomass affect us just as much in North-America. Industries developing and expanding everywhere: clear-cutting our forests to produce wood-chips or pellets for overseas markets.
Action on the climate front must not come at the expense of forests. In fact, we have to INCREASE carbon uptake NOW for fast mitigation. This can only happen by protecting and expanding the world's forests.  Please, act accordingly.

Irmgard and Paul Lipp and family 
Nova Scotia, Canada

The EU’s global leadership in the fight against climate change is invaluable. Increasing the 2030 EU GHG reductions target from 40% to 50% or 55% is essential. But stronger climate action must not come at the expense of forests. 

To date, EU Renewable Energy Directives (RED) intended to reduce GHG emissions have classified the burning of biomass for energy as “zero carbon.” Far from being zero carbon, wood-fired electricity and heating-units using green wood chips for fuel emit more CO2 per unit of energy output than fossil-fired units. For example, in 2016 at the Drax Power Plant in the UK, burning coal produced 873 kilotons (kt) of CO2 per terawatt hour of electricity(TWH). Burning biomass produced 902 kt CO2 per TWH. 

Under current RED, biomass, particularly wood and wood-waste, is the biggest source of renewable energy in the EU. In 2019 the Drax power station burned 7.05 million tonnes of wood pellets. 65% of those wood pellets came from the USA. 

Harvesting this volume of wood for biomass is devastating already stressed forests on both sides of the Atlantic. Here in Canada, our forests now sequester 30% less carbon than in 1990. In Annapolis County, Nova Scotia where I live, we have seen a 15% reduction in forest cover between 2000 and 2018. This is due to harvesting, the majority of it in its least sustainable, most damaging form: clearcutting.

When a forest is clearcut, while trees may in time regrow and begin to sequester carbon again, they will take a minimum of ten years to do so in any significant way, and far longer to fully replace the carbon sink capacity of the forest that was removed. This is time we don’t have. Also, more carbon is stored in the top metre of soil in a natural forest than is contained in all the woody material above ground. When sunlight hits that newly exposed forest floor, the soil releases most of the carbon it has been storing. The only forestry we should be practicing in a climate and biodiversity emergency is closed canopy, ecological forestry. This kind of forestry would not, could not and should not produce the quantity of wood currently required by plants burning pellets for the generation or co-generation of electricity.

In Nova Scotia, citizens have repeatedly declared that they want an end to clearcutting but the government department responsible for monitoring forestry industry activities is staffed by veterans of that industry. Public consultations are organised by government  then ignored while the industry continues to cut as much ‘fibre’ as it can. This is decimating what little remains of the rich, biodiverse, uneven aged Acadian forest that once covered Nova Scotia. Between 1958 and 2003 the proportion of forest in Nova Scotia aged more than 61 years fell from 59% to 13.5%. Since 2003 the pace of clearcutting has increased. 

This year, Northern Pulp, a sawmill that contaminated an Indigenous community’s land for 50 years, was finally closed down. This cut demand for fibre in our province and might offer an opportunity to start restoring our forests. Instead our provincial government, hand in glove with industry, is searching for an export market. They already export biomass to the UK and Europe and are eager to export more. Make no mistake, these are NOT sustainably sourced woodchips. Please, please do not encourage further destruction of our forests by continuing with the travesty of burning biomass for “green” energy.

The biodiversity crisis is inseparable from the climate crisis. Forests offer a natural solution for both crises. We need a climate policy that puts forests first. Please stop classifying the burning of biomass as “zero carbon.” End all subsidies for biomass harvesting and burning. Instead channel that money into protecting and restoring forests in the EU. That will give us a chance to protect and restore our forests too. This is a global emergency. We must work together to solve it.

organization: ZERO - Association for the Sustainability of the Earth System
feedback:
The Special Report of the IPCC on Global Warming of 1.5°C has shown that missing the 1.5°C temperature target all countries have agreed to under the Paris Agreement entails severe additional damages to the global ecosystem and increases the chances of hitting systemic tipping points that could spiral global heating out of human control.
The recent UNEP Emissions Gap report has underlined that current efforts will only limit global temperature increase to above 3°C above pre-industrial levels by the end of the century. The report also stressed that in order to keep temperature rise to 1.5°C all countries need to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions annually by 7.6% between now and 2030, implying a 2030 climate target of at least 65% for the European Union. In light of the EU’s global and historic responsibility and capacity to act and the equity principles underpinning the Paris Agreement, the impact assessment must also consider emission reduction pathways achieving higher than 55% emissions reductions by 2030 and climate neutrality by 2040 in order to provide for a reasonable likelihood of keeping the 1.5°C goal of the Paris Agreement attainable.
It´s very clear that increasing climate ambition requires increased decarbonisation from all economic sectors, and particularly an increase of the 2030 energy targets. Although the revision of these targets can take place together with the revision of the relevant legislation, it is important to keep underlining the key role of energy efficiency and renewable energy to significantly reduce emissions. The trajectory towards a true 100% renewable energy supply needs to be included into the assessment.
The full implementation of the current 2030 climate and energy legislative framework will only deliver emissions reductions of around 45%. It will be critical that the planned revision of implementing legislation, such as the EU-ETS, the Effort Sharing Regulation (ESR), the LULUCF Regulation, the CO2 Standards for Cars and Vans, the Energy Efficiency Directive (EED), the Renewable Energy Directive (RED), the Energy Taxation Directive, and all forthcoming new policy measures to underpin the delivery of  the significantly increased 2030 climate ambition. Further to these, the European Commission needs to develop clear sectoral decarbonisation strategies, including clear action plans that demonstrate how these strategies will be achieved and financed, in particular for the industry, transport, buildings, agriculture and forestry sectors.
In the bioenergy sector it´s important that the assessment addresses the environmental impact of land-use within the roadmap to 1) assess the CO2 and environmental impact of bioenergy and 2) expand beyond climate and energy legislation to sustainably achieve the EU’s carbon neutrality goal through actions that enhance the biodiversity and resilience of forests.
Several EU countries, such as Portugal, are anticipating measures of their carbon neutrality strategy for 2050 along the decade 2020-2030 under the need to accelerate action. It´s real that insufficient responses to the climate crisis today will cause far reaching and irreversible damages to future generations, directly from extreme weather events that are expected to become more frequent and severe due to intensifying global heating. They also can significantly exacerbate associated future challenges, such as conflicts over water, resources and materials, public health strains and increasing wealth inequality globally and regionally.
Any assessment of increased climate action needs to draw the full picture of its direct benefits (e.g. employment, reduced energy costs and import dependency, competitiveness) and avoided costs (e.g. environmental damage, health costs, fossil fuel subsidies), and implementing alternative solutions (e.g. energy efficiency, demand response, storage, increased flexibility) to prevent lock-in into carbon-intensive pathways.

Thank you for considering my feedback. 
I applaud the efforts of the EU to reduce emissions, and I wish my country would be as committed to this as you are. I do believe, however, that burning trees in the form of biomass to produce power has some special considerations. First, as a citizen of Nova Scotia, Canada where your biomass supply comes from, I believe I am a stakeholder in your decisions. I see several problems:
First, the trees you burn today won't be regrown to anywhere near their former capacity to sequester carbon by 2050. Forests regrow in centuries, not decades. While it looks like a closed loop, the loop is far too long to get us where we need to be.
Second, the earth under a forest contains 10X the carbon contained in trees themselves. Once this is exposed to the sun, it decomposes into CO2 and Methane. It can take a century to return the nitrogen to its former levels, and almost as long to sequester the carbon that was lost in the first place.
Third, as a resident of Nova Scotia, it is I that have to live with the results of deforestation: habitat loss, water acidification, erosion, groundwater contamination, tourism loss, species extinction, and an unsightly mess that lessens our quality of life. In this case, out of sight, out of mind for Europe is taking place in my back yard, and it is I that will be forced to bear the unaccounted costs of your decision.

While I applaud the goals of the EU 2030 Climate Target Plan, I have grave concerns about the inclusion of plans to burn wood as biomass for power generation.  First, it is not a carbon neutral type of energy.  Trees that are already doing a good job of effectively sequestering carbon should not be cut down to feed a biomass power generating station.  The notion that a new tree will grow in its place, creating a carbon neutral balance is just not accurate.  It will be a good 30 years or more before the "replacement tree" will ever be sequestering as much carbon as the already existing tree.  Further, to cut down trees in Canada, for shipment to European power generating plants, requires heavy machinery to fell the trees (using fossil fuels), then trucks to transport the trees out of the forests and often many kilometres to a processing facility (using more fossil fuel), then the wood is chipped (using more fossil fuel), and loaded on ships to cross the Atlantic Ocean (using more fossil fuel).  This does not make any sense whatsoever as far as trying to reduce carbon emissions.  Further, our forests here in Nova Scotia are being depleted in order to produce wood chips for generating electrical power in Europe.  At a time when all of us should be trying to protect the biodiversity of our forests and protect habitat for wildlife, it is very wrong to be basing your power generation needs on a plan which uses the forests of my country, or any country, for that matter -- especially from a source on the other side of an ocean.  This is entirely unsustainable.  We must all work together to protect what remains of the forests on this planet -- the lungs of our planet.  Thank you.

The EU’s global leadership in the fight against climate change is invaluable. Increasing the 2030 EU GHG reductions target from 40% to 50% or 55% is essential. But stronger climate action must not come at the expense of forests. 

To date, EU Renewable Energy Directives (RED) intended to reduce GHG emissions have classified the burning of biomass for energy as “zero carbon.” Far from being zero carbon, wood-fired electricity and heating-units using green wood chips for fuel emit more CO2 per unit of energy output than fossil-fired units. For example, in 2016 at the Drax Power Plant in the UK, burning coal produced 873 kilotons (kt) of CO2 per terawatt hour of electricity(TWH). Burning biomass produced 902 kt CO2 per TWH. 

Under current RED, biomass, particularly wood and wood-waste, is the biggest source of renewable energy in the EU. In 2019 the Drax power station burned 7.05 million tonnes of wood pellets. 65% of those wood pellets came from the USA. 

Harvesting this volume of wood for biomass is devastating already stressed forests on both sides of the Atlantic. Here in Canada, our forests now sequester 30% less carbon than in 1990. In Annapolis County, Nova Scotia where I live, we have seen a 15% reduction in forest cover between 2000 and 2018. This is due to harvesting, the majority of it in its least sustainable, most damaging form: clearcutting.

When a forest is clearcut, while trees may in time regrow and begin to sequester carbon again, they will take a minimum of ten years to do so in any significant way, and far longer to fully replace the carbon sink capacity of the forest that was removed. This is time we don’t have. Also, more carbon is stored in the top metre of soil in a natural forest than is contained in all the woody material above ground. When sunlight hits that newly exposed forest floor, the soil releases most of the carbon it has been storing. The only forestry we should be practicing in a climate and biodiversity emergency is closed canopy, ecological forestry. This kind of forestry would not, could not and should not produce the quantity of wood currently required by plants burning pellets for the generation or co-generation of electricity.

In Nova Scotia, citizens have repeatedly declared that they want an end to clearcutting but the government department responsible for monitoring forestry industry activities is staffed by veterans of that industry. Public consultations are organised by government  then ignored while the industry continues to cut as much ‘fibre’ as it can. This is decimating what little remains of the rich, biodiverse, uneven aged Acadian forest that once covered Nova Scotia. Between 1958 and 2003 the proportion of forest in Nova Scotia aged more than 61 years fell from 59% to 13.5%. Since 2003 the pace of clearcutting has increased. 

This year, Northern Pulp, a sawmill that contaminated an Indigenous community’s land for 50 years, was finally closed down. This cut demand for fibre in our province and might offer an opportunity to start restoring our forests. Instead our provincial government, hand in glove with industry, is searching for an export market. They already export biomass to the UK and Europe and are eager to export more. Make no mistake, these are NOT sustainably sourced woodchips. Please, please do not encourage further destruction of our forests by continuing with the travesty of burning biomass for “green” energy.

The biodiversity crisis is inseparable from the climate crisis. Forests offer a natural solution for both crises. We need a climate policy that puts forests first. Please stop classifying the burning of biomass as “zero carbon.” End all subsidies for biomass harvesting and burning. Instead channel that money into protecting and restoring forests in the EU. That will give us a chance to protect and restore our forests too. This is a global emergency. We must work together to solve it.

Ihr vorgelegtes Konzept habe ich mit Interesse zur Kenntnis genommen. Die vorgeschlagenen Eckwerte reichen aus mehreren Gründen nicht aus, hierzu gibt es mehrere Gründe und Zusammenhänge.

Beispiel 1,5° Ziel:
Das IPPC definierte eindeutig die Einhaltung der Nichtüberschreitung einer weltweit durchschnittlichen Erwärmung des Klimas von 1,5°C als Mindestvoraussetzung zur Erhaltung der Klimatisch erforderlichen Voraussetzung zur Erhaltung der Überlebensmöglichkeit der Menschheit. Dieses wurde im Pariser Klimaschutz Abkommen auch so vereinbart.  Ihre Ziele widersprechen diesem Abkommen. Unter Berücksichtigung der mit dem CO2 Ausstoß zusammenwirkenden Emissionen von Methangas und Lachgas liegt das weltweit maximal zur Verfügung stehende maximale CO2 Budget niedriger als angenommen. Das liegt an den mit dem Auftauen der Permafrostböden freigesetzten Methangas und den Emissionen von Methan und Lachgas bei der Förderung der Fossilen Energieträger. Eine Studie (https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-019-1368-z) hat aufgezeigt, dass wir, um das 1,5°C Ziel mit 50% Wahrscheinlichkeit noch einhalten zu können bis 2038 CO2 Emission Neutralität erreicht haben müssten, für eine Wahrscheinlichkeit von 66% sogar 2030.

Um eine Wahrscheinlichkeit der Einhaltung der 1,5°C Grenze jetzt noch garantieren zu können, müssten wir, unter Berücksichtigung der Verzögerungen im Gesetzes Verfahren, die CO2 Neutralität bis 2028 anstreben. Es zählt nämlich, physikalisch betrachtet, immer die Fläche unter der CO2 vs. Time Kurve. Aufgrund der Tatsache, dass Europa viel mehr CO2 Emittiert als industriell weniger entwickelte Länder, wir die CO2 Neutralität schon sehr viel früher erreichen müssten, nämlich 2026. Dazu hätte die Reduzierung der CO2 Emission bereits zum 01.01.2020 einsetzen müssen. Aufgrund der bisher ungenügenden Maßnahmen, ist es sogar erforderlich dieses bereits ein Jahr früher, nämlich 2025 CO2 Neutralität erreichen. Dies wäre also erforderlich um die Erhaltung der Überlebenswahrscheinlichkeit der Menschheit mit einer Wahrscheinlichkeit von 66% zu ermöglichen. Ihre selbstgesteckten Ziele Widersprechen also dem Pariser abkommen und der aktuellen Forschungslage.

The climate crisis is the greatest threat to world security and the future of our children. It is imperative that the EU act assertively to reduce GHG emissions. One powerful way to achieve this goal would be to stop the subsidization and burning of biomass which is misleadingly promoted as a green energy. That such a travesty is allowed and supported by current EU policy speaks volumes to how misguided the leadership on this issue has become. Some points to consider below:
-Biomass burning for energy produces more GHG emissions than coal burning.
- Not only European forests are being destroyed but North American forests are feeding EU biomass burning plants.
- The ability of our forests to sequester carbon is being compromised not to mention the damage from degradation of soil and CO2 sequestration resulting from clear cutting.
- Biomass burning is being subsidized by governments because the forestry industry has misleadingly convinced governments that it is green energy.
- Subsidies to biomass occur at the cost of subsidies to actual green energies such as wind, solar, geothermal.
- Currently, solid and gaseous biomass, particularly wood and wood-waste, is the biggest source of renewable energy in the EU.
- We need our forest carbon sinks to slow down global warming and biomass burning destroys those carbon sinks.
- Despite claims to the contrary by the forestry industry often the wood being burned is not waste wood but mature older trees.
- Biomass burning is not carbon neutral. The industry claim of carbon neutrality of biomass is based on a now discredited assumption that because new trees are planted where mature trees have been harvested, the new growth provides an offsetting sink to the carbon released from the burned wood. However, it would take those new trees many decades to absorb the atmospheric carbon emissions produced by the tons of wood pellets burned in a single day.

An important point is that biomass combustion (wood burning) as a form of bioenergy is not CO2 netral and not climate neutral. CO2 emissions from biomass combustion are twice as high as from gas and even higher than from coal combustion. In addition, it will take many decades before the accumulated CO2 debt is again established by forest planting, if forestplanting takes place at all. There is no time to loose to achieve the goal of climate neutrality in 2050. Large efforts must be made to energysaving, wind and solar energy, soil energy and forest planting. Forest planting is good for the climate ánd for the restoration of biodiversity. Biomass combustion is counterproductive. The REDII (Renewable Energy Directive) must be adjusted accordingly.

Maarten Visschers
Leefmilieu, www.leefmilieu.nl

feedback: Current EU regulations suggest that woody biomass is climate neutral. That makes it tempting for policy makers to replace fossil fuels with woody biomass. However, the scientific facts are otherwise. The attached factsheet of the Royal Netherlands Academy of Sciences states: "The combustion of wood in power stations and fuelling cars with bioethanol and biodiesel make virtually no contribution to reducing CO2 emissions. These technologies are therefore unsuitable for facilitating the transition to sustainable energy generation."   (https://knaw.nl/en/news/publications/position-paper-biofuel-and-wood-as-energy-sources-1). Woody biomass produces large amounts of CO2. Burning wood generates 109.6 kg CO2 per gigajoule (GJ) as opposed to 95 kg/GJ for coal and 56.6 for natural gas. In addition, growing and harvesting of trees, drying of wood and transporting wood pellets also generate large amounts of CO2. It takes between 20 and 200 years for this CO2 to be incorporated into growing trees - if equivalent amounts of trees are planted at all. Even dead wood is better left in forests, because it takes decades to decompose (Stephenson, A.L., and Mackay, D.J. (2014). Life Cycle Impacts of Biomass Electricity in 2020. UK Department of Energy and Climate Change. Search for "decay"). For these reasons, the EU should stop defining wood fuels as "climate neutral" and should discourage their use.

The shipping industry organisations to which the Spanish Shipowners’ Association (ANAVE) belongs, at world (ICS, BIMCO, etc.) and European (ECSA) level, are fully committed to the quickest possible reduction of the CO2 emissions from maritime transport, in line with the targets adopted at the International Maritime organization (IMO) with a view to get a full decarbonisation as soon as possible. 
We also share the aspirations expressed by the European Institutions (mainly Commission and Parliament) that the EU could have a leading position in this process. In particular, in the context of the Green Deal. 
When coming to the ways and specific measures to put this into practice, ANAVE believes that it would be a great advantage for the EU interests as a whole to channel these genuine aspirations in such a way that these measures, at the same time: 
	A. Deliver the greatest effects in terms of CO2 reductions at world level and 
	B. Minimize the possible negative impact for the EU economic interests. 

	A. How to deliver the greatest effects at world level from EU efforts? 
	— Maritime transport is a global activity and global warming also a global challenge. These facts fully justify that the task of reducing and eventually eliminating CO2 emissions from shipping has been commissioned by the United Nations to the IMO. 
	— The IMO is, indeed, the single international forum where global measures can be adopted to be applied to all ships under all flags and operating worldwide. 
	— On the contrary, regional measures which could be agreed and implemented only at EU level could be applied only to EU flag ships (about 20% of the world fleet) or, at the most, to ships taking part in EU shipping trade (about 30% of total world seaborne trade). 

	B. How to minimize the possible negative impact for the EU economic interests? 
	— Market measures to reduce CO2 emissions from shipping would indeed increase the cost of shipping companies to which they apply. 
	— This, on turn, will increase transport costs for the customers of these shipping companies. 
	— Therefore, the application of regional measures only with EU scope would increase transport costs for EU shipping companies and also for the EU importing and exporting industries, deteriorating their competitive position vis-à-vis their international competitors. 
	— On the contrary, measures agreed in the IMO and applied worldwide will increase in a similar way the costs of all ships and shipping companies and the transport costs of all transport users, thereby avoiding relative loss of competition for EU companies. 

Is there any possible additional benefit for EU interests from working at the IMO in the adoption of global measures? 
— The EU maritime cluster involves companies and industries that are world leaders in maritime technologies. 
— For many of these companies, the process to decarbonise maritime transport brings a world of opportunities to develop and put in the market new technologies and solutions. The EU may lead the world in this area. 
— In case that global IMO measures, instead of EU regional measures, are applied, the potential market for these European maritime industries will be 3 or 4 times higher. 

What about the R&D necessary efforts? 
— The full decarbonisation of shipping will not be reached through purely economic measures, such as Market Based Measures, simply because the necessary technologies are not available yet. 
— It would also entail very significant research efforts and investments to develop new zero-carbon fuels and propulsive technologies needed to decarbonise shipping. 
— The shipping industry has already proposed to the IMO the creation of a shipping R&D fund from shipping companies’ contributions of about $ 500 million/year in 10 years. 
— The EU could take a lead in contributing to the necessary R&D efforts, but it would be a great advantage for the EU that this R+D task is also assumed globally by all IMO member States.

In the thermal power plants in Sweden, trees from clear-cuts and thinning are being burnt. These are dry dead trees, deciduous trees, trees with internal decay, etc. – trees that should have remained as environmental consideration measures in forests, timber fields and on clear-cuts. In Sweden, about 90-95 million cubic meters (m3) of forest is harvested per year. Of this, about 10% goes to bioenergy, 20-30% to long-lived products such as wooden boards and planks and 60-70% to paper, diapers, cardboard, sanitary pads, napkins and other short-lived products. That is, about 70-80% of the timber from the Swedish forestry becomes short-lived products which end up as carbon dioxide in the atmosphere after a very short period of time. The forest industry and advocates of bioenergy forget that fossil fuels cannot be easily replaced with wood from the forest in any way. This is the case with oil, for example.

Amount of wood needed to correspond to 1 m3 of oil:
Pine, stemwood of different quality 5.0 – 6.4 m3
Spruce, stemwood of different quality 5.1 – 7.4 m3
Birch, stemwood  4.2 m3
Aspen, stemwood 5.4 m3
Alder, stemwood 5.8 m3

When it comes to biofuels as wood chips, the amount of wood needed is even larger:
Wood chips, residues from clear-cuts 10-12 m3

This means that in a total, about 6-8 m3 of wood is needed on average per cubic meter of oil depending on quality.

We imported about 23 million cubic meters of crude oil to Sweden in the years 2016 and 2017. If we are to replace all oil with bioenergy from the forest, we would have to harvest about 138-184 million cubic meters of forest. That is far more than the 90-95 million m3 harvested today every year. If we are to continue to produce the same amount of paper, cardboard, napkins and diapers as well as wooden boards and window frames, etc., the annual harvesting rate must increase up to 228-279 million cubic meters of forest. It is therefore reasonable to ask; how can this rate of forest harvesting be ecologically sustainable in the long run without negatively affecting ecosystems and biodiversity? This, especially, when we know that not even the 95 million cubic meters that we harvest today consents with a long-term ecologically and sustainable forestry due to negative impacts on the ecosystem and biodiversity in the Swedish forest.

The whole forest and biofuel industry say that "we harvest less than the growth" (the forest growth in Sweden is about 120 million cubic per year). However, the truth is that we cut the available growth considering that growth in the Swedish forest also occurs in our national parks, nature reserves, voluntary set-aside areas, etc., that is, forests that are protected for the sake of biodiversity. How do the biofuel advocates and the forest industry in Sweden reason when the forest should meet the increased demands for energy, wooden planks and boards, paper, cardboard, diapers, biodiversity, nature tourism, living ecosystems, etc? As a forest biologist I honestly can't work it out.

It is obvious that the words bioenergy and bioeconomy are new buzzwords originating from the forest and bioenergy industry. Frightening as it seems, it has attracted both parts of the public and politicians to believe that we will solve the climate and environmental problems with the Swedish forestry model – by logging natural forests and replacing them with planted timber fields. I wonder if there is any scientific evidence of climate benefits by destroying forest ecosystems? I also wonder if the forest and bioenergy industry has ever thought of planetary boundaries and what the earth's ecosystems can withstand?

I hope you all do understand that this issue about climate change and loss of biodiversity is closely related to our way of life and economic system. We need to think twice before we make decisions about how we should tackle these issues. Is the impact on our only planet and it´s ecosystems worth it? What will our future generations say about our decisions?

It is good to have more ambitious goals. I would like to question if even 55% is ambitous enough for 2030.
Looking at the 60 years form 1990 to 2050 we should have achieved 50% already in 2020, if we have an equal absolute reduction every yer (1.67% per year or 16.7% per decade). According to this simple calculation the goal should be 67% for 2030. I know that we have not done enough in the past to achieve 50% in 2020. Now it will be harder to acheive 67% reduction in 2030. However, knowing that we have not done enough in the past must not be a reason to continue not to do enough and to postpone the reductions. The sooner we understand that it was wrong not to do enough and start to do more, the easier it is to avoid a global catastrophy.

The paper also talks about social and economic trade offs and balances. It is good to consider these things. Unfortunately, the paper does not talk about the consequences of not doing enough in the coming decade and about the costs and problems that will arise to live with the consequences (or die as a consequence). I am afraid that this leads to a mind-set where 90% of the time we talk about the problems which the carbon reduction measures will cause and therefore be to shy to take the required measures. If we talk about electricity and heating becoming more expensive which could be a problem for poor people in Europe, then we should also talk about houses being destroyed by forest fires, tornados and floods, about regions drying out, lack of drinking water and so on, and then take a balanced decision. You should not talk only about the problems caused by GHG reduction and then to pretend to take a balanced decision (while in reality mostly ignoring the more serious problems caused by climate change).

It is mentioned in the paper that the EU stands only for 10% of global GHG emissions. However, the EU is an important trade partner of other big economies which stand for more emissions. I would like to suggest that the EU uses this position to force the other contries to reduce their emissions, too. One way to do so could be import taxes on all goods according to the GHG emissions caused by the lifecycle (production, use, disposal) of these goods.

On behalf of my daughter and coming generations, please plan for a faster reduction of GHG emissions!

Sehr geehrte EU, 

bezugnehmend auf aktuelle Studien des IPCC und aller führender Wissenschaftler ist das neuerlich Ziel von 50-55% CO2e Reduktion im Vergleich zu 1990 bei weitem nicht weitgehend genug.

Das Ziel die Treibhausgasemissionen im Jahr 2030 um 50 - 55% im Vergleich zum Jahr 1990 zu senken ist nicht mit den Zielen des Pariser Kimaabkommens zu vereinbaren. Bei Überschreitung einer globalen Erwärmung um 1.5 °C ist die Bevölkerung der Erde großen Gefahren ausgesetzt, da die Rückkopplungseffekte die Erwärmung der Erde vorantreiben, egal was die Menschheit tut, um ihre Emissionen zu senken. Es ist daher wichtig das 1.5 °C Ziel einzuhalten bzw. die Erderwärmung auf "deutlich unter 2 °C" zu halten, wie es im Pariser Klimaabkommen gefordert wird. Laut dem IPCC müssen die Treibhausgasemissionen bis 2030 dazu aber um ungefähr 45% im Vergleich zum Jahr 2010 sinken.
Unzureichender Klimaschutz bedeutet konsequente Nichtbeachtung der Grundrechte unzähliger Menschen, die von den Folgen des Klimawandels bedroht sind und sein werden. Wenn Sie die Forderungen der Wissenschaft nicht ernst nehmen, werden die Kipppunkte erreicht und die irreversible Zerstörung wird herbeigeführt.  Das können Sie nicht verantworten. Die Vermeidung des ökologischen Kollaps ist möglich - die Maßnahmen müssen nur ergriffen werden. Dazu muss eine Reduktion der Treibhausgasemissionen auf Netto - Null bis 2025 für die wirtschaftsstarken EU Staaten und bis mindestens 2030 für die wirtschaftsschwächeren EU Staaten anvisiert werden. Auch die durch die EU verursachten Emissionen in anderen Staaten dürfen nicht vergessen werden.

FORATOM welcomes the goal of increasing the EU 2030 energy and climate targets, provided that the decision is taken on the basis of a rigorous impact assessment which considers all low-carbon energy sources, including nuclear. 
In our opinion, it is clear that unless the EU sets ambitious 2030 targets, it will be almost impossible to achieve carbon neutrality in 2050. 
We remain convinced that the intermediate decarbonisation targets in the transition towards 2050 cannot be achieved without the Long-Term Operation (LTO) of existing nuclear reactors. In fact, if the EU were to invest in maintaining a fully operational nuclear fleet over this period, 58% of its electricity would come from low-carbon sources by 2030 – making it the global leader on climate change policy. If not, the share would drop to 38%, increasing the cumulative emissions by around 1,500 million tonnes of CO2 by 2030 (more info can be found in the attached position paper) and this, despite the significant investments efforts in renewables and energy efficiency that the EU is committed to make.
Meeting the EU’s ambition to decarbonize its economy will require the use of all low-carbon sources, and the LTO of the existing nuclear fleet will have a significant impact on this transition. Indeed, LTO offers numerous benefits: it is unarguably more economically advantageous than other power sources; it requires a much lower capital investment cost, leading to low investment risks for investors and capital markets, and lower con¬sumer costs. Likewise, from a technical point of view, the LTO of nuclear reactors  provides a great advantage thanks to the “…timely implementation of reasonably practicable safety improvements to existing nuclear installations” which brings older generation reactors to a level of nuclear safety standards in compliance with the amended Nuclear Safety Directive. LTO also reduces the EU’s energy import dependency – mainly fossil fuels – and provides reliability to the grid. Furthermore, low-carbon nuclear generation provides firm capacity to the electricity system. On this point, it should be borne in mind that the lack of commercial maturity of storage technologies might lead to a fossil fuel power plant lock-in effect if the pace of phasing out dispatchable carbon intensive technologies is not properly taken into consideration. Last but not least, LTO helps the industry maintain and upgrade the competences of operators and suppliers, which will allow it to prepare for the future renewal of the fleet.

In order to ensure that Europe can make the most of the benefits offered by the LTO of existing nuclear reactors, FORATOM has put forward the following policy recommendations:
•	Ensure a coherent, consistent and stable EU policy framework (including Euratom).
•	Continue to implement the necessary measures to reach the ambitious net-zero CO2 emissions target for the EU in 2050, as endorsed by the Council in December 2019.
•	Develop and implement a strong industrial strategy to ensure that Europe maintains its technological leadership.
•	Support human competences development.

Ich bin sehr froh, dass die Europäische Kommission die Initiative ergriffen hat einen neuen „Klimazielplan 2030“ zu entwickeln. Dabei sollte insbesondere darauf geachtet werden, dass durch das Konsumverhalten innerhalb Europas verursachten Treibhausgase in anderen Erdteilen emittiert werden. Diese Emissionen müssen in die Zielsetzung einbezogen werden.

Ich erwarte, dass die Europäische Union ab sofort eine konsequente Politik zum Eindämmung der Klimaerwärmung umsetzt. Das Pariser Klimaschutzabkommen ist bindend und es müssen seitens der EU alle Anstrengungen (whatever it takes) unternommen werden, um dieses einzuhalten. Wir wissen alle, dass es nur den Weg gibt, so schnell wie möglich zu reduzieren, dafür reicht nicht 2050 (das sind 30 Jahre und etwas weniger als mein ganzes Leben), dafür reicht nicht 2040 oder 2030. Wir sehen an der Corona-Krise, wie schnell Einschränkungen gesellschaftlich akzeptiert werden, wenn es um die Gesundheit geht. Bei der Klimakrise geht es um nicht weniger als die Gesundheit, es geht um die menschliche Existenz. Also zeigen Sie bitte, dass Sie es ernst meinen, Europa soll klimaneutral werden und zwar so schnell wie möglich!!! Möglich ist vieles, wenn man es will.

Die angesetzten Ziele der neuen Initiative sind viel zu niedrig. Das 1,5° Ziel kann durch eine 50% Senkung der Treibhausgasemissionen gegenüber dem Jahr 1990 bis 2030 nicht erreicht werden! Die wirtschaftsstarken EU-Staaten müssen bis 2025 auf Netto-Null kommen und die wirtschaftsschwächeren bis 2030. Die EU muss das Pariser Abkommen endlich ernst nehmen und dadurch die Führungsrolle übernehmen. Am Anfang ist es zudem einfacher die Emissionen zu verringern, deswegen muss vor allem jetzt entsprechend gehandelt werden, um sich später den noch größeren Herausforderungen stellen zu können. Unser Konsum führt zudem zu riesigen Emissionen in anderen Teilen der Welt, auch dafür sind wir verantwortlich!
Sehen Sie der ganzen Wahrheit der Klimakrise ins Auge und handeln Sie jetzt. Bewahren Sie unsere Erde, damit sie auch in den kommenden  Jahren ein lebenswerte Ort bleibt. Gefährliche klimatische Kipppunkte dürfen nicht länger in Kauf genommen werden.

Vielen Dank

The Commission intends to propose an increasing of the EU’s GHG emission reductions target for 2030 to at least 50% and towards 55% compared with 1990 levels.  In this respect, the EOS response focuses on the role of biomass-based products and nature-based solutions in achieving a sustainable, circular and environmental-friendly economy. According to the Regulation on Land Use, Land Use Change and Forestry (Regulation EU 2018/841), EU Member States are requested to comply with the so called “no debit rule”, which requires EU Member States to ensure that emissions from the LULUCF sector do not exceed removals from 2021 to 2030. Meaning: the LULUCF sector shall not become a net source of GHG emissions.  Today more than two-fifths of Europe is tree-covered. Between 1990 and 2015, the area covered by forests and woodlands increased by 90,000 square kilometres - an area roughly the size of Portugal.  In Europe, 33 % of the total land area (215 million ha) is covered by forests, with a positive trend of increase for the forested areas. Other wooded lands cover an additional area of 36 million ha. 113 million ha are covered by coniferous forests, 90 million ha by broadleaved ones and 48 million ha by mixed forests. (Source: JRC). Many of Europe’s forests are managed to produce wood to make paper, or timber for construction, or as fuel. As trees in those forests are felled, more are planted, and European forests expand by an area the size of 1,500 soccer pitches every day. (Source: the World Economic Forum). 
Nevertheless, forests might be negatively affected by climate change causing an increase of the forest disturbances. Climate change have an effect on important abiotic ( re, drought, wind, snow and ice) and biotic (insects and pathogens) disturbance agents. Warmer and drier conditions particularly facilitate, drought and insect disturbances, while warmer and wetter conditions increase disturbances from wind and pathogens. Widespread interactions between agents are likely to amplify disturbances, while indirect climate effects such as vegetation changes can dampen long-term disturbance sensitivities to climate. Future changes in disturbance are likely to be most pronounced in coniferous forests and the boreal biome.

Ich halte die derzeit gesteckten Maßnahmen in der EU nicht für ausreichend genug um die Erwärmung unseres Planeten auf das Paris-Ziel von 1,5 Grad zu begrenzen. Eine weltweite Klimaneutralität bis 2050 ist nur zu erreichen, wenn die EU für sich selbst Klimaneutralität wesentlich eher erreicht, um den anderen Ländern ausreichend Zeit für eine Transformation zu geben. Die EU ist wirtschaftlich stark aufgestellt und muss hier eine Vorreiterrolle einnehmen. Bei all dem ist zu berücksichtigen, dass unser Konsum in Europa maßgeblich zu Treibhausgasemissionen in der Welt beiträgt. Viele hier konsumierte Güter werden aber außerhalb von Europa hergestellt, aber unseren verursachten Emissionen nicht hinzugerechnet. Das wäre aber fair und gerecht und würde unsere weltweite und solidarische Verantwortung deutlich aufzeigen.
 Dies führt mich bei meinen Überlegungen zu der Forderung, dass die EU bis 2030 treibhausgasneutral sein muss. Das ist nicht einfach eine politische Ansicht, sondern eine Notwendigkeit für das Überleben der Menschheit. Bereits jetzt sind klimatische Prozesse in Gang gesetzt, die sich gegenseitig verstärken und uns Nähe an den „Point of no Return“ gebracht haben. Jetzt zu handeln sichert das Überleben der Menschen auf diesem Planeten. Dies ist auf einer drei oder vier Grad heißeren Erde nicht mehr möglich. 
Was nutzt uns eine florierende und rohstoffintensive Wirtschaft, wenn unser menschlicher Organismus auf dieser Erde nicht mehr funktioniert, wenn er kollabiert? Der Erde sind wir Menschen egal, uns Menschen darf aber die Erde nicht egal sein, denn nur auf einer intakten Erde können wir atmen, essen, leben ... und Wirtschaften.
Eine schnelle Reduktion der Treibhausgasemissionen ist in vielen Bereichen notwendig. Der Energiesektor, der Bausektor und der Verkehrssektor sind hier maßgebend. Doch leider ist der Endenergieverbrauch in Deutschland seit 1990 kaum gesunken, der Verbrauch von Kraftstoff ist nahezu konstant. Auch wenn immer mehr Energie effizient genutzt und auch regenerativ erzeugt wird, so verhindern unter anderem Konsumsteigerungen einen Rückgang.
Es gilt also in vielen Bereichen gegenzusteuern und mutige politische Beschlüsse zu fassen und genau das erwarte ich von Ihnen. Um es bewusst pathetisch zu formulieren: Das Überleben meiner Kinder und Enkelkinder liegt in Ihren Händen. Das ist Herausforderung und Chance zugleich. Seien Sie mutig und gehen Sie voran!

The climate crisis is the greatest threat to world security and the future of our children. It is imperative that the EU act assertively to reduce GHG emissions. One powerful way to achieve this goal would be to stop the subsidization and burning of biomass which is misleadingly promoted as a green energy. That such a travesty is allowed and supported by current EU policy speaks volumes to how misguided the leadership on this issue has become. Some points to consider below:

-Biomass burning for energy produces more GHG emissions than coal burning.
- Not only European forests are being destroyed but North American forests are feeding EU biomass burning plants.
- The ability of our forests to sequester carbon is being compromised not to mention the damage from degradation of soil and CO2 sequestration resulting from clear cutting.
- Biomass burning is being subsidized by governments because the forestry industry has misleadingly convinced governments that it is green energy.
- Subsidies to biomass occur at the cost of subsidies to actual green energies such as wind, solar, geothermal.
- Currently, solid and gaseous biomass, particularly wood and wood-waste, is the biggest source of renewable energy in the EU.
- We need our forest carbon sinks to slow down global warming and biomass burning destroys those carbon sinks.
- Despite claims to the contrary by the forestry industry often the wood being burned is not waste wood but mature older trees.
- Biomass burning is not carbon neutral. The industry claim of carbon neutrality of biomass is based on a now discredited assumption that because new trees are planted where mature trees have been harvested, the new growth provides an offsetting sink to the carbon released from the burned wood. However,  it would take those new trees many decades to absorb the atmospheric carbon emissions produced by the tons of wood pellets burned in a single day.

Comment to the EU on burning biomass for energy 2020-04-09

There is no disagreement that we must fight against climate change. But stronger climate action must not come at the expense of forests. This feedback will focus on the role of biomass-based products and nature based solutions.” (2030 Climate Target Plan)

Classifying the burning of biomass for energy as “zero carbon.” is erroneous and has had severe impacts on the biodiversity and carbon sink capacity of forests in Europe and North America. Far from being zero carbon, wood-fired electricity and heating-units using green wood chips for fuel emit more CO2 per unit of energy output than fossil-fired units. 

The EU must end the “green” classification of biomass for energy that gave rise to subsidies. Without subsidies it is unlikely plants burning biomass for energy would be economically feasible, especially as the cost of truly renewable energy continues to drop. 

The harvesting of wood for biomass is devastating forests on both sides of the Atlantic. In the name of supposedly “green” energy, this is damaging our carbon sinks when we need them the most. Forests are a proven, low cost, high benefit “technology.”  They are sequestering carbon right now..

When a forest is clearcut, as far too many are in the EU and in North America, while trees do regrow, it will take generations to fully replace the carbon sink capacity of the forest that was removed. In addition, more carbon is stored in the top metre of soil in a natural forest than is contained in all the woody material above ground. When sunlight hits that newly exposed forest floor, the soil releases most of the carbon it has been storing. The only forestry we should be practicing in a climate and biodiversity emergency is closed canopy, ecological forestry. We need to support the health and resilience of forests, not destroy them.

In Europe, many countries have seriously degraded their carbon sink, a decline directly related to excessive harvesting. Here in Canada, our forests now sequester 30% less carbon than in 1990. In Nova Scotia where I live we have seen a 15% reduction in forest cover between 2000 and 2018. This is almost entirely due to harvesting, the majority of it in its least sustainable, most damaging form: clearcutting.

In Nova Scotia, while citizens have repeatedly declared that they want an end to the clearcutting that is devastating forests all across our province, our government is entwined with the forestry industry. The government department that should be monitoring the activities of the forestry industry here is staffed primarily by veterans of that industry. Public consultations are organised by government and then ignored while the industry continues to cut as much ‘fibre’ as it can. This is decimating what little remains of the rich, biodiverse, Acadian forest that once covered Nova Scotia. 

This year, Northern Pulp, a sawmill that contaminated an Indigenous community’s land for 50 years, was finally closed down. This cut the demand for fibre in our province and might offer an opportunity to start restoring our forests. Instead our provincial government, hand in glove with industry, is searching for an export market. They are already exporting biomass to the UK and Europe and are eager to export more. Make no mistake, these are NOT sustainably sourced wood chips. Please, please do not encourage further destruction of our forests by continuing with the travesty of burning biomass for “green” energy.

The biodiversity crisis is inseparable from the climate crisis. Forests offer a natural solution for both. We need a climate policy that puts forests first. Please stop classifying the burning of biomass as “zero carbon.” End all subsidies for biomass for energy harvesting. Instead channel that money into protecting and restoring forests in the EU. That will give us a chance to protect and restore out forests too. This is a global emergency. We must work together to solve it!

Comment to the EU on burning biomass for energy:

Addressing climate change and enhancing the EU’s global leadership role in the fight against climate change is to be commended. But stronger climate action must not come at the expense of forests.

EU Renewable Energy Directives (RED) intended to reduce GHG emissions have classified the burning of biomass for energy as “zero carbon.” Not only wrong, this practice has had severe impacts on the biodiversity and carbon sink capacity of forests in Europe and North America. Far from being zero carbon, wood-fired electricity and heating-units using green wood chips for fuel emit more CO2 per unit of energy output than fossil-fired units. In 2016, the Drax Power Plant in the UK, burned coal to produce 873 kilotons (kt) of CO2 per terawatt hour of electricity(TWH). Burning biomass produced 902 kt CO2 per TWH. [Mary S. Booth, PhD Ecosystem Scientist Webinar: The Threat to Forests and Climate From Burning Forest Biomass]

Harvesting wood for biomass is devastating forests on both sides of the Atlantic. This green-washed practice attacks our carbon sinks when we need them most. Unlike other forms of carbon capture, forests are a proven, low cost, high benefit “technology.” These havens of biodiversity are sequestering carbon now.

After clearcutting, it will take a minimum of 10 years for trees to grow and sequester carbon again. It takes far longer to fully replace the carbon sink capacity of the forest that was removed. More carbon is stored in the top metre of soil in a natural forest than is contained in all the woody material above ground. When sunlight hits that newly exposed forest floor, the soil releases most of the carbon it has been storing. 

The only forestry we should be practicing in a climate and biodiversity emergency is closed canopy, ecological forestry. This kind of forestry would not, could not and should not produce the quantity of wood currently required by plants burning pellets for the generation or co-generation of electricity.

The people of Nova Scotia have repeatedly declared they want an end to clearcutting - it is devastating forests all across our province. The biggest stumbling block is our government which is entwined with the forestry industry. 

This year, Northern Pulp, a sawmill that contaminated an Indigenous community’s land for 50 years leading to horrific cancer rates in the community and polluted the air for everyone in the area, was finally closed down. This cut the demand for fibre in our province and could offer an opportunity to start restoring our forests. Instead, our provincial government, hand in glove with industry, is searching for an export market. They are already exporting biomass to the UK and Europe and are eager to export more. These are NOT sustainably sourced woodchips. Please do not encourage further destruction of our forests by continuing promote biomass burning as “green” energy.

The biodiversity crisis is linked to the climate crisis. Forests offer a natural solution for both. We need a climate policy that puts forests first. Please stop classifying the burning of biomass as “zero carbon.” End all subsidies for biomass for energy harvesting. Invest in protecting and restoring forests in the EU. This will give us a chance to protect and restore our forests too. This is a global emergency. We must work together to solve it for ourselves and future generations.

Yours, very sincerely.
