TSP is a European think tank: its mission is to act as a proactive source of proposals which focus primarily on the resources required to make the shift to an economy free of dependency on fossil fuels (and therefore of GHG).

Clean energy
TSP values the EC priority on energy efficiency and on a rapid phasing out of coal in the power sector. We advocate:
•	For an explicit and predictable carbon price signal in the EU ETS, with a carbon price corridor: carbon price floor starting at 40€/ton in 2021 and growing
•	Not to see gas as an energy of transition: for TSP: recourse to gas is a technological lock-in to be avoided
•	The end of investment in fossil fuel (including new investment in gas infrastructure)
•	The inclusion of any decarbonized source of energy in the energy mix - any mix of renewables and nuclear power, according to national preferences, as long as decarbonization is maximized.

Sustainable industry
TSP welcomes the development of a circular economy, the improvement of material efficiency and the increase of life-spans. We suggest:
•	The use of waste and biomass for heating in chemical industries
•	A sober and sustainable digitalisation (lean ICT)
•	The non-export and landfill of recoverable wastes.

Building and renovating
As part of a roadmap for the renovation wave, TSP suggests the following measures:
•	The target of “low energy building” level by 2050 for all pre-1990 constructions
•	The generalisation of Building Renovation Passports in all EU, with strong support from EC and in a mandatory way at national level
•	The obligation to all public buildings to make a substantial renovation at a very low carbon footprint standard

Sustainable mobility
TSP welcomes the GD ambition to cut transport emissions by 90%.
We advocate:
•	A multimodal approach that includes the development of public transport systems, bicycle systems, carpooling, bus networks and home-workplace mobility
•	Small and efficient cars (less than 2L/100km) when personal car is absolutely necessary: this can only be achieved with lighter, slower and less powerful cars
•	Prices that reflect CO2 emission especially for the aviation sector
•	The link between major cities with high-speed rail services, when decarbonized electricity is available

Biodiversity
TSP values the ambition of the EC to develop and enforce a Biodiversity Strategy.
TSP proposes the implementation of a Forest Strategy Program: a program based on the substitution of high-emission construction material by wood, sustainable management of the resource and value-making chain.

Agriculture
TSP welcomes the goals of “Farm to Fork” Strategy and advises to:
•	Create a "High Environmental Quality" label for livestock
•	Substitute the current subsidy-based approach by a remuneration of farmers depending on the adoption of such a label (via the CAP)
•	Harmonize the evaluation of losses and waste, and improve the reliability of the data
•	Standardize best-before/use-by dates on food products, making the information clear for consumers
•	Encourage awareness campaigns to the public concerning food waste

Finance
TSP welcomes the GD intention to better embed sustainability into corporate governance framework, disclose climate and environmental data, and integrate climate risk data into the financial system.
TSP suggests to:
•	Dedicate significant resources for the analysis of climate change-related risks, and mainstream those long-term risks in the credit rating of companies by financial agencies; stress tests must include oil shocks (from the perspective of physical quantities, not of prices)
•	Set up a « brown penalizing factor », for investments aggravating climate risks

Education
Europe must create a “Green Bologna Process”: indeed, the academic response to youth mobilisation is teaching climate change and energy related facts to all students.

Further information: https://theshiftproject.org/en/home/

Liebe EU Commission,
ich bin 25 Jahre alt, studiere Physik im Master und freue mich sehr, dass die Diskussion im Raum steht die Klimaziele an die wissenschaftlichen Tatsachen anzupassen. Jedoch fehlt mir in der Zielsetzung bis jetzt die Ehrlichkeit und der Mut die Tatsachen beim Namen zu nennen.

Es wird gesagt, dass die EU eine Führungsrolle im Kampf gegen den Klimawandel eingenommen hat. Aber noch hört die EU nicht auf wissenschaftlichen Tatsachen und Warnungen. Der IPCC von 2018 gibt vor, dass die Welt bis 2050 klimaneutral sein muss.
Dabei müssen auch historische Emissionen in Betracht gezogen werden. Geht man vom weltweiten Treibhausgasbudget ab 2016 aus, um mit einer 2/3-Wahrscheinlichkeit unter der überlebenswichtigen 1.5 Grad Grenze zu bleiben, und verteilt diese Menge gleichermaßen auf jeden Menschen, so müsste zum Beispiel Deutschland bei einer linearen Treibhausgasreduktion spätestens 2025 bei Nettonull sein. Eine 2/3 Wahrscheinlichkeit ist wahrlich nicht viel. Wer von uns würde in ein Flugzeug steigen, wenn die Wahrscheinlichkeit zu sterben 1/3 beträge? Und doch ist dies die höchste Wahrscheinlichkeit, die uns die Wissenschaft gibt, um eine lebenswerte Zukunft zu haben.
Die Klimakatastrophe ist eine weltweite Krise, die wir gemeinsam lösen müssen. Daher ist der Aspekt der Klimagerechtigkeit so wichtig. Wir in der EU können nicht mehr CO2 beanspruchen als die Länder im globalen Süden. Uns steht nicht mehr CO2 zu als jedem anderen Menschen. Deshalb müssen wir das CO2 Budget spätestens ab 2016 (spätestens nach Paris!) gerecht auf die Weltbevölkerung aufteilen.

Zusätzlich geht der IPCC von hohen negativ Emissionen aus. Stand heute gibt es aber noch nicht die Möglichkeit so große Mengen CO2 wieder aus der Atmosphäre zu holen. Wir dürfen uns bei der Zielsetzung der Emissionen nicht in Tagträumen verlieren und denken die Zukunft wird es schon regeln. Wir müssen jetzt realistisch denken und energisch unsere Zukunft bewahren.

Außerdem kam gerade raus, dass die Klimasensitivität höher als gedacht ist. Also eine bestimmte Menge an Treibhausgasen zu einer noch höheren Erderhitzung führt als befürchtet. Das ist also ein Grund mehr zu handeln. Vom weltweiten CO2 Budget müssen wir außerdem die Emissionen abziehen, die durch die Waldbrände und durch den Permafrost in den letzten Jahren frei geworden sind. Damit ist unser Budget nochmal geringer und wir müssen eigentlich schon vor 2025 bei Nettonull sein.

Von alldem lese ich in dem „2030 Climate Target Plan“ nichts. Ich appelliere an Sie: Sagen Sie die Wahrheit! Und bis jetzt müsste diese heißen: Wir steuern gerade auf eine 3-4 Grad heißere Welt zu. Dies wird mit hoher Wahrscheinlichkeit eine Kaskade von Kipppunkten lostreten und uns wahrscheinlich in eine Heißzeit katapultieren. In den letzten 10-20 Mio. Jahren war es auf dieser Erde nichtmehr so heiß und wir wissen nicht wie und ob es in solch einer Welt noch Zivilisation geben kann. (Ich persönlich denken Nein, denn wenn wir uns den „Totesstreifen“ (1000 km über- und unterhalb des Äquators), also die unbewohnbaren Flecken der Erde bei einer 4 Grad heißeren Welt in 2100 anschauen, glaube ich kaum, dass wir als Zivilisation das schaffen. Zusätzlich natürlich zu den Unwettern und Nahrungsmittelknappheiten etc.)

Ich bitte Sie, hören Sie auf die Warnungen der Wissenschaft und handeln Sie verantwortungsbewusst. Geben Sie meiner und künftigen Generationen eine Zukunft auf diesem Planeten.

Ich will in einer EU Leben, die wirklich eine Führungsrolle einnimmt und sich für eine 1.5 Grad Grenze einsetzt. Für eine Zukunft für meine und zukünftige Generationen. Lasst uns dafür gemeinsam einstehen und die Emissionreduktionsziele so anpassen, dass dies möglich wird: Eine Reduktion der Treibhausgasemissionen auf Nettonull bis 2025 für die wirtschaftsstarken EU Staaten und bis mindestens 2030 für die wirtschaftsschwächeren EU Länder. Dabei müssen auch durch die EU verursachten Emissionen in anderen Ländern miteinbezogen werden.

Dear EU Commission, I am glad for this plan and for going in the right direction to prevent a climate crisis. However, your plan is currently not ambitious enough. If in times of the coronavirus crisis, massive and disruptive measures haven been taken and proven successful this must be as well possible in regards to the climate crisis. Generally saying, the targets you have currently set are unrealistic to reach the 1.5°C target and must be improved. 

First of all, your targets are not compatible with the 1.5 ° C goal as the associated IPPC report emphasizes a reduction in greenhouse gas emissions of around 45%  to 2030 (compared to 2010). 
Furthermore, we demand that you also include global justice issues in your objectives and we also must become greenhouse gas neutral faster than others. According to what the IPCC report is saying, the world must be climate neutral by 2050. Therefore if we want to give the developing countries more time, the EU would have to be climate neutral earlier in order to jointly reach the goal on time. Moreover, a lot of greenhouse emissions used for consumption in Europe are done in other parts of the world. Therefore, we demand this should be taken into account when setting the goals. 
You also say in your plan that you want a so-called balanced way to reach reduction goals of the greenhouse emission. However, you are not taking into account and consider that it is easier to lower the emissions at the beginning and afterward it becomes more difficult and complicated. For a balanced path and to be sure to reach the set goal, much more would have to be done and saved at the beginning compared to the end.

Making plans which are not ambitious enough is in my opinion equal to admitting and saying you are not doing enough to create a secure future for next generations. You should be aware that goals are not ambitious and disruptive enough in order to preserve our livelihood and planet. You must set higher goals and reduce greenhouse gas emissions as soon as possible, even if this requires engaging in uncomfortable situations that might change our daily lives.  

Thank you for allowing me to submit my feedback on this highly important topic.
Valentina Gregorcic,
Slovenia

Das Vorhaben der EU-Kommission greift zu kurz. Auf alle Fälle müsste mindestens enthalten sein:
1. Die atomar-fossile Energiegewinnung wird bis 2030 vollständig abgelöst von Erneuerbarer Energiegewinnung (EE).
2. EE wird nicht mehr durch Gesetze behindert, aber durchweg gefördert.
3. Beim Ausbau von EE hat die dezentrale Bürgerenergie den Vorrang.
4. Der Speicherausbau geht vor Großnetzausbau. Ein intelligenter Kleinnetzausbau wird gefördert.
5. CO2 wird aktiv zurückgeholt (Methanol, Aufforstung, Pflanzenkohle) und O2 gewonnen.
6. Folgegesetze werden zügig angepasst (Steuer, Bau, Förderrichtlinien usw.).
All das haben schon viele Wissenschaftler durchgerechnet. Es geht noch zu verwirklichen. Wenn das bis 2030 nicht gelingt, wird der Kipppunkt, von dem es kein Zurück mehr gibt, erreicht sein. Und dann macht das Klima, was es will, und nicht das, was der Erde gut täte.

Wenn die Treibhausgasemission bis Ende 2030 halbiert und dann bis Ende 2050 auf netto null reduziert wäre, dann hätte die Menschheit eine Chance von 50 Prozent, die Klimaerhitzung bei 1,5 Grad zu stabilisieren. Dieses Risiko einzugehen und an Plänen zur Umsetzung dessen festzuhalten, ist meines Erachtens grob fahrlässig. Erst recht vor der Tatsache, dass der Weltklimarat IPCC eine „Klimahypothek“ nicht mitgerechnet hat: Es ist unklar, wie groß das tatsächlich noch vorhandene Co2-Budget ist, da vorhandene Treibhausgasspeicher (wie Co2 in Permafrost, Methan in Feuchtgebieten) wenig erforscht sind, aber ebenfalls einen großen Anteil an Emissionen haben könnten und somit ein zusätzliches großes Risiko darstellen. Die bisher getroffenen Maßnahmen, das 1,5-Grad-Ziel zu erreichen, sind meines Erachtens viel zu gering. Schon jetzt sind die Ziele des Pariser Abkommens (für bis heute) nicht erreicht worden. Bei der Klimakrise steht unser aller Leben auf dem Spiel. Darf man da nicht etwas mehr Sicherheitspuffer erwarten? Lieber zu viele als zu wenig Maßnahmen treffen. Das wäre eine im Sinne von „pro Menschen“ authentische, wirklich für den Menschen und Arten/ Tiere gemachte Politik! Ihre Richtung stimmt zwar, die Geschwindigkeit ist aber noch deutlich zu langsam.

Liebe EU-Commission,
ich finde es als EU-Bürger sehr gut, dass Sie sich Gedanken um das Klima und um unsere Zukunft machen. Als ein sehr junger Bürger habe ich jedoch die Befürchtung, dass Ihre Ziele noch nicht hoch genug gesteckt sind. Im IPPC Sonderbericht über 1.5°C globale Erwärmung sind nicht alle Risiken des Klimasystems enthalten. Darüber hinaus fordert der IPCC Sonderbericht, dass die Treibhausgase um ca. 45% gegenüber dem Jahr 2010 bis 2030 reduziert werden. Darüber hinaus vermisse ich globale Klimagerechtigkeitsaspekte und eine Beschreibung, die frühere Emissionen als schädlicher wertet als spätere. Wenn wir frühzeitig reduzieren kann sich die Bevölkerung Langfrist besser darauf einstellen. Bitte bleiben Sie ehrlich und tun Sie wirklich was Sie können. Ich sehe mehr Potential und hoffe, dass Sie dies auch umsetzen können. Ich hoffe, dass Sie Ihre Ziele höher setzen und ich als ein EU-Bürger würde gerne diesen Weg mit Ihnen gehen um eine gute Zukunft zu gestalten.

organization: Euromines, the European Association of Mining, Metal Ores & Industrial Minerals
feedback:
As the recognized representative of the European mineral raw materials industry covering more than 42 different metals and minerals and employing 350.000 directly and about four times as many indirectly, Euromines welcomes a European Green Deal to put Europe on the right track to a sustainable future and is prepared to take the necessary measures to make it the world's first climate neutral continent.

At the same time, we believe that efforts, climate ambitions and targets should be aligned with the fundamental principle of sustainable development, ensure the essential current needs and safeguard the needs of future generations while contributing to the economic, social and environmental development. Fossil Free Berlin begrüßt den Schritt der Europäischen Union (EU) ihr Klimaziel für 2030 zu erhöhen. Die geplante Reduktion der CO2 Emissionen bis 2030 von bisher 40% auf 50-55% im Vergleich zu 1990 ist ein erstes Symbol dafür, dass die EU Ihre Verpflichtungen aus dem Pariser Klimaabkommen von 2015  und die Auswirkungen der Klimakrise anerkennt.

Entscheidend ist jedoch, dass es nicht bei einer Zielsetzung bleibt, sondern es zu einer tatsächlichen Umsetzung längst hinfälliger Maßnahmen kommt. Denn auch wenn wir die Verschärfung der Klimaziele begrüßen, führen Ziele allein nicht zur Veränderung.

Diesbezüglich ist ebenso zu berücksichtigen, dass selbst eine reale Reduktion der CO2 Emissionen um 50-55% deutlich hinter dem zurückbleibt, was die Einhaltung des Pariser Abkommens gebietet. Aus wissenschaftlicher Sicht ist in der EU bis 2030 eine 75%ige Reduktion der energiebedingten* Emissionen ggü. 1990, sowie das Erreichen von Nullemissionen aus Energienutzung bis 2035-40 notwendig. 

Die Klimakrise stellt eine substanzielle Bedrohung für unsere globale Gesellschaft, die weltweite Tier- und Pflanzenwelt sowie unsere gemeinsamen Lebensgrundlagen dar. 
Ein weiterer Aufschub notwendiger Maßnahmen zur Reduktion von Treibhausgasen und zur Eindämmung der Klimakrise, lassen sich nicht mit dem wissenschaftlichen Forschungsstand vereinbaren und erhöhen das Risiko von irreparablen Schäden in unseren gesellschaftlichen Systemen (z.B. Überlastung des Gesundheitssystems) sowie wichtigen Ökosystemen.
Die Erhöhung des Reduktionsziels sollte durch ein Verfahren begleitet werden, das sektor- und ressortübergreifende Prüfungen der Emissionspfade und gegebenenfalls notwendige Anpassungen erlaubt.


*Energiebedingte Emissionen sind etwa 80% der Gesamtemissionen in der EU. Der Rest sind v.a. Emissionen aus der Landwirtschaft und prozessbedingte Emissionen der Industrie (die sind in der obigen Berechnung ausgeklammert).

Biomass is a disaster for the climate, for forests and for communities. Allowing the exploitation of the last primary forests for energy is guaranteed to make climate change worse, not better. Burning forests for fuel will not decarbonize the economy, it will not lead to carbon neutrality, and it will not make the EU a global leader in the fight against climate change.

Natural forests are our best ‘weapon’ in this fight. They are Earth’s only real carbon capture and storage devices, not to mention repositories of dwindling biodiversity. Protecting and restoring forests is essential for addressing both the climate and the biodiversity crisis. The world needs climate policy that puts natural forests first.

To paraphrase the Environmental Paper Network, the use of forests for bioenergy is encouraged by flawed accounting that considers it a “zero-emission technology”, with its true carbon cost rarely appearing accurately on any nation’s balance sheet. Future greenhouse gas “reductions” must not come at the expense of forests.

To get closer to real carbon neutrality:

1.	End reliance on burning wood as “zero carbon” renewable energy.
2.	Prioritize and incentivize the protection and restoration of natural forests.
3.	Redirect the current subsidies that the EU currently spends on cutting and burning wood to protect and restore forests.

Thank you for allowing me to submit feedback to this important process.
Michelle Connolly
Canada

Liebe EU,

es gibt klare wissenschaftliche Erkenntnisse, dass wir jetzt ganz dringend Klimaschutz brauchen. Wir haben ein "CO2-Budget", das massiv schwindet. Wir müssen jetzt aus diversen Gründen daher massiv den Klimaschutz vorantreiben:
1. Immer mehr Wissenschaftler, Versicherungen und Experten sagen, dass wenn wir unseren Ausstoß nicht schnell massiv reduzieren, dann gibt es massive Einflüsse auf unser Leben. Erste Sachen konnten wir die letzten Jahre sehen. Mehr Hitzesommer mit schlechten Ernten, mehr Hochwässer, .... dies sollten wir verhindern.
2. Die Technologien bezüglich Klimaschutz werden in den nächsten Jahren der nächste "Gigatrend". Wenn wir in Europa in diesem Thema vorne dabei sein wollen, dann müssen wir jetzt Vorreiter sein.
3. Es wäre ein riesen Vorteil für die Bevölkerung, wenn eine entsprechende Infrastruktur aufgebaut wird, z.B. Nachtzüge, erneuerbare Energien, ...
4. Jetzt in der Corona-Krise brauchen wir unbedingt wirtschaftlichen Anschub. Mit entsprechenden Konjunkturmaßnahmen, die gleichzeitig den Klimaschutz unterstützen, könnte man zwei Probleme mit einer Maßnahme lösen.

Daher möchte ich Sie bitten, dass die Klimaziele der EU jetzt sehr hoch angesetzt werden. Bitte strengen Sie sich an, dass wir sehr schnell unseren CO2-Ausstoß reduzieren. Wir als Europäer können Vorreiter und Vorbild für die ganze Welt sein. Darum bitte ich sie.

viele Grüße
Christian Sauter

In your current deliberations please look beyond just the targets and also reevaluate the global impact and far-reaching effects of biomass electrical generation. 

Biomass for energy is not green. It is not zero C02. http://mitsloan.mit.edu/shared/ods/documents/?PublicationDocumentID=4581 

Additionally, the biomass market encourages clearcutting in Canada (and in all countries that supply the fuel). 

The clearcutting management model mines the forest with long-term detrimental effects . https://www.theguardian.com/world/2019/dec/04/canada-logging-scars-forests-regenerate?CMP=Share_iOSApp_Other
Clearcutting radically and permanently disrupts the ecosystem for many species, both flora and fauna. A non-native species monoculture stand is planted and managed with greenhouse-gas-producing fertilizers and equipment. Herbicides are used to destroy “intruding” hardwoods (the best species for carbon sequestration) and eventually, biocides are needed for insect infestations which naturally follow in a non-diversified stand devoid of natural predators. 

To establish lower emission targets for greenhouse gases, the EU must understand and acknowledge that burning forestry bi-products (pellets or chips) for generating electricity produces more greenhouse gases than burning coal. Further, using forestry bi-products to produce electricity creates a market for these bi-products that leads to destructive forestry practices, far beyond your boarders, that in turn contribute significantly to the global climate emergency. 

We are all interconnected now. By removing the market for forestry bi-products, the EU will not only lower its greenhouse gas emissions but also lower emissions in the supplier countries. 

Thank you for your consideration of my comments in this correspondence.  

Aloha,
s. j. hauer, Global Citizen

While we laud the European Union for moving to more aggressive targets for Green House Gas emissions we would challenge continuing the position that “Emissions from the fuels in use, eu, shall be taken to be zero for solid and gaseous biomass.”

A recent study has shown that the net GHG emissions from biomass fuelled electrical generation are higher than coal plants. At the same time the market for forestry byproducts (chips and pellets) has driven the wide scale adoption of clearcutting as a “management” choice for forest industries. This will ultimately lead to the destruction of forest ecosystems.

We prefer even more aggressive targets than those currently being considered but most important, we  strongly urge an end to treating biomass as “zero CO2“ in the Renewable Energy Directive and the Emissions Trading Scheme.

organization: Institut Agrícola Català de Sant Isidre
feedback:
Regarding the 2030 Climate Target Plan, we would want to add some additional comments. First, the review of the climate action plans and emission reduction will go through an in-depth review of the activities and sectors that today are called 'strategic' and what strategy to follow with them in terms of emissions reduction: food, utilities, energy networks, and medical devices among others. In the same way, it will be necessary to review the role of emissions reduction of the sectors of 'discretionary consumption' mostly not incorporated  in the ETS system (the case of transport or construction), because they are the key to a rapid recovery of the economy if there is no destruction of capital (company closings, mass unemployment ...).

Second, the future ETS must take into account not only the 'issuers', but also the sectors with “sink” capacity that must be accounted for as sectors capable of putting “new rights” on the market, allowing a moderation on the price of a ton of CO2. Appropriate measures to avoid double counting should be taken, this would nevertheless provide a significant incentive for carbon sequestration strategies by having market remuneration.

Third, the increase in the EU's climate target to 2030 is not only related to Energy - although this activity is the main emitter -, the reduction of fossil hydrocarbons and the emissions that they entail globally, implies other many changes that must be accompanied by the deployment and development of the different European strategies. Thus, the Strategy on single-use plastics, and fossil raw materials in general, must have an adequate substitute in the market for renewable raw materials.

This implies the full development of the Bioeconomy Strategy, which today is hardly being rolled out. A mismatch in the “timing” of the different strategies only means that the productive sectors are left without supply alternatives, at a competitive price, for current raw materials.
The same happens when we analyze the forestry strategy at the level of the European Union, the regulations on fire prevention or the proposals for renewable energy installations in European territory with respect to the legislative proposals linked to the territorial protection of ecosystems ... they simply often turn out to be incompatible, making it impossible to adaptively and rationally use the territory of the EU aimed at the production of renewable raw materials.

To sum up, it is necessary to reform the emissions trading system with the aim of incorporating the sink sectors. It is also of interest that the different laws and strategies are coordinated at the European Union level to avoid contradictory situations that only harm the business fabric of the EU. The advancement of certain climate objectives, which foresee certain technological developments for their attainment, may be advanced when these developments have occurred, doing it the other way around is a deep recklessness and a certain risk for companies, which can easily lose all their competitiveness.

Llegó el momento del cambio de paradigma en la jardinería.

La jardinería debe convertirse en una herramienta para mejorar la resiliencia de las ciudades frente a la crisis climática, que valore más los beneficios ecosistémicos que las razones estéticas y que además ayude a la creación de mayor tejido social y conciencia ambiental. 

La mayoría de la sociedad empezamos a comprobar en nuestras vidas cotidianas la emergencia climática en la que nos encontramos, viendo cómo año tras año padecemos más calor, más sequía y más contaminación, con todo lo que esto implica para nuestra calidad de vida. 
Tal como ha reconocido recientemente la ONU, una de las muchas medidas que se deben llevar a cabo es que las ciudades se armen de vegetación y bosques urbanos, ya que las plantas absorben CO2, mejoran nuestra salud física y mental, retienen el agua, rebajan la temperatura en verano y sirven de sustento de todo un ecosistema urbano biodiverso. 

Por eso creemos que es importante que dejen de primar los criterios paisajísticos sobre los medioambientales en la gestión de la infraestructura verde urbana. Vivimos en relación directa con otros muchos elementos bióticos y abióticos y no entendemos como una actividad tan importante para la gestión de nuestro ecosistema se rige casi siempre por cuestiones estéticas o medidas cortoplacistas que no tienen en cuenta de manera holística la ecología urbana. 

Desde Arriba las Ramas hemos redactado un manifiesto que invita a una reflexión crítica de nuestros hábitos en la gestión de la vegetación y de la infraestructura verde de las ciudades. 
Porque el camino se hace al andar, hemos acompañado este manifiesto de una propuesta abierta de medidas, entre ellas priorizar el uso de planta autóctona, un mayor conocimiento y uso de la vegetación espontánea (mal llamadas “malas hierbas”), por ejemplo sustituyendo praderas de césped por praderas de plantas adventicias, una mayor diversidad de arbolado urbano, una planificación de desbroces que tenga en cuenta los servicios ecosistémicos del resto de seres vivos del ecosistema urbano (como por ejemplo los polinizadores) y alcorques biodiversos que cobren la importancia que se merecen a nivel ambiental y social, así como evitar setos monoespecíficos y favorecer aquellos que sirvan de alimento y refugio a la fauna urbana (especialmente a las aves). 

Estas medidas, además de ser compatibles con el uso público y los valores culturales y ornamentales, suponen un ahorro de los recursos económicos, aumentan los beneficios ecosistémicos y la resiliencia urbana frente al cambio climático y, con ayuda de la educación ambiental, tienen también un gran valor social al conectar a la ciudadanía con la naturaleza, fomentando así la recuperación de las raíces vinculadas al campo y la creación de tejido social a través de la biodiversidad que nos rodea.

El objetivo es que este cambio del paradigma en jardinería llegue a la administración de tal manera que lo incluya en las cláusulas ambientales de los pliegos de las licitaciones públicas y a su vez que las asociaciones empresariales lo incorporen a sus medidas de buenas prácticas.



Autor: Manuel de la Puerta Salazar.
Arriba las Ramas (arribalasramas@gmail.com) es una asociación de custodia del territorio enfocada a la plantación de árboles y la restauración de los ecosistemas.

Die Initiative der Kommission ist lobenswert, allerdings leider nicht ambitioniert genug.
Speziell in Zeiten, wo die Umsetzung von EU-Vorgaben in nationale Realität Jahre (oder teils über ein Jahrzehnt – siehe PKW Emissionen, siehe Düngemittelverordnung) auf sich warten lässt, ist das an sich lobenswerte Ziel der Kommission zu wenig drängend. Dringlichkeit ist derzeit in den Massnahmen gegenüber der Corona-Krise ersichtlich, eine ähnliche Dringlichkeit in Anbetracht der Klima-Krise höchst wünschenswert. So wie die Bevölkerung die aktuellen Einschränkungen aufgrund Corona zu akzeptieren bereit ist, ist ähnliches denkbar, wenn denn die Dringlichkeit entsprechend kommuniziert wird. Nach der Corona-Krise darf es kein Zurück zur bisherigen wirtschaftlichen Überproduktion geben; die eingeleiteten Massnahmen müssen zu einer Transformation der Wirtschaft in Richtung Nachhaltigkeit genutzt werden, und zwar mit deutlich ambitionierteren Zielen.
Und so, wie schon bisher relativ ambitionierte umweltpolitische Vorgaben (Wunschträume) in Realität oft ausgesessen wurden, wäre eine sofortige Umsetzung nur durch baldige (jährliche) Überprüfungen und Nachjustagen sicherzustellen. Wie in der Initiative angedeutet, beinhaltet der erforderliche Wandel die Transformation umweltschädlicher Industriezweige hin zu solchen, die technisches Know-How in Umwelttechnik zu investieren bereit sind. Auf diesem zukunftsorientierten Pfad muss die EU Marktführung anstreben. Fortschritt durch Technik muss zugunsten der Umwelt gehen, nicht zugunsten der Gewinne. Umweltschädigende Produkte und Produktion dürfen nicht weiterhin positiv in die wirtschaftliche Bilanz eingehen – der Begriff „Wachstum“ bedarf einer neuen Definition.
Neben den technischen Möglichkeiten, die Europa sicherlich aufweist, ist auch vor dem Hintergrund der Klimagerechtigkeit ein schnellerer Ausstieg aus den klimawirksamen Emissionen durch die EU fordern. Nicht nur hat die EU historisch einen grossen Vorsprung an CO2 Emissionen, der rückzubauen ist, sondern auch in Europa konsumierte Güter aus anderen Teilen der Welt in die CO2 Bilanz sind einzubeziehen.
Die EU muss die gesetzten Ziele daher signifikant früher erreichen.

If the EU’s purpose is to address the topic of climate change and to become better leaders in this fight, the target for 2030 to reduce GHG (green house gas) emissions by 50% or more is critical.  

My feedback is focused mostly on the area of the assessment concerned with “how the EU can increase the absorptions of CO2 emissions over time, including in its natural sinks and the role of biomass-based products and nature-based solutions.” (2030 Climate Target Plan) 

It is scientifically unsound to make claim, by the EU Renewable Energy Directives (RED), that the burning of biomass for energy is classified as “zero carbon.” This is false information and will lead to continuous and severe negative impacts on the biodiversity and carbon sink capacity of forests in Europe and North America. 

Action on climate change must never come at the expense of our forests – both here in North American where I live and have witnessed devastating losses to our forest canopy and in Europe.   

Canadian forests now sequester 30% less carbon than in 1990. In Kings County, Nova Scotia (where I reside) we have seen 15% reduction in forest cover between 2000 and 2018. This is almost entirely due to clear cut harvesting. 
Residents in Nova Scotia have repeatedly demanded a stop to the clearcutting that is devastating forests and our wildlife populations all across our province.  Our pleas fall on deaf ears as our government is entwined with the forestry industry. The government department should be regulating and monitoring the activities of the forestry industry, not advocating for them.  Clear cutting is decimating what little remains of the rich, biodiverse, uneven aged Acadian forest that once covered Nova Scotia.  

In 1958 we had 1,441,067.2 ha. (34%) of forest between 61-80 years of age; 678,149.3 ha. (16%) of forest between 81-100 years of age; 381,359 ha. (9%) of forest over 100 years of age. By 2003, we had 12% of forest between 61-80 years of age; 1.2% between 81-100; 0.3% over 100. In the 45 years between 1958 and 2003 the proportion of forest aged less than 61 years rose from 41% to 69%. In the last 17 years the pace of harvesting has risen considerably as contractors clear cut ever more, using highly efficient equipment. 

Following a clear cut, trees will, in time, regrow and begin to sequester carbon again – in 10 years or so.  It would take far longer to replace the carbon sink capacity of the forest that was destroyed. In addition, more carbon is stored in the top metre of soil in a natural forest than is contained in all the woody material above ground. When sunlight hits that newly exposed forest floor, the soil releases most of the carbon it has been storing. The only forestry we should be practicing in a climate and biodiversity emergency is closed canopy, ecological forestry. This kind of forestry would not, could not and should not produce the quantity of wood currently required by plants burning pellets for the generation or co-generation of electricity. 

Wood-fired electricity and heating-units using green wood chips for fuel emit more CO2 per unit of energy output than fossil-fired units. For example, in 2016 at the Drax Power Plant in the UK, burning coal produced 873 kilotons (kt) of CO2 per terawatt hour of electricity(TWH). Burning biomass produced 902 kt CO2 per TWH. In 2019 the Drax power station burned 7.05 million tonnes of wood pellets. 65% of those wood pellets came from the USA.
I am asking you - please do not encourage further destruction of our forests by continuing with the travesty of burning biomass for “green” energy. 
Our climate change crisis is intertwined with our biodiversity crisis.  Forests offer a natural solution for both. We need a climate policy that puts forests first. Please stop classifying the burning of biomass as “zero carbon.” End all subsidies for biomass for energy harvesting. Instead channel that money into protecting and restoring forests in the EU and at home in Canada.  Thank you!

I applaud the EU for creating policy to achieve zero carbon emissions but am dismayed that large scale biomass burning is receiving your  approval.

I own a small woodlot in Nova Scotia, Canada and am always pleased to find markets for products from my sustainably managed property. I am on the board of the Nova Scotia Woodlot Owners and Operators Association as well as the Western Woodlot Services Cooperative (WWSC). Both these organizations support small woodlot owners and encourage ecological forestry. Low value biomass for large scale operations is not compatible with ecological forestry. The WWSC does support providing biomass from silviculture operations for local heating plants such as schools and hospitals using new highly efficient wood gasification units. Neither organization endorses the large scale clear cutting of Nova Scotia forests to produce chips for export or to produce pellets for export. This is a continuation of unsustainable forest practices at a time when we need our forests for carbon sequestration and to protect biodiversity.
 
The biodiversity crisis is intertwined with the climate crisis. Protecting and restoring forests is essential for addressing both. Burning forests for fuel is destroying forests and harming the climate. Stopping this practice is FAST MITIGATION –which we desperately need.  We need a climate policy that puts forests first. 

End reliance on burning wood as “zero carbon” renewable energy. Prioritize and incentivize protection and restoration of natural forests. The EU spends billions per year on subsidies for cutting and burning wood - they should re-direct that support to restore forests. Future GHG “reductions” must not come at the expense of forests!

There are opportunities for small scale biomass operations and I believe Austria is manufacturing highly efficient wood gasification units. Again these units should be using locally supplied biomass obtained as by-products from sustainable forest silviculture operations. The EU must realize that shipping pellets from North America or even from other countries in Europe does not qualify as "zero carbon".

Dear Commission, 
I really appreciate the opportunity to give you feedback generally and especially on the climate plan as it is a real emergency. Here it is:
- Dare to be more ambitious instead of aiming at a “balanced reduction pathway” and take the Paris climate agreement seriously!  (As you see in the current Covid 19 crisis, a very large part of citizens DO accept [temporary] even strong restrictions if they understand and are convinced of the benefit – even more if they realize that it is much more easier and effective to act FAST; we’ve seen positive results of countries acting fast – and how dangerous the ecological and social tipping points will be & are already).

- Consider to the same amount ecological, economic and social aspects (justice! Also a global one), so integrate and empower the CITIZENS as well (by the way one of the 10 pillars of another deal – the Green New Deal for Europe – you probably know it, https://www.gndforeurope.com/10-pillars-of-the-green-new-deal-for-europe).
- Even if this may be a national issue, but in the present covid-19 situation, SMEs should be supported in a SUSTAINABLE way (e.g. by establishing a bonus for purchasing a cargo-carrying bicycle instead of this crazy scrapping premiums for cars as it was the case in Germany after financial crash…).
I urgently ask you to consider the feedback, discuss it and revise the climate plan to a one that respects its name. Thank you.

organization: University of Bonn, Center for Development Research
feedback:
Climate change is one of the biggest threats to our planet and humanity and I am hopeful that governments all around the world are starting to adopt policies that consider these impacts to a bigger degree than before. However, at the same time I am concerned that these policies generate increasingly perverse and unintended outcomes as we are seeing them already today. A considerable share of bioenergy is harvested from biomass from forests. Assuming an additional increase of bioenergy supported by European subsidies, this increases the demand for wood and puts additional pressure on forests leading to deforestation on behalf of the EU and its climate policy. It is problematic if biomass, and particularly wood, is considered as carbon neutral as land is not an unlimited resource. It is needed for food, housing, infrastructure, climate regulation, water regulation and all other ecosystem services we depend on.

Primary forests are the most functional ecosystems providing a bulwark against climate change in terms of mitigation and adaptation (Freudenberger et al. 2010). About 50% of above ground biomass is stored in the largest 1% of trees (Lutz et al 2018). The extensive use of forest biomass as an energy source leads to the logging of trees (often old growth trees, important carbon sinks with a high biodiversity value), the removal of large amount of dead wood (crucial for the micro climate in forests and their long-term resilience and biodiversity) and the replacement of primary forests with fast growing plantations to satisfy the market demand. As a result, burning primary forests with the aim to prevent climate change is not only irrational but even contra productive. 

Lutz, James A., et al. "Global importance of large‐diameter trees." Global Ecology and Biogeography 27.7 (2018): 849-864.
Freudenberger, Lisa, et al. "A global map of the functionality of terrestrial ecosystems." Ecological Complexity 12 (2012): 13-22.

I am encouraged that the EU is seeking to deepen its commitment to playing its part in confronting the climate crisis the whole world faces but I remain deeply concerned that the proposed strategy continues to condone the perverse proposition that burning wood for electricity is climate neutral.  As any physicist can tell you, burning wood is actually more GHG polluting than burning coal.  It is thus extraordinary that the EU perversely allows coal-fired power stations to convert furnaces to burning wood and to avoid accounting for the subsequent emissions.  

The claim that emissions attributable to burning wood can be ignored because they can be offset against sequestration within the forest from when the wood was harvested has logical validity but no basis in reality for wood derived from the degradation/harvesting of native/natural forests.  Plantation-grown wood may be more credibly regarded as 'carbon neutral' in that any emissions from burning can be offset against prior sequestration in growing the agricultural crops beforehand.  For native/natural forests, however, where emissions precede sequestration, neutrality is not a logical proposition.  

Furthermore, the EU allows imports of wood for burning in power stations without any requirement for such imports to be accompanied by offset certificates issued by a credible regulatory authority in the country of origin.  To presume, without evidence, that such offsetting is occurring is bad enough but to allow such imports when the most cursory of investigations would establish systematic degradation of carbon stores/sinks/reservoirs without significant regrowth/restoration on any timescale of interest to policy-makers is unworthy of the EU as one of the world's greatest trading blocks.  

I have spent much of my working life as a conservation campaigner in defence of native/natural forests and the biodiversity they sustain and I urge you to adopt a climate strategy that commits the EU and its member states to removing the GHG accounting perversities that allow wood to be burnt so unhelpfully.  Some years ago I had the privilege of being involved in encouraging the EU to adopt a regulation to prevent fish and fish products from 'IUU' fishing entering EU markets and in supporting the EU in using its market power to clear its fish supply chains of 'IUU' tainted product.  I am thus profoundly disappointed to find a different part of the Brussels bureaucracy so obviously involved in perverse encouragement of profoundly destructive forestry activities in non-EU countries and of condoning the actual increase in GHG emissions when claiming to be reducing them.  To claim that such burning of wood is renewable is to add insult to injury.  Such hypocrisy is not worthy of the EU.

Yours faithfully,
Alistair Graham
Tasmania, Australia

Nieuwe klimaatdoelstelling voor 2030 zeer welkom - Streven naar een volledig koolstofvrije economie en industrie in plaats van koolstofneutraliteit tegen 2050.
Het engagement van de EU om de opwarming van de aarde aan te pakken is een belangrijk signaal. Koolstofneutraliteit of een netto-nuluitstoot is echter niet hetzelfde als het vereiste volledig koolstofvrij maken van onze energiesystemen. Vertrouwen op zogenaamde negatieve emissietechnologieën (NET's) zoals koolstofafvang en -opslag (CCS) of koolstofafvang en -gebruik (CCU) is zeer riskant en houdt het huidige klimaatvijandige gebruik van fossiele brandstoffen gewoon in stand. 
De voorgestelde vermindering van de uitstoot van broeikasgassen met ten minste 50% tot 55% ten opzichte van het niveau van 1990 tegen 2030, in plaats van ten minste 40% zoals voorzien op dit moment, is dringend nodig en wordt ten zeerste toegejuicht.
Dit kan echter niet worden bereikt als de EU geen aandacht besteedt aan het volgende:
Groeiende wetenschappelijke bewijsvoering over grote negatieve impact op klimaat/milieu van gas als brand-/grondstof in energie-, petrochemie- en kunststofsector en onverenigbaarheid met EU-klimaatdoelstellingen en verplichtingen in het Parijs-akkoord. EU dient lidstaten te verplichten om overheidsfinanciering en verlenen van subsidies en/of voordelen allerlei aard stop te zetten voor projecten op basis van fossiele brandstoffen, meer uitgebreide klimaatimpactstudies uit te voeren en wetenschappelijk onderbouwde plannen op te stellen voor geleidelijke transitie in energiesector en petrochemie. De noodzaak van snelle uitfasering fossiel gas - in combinatie met hervorming van gebrekkige ETS-systeem dat grote vervuilers gratis emissierechten geeft - is een onbetwistbaar feit. Volgens studie "Natural Gas & Climate Change" (2017 - Prof. K. Anderson & Dr. J. Broderick, Universiteit Manchester) hebben fossiele brandstoffen (ook aard-/schaliegas) geen plaats in het EU-energielandschap na 2035 in een 2°C-scenario. Het IPCC-rapport van oktober 2018 over gevolgen opwarming van de aarde met 1,5°C boven pre-industriële niveaus, benadrukt echter dat men opwarming met 2°C dringend moet voorkomen en Europa het gebruik van fossiel gas zo snel mogelijk dient af te bouwen. Een recente studie van Stanford University benadrukt dat "de huidige wereldwijde opmars van gaswinning en aanverwante infrastructuur verantwoordelijk is voor sterke toename globale uitstoot uit fossiele brandstoffen" en "een bedreiging vormt voor het Parijs-akkoord en gezondheid van de planeet".  
Door experten als onnodig beschouwde fossiele-gasprojecten op 4e lijst Projecten van Gemeenschappelijk Belang (PCI) van EU, zijn nooit onderwerp geweest van een grondige klimaatimpactanalyse. Gezien hun economische levensduur veel verder gaat dan 2050, creëert dit een gevaarlijke fossiele verankering en een hoop waardeloze activa gefinancierd met overheidsgeld. Om klimaatdoelstellingen te halen moet EU onmiddellijk stoppen met subsidiëren van fossiele-brandstofprojecten op PCI-lijst. Petrochemie/plasticindustrie investeert momenteel massaal in nieuwe, klimaatvijandige installaties die nog meer plasticvervuiling genereren. IEA voorspelt dat zij snel de grootste drijvende kracht achter wereldwijde ontginning van olie en gas worden (nu al grootste industriële verbruiker fossiele brandstoffen met 14% van wereldwijde olie en 8% van primaire gasvraag)
De voorgestelde dringend noodzakelijke vermindering van de uitstoot van broeikasgassen met ten minste 50% tot 55% voor 2030 ten opzichte van het niveau van 1990 kan niet worden bereikt als de EU het huidige inconsistente gedrag van investeerders en autoriteiten blijft negeren

More and more people see the urgency to fight  Climate Change and are willing to accept far reaching rules and regulations. So please try as hard as you can to make faster progress "Transforming our world" as committed in the Agenda 2030. For realizing  the 1.5 Degree Goal, early and far reaching actions have to be taken the sooner, the better. Thank you in the name of future generations!

Dear Members of the Commission,
In my reading of your Target Plan there are several indications of which existing plans and regulations that you would like to examine. I strongly urge you to include the question of reposessing the energy sector into the public hands. We the people are ready for ambitious actions, as you are well aware. With this, climate legislation would be greatly facilitated. Furthermore, you must include the issue of biodiversity and deforestation in Europe. Finally, I miss a dicussion of the role of strengthening trade ties with countries that now emit very little CO2,  with those that create climate plans and with those that are most greatestly effected by climate change. We could increase barriers with climate offenders, as a point of discussion.

What you are proposing is only going to add more carbon into our already polluted atmosphere. Studies are showing that burning wood is worse than coal. We need to get off both if we are going to meet targets that will reduce our carbon output which will ultimately save our planet. We haven't enough time left to regenerate our forests once they have been cut down for biomass as the means for our fuel. We need to look at other alternatives such as wind, solar, and water power. We need to do this now.

Dear European Commission, 
while the plan to reduce emissions by 50-55% by 2030 is a step in the right direction, it sadly is far from enough to stop warming below 2°C, let alone 1.5°C. And scientists are warning us, that if we are not able to stop warming below these thresholds, we will cross tipping points in the climate causing feedback loops, which will further warm the climate. This must be avoided at all costs. Therefore I urge you to adopt a plan for net-CO2-neutrality by 2025 for economically stronger countries and by 2030 for the whole European Union.
With love and hope,
Adrian Kersten

Meiner Einschätzung nach sind mehrere Ziele hier falsch gesetzt:

1. Klimagerechtigkeit bedeutet, dass unterschiedliche Länder unterschiedlich schnell ihre Emissionen reduzieren müssen, z.B. Deutschland schneller als der Durchschnitt, weil höhere Emissionen stärkere Reduktionen erfordern, um eine gerechte THG-Restemission pro Kopf zu erreichen. Dabei werden schon historische Emissionen ausgeblendet, was Länder wie Deutschland noch mehr begünstigt.

2. der fünfte Sachstandsbericht des IPCC ist bereits überholt, der sechste ist in Arbeit (Veröffentlichung April 2021, derzeit wird der Entwurf von Forschern intern begutachtet) und wird die zulässigen Restemissionen weiter mindern: d.h. die Paris-Ziele wie 2050 global sind auch vor diesem Hintergrund bereits überholt.

Damit reichen Ziele wie 50 oder 55% Reduktion von THG bis 2030 bei weitem nicht mehr aus. Für Deutschland ist es eher realistisch, bis 2030 bereits ca. 90% der THG-Emissionen einzusparen und die Klimaneutralität bis spätestens 2035 zu erreichen. Eine Beispielrechnung von Prof.Rahmstorf vom PIK ist hier zu finden: https://scilogs.spektrum.de/klimalounge/wie-viel-co2-kann-deutschland-noch-ausstossen/

Erschwert wird das Ganze durch zusätzliche Emissionen von Kippelementen im Erdsystem wie denen des schmelzenden Permafrosts, der die möglichen Restbudgets weiter vermindert, hier ist sogar eine Halbierung des Restbudgets möglich mit entsprechenden Folgen für den Zeitrahmen.

Zudem muss auch die Landnutzung im Auge behalten werden, und zwar sowohl direkt in der EU als auch durch die Ernährung der Einwohner der EU.

Kurz zu den THG: CO2 als Hauptproblem erfordert einen möglichst raschen Ausstieg aus der Nutzung fossiler Energiequellen inklusive Erdgas (i.W. Methan) sowie die Beendigung des Herstellens und Nutzens von Verbrennungskraftmaschinen aller Art, z.B. Automotoren, Schiffsmotoren oder Flugzeugtriebwerken, bei letzteren beiden ist im Bestand nur in geringem Umfang ein Ersatz von Ölderivaten durch nachhaltige Biokraftstoffe z.B. aus Jatropha-Wüstenpflanzen möglich. Entsprechend muss Erneuerbaren schnellstmöglich als Ersatz zum Durchbruch verholfen werden, stellenweise kann auch auf Wasserstoff umgestiegen werden, der mit Erneuerbaren Energien hergestellt wird. Generell wird die Sektorkopplung immer wichtiger.

Bei Methan (CH4) stellt neben Lecks im Erdgastransport die Rinderwirtschaft die größte Quelle dar, die stark reduziert werden muss inklusive der Rinderfleischimporte, aber auch zuviele Schafe emittieren unnötig viel Methan. Auch fügt diese Art der Tierwirtschaft über falsche Landnutzung der Natur schweren Schaden zu: Zerstörung von Lebensräumen und Artensterben sind die Folge.

The key environmental objective of this initiative -- to address the issue of climate change and enhance the EU’s global leadership role in the fight against climate change – is laudable. Increasing the 2030 EU GHG reductions target from 40% to 50% or 55% is essential. But stronger climate action must not come at the expense of forests. This feedback will focus particularly on the area of the assessment concerned with “how the EU can increase the absorptions of CO2 emissions over time, including in its natural sinks and the role of biomass-based products and nature based solutions.” (2030 Climate Target Plan)

To date, EU Renewable Energy Directives (RED) intended to reduce GHG emissions have classified the burning of biomass for energy as “zero carbon.” This is erroneous and has had severe impacts on the biodiversity and carbon sink capacity of forests in Europe and North America. Far from being zero carbon, wood-fired electricity and heating-units using green wood chips for fuel emit more CO2 per unit of energy output than fossil-fired units. For example, in 2016 at the Drax Power Plant in the UK, burning coal produced 873 kilotons (kt) of CO2 per terawatt hour of electricity(TWH). Burning biomass produced 902 kt CO2 per TWH.

Current regulations have led to perverse subsidies such that the Drax plant in the UK received, in 2019, £861.5 million (£2.36 million per day). The EU must end the “green” classification of biomass for energy that gave rise to such subsidies. Without subsidies it is unlikely plants burning biomass for energy would be economically feasible, especially as the cost of truly renewable energy continues to drop.

Under current RED, though, solid and gaseous biomass, particularly wood and wood-waste, is the biggest source of renewable energy in the EU. It is used for the production of electricity, heating and cooling. In 2019 the Drax power station burned 7.05 million tonnes of wood pellets. 65% of those wood pellets came from the USA.

Not only does burning biomass emit significant GHGs at the smokestack, the harvesting of wood for biomass is devastating forests on both sides of the Atlantic. In the name of supposedly “green” energy, this is damaging our carbon sinks when we need them the most. Unlike other forms of carbon capture, forests are a proven, low cost, high benefit “technology.” They are sequestering carbon right now. They are also havens for biodiversity.

When a forest is clearcut, as far too many are in the EU and in North America, while trees may in time regrow and begin to sequester carbon again, they will take a minimum of ten years to do so in any significant way, and far longer to fully replace the carbon sink capacity of the forest that was removed. In addition, more carbon is stored in the top metre of soil in a natural forest than is contained in all the woody material above ground. When sunlight hits that newly exposed forest floor, the soil releases most of the carbon it has been storing. The only forestry we should be practicing in a climate and biodiversity emergency is closed canopy, ecological forestry. This kind of forestry would not, could not and should not produce the quantity of wood currently required by plants burning pellets for the generation or co-generation of electricity.

We should not assume that forests will regrow as they have in the past. Forests are already under pressure from factors related to climate change. They face increased mortality and reduced regeneration linked to stress from heat, drought, ice and wind storms, wildfires and abrupt swings in temperature. Invasive insects and plants, ozone and other forms of air pollution add to the damage. We need to support the health and resilience of forests, not destroy them.

Do the right thing! Stronger climate action must not come at the expense of forests!! That is counterproductive!

The biodiversity crisis is inseparable from the climate crisis. Forests offer a natural solution for both. We need a climate policy that puts forests first. Please stop classifying the burning of biomass as “zero carbon.” End all subsidies for biomass for energy harvesting. Instead channel that money into protecting and restoring forests in the EU. That will give us a chance to protect and restore our forests too. This is a global emergency. We must work together to solve it. Thank you. Debra Kuzyk, Nova Scotia CANADA

Permafrost, ice caps, glaciers, forests and coral reefs. With love and horror, 
Fabian Schmitt

Dear Commission, 

the 2030 Climate Target Plan is a step towards a change in climate politics. But it just remains one step of a stair, which requires more steps. The climate crisis should be treated at least like the actual corona crisis. It's a crisis that changes our livelihood for the next centuries including food sovereignty.
In addition a change has to be made as fast as possible, because otherwise we reach the tipping points, that scientist warn to reach in 10 to 15 years. According to that we should force CO2-neutrality for the year 2025.
We need a clear commitment to the 1,5°C aim - and not to the 2°C. The IPCC showed, that even 1,5°C change lead to fundamental changes threatening ecosystems and lives. 
We need a mechanism that sanctions state or economy activitys that are against the 1,5°C aim. And on the other hand we need mechanism that promote sustainable action.
We Europeans have the economic power to lead the change, the whole globe needs.

We strongly support setting the new 2030 climate goal and we propose to set it as high as possible. Since we support the CAN Europe call for an increase of the EUs 2030 climate target to at least 65% compared to 1990, we want the 2030 goal to be set on at least the proposed 55% compared to 1990.  We believe it is necessary that this 2030 goal is included in the European Climate Law, because it would be a great weakness of this piece of legislation if it is not included. Adding this goal later is weakening the whole process of strengthening EU ambitions about climate action.
The first imperative in the path towards this goal is that the loss of biodiversity should be stopped in the same time. Protecting biodiversity in this manner is not only the possible co-benefit as it is described in the chapter “Likely environmental impacts”, but it should be the defined co-effect. Climate mitigation measures should be tailored in the way that their effect would significantly contribute to stop biodiversity loss which is the second, equally life threatening global problem.
There should be an emphasis on consumption patterns and general awareness raising about their impacts on climate. The environmental (GHG) cost should be internalised in all products that are consumed in EU (regardless if they are produced in the EU or outside) – financial and tax “tools” can be very effective in this matter.
Although it seems the change of energy production is the core issue in addressing the climate change, the overall change in society – production and consumption - is necessary, specially in the fields of food production and transport. Food production should follow three imperatives: enough food for all, producing food that is healthy for people and has low environment/carbon footprint. The land should be used mostly for producing healthy food for people. Transport seems as it is something “outside our reach” – it has its own growth that “can’t be stopped”. This is not true. It is not logical that we reduce GHG emissions in transport sector in the way that they still grow. EU has to do some significant steps to allow member states to address transit transport with some “climate friendly” measures or to adopt some common measures to address this problem. We strongly support adopting measures for addressing the emissions from the maritime sector and aviation, not only inside EU, but also coming from outside.
By declaring the climate crisis the European Parliament stated that all policies and regulations should be reviewed – for the crisis measures and the path towards 2030 climate goals, this review is very important. In essence, this is about “mainstreaming” climate change (and biodiversity) through all policies and regulation (on EU and national levels). We propose to strengthen the strategic environmental assessment as an already existing tool and expand it in a way in which it would be a practical and operative tool to assess the impacts of all plans and regulations on climate.

Parvenir aux objectifs fixés sans réduire notre train de vie est illusoire. L'UE doit appuyer bien sûr l'ensemble des moyens qui peuvent nous aider à réduire l'impact GES, mais elle doit surtout revoir sa politique en mettant comme filtre de ses décisions la sauvegarde du vivant. Entre deux politiques, toujours choisir celle qui n'aura pas d'impact sur le vivant (de toute nature - animal, végétal, humain). Pour cela, l'UE ne doit plus être uniquement qu'économique et à la solde d'un système qui souhaite toujours plus de croissance, mais doit être véritablement initiateur d'un système nouveau. 
L'UE doit avoir pour mission de protéger ses habitants, son territoire, son milieu. L'UE dispose de la force et de la capacité de créer un nouveau système , un nouveau monde. C'est l'avance qu'elle prendra sur les autres continents qui détermineront son rôle au niveau international dans les années à venir. Mais pour cela, il faut une vision pour l'avenir et suffisamment de pédagogie pour expliquer aux Européens que nous devons tous aller vers un mode de fonctionnement moins énergivore, mois destructeur.
Cela implique également de disposer de courage politique pour mettre en oeuvre des mesures qui aillent dans le sens d'une décroissance. Limitation du droit au voyage en avions, en voiture. Interdictions de circulation aux véhicules individuels dans les villes, révision complète de la PAC pour encourager le retour à une agriculture à taille humaine, écologique. Mettre en place des ceintures vertes nourricières autour des villes. Verdir les villes. Soutien économiques à l'économie réelle et à une économie verte et non plus à l'économie spéculative.
L'UE doit être totalement autonome en matière énergétique, alimentaire, sanitaire. La crise du covid-19 a montré à suffisance l'absolue nécessité de disposer des moyens industriels européens capables de fabriquer tout ce dont nous avons besoin en matière alimentaire et de santé.
Il convient de mettre en place également une véritable politique du "pollueur-payeur". Pourquoi les produits importés de Chine sont-ils moins chers que ceux produits ici? Pourquoi l'avion pollueur coûte moins cher que le train pour des courtes distances, pourquoi est-ce toujours la voiture qui est avantagée d'un point de vue financier plutôt que les transports en commun? Tout cela doit changer et doit faire l'objet du nouveau système à mettre en place.
A côté de cela, il convient de commencer déjà maintenant à éduquer les nouvelles générations pour une consommation raisonnée. C'est en donnant à tous les citoyens européens une direction claire, attrayante et viable tout en intensifiant les effort d'éducation, et d'information que l'UE se retrouvera renforcée.
J'espère que l'UE sera à la hauteur du défi qui l'attend, car si elle ne l'est pas, c'est tout notre monde qui s'effondrera... et dans pas très longtemps, malheureusement.

Taking into account  the reduction potential of individual EU's countries and the current situation caused by the pandemic, which is already affecting the EU economy, the problem of reduction should be approached rationally - excessive ambitions will not help achieve new goals and will discourage citizens from acting for climate protection - something that is unreal does not encourage action.
Currently EU reduction levels are taken into account:
1) A 20% reduction target in 2020;
2) The 40% target for 2030 set by the Council in October 2014; final arrangements in the so-called the winter package was adopted in mid-2019 
3) The new target of 50-55% reduction in 2030 proposed in the Green Deal.
Given the lack of an up-to-date assessment of the impact of the new target on the EU and individual economies, the lack of financing mechanisms for accelerated reduction, the length of negotiations on the division of new reduction requirements into individual countries, as well as the possible effects of the crisis  on the ability of economies to take on new challenges, as an EU citizen, I express my opinion on the need to maintain the current level for 2030, i.e. 40%, along with the implemented legal regulations in the winter package.
Keeping the target will be a stabilizing signal for the economy. In addition, due to the possible effects of the crisis, flexibility should be assumed in the design of goals for individual years (temporary deviation from the indicator for a given year).

Utrzymanie celu będzie sygnałem stabilizującym dla gospodarki.

Z punktu widzenia polskiej gospodarki poziom emisji sektorów objętych ETS, który w 2018 r. wyniósł 201 mln ton (energetyka i ciepłownictwo systemowe -146 mln ton), ma tendencję spadkową i jest zależny od możliwego tempa  zastępowania źródeł emisyjnych (węglowych) mocami OZE i gazowymi. W okresie 2020-2030, zgodnie z symulacjami wykonanymi na potrzeby projektu  Polityki energetycznej PEP2040, a także oceną ekspercką,  nie jest możliwe zrealizowanie inwestycji w ograniczenie emisji o dodatkowe 20% w stosunku do zadeklarowanych 30% w KPEiK. 
Stąd rekomendacja utrzymania dotychczasowego celu redukcji emisji w 2030 r.

Please find IV's full position paper with a more detailed explanation on the following points in the attached document.

Amid the Covid19 outbreak and crisis, a "business as usual scenario" is not possible. Consultations and initiatives foreseen in the Commission’s Work Programme that are not essential to fighting the current crisis should be temporarily postponed. This deferral should not change the proposed measures’ content, however, it will allow policy-makers to include the Covid19 consequences into their assessment allowing them to base the consultations’ results on reliable data. This suggestion covers a number of new initiatives, which are highly important for Europe’s future, but that are not necessary now to deal with the Covid19 crisis. One example is the Commission’s plan to conduct an impact assessment on the 2030 targets. If the Commission proceeds with this plan regardless, it would fall short in taking the unfortunately likely severe Covid19-consequences on Europe’s economy and society into consideration. The assessment’s results would not be based on reliable data and therefore, could not serve as a dependable basis for further (regulatory) actions. IV therefore urges the Commission to prioritise vital projects and initiatives to fight Covid19 instead of continuing with a “business as usual scenario”.

The European Union only recently adopted legislation to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 40% until 2030 compared to 1990 levels. This is the most ambitious target among the world’s major economies while the EU only accounts for 10% of global emissions. In 2018, the European Commission proposed that the EU should become climate-neutral by 2050, which was endorsed by the European Parliament, but is still pending approval by the European Council.

The Federation of Austrian Industries (IV) stands behind the EU’s target to reduce greenhouse gas emission by 40% until 2030. The recently established framework with targets on renewable energy, energy efficiency as well as other sectoral policies would even reduce emissions by around 45% until 2030. IV asks the Commission to consider the following points for effective climate action until 2030 and beyond:

1.	Focus on implementing the 2030 targets.
2.	Avoid carbon and investment leakage.
3.	Provide predictability and investment security.
4.	The EU emissions trading system (ETS) is an effective and ambitious tool to reduce greenhouse gas emissions from the European manufacturing and energy sectors by controlling the number of issued emission certificates. The current system works well. 
5.	Work towards a global level-playing field.
6.	Ensure security of supply and affordable energy at competitive prices. 
7.	Meet Increased investment needs and establish ideal investment conditions.
8.	A strong economic pillar is a prerequisite: The need for a strong future-oriented and ambitious industrial strategy.

1.  New 2030 climate target highly welcomed - Full decarbonisation instead of carbon neutrality by 2050 needed

The EU commitment to tackle global warming is an important signal. However, carbon neutrality or net-zero is not the same as the needed full decarbonisation of our energy systems. Relying on so-called negative emissions technologies (NETs) such as Carbon Capture and Storage (CCS) or Carbon Capture and Use (CCU) is highly risky and upholds the current climate hostile fossil fuel business as usual. 

The proposed urgently needed cut in greenhouse gas emissions of at least 50% to 55% for 2030 from 1990 levels, rather than at least 40% currently, is highly welcomed.

However, this can’t be achieved if EU doesn’t pay attention to the following:

2. Significant negative climate role of gas (need for stop of public funding for fossil fuel projects, need for proper climate assessments & need for energy/petrochemical sectors phase-out plans)

Increasing scientific evidence about the negative climate role of fossil gas from the energy and petrochemical/plastic sector show the incompatibility with EU’s climate targets and our obligations under the Paris Agreement. The need for a swift phase-out of fossil gas – accompanied by a reform of the flawed Emissions Trade System (ETS) that gives free emissions allowances to big polluters – is an indisputable fact.

According to the 2017 “Natural Gas and Climate Change” study by Prof. Kevin Anderson and Dr. John Broderick, University of Manchester, “fossil fuels (including natural gas) have no substantial role in an EU 2°C energy system beyond 2035” - if Europe wants “to meet its Paris 2°C commitment”.  

However, the October 2018 IPCC report special report on the impacts of global warming of 1.5 °C above pre-industrial levels underlines the urgent need to avoid a 2°C global warming – urging Europe even more to phase-out fossil gas asap. 

A recent study by researchers at Stanford University and other institutions highlights that the current global push for fossil gas and related infrastructure is responsible for the significant rise in global fossil fuel emissions – “threatening the Paris Agreement and planet health”.  

The EU has recently voted for the 4th list of the so-called Projects of Common Interest (PCI). The fossil gas projects on the list – deemed as unnecessary by market analysts – never received a proper climate assessment. Given the fact that their economic lifespan goes way beyond 2050, this creates either a dangerous fossil lock-in or stranded assets funded with public money. To achieve the proposed current and future 2030 climate targets, the EU must stop immediately to subsidize the fossil fuel projects on the PCI list.

The IEA forecasts that petrochemicals are about to rapidly becoming the largest driver of global oil. Today, the chemical sector is already the largest industrial consumer of fossil fuels, accounting for 14% of global oil and 8% of gas primary demand. 

According to calculations recently published by the Center for International Environmental Law (CIEL), full plastic lifecycle emissions (including the extraction of fossil fuels, production, transport, consumption and disposal) alone will generate 56 gigatons of CO2 by 2050. This corresponds to 10 – 13 percent of the global carbon budget we have left to stay within a 1.5 ° global warming scenario.

However, petrochemical/plastic companies are investing right now in new, unneeded, climate hostile and plastic pollution increasing facilities - justifying these investments with current ETS and a lack of a full lifecycle climate impact assessment. 

The proposed urgently needed cut in greenhouse gas emissions of at least 50% to 55% for 2030 from 1990 levels cannot be achieved if EU ignores current inconsistent behaviour of investors and authorities.
