The unprecedented covid-19 pandemic has deeply disrupted the EU economy and has already brought enormous social and economic consequences. While efforts should remain focused on protecting the health of EU citizens and on tackling the immediate impact of social and economic consequences, we emphasise our continued support for EU’s long-term objective of climate neutrality by 2050. The European Green Deal must remain at the core of EU’s political ambition and of measures to restart economic development and a just transition in Europe. 

According to the European Environmental Agency, assuming that the EU 2030 target of 40% domestic reduction is met, faster decreases in GHG emissions will be necessary to achieve its long-term decarbonisation objective of climate neutrality by 2050 . The current EU’s 40% GHG reduction target for 2030 is not in line with the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) recommendations, neither in line with the trajectory of climate neutrality by 2050.

EUROCITIES calls on the European Commission to propose an upwards revised target binding for all member states to ensure enforcement and to prepare the European Union for the transition towards climate neutrality by 2050.

An upwards revised EU GHG reduction target by 2030 should be accompanied by a consequent revision of the 2030 climate, energy and transport frameworks, such as the Renewable Energy Directive, the Energy Efficiency Directive, the ETS Directive and the forthcoming Sustainable and Smart Mobility Strategy, to match with the overall ambition.

Achieving the goals of GHG emission reduction by 2030 and climate neutrality by 2050 will be challenging for all. But in this fight to mitigate global warming and adapt to climate change, European cities are showing the way: 64% of EUROCITIES members have already committed to become climate neutral by 2050 . Among them, 12 have committed to become climate-neutral even before 2040. Cities are an integral part of the solution: they have a wealth of expertise and experience that are hugely beneficial to developing plans and strategies, policy and regulation. Strong collaboration between EU, national and local actors will be decisive in achieving the EU 2030 and 2050 objectives.

Adequate financial support will be necessary to sustain the transformation process in cities and to meet more ambitious EU GHG reduction targets by 2030. The role of Horizon Europe will be instrumental in this transition. Similarly, the 100 climate-neutral cities mission should also enable the transition by showing the way to many more local authorities. 

As cities, we are fully committed to working with the European Commission, and with all levels of government, to tackle the challenge of climate change, to halve GHG emissions by 2030, to reach climate neutrality by mid-century  and to work towards a future where all people benefit from a healthy, resilient and safe environment.

The Inception Impact Assessment on the 2030 Climate Pact must align the EU’s climate efforts to a pathway compatible to limiting global temperatures to 1.5°C and to a just transition which leaves no one behind. 
 
The Commission’s impact assessment proposes to assess the impact of increasing the 2030 climate target from 40% to at least 50% and towards 55% in a responsible way. But the latest scientific evidence shows that this target range is clearly inadequate to limit global temperatures to 1.5°C as agreed by the European Union under the Paris Agreement.
 
As the UNEP Emissions Gap Report 2019 makes clear, global emissions need to be cut by 7.6% per year, starting now, in order to limit global warming to 1.5°C. For the EU – even without taking into account equity-related issues such as per capita emissions or responsibility for historical emissions – this means a cut of 68% by 2030 relative to 1990 levels. WWF’s position is that the EU should be aiming to cut emissions by 2030 by at least 65%, and to review this target following the global stocktake under the Paris Agreement in 2023. WWF therefore calls for the Inception Impact Assessment to assess the impacts of increasing the 2030 EU GHG reductions target to 65%. 
 
Increasing the pace of decarbonisation in light of the Paris Agreement’s objective to limit global temperatures to 1.5°C is also in line with the principle of a just transition which leaves no one behind.
 
Ensuring a just transition does not equate to slowing the transition nor reducing its ambition. Indeed, in many cases, higher ambition accompanied by a managed, supported and planned transition can bring more benefits to communities and the most vulnerable than by taking a slower route to climate neutrality. This is for 2 principle reasons: first, climate change most negatively impacts the most vulnerable and least able to adapt in society and second, it locks communities into a longer transition. So-called bridging technologies such as fossil gas require significant investments which can take up to 30 years to be recuperated and the infrastructure is of little to no use in a fully-climate neutral system. The burden of the climate impacts and the costs of potentially stranded assets are paid by taxpayers rather than the polluters.
 
When setting ambition, it is therefore essential to consider the need for decisive, substantial and consistent financing of investments to enable a faster and more direct transition. Investments in energy efficiency accelerate the transition and represent no regret solutions generating many jobs and simultaneously addressing energy poverty. Likewise, significant, early and direct support to renewables heating systems including notably by subsidising a direct switch from coal to heat pumps or other renewable heat sources will assist vulnerable and poorer communities and reduce the overall cost of the transition.
 
A just transition means that the transition to climate neutrality leaves no one behind. Costs are equitably shared and benefits spread equally. Put another way, it means that inequalities do no increase, or may even be decreased by the transition. The costs of the transition should be considered over the long term and any public support should be targeted at no regret options in the transition that place the wellbeing and empowerment of people first.

Targets: ActionAid International welcomes the initiative to increase the EU’s GHG emission reductions target for 2030. However, we believe a 50 to 55% target compared with 1990 levels is not aligned with science and equity, as it will not ensure the EU does its fair share to limit global warming to 1.5°C. Saying that the EU accounts for less than 10% of global emissions is a massive under-evaluation of actual emissions as it doesn’t reflect emissions incorporated in products and goods we import. Thus, ActionAid is pleading for reductions of at least 80% by 2030, and 100% by 2040.  As even 80% of emissions reduction would not meet the EU fair share by 2030, additional resources must be allocated to support developing countries with grant-based climate finance. In spite of having contributed little to climate change, many developing countries are particularly vulnerable to its impacts.

Policy options: We welcome the approach aiming at identifying all legislative measures needed to effectively reach more ambitious targets to achieve a just transition. We suggest, however, to take into account the post-Covid situation to determine which sectors of the economy should be supported based on their sustainability, circularity and climate-proofing. Support must also be provided to fund the transition of workers employed in unsustainable sectors of the economy towards other sectors.

On agriculture, we draw the EU’s attention to our report about how to engage in a just transition in agriculture, which identifies four key principles for such transition. 

On sustainable finance and taxation, governments should introduce mandatory regulations. Ongoing measures to make finance more sustainable are too slow, as shown by the damaging short-term financial speculation during the Covid-crisis. We need to put an end to short term speculation and investments in fossil fuels. A progressive Climate Damages Tax on oil, gas and coal extraction following the Polluter Pays principle could raise significant funds needed for the just transition. Also, to respond to Covid-19, Europe must adopt a financial transaction tax to reduce high-frequency and automated trading and introduce a Covid-19 Wealth Tax and a tax on excess corporate profits. When considering EU Carbon Border adjustment, potential impacts on developing countries must be assessed. [https://actionaid.org/publications/2020/actionaid-discussion-paper-eu-carbon-border-adjustment] Finally, at least part of the revenues raised by European environmental taxes and Financial Transaction tax should fund climate-related losses and damages in developing countries.

Policy coherence for Development: The inception impact assessment acknowledges that “demand for critical raw materials that are crucial for the deployment of green technologies will increase significantly”. The principle of Free, Prior and Informed Consent must play a key role to ensure that this growing demand for minerals and the transition in energy does not cause land grabs, environmental destruction and socio-economic harm from scaled-up mining. Furthermore, in order to reduce the need for mining of raw materials, recycling of metals and minerals in and outside of the EU should be done on a larger scale to increase sustainability. 

Socioeconomic & environmental standards for new raw materials: Businesses have the responsibility to address adverse human rights and environmental impacts of their operations. The EU should adopt mandatory regulation for businesses to avoid such adverse impacts, especially in countries where the legal framework is weak. The EU must ensure that companies supplying EU countries with renewable energy sources like solar and wind energy abide by responsible business standards. The EU conflict minerals regulation does not cover copper and cobalt, also linked to human rights abuses. The EU should ensure that the extraction of minerals in developing countries comes with tax transparency and no tax avoidance.

Natural Resources Institute Finland (Luke) supports the Commission’s proposal of EU’s climate neutrality by 2050, tightening the EU’s GHG emission reductions target for 2030, as well as the goal of a just and fair transition. In order to support the Commission in its work, Luke suggests the following elements to be considered in the Climate Target Plan.

The faster the transition, the more carefully the transformation of the relevant industries needs to be planned. In the transition, the industries using natural resources, especially agriculture and forestry, will face both challenges and opportunities. When re-designing the EU climate and energy policy framework and in order to utilize the arising opportunities and tackle the challenges, a systematic understanding of the processes and structures as well as their variation across the MS’s and regions is essential. Therefore, referring to the Section D, Luke suggests that in ex-ante policy impact analysis, the EU should exploit the knowledge, data collection, and modelling capacities developed in H2020 projects, e.g. the DIABOLO  project .  

The inception impact assessment anticipates further development of actions under the Green Deal, such as the circular economy, the EU industrial strategy, sustainable and smart mobility, the greening of agriculture policy, and preserving biodiversity. Luke emphasizes that bioeconomy should also be acknowledged. For example, wood can replace fossil-based raw materials needed for hygienic products, packaging, textiles, and construction. This is also linked to the EU’s industrial strategy and investments: in order to improve material and energy efficiency and to decrease the negative environmental footprint, the EU needs a profound transformation of production technologies and processes along the value-chains and networks of sustainable, circular bioeconomy. By modernizing its green industry, the EU could develop its competitive advantage and secure a fair transition while reaching the objective of climate neutrality.  

As to agriculture, it is important to recognize the specific characteristics in production conditions in the national and regional scales. Special attention should be paid to agriculture in regions where natural conditions such as soil type (i.e. peat soils) create a potential source of high GHG emissions. In rural areas, policy measures and instruments should provide a just and fair compensation for reaching the GHG reduction targets. Furthermore, as it is likely that supporting only investments aimed to promote emission reduction technology in agriculture is not effective enough in economic terms, the fair and just transition in agriculture may need instruments for direct compensation of farmers’ income losses. A similar approach should also be adopted in those rural areas where peat production for energy and other activities with high GHG emissions contribute greatly to the economic viability of local communities.

The EU’s land use sector - forests especially - is an important carbon sink. However, in the changing climate with frequent natural disturbances, the risk of losing carbon storages in forests increases. Therefore, in the EU policy making, the vital role of sustainable and profitable forestry that enables the active management and mitigation of large-scale disturbances (e.g. drought, forest fires, storms, pests, floods) should be acknowledged. The risk of unfavorable and uncontrollable development of the carbon sinks and storages of forests are already materializing in several MS’s. This emphasizes the need for open, multilateral, and science-based discussion how to balance between the different uses of forests while simultaneously increasing forests’ resilience in the changing climate.

Referring to Section B, R&D&I is required particularly in the fields of sustainable, circular bioeconomy and transition to material and energy efficient value chains. The EU could be a forerunner also in R&D&I in these fields.

organization: ECRA - The European Climate Research Alliance
feedback:
ECRA - The European Climate Research Alliance
Submission for feedback to Commission inception impact assessment roadmap for the 2030 Climate Target Plan

For the past years, scientists have relentlessly alarmed decision makers and citizens that all commitments combined are nowhere near to avoid climate breakdown. The Special Report of the IPCC on Global Warming of 1.5°C has shown that missing the 1.5°C temperature target all countries have agreed to under the Paris Agreement entails severe additional damages to the global ecosystem and increases the chances of hitting systemic tipping points that could spiral global heating out of human control. In addition, the recent UNEP Emissions Gap report has underlined that current efforts will only limit global temperature increase to above 3°C above pre-industrial levels by the end of the century. The report also stressed that in order to keep temperature rise to 1.5°C all countries need to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions annually by 7.6% between now and 2030, implying a 2030 climate target of at least 65% for the European Union. In light of the EU’s global and historic responsibility and capacity to act and the equity principles underpinning the Paris Agreement, the impact assessment must also consider emission reduction pathways achieving higher than 55% emissions reductions by 2030 and climate neutrality by 2040 in order to provide for a reasonable likelihood of keeping the 1.5°C goal of the Paris Agreement attainable.

The role of science was of high importance and continues to be. Science and evidence-based knowledge needs to stay an underlying principle of decision making, in particular for areas of Climate Action and climate targets. ECRA - the European Climate Research Alliance - and numerous other organisations and networks are happy to support and inform decision-makers in their processes, whether on the micro, national, or supernational (EU), or international level; for weather and climate trends and climate interaction with other natural processes.

Fortum welcomes the Commission’s approach to the revision of the 2030 climate target including the Inception Impact Assessment and consequent Public Consultation. Taking into account the significance and wide-ranging impacts of the initiative, such an inclusive and transparent preparatory process is most appreciated. 
The EU should set targets and implement policies in line with the Paris Agreement. Fortum strongly advocates the climate neutrality target for 2050, because it will increase long-term predictability of climate policy and provide a signal for low-carbon investments.
Following the 2050 target, a cost-efficient emission reduction pathway towards 2050 should be established. Intermediate climate targets for 2030 and 2040 should take into account cost-efficiency, effectiveness and fairness of GHG emissions reduction. Focus should be on early action. This may necessitate higher targets for 2030-2040 than the linear pathway from today until 2050 would otherwise assume. Investments after 2030 to achieve climate neutrality by 2050 would most likely be frontloaded in case of higher ambition to 2030. 
Fortum fully supports the higher ambition (50-55%) for 2030, but highlights the fact that the intermediate targets need to be reasonably achievable. The transition should be just and socially fair, meaning that costs should not be too high and EU financial instruments should be used to allow affordable energy transition to all. 
The current 2030 three-target (climate, renewables, energy efficiency) approach needs to be carefully reconsidered and revised. In our view, there is no need for separate renewable energy or energy efficiency targets after 2030. Climate target, carbon pricing and cross-sectoral flexibility would be the most cost-efficient, technology neutral and flexible set of tools to drive the low-carbon investments. 
In the context of an increased climate target for 2030, a decisive issue is to allocate the additional emission reduction efforts between the three sectors (ETS, non-ETS and LULUCF) and to allow increased flexibilities across sectors. The Communication following the 2030 Impact Assessment should provide a set of options for the sectoral allocation of the emission reduction efforts needed to reach the revised 2030 target. Following this, a robust impact assessment is needed for various options in each sector (e.g. how to increase the ETS ambition, increase of LRF/cap rebasing/etc). In Fortum’s opinion, the EU ETS sector with an extension to some new sectors could take the main responsibility for the increased emission reduction effort. 
Currently the ETS covers about 45% of the EU GHG emissions, but this share is expected to decrease to 35% by 2030. To maintain the key role of the ETS, it is important to have more sectors under the ETS cap. At the same time, non-ETS sectors have an increasingly important role in decarbonization of society, but in many member states non- ETS sectors are costly to decarbonise, which highlights the importance of cost-effectiveness. As the EU ETS is the most cost-effective policy instrument at the EU’s disposal, the priority should be given to extending the ETS instead of relying on less-efficient national policies. Fortum supports the ETS extension especially to heating and cooling sector.
Carbon dioxide removal and negative emissions will play an important role when the climate targets are becoming more stringent. European legislation currently poorly recognizes the technological solutions for carbon removal and does not provide any economic incentives for their deployment. The 2030 target setting should take into account carbon removals and negative emissions and the Commission should take an initiative to develop policy options and regulatory changes in order to integrate CO2 removal into the revision of legislation in 2021. In Fortum’s opinion, inclusion of CO2 removals and negative emissions in the EU ETS would be the most feasible option.

CERMI is a responsible and proactive organization from civil society;  that is the reason why it bets the following demands so that the European Commission's 2030 Climate Change Plan:
1.	Incorporate universal accessibility in all the communication and dissemination actions of The Plan, paying special attention to specific actions to raise awareness and training on climate change.

2.	Maximize employment opportunities for people with disabilities, and minimize the negative impacts of the transition. In the context of the high global unemployment rate and low activity rate of people with disabilities, as well as the persistence of discrimination, a fair transition, with its inherent focus on social inclusion and the eradication of poverty, offers the unique opportunity to lead to greater empowerment of people with disabilities, minimizing the negative impacts of the economic transition.

3.	Establish alliances with civil society organizations representing persons with disability and their families. This is essential to add new voices to the green agenda and above all to incorporate inclusion and accessibility to all political and awareness actions related to the climate emergency.

4.	Address the causes of uprooting, which devastate rural areas, by promoting policies, strategies and actions for economic development and respect for the environment. In addition to “green” results, vital solutions are needed for all people, including those who have disabilities, to remain in their environment of origin and choice, with quality of life. The incessant depopulation of rural areas and the disappearance of the peasantry are amongst the causes that are causing the climate crisis that the world is experiencing, so this phenomenon must be attacked with full energy, making the rural environment a decent, inclusive and green space.

I think this is a very valuable step, as it is important to set an ambitious target to ensure that the transition is driven as strongly as possible, while also recognizing the potential side effects, both positive and negative, of the low carbon transition.  Undoubtedly there will be resistance, particularly from those who have invested in infrastructure or equipment that comes under threat of being obsolete before its time; this emphasizes the importance of an objective, up-to-date evidence based approach to decision making, both so that policy is clear and that companies have as much information as possible to make good decisions.  With this in mind, I want to stress that it is important to consider the full system impacts of decisions, or in the transport sector a well to wheel approach so that emissions aren't just shifted from being reported at one sector of the economy to another.

organization: Ministry of the Environment of Republic of Estonia
feedback:
Estonian input to the Public consultation related to 2030 Climate Target Plan (Roadmap)
Estonian positions:
Estonia is fully committed to act decisively and ambitiously in order to achieve climate neutrality in the EU by 2050. In order to turn this into a success story for every Member State and the EU as a whole, we need to create the right enabling conditions and incentives. In order to ensure a just transition, where truly no one is left behind, adequate EU level funding, flexibility and realistic goals have to be set. 
Estonia is planning to reduce its GHG emissions by 70% by 2030 compared to 1990. Additionally, we intend to have 42% of our energy consumption from renewable sources by that time.
Re-opening the 2030 targets needs to be based on a solid impact assessment on sector and Member State level and take into account the trajectory of the whole EU as well as every Member State individually. The assessment has to build on the National Energy and Climate Plans (NECPs) for 2030 and take into account the planned contribution of individual Member States towards the EU objective. In the current situation, the impact assessment also needs to take into account the socio-economic situation that has developed as a consequence of the Covid-19 pandemic and the resulting short-term as well as potential long-term changes in the structure of economy and their estimated impacts/implications on the achievement of the EU climate policy targets for 2030.
The analysis made on the impacts and possibilities of increasing Estonia’s climate targets in 2019 showed that altering the already agreed target levels for 2030 is not necessarily needed to achieve climate neutrality in Estonia by 2050, since our chosen track is already ambitious enough. Furthermore, it takes time for investments to result in actual reductions of greenhouse gas emissions. Thus, the actual progress made needs to be taken into account when adjusting the goals for the 2030–2050 period.
Further analysis is needed on the impacts the increasing of the targets have on the economy, the natural environment and society at large. In doing so, the setting of a possible new EU-wide target for 2030 must take into account the targets already set by Member States and their contribution to the overall EU target as reflected in the NECPs. It is also appropriate to discuss to what extent the move towards an EU-wide target could be supported by the instruments and financial means foreseen from the EU budget within the next Multiannual Financial Frameworks. The impacts of potential amended target levels on the budgetary needs as well as vice versa need to be taken into account when negotiating and shaping the next EU multiannual budget priorities and rules.
It is important for Estonia that the Member States have sufficient flexibility, both between EU ETS, ESR and LULUCF sectors as well in the design and implementation of their plans. The possibility to allocate free allowances shall continue until the end of the period in accordance with the agreed rules in the sectors exposed to carbon leakage.
If the agreed EU level targets 2030 will be revised, the Member States contributions made so far must be taken into account. Large-scale investments and additional measures are needed in all sectors already today. Achieving the ESR objective is especially challenging. In 2018 ESR sectors in Estonia made up about 30% of Estonia's total GHG emissions and this share is increasing. The current ESR commitments are already causing difficulties, as in 2005 Estonia had the lowest emissions in the ESR sector in a couple of decades. Efforts are needed to increase active mobility, reduce congestion and shift freight to an environmentally friendly alternative.

EUSTAFOR welcomes the European Commission’s initiative to develop a Communication for setting the climate target for 2030, within the objective of climate neutrality by 2050. As stated in the Roadmap, the EU’s land use sector (agriculture land, forests and other natural land) is presently a net sink of CO2, meaning that it removes more CO2 from the atmosphere than it releases GHGs. It is estimated that EU forests and the forest- based sector currently contribute to the overall climate mitigation by absorbing about 13% of the EU’s total emissions .  
EUSTAFOR notes the fact that the potential risk of carbon leakage is acknowledged by the Roadmap. Forests and forest products function as a cornerstone of Europe’s bioeconomy. They have a long history of providing a sustainable alternative to fossil-based materials and fossil energy, helping decouple economic growth from resource depletion and adverse environmental  impacts. 
Sustainable forest management (SFM) improves the ability of forests to maintain and enhance carbon sinks and stocks, including by transferring carbon to wood products . In order to maximize the potential of forests to regulate climate, they must be actively and professionally managed to make them “climate-fit”. SFM aimed at providing biomass, timber, non-wood resources and other ecosystem functions and services, can lower GHG emissions and can contribute to adaptation. Therefore, State Forest Management Organizations with their knowledge and expertise, can actively contribute to the initiative of assessing how to increase the absorptions of CO2 emissions over time, including in its natural forest sinks and the role of biomass-based products and nature-based solutions. This should be done within the framework of the EU Forest Strategy, including by the proper involvement of experts from the Member States and stakeholders through the Standing Forestry Committee and the Civil Dialogue Group on Forestry and Cork. 
EUSTAFOR shares a view that the best practical way to include forests and forest management into overall climate and energy framework, including the upcoming sustainable finance framework would be/was to use the risk-based approach for forest biomass as applied in the Renewable Energy Directive (recast) which properly covers sustainability concerns in forestry and which was adopted by all respective EU institutions and Member States. This would avoid confusion, legal uncertainty and subsequent restrictions to investments in the forestry sector. 
The objective of this initiative is to propose an increased climate target for 2030 to prepare the EU for the transition towards climate neutrality by 2050, including through an amendment of the recently proposed European Climate Law. EUSTAFOR wishes to express its concern that the current proposal for the Climate Law is not enough focused on phasing out fossil use. It is very focused on no net emissions without exactly defining what that means. It might mean that we will still have lots of fossil energy and products in the system, expected to be compensated by the forest carbon sink. That might also lead to new demands for setting aside forest lands, which is a risky climate strategy considering storms, insects, fires. Climate change has a significant impact on forests. A case in point is the recent severe damage in 1,2 million hectares
of European forests resulting from extreme weather and climate events, followed by pests and diseases, throughout Europe. Our members report that over 36 million m3 of wood have been lost and recovery will require additional workforce and funding of up to 800 million EUR, presenting both logistical and financial challenges for many state forest organizations. Well-designed EU strategies and financial instruments are needed more than ever! Only healthy and thriving forests can efficiently provide climate-related services.

Sehr geehrte Damen und Herren,

ich habe Ihre Initiative gelesen und bin froh darüber, dass überhaupt eine Initiative besteht. Leider muss ich feststellen, dass dies viel zu wenig ist! 

Ihre Ziele sind nicht vereinbar mit dem 1,5°C Ziel. Im IPCC Sonderbericht zu 1,5°C globaler Erwärmung wird eine Reduktion der Treibhausgasemissionen bis 2030 um 45% gegenüber dem Jahr 2010 gefordert. Davon sind Ihre Ziele weit entfernt! Und sogar in diesem PCC Sonderbericht zu 1,5°C globaler Erwärmung wird nur eine Wahrscheinlichkeit von 50% der Einhaltung des 1,5°C Ziels anvisiert. Außerdem sind dort noch nicht alle Erkentnisse enthalten und der IPCC bringt strukturell sehr konservative Schätzungen hervor. Sogenannte Kipppunkte wurden beispielsweise gar nicht berücksichtigt. 
Wie weit sind die CCS Technologien, die ja Teil des IPCC-Szenarios sind, das der Welt eine Dekarbonisierung ERST 2050 erlauben würde. Die EU müsste bald schon in riesigem Umfang Negativemissionen vorweisen können - wenn sie diese Aussicht nicht realistisch vermitteln kann, betreibt sie Cherry-Picking.
Aus diesen Gründen sind Ihre Ziele also nicht einmal mit dem Pariser Abkommen vereinbar. Sie sagen, eine Führungsrolle ist gefragt, da der weltweite Fortschritt bezüglich der Pariser Ziele unzureichend sei. Eine Führungsrolle würden Sie aber nur dann einnehmen, wenn die EU das Pariser Abkommen ernst nimmt. Das 1.5°C Ziel einzuhalten wäre eine Führungsrolle. Wir fordern von der EU eine Politik, die das Leben auf dem Planeten schützt und diesen auch für künftige Generationen lebenswert erhält.

Des Weiteren haben Sie keine globalen Gerechtigkeitsannahmen in Ihre Ziele miteinbezogen. Die EU Staaten emitieren schon viel länger Treibhausgase als andere Nationen, insbesondere im globalen Süden. Außerdem sind wir wirtschaftlich viel besser aufgestellt. Es wäre also nur fair, wenn wir auch früher damit aufhören würden. Auch beziehen Sie Emissionen nur auf Emissionen IN Europa, Emissionen für europäischen Konsum im Ausland werden nicht mit einbezogen. Das ist ein klarer Denkfehler.

Sie bestätigen, dass durch eine schnellere Reduktion der Treibhausgasemissionen die Ausführung von Artikel 37 aus der Charta der Grundrechte verbessert und dabei keine anderen Grundrechte beschränkt. Konsequenterweise müssten Sie dann schnellstmöglichst Treibhausgasemissionen verringern, um eine möglichst große Gewährleistung der Grundrechte sicherzustellen. Im Gegensatz dazu würde ein zögerliches Handeln Einschränkungen der Grundrechte bedeuten.

Und selbst, wenn man Ihre Zielsetzung korrekt findet: Sie erwähnen in Ihrem Papier, dass Sie einen "ausbalancierteren" Weg bis dahin wollen. Dabei wir nicht berücksichtigt, dass es am Anfang leichter ist Emissionen einzusparen, hinterher wird es schwieriger. Für einen ausbalancierten Weg müsste also am Anfang viel mehr eingespart werden als am Ende, damit es immer mit ähnlichen Anstrengungen verbunden ist.

Sie sagen, die EU wolle tun "whatever it takes", um klimaneutral zu werden. Handeln Sie auch danach! 
Ansonsten soll Ursula von der Leyen die Wahrheit sagen: "Wir tun nicht genug, um eine sichere Zukunft für die junge Generation herzustellen. Wir nehmen eine Erhitzung des Planeten von 3°C bis zum Ende des Jahrhunderts in Kauf sowie die Überschreitung fataler klimatischer Kipppunkte. Wir haben keine Ahnung, wie die Zivilisationen mit den dann eintretenden Zusammenbrüchen umgehen können"

Insgesamt sind dies alles also viel zu geringe Ziele, da es um den Erhalt unserer Lebensgrundlagen geht! Wir müssen uns also höhere Ziele setzen und sofort so schnell wie möglich Treibhausgasemissionen reduzieren. Darum fordere ich, dass wir eine Reduktion der Treibhausgasemissionen auf Netto-Null bis 2025 für die wirtschaftsstarken EU Staaten und bis mindestens 2030 für die wirtschaftsschwächeren EU Staaten
anstreben. Dabei sollen auch durch die EU verursachte Emissionen in anderen Staaten miteinbezogen werden.

organization: ARRCC - Australian Religious Response to Climate Change
feedback:
ARRCC, the Australian Religious Response to Climate Change, is a stakeholder insofar as we all share one biosphere. We commend the EU’s positive goal of cutting greenhouse gas emissions 50 – 55% by 2030 on 1990 levels, but strongly opposes biomass burning for energy as one pathway to achieving this. From our diverse faith traditions, we believe that humanity has been called to be stewards of our sacred earth and that policies are best guided by scientific advice, not from self-interested forestry or extractive industries. For the best sources on biomass burning, please see: https://www.biomassmurder.org/research/index.html 

The current EU acceptance of burning biomass for energy is a grave mistake. For the equivalent weight, it causes more greenhouse gas pollution than coal burning and reduces much-needed carbon sequestration because of the destruction of forests. It is not somehow equivalent to other renewable energy sources. It is argued that forests do eventually regrow, but this fails to take into account the slow pace of regrowth and the degradation of carbon sequestration during the harvesting process. The net impact is to greatly increase in emissions, not decrease it. 

It is outrageous that the practice diverts massive national and EU subsidies away from authentic renewable energy generation which could, in fact, reduce emissions. This is an additional loss for the biosphere and creates a further risk to humanity's future.

In the meantime, the EU and humanity as whole loses valuable biodiversity in the forests exploited to feed the biomass-burning power plants, some of those forests being in North America. It is a tragic waste which will be lamented by our children and grandchildren.

These presented goals are not enough to stop the devastating effects of the climate crisis now and in the future and also not enough when trying to go for 1.5 degrees. Although I appreciate that you try to intensify the efforts in light of the clear feedback based on the poll that EU-citizens see climate change as a threat, I do not understand why it is still more important to ensure economic growth instead of taking science serious and act in a social just way. More important than firms and a number should be the well-being of people. It also concerns me a lot that the emissions of consumption of people in the EU are produced in the global south and they are not counted in your calculation. The EU should take much greater efforts to be a role model as other countries should be given the chance to take longer. People in these countries are the victims of the accumulation of wealth the countries in the global north gained by exploiting people of other parts of the world over centuries. Thus, global climate justice is not considered in the new strategy and this is not acceptable. I am really disappointed that the EU does not do whatever it takes but is still far from taking measures that would reduce emissions to a level which can sustain a planet to live on even though people understand the risk and ask for a political answer. In my opinion this should mean that the rich EU-countries should at least head for carbon neutrality by 2025. I am also hoping for citizens' assemblies on EU-level to improve the democratic process of the EU when figuring out a plan to reduce emissions. At the moment the structures fall short in considering people from different backgrounds which could bring more just outcomes, while listening too much to big companies which destroy the environment for short term profit. 
To conclude, I hope that this new strategy will be improved to take measures which could actually lead to the goal agreed upon in Paris (1.5 degree), putting people in the center instead of the economy, consider climate justice and try to implement more democratic ways for decision-making (citizens' assemblies).

Climate change is the biggest threat we face. But unfortunately we havn´t responded to this threat as decisive as to the current corona crisis. But we can learn from the reaction to corona - if governments understand the nessecity to act on climate change, then we´ll have a chance to limit climate change an save lives. But still EU and national governments invest in fossil fuel infrastructure all over the continent. This is like forcing people to gather in times of corona.

If the coronavirus crisis has shown anything is that the climate change is the most important issue of the 21st century. Many scientists agree that such crisis are climate-change induced or at least facilitated. Aside even from such pandemic, this is our survival that is at stake. The European commission needs to take stronger and faster actions to slow global warming and to transit towards climate-neutrality. The safety and survival of all future generations will be severely impacted by the measures taken today or by the delay in taking such action. It is vital that the European Union fulfills its obligates and assumes its responsibility in that respect. The time to try and reverse the human activities' impact on the planet will be soon gone.

External effects can compleately reverse well-intentioned measures. Imported products that rise overall carbon emissions such as biofuels from oil palm or soybean oil (still double as harmfull as normal diesel) have not only to be banned as climate smart substitutes, but to negative external emissions effects have to be considered in calculations if imported. Carbon foodprint data is already availlable at large scale and a lot of reasearch in this area is ignored within policies. The carbon footprint, as well as the ecological footprint of imported products, mostly those which have alternatives here that are included in calculations and measures) have to be considered in targets and policies. 
An example: It is a shame that as consumer you still cannot choose to exclude palm oil when refueling your car, which involves EU citizens unwillingly in enormous external ecological degradation and ghg-emissions (the plans to exclude palm oil only until 2030 are still a scandal and does not include soybean oil or other products), as EU policies stipulate addition of 10% of biofuels. Such miscalculation (also excluding NOx emissions) and contra-productive effects are known since years and the 2030-target-policies should not be allowed to exclude huge external ecological or ghg-emissions effects through imports of various products, including various agricultural products, such as fodder grains for meat production. Strong measures within the EU do not help if emissions are externalized or if there are no standards and rules for international importers and producers that destroy climate elsewhere.
Further reading for "imported" carbon emissions: https://www.carbonbrief.org/mapped-worlds-largest-co2-importers-exporters

The EU's climate objectives can only be achieved if ambitious recycling targets are set, which must be accompanied by landfill bans in all Member States for combustible waste. In times of the corona crisis, massive measures will be taken, and this must also be possible in connection with the climate crisis, otherwise we will have an additional raw materials crisis in the future.

It is high time that we also changed our approach to resource consumption, and a change in the use of raw materials is urgently needed. Global material consumption has tripled in recent decades and is expected to double in the next 40 years without intervention. Recycled materials cover only 12% of the EU material demand! High recycling rates for paper and glass - published by the statistical offices - conceal the still poor "reuse rates" across all material sectors. However, for reasons of security of supply, a genuine recycling system for all raw materials (metallic, mineral but also bio-based) must be introduced urgently. Especially the so-called "future technologies" groan under supply bottlenecks and fluctuating prices. Important raw materials, which are used for technologies such as energy efficiency or digitalisation, are not available in sufficient quantities at the current growth potential. 
The majority of products marketed in the EU today are mainly based on unsustainable and sub-optimal use of resources. Many products are short-lived, non-reusable and irreparable. This still leads to a high volume of waste in the EU. Annual increases of 5% have been recorded since 2010 alone. Much of the waste is not recycled, a considerable proportion is still landfilled (23 %) and is thus lost to the economic cycle. In addition, millions of tonnes of waste are exported, which also means that they are lost to the European recycling industry.  

Sales and market conditions for recycling raw materials urgently need to be improved. The public sector is in demand on several fronts. On the one hand, it must set an example for increased use, but also remove obstacles to reuse in the EU product, consumer and chemical regulations.  It is hoped that the new Green Deal Action Plan and the Climate Plan 2030 will drive forward a policy for "sustainable products" in order to promote the design, production and marketing of sustainable products. Minimum requirements are planned to prevent environmentally harmful products from being placed on the EU market. Re-use and repair will also be prioritised over recycling.

We are in dire need of stronger initiatives from governments and the EU in terms of climate change regulations. Imposing lower emissions to member states is not only a desirable goal, but a necessary one. Our survival is at stake. 

I have studied and lived in both France and the UK. Most people I know and met, whether in France or the UK, are well-aware of the necessity of changes and are asking for them. The overwhelming general opinion of EU citizens is for stricter measures regarding climate action. We need the EU to step in and lead by example. Do not let politics and governments drive you away from these fundamental goals. 

Thank you for offering a stronger course of action. We can do this.

Der Climate Target Plan der Europäischen Union ist eine notwendige und begrüßenswerte Initiative. Dennoch reichen die beabsichtigten, gegenüber dem Green Deal verbesserten Etappenziele bei der Reduktion der Treibhausemissionen nicht aus! Das im Pariser Klimaschutzabkommen vereinbarte Ziel, die Erderwärmung auf 1.5 Grad zu begrenzen, erfordert ein tiefgreifendes Umdenken in Wirtschaft und Gesellschaft, und die erforderlichen Maßnahmen müssen so schnell und konsequent wie möglich vereinbart werden, Klimaneutralität bis 2050 ist viel zu spät! Schon jetzt befindet sich das Klima vermutlich nah an gewissen Kipppunkten, die, einmal erreicht, einen nicht mehr aufzuhaltenden Domino-Effekt verursachen (auftauende Permafrost-Böden, Waldbrände, sich erwärmende Meere, abschmelzende Gletscher), der der Menschheit die Kontrolle letztendlich aus der Hand reißt und unseren Planeten in großen Teilen unbewohnbar werden lassen wird.  Erkennen Sie und kommunizieren Sie die Gefährlichkeit der Lage gegenüber den Bürger*innen Europas und machen Sie endlich wissenschaftsbasierte Erkenntnisse zum Leitstern Ihrer politischen Arbeit, wie jetzt in der Corona-Krise, wo die Empfehlungen von Ärzt*innen und Statistiker*innen die Handlungen der Regierungen begründen und nicht Interessen der Lobbyvertreter!
Europa hat gegenüber dem Rest der Welt eine ungeheure Verantwortung, weil unser Wohlstand, beginnend mit der Kolonialzeit, auf der Ausbeutung von Ressourcen anderer Länger- Natur, Rohstoffen und menschlicher Arbeitskraft- aufbaute und noch immer aufbaut. Daher müssen wir eine Vorreiter-Rolle spielen bei der Reduktion von CO2 und alles dafür tun, dass das Artensterben und die weitere Vernichtung von Lebensräumen gestoppt wird! Wenn wir es nicht schaffen, wie können wir ärmere Länder dazu bringen, alles in ihren Kräften nötige zu veranlassen, um ihrerseits das Klima zu schützen? Streben Sie Klimaneutralität bis 2030 an anstelle erst 2050, verabschieden Sie sich endlich vom toxischen Zwang des wirtschaftlichen Wachstums, schaffen Sie wirtschaftliche Anreize für eine Postwachstumsgesellschaft und beziehen Sie mithilfe von Bürger*innenversammlungen die Bevölkerung Europas in den Prozess mit ein. Nur so kann es gelingen, einen sozial gerechten und von allen aktzeptierten Strukturwandel herbeizuführen. Eine bessere, gesündere, schönere Welt für alle ist möglich, wenn wir unsere kleinlichen und gierigen, auf kurzfristige Befriedigung ausgelegten Zwänge ablegen, über nationale Grenzen hinweg gemeinsam auf dieses Ziel hinarbeiten.

Hallo Europäische Kommission,
ich möchte Sie daran erinnern, dass Sie mit dem Pariser Klimaabkommen das Ziel gesetzt haben den globalen Temperaturanstieg dieses Jahrhunderts auf deutlich unter 2 °C zu begrenzen. Es gibt Studien die besagen, dass selbst das 2 °C Ziel nicht ausreicht, um irreversible Rückkopplungsprozesse, die das Weltklima weiter anheizen, zu verhindern. Der IPCC gibt an, die Welt muss bis 2050 klimaneutral sein (wobei bewusst „bis zu 100 Milliarden Tonnen Kohlendioxid“ nicht mitgezählt werden, die durch die Instabilität von Permafrost-Böden und Feuchtgebieten freigesetzt werden könnten).
Ihr Vorschlag, die Treibhausgasemissionen um mindestens 50 % bis 55 % gegenüber dem Niveau von 1990 zu reduzieren, reicht demnach lange nicht aus, um diese Ziele zu erreichen! Ich fordere deutliches Handeln von Ihnen und schlage eine Reduktion der Treibhausgasemissionen auf Netto-Null bis 2025 vor! 
Sie sagen selbst von sich, die EU wolle alles tun, was nötig ist, um klimaneutral zu werden. Das sehe ich bisher nicht. Es ist jetzt an der Zeit die Weichen zu stellen und realistische Ziele zu vereinbaren, um den Temperaturanstieg auf 1,5 °C zu begrenzen, anstatt Symbolpolitk zu betreiben. 
Wichtig ist: Klimagerechtigkeit und soziale Gerechtigkeit müssen zusammen gedacht werden! Bisher haben Sie keine globalen Gerechtigkeitsaspekte in Ihre Zielsetzung einbezogen. Um Ländern des globalen Südens zur Erreichung von Klimaneutralität mehr Zeit geben zu können, muss die EU deutlich früher klimaneutral sein – wobei auch wirtschaftsschwächere Staaten in der EU bedacht werden müssen, sodass diese ebenfalls mehr Zeit als wirtschaftsstarken Staaten eingeräumt wird. Bedenken Sie bitte auch, dass eine Menge in der EU konsumierte, aber nicht produzierte Güter, Treibhausgase in anderen Teilen der Welt emittieren.
Es ist jetzt an der Zeit die Welt nachhaltig, sozial und zukunftsfähig zu gestalten. Wir haben doch nur diese eine Erde! Je länger Sie warten, desto größer werden die Probleme und desto schwieriger und teuer wird es sie zu lösen. Bitte seien Sie sich Ihrer Verantwortung bewusst. Nehmen Sie eine authentische Führungsrolle in der Klimakrise ein. Handeln Sie in Einklang mit der Wissenschaft und tun Sie wirklich „whatever it takes“ (Corona hat uns gezeigt, dass das möglich ist).

Production d'électricité :
Pour commencer une petite note d'optimisme : l'union est (nettement) en avance sur les autres grands ensembles mondiaux dans la décarbonation de son mix electrique. La production d'électricité de l'union européenne est assurée à 60 % par des sources bas carbone (35 % renouvelables et 25 % nucléaire) là où celle des Etats Unis l'est seulement à 38 % (20 % nucléaire et 18 % renouvelables) et celle de la Chine à 30 % (26 % renouvelables et 4 % nucléaire). Si l'on veut aller encore plus loin, il faut encourager chaque Etat à développer conjointement les énergies renouvelables et nucléaire. Il faudrait aussi encourager les systèmes de stockage de type STEP (station de transfert d'energie par pompage) et accroitre les interconnexions entre les pays. Les centrales à charbon, fioul mais aussi au gaz sont à bannir le plus possible. Ne croyons pas que le gaz est un moindre mal, l'utilisation massive du gaz comme "énergie de transition" serait un crime contre le climat.
Résidentiel et tertaire
Là encore, le travail est initié par les réglementations thermique sur les constructions neuves qui permettent depuis quelques années de construire des bâtiments plus sobres. Mais c'est insuffisant (le taux de renouvellement des logements est de 1% par an environ). Il faut rénover massivement les logements et les bureaux existants en les isolant davantage et en remplaçant, dans la mesure du possible, les chauffages fioul et gaz par des chauffages biomasse. Cela créera de surcroit beaucoup d'emplois pour de nombreuses années.
Transports :
Il faut encourager les transports fluviaux et ferroviaires plutôt que routiers et aériens. L'hydrogène pourrait être utilisé pour la mobilité lourde (camions) et l'électrique pour la mobilité légère (voitures). Il faut également renforcer les transports en communs. 
Tout cela est ambitieux mais cela peut se financer par les economies que cela créera et par une taxe sur les importations hors union proportionée au comportement climatique du pays de provenance des importations. Les milliards sont de sortie pour relancer l'économie après le Covid19. Dépensons les biens, la recherche dans le domaine de la santé et le développement durable c'est plus important que de renflouer à tout prix les compagnies aériennes.

In this sense, it should be assumed that major financial mechanisms and additional aid will be required in an important way at the local level mainly during the firs years of transition. A transition of this nature will require massive investment at the beginning, ant then gradually be distributed for the maintaining of the "structure". This situation should be clearly exposed and managed in the coming initiative to increment reduction targets.
From this initiative is expected to obtain the overall architecture in which governments should work (the type and ambition of action and policies required beyond climate and energy, including transport, agriculture & forestry, nature-based solutions and green infrastructure, industry, waste, water, environment and consumer choices). Local governments are able to achieve some of these policies, but much of the measures should be done at the national/communitarian - legislative- level, which are far from being fast. Is supposed that local governments must respond as a consequence of the supra-local levels, so, if this initiative goes on, in order to be effective, the coming movements should be done at the maximum speed (considering deadlines and targets for 2030, 2050). 
Some impacts are expected to happen from the increasing of GHG reductions targets to 50% or 55% for 2030. Thus, the proposed transition should be realistic and coherent since some of the economic sectors more impacted by such transition (vehicle manufacturing, energy intensive industries, etc.) will directly have social and employment impacts. So, even when an initiative of this kind will require a significant shift of investments towards a more sustainable path, it also must include overwhelming economic strategies to counteract the transition periods. Also related to the economic impacts, it is well know that climate change affects differentially to rich and poor, old and young, and that these differences also have a clear territorial expression (for instance Mediterranean countries, have a drier climate and natural conditions), so, the assessment of expected impacts should also have into account such territorial differences.	
Emissions regarding of the transportation and mobility sector (including aviation and shipping) play a central role in this transition effort to climate neutrality by 2050. Thus, a comprehensive strategy as well as legal mechanisms (e.g. taxation, restrictions) becomes crucial. The targets you have set are unrealistic to reach the 1.5°C target. Based on the current state of scientific research on climate change (IPCC report), a 45% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 2030 compared to 2010 is urgently needed.
However, even the global warming of 1.5°C, as stated in the IPCC Special Report, does not include all risks of the climate system, as many factors are subject to great uncertainty and only the scientific consensus is presented. 

The CCS technologies included in the IPCC scenario would not allow the world to be decarbonised until 2050. However, the development of these technologies is not yet mature and so far no negative emissions from CCS technologies within the EU are foreseeable in the next few years. The reference to these technologies is subject to great uncertainty and depends on the degree of technological development. 
 You speak of a leadership role to send a more ambitious signal to the world community, as global progress towards the Paris targets is insufficient. You would take a leading role if the EU were to take seriously the current scientific state of affairs and the Paris agreement with its 1.5°C target. To this end, clear, far-reaching and drastic measures must be taken that finally make a realistic contribution to achieving the target. 
The EU should adopt a policy that protects life on the planet, now and in anticipation of future generations. 

Its draft lacks the global justice aspect. If the world is to achieve climate neutrality by 2050, the rich Europe, which has long been emitting greenhouse gases, must become greenhouse neutral much faster than the many developing countries. Because the countries of the global South will need more time. 

Your objective must also take into account the fact that large quantities of greenhouse gases are emitted in other parts of the world for consumption in Europe. Otherwise, outsourcing of emissions would be possible. 
You must be aware that an early reduction in emissions is easier, will lead to lower follow-up costs and is therefore the only sensible decision for the benefit of society. 

Tell the truth! This would be: "We are currently accepting a heating of the planet of 3°C by the end of the century and the exceeding of fatal climatic tipping points. We have no solutions for how civilizations can deal with the collapses that will then occur. Our goals are set too low to ensure a secure future for the younger generation."

For these reasons, I am calling for an amendment to your drafts. The target must be a reduction in greenhouse gas emissions to net zero by 2025 for the economically strong EU countries and by at least 2030 for the economically weaker EU countries. Include emissions caused by the EU in other countries. 

Many thanks!
Drop completely the plan. Economies has to be fixed first.

Es ist gut, dass die EU ihre Klimaziele für 2030 weiter verbessern möchte und nun den CO2-Ausstoß auf 50 bis 55% statt der ursprünglichen 40% gegenüber 1990 senken möchte. Doch leider ist das nicht genug um tatsächlich die Ziele des Pariser Abkommens einzuhalten. So wird die Erderwärmumg nicht auf unter 2 °C geschweige denn auf 1,5 °C reduziert. Um tatsächlich etwas zu bewirken und damit den Lebensraum zukünftiger Generationen zu sichern, sind drastischere Maßnahmen erforderlich. Wenn die EU wirklich als Vorbild in Sachen Klimaschutz vorangehen möchte, sollten wir bis 2030 klimaneutral werden und so anderen Ländern auf der Welt den richtigen Weg aufzeigen und ihnen bis 2050 die Möglichkeit geben, es der EU gleich zu tun.
Wir sehen anhand der aktuellen Coronapandemie, was eine Naturkatastrophe für Auswirkungen haben kann. Man mag sich nicht weiter ausmalen, wie dann die Folgen des Klimawandels aussehen werden. 
Kurzfristig bedarf es höherer Anstrengungen, doch sollten wir langfristig  denken und handeln und dabei die Verantwortung auch für kommende Generationen übernehmen. Deshalb sollte die EU-Kommission jetzt die nötigen Weichen stellen und nicht warten, bis die nächste Kommission im Amt ist. Laut der momentanen Planung soll erst im September getagt werden. Bis dann die nötigen Gesetze verabschiedet sind, ist viel zu viel Zeit vergangen.
Kim Rosebrock

Aena is one of the main airport operators of the world and is firmly committed to take action against climate change to achieve the Paris Agreement goals. In this regard, Aena consider this public consultation very positive but it is necessary to make some comments for its consideration.

In this regard, Aena is aware about the need to move towards a carbon neutral society so we are in favour of government policies that support decarbonisation and alternative fuels that can support us on our journey. In this path, we cannot forget the important role that air transport plays in the world economy, being especially significant in Spain due its key role in trade, tourism and investment. Additionally, air transport is the fundamental pillar to guarantee the connectivity of the territory, and its social and territorial development, given the geographical characteristics of Spain and its position as a peripheral country.

Consequently, Aena considers that to reach more ambitious decarbonization targets is necessary the development of new technologies but we have an overall risk since it is possible that they could not evolve as quick as the higher 2030 GHG emission reduction target requires. For this reason, and regarding the accomplishment of the new targets, we consider that investment and innovation should be push forward by EU politics for the aviation sector, being necessary to promote and guarantee the supply at airports for biofuels or alternative fuels for aviation. In addition, the development of other technologies such as electric propulsion would be beneficial to the sector's contributions to carbon emission reductions which must be incentivized economically to achieve the expected results in the shortest period of time.

In addition, Aena considers that there are certain social mobility risks related to higher aviation costs. As carbon costs, purchase of energy and new taxes on CO2 emissions for the aviation sector could lead to higher costs, airport fees and airlines fares will likely raise. Taking into account that around 80% of aviation CO2 emissions are emitted from flights of over 1,500 km in the world, for which there is no practical alternative mode of transport, this could have an impact on the number of passengers able to travel in the medium term and can lead to certain mobility restrictions for the entire society.

Bisher fokussiert sich der europäische Green Deal und das Klimaschutzgesetz lediglich auf das Ziel der Erreichung einer Klimaneutralität bis 2050 und gibt dabei weder konkrete Zwischenziele bis dahin an noch die Möglichkeit deren Kontrolle. Die Ziele sollen ab 2030 eigenständig von der Kommission alle fünf Jahre angepasst werden, anstatt dass ein unabhängiger, wissenschaftlicher klimapolitischer Beirat die Einhaltung der Ziele jährlich(!) kontrolliert. Ein solcher Beirat ist obligat, um das jährliche CO2-Budget sowie (nicht) erreichte Ziele öffentlich (!) herauszugeben und Empfehlungen für das kommende Jahr zu stellen, mit denen die Ziele zu erreichen sind (z.B. Divestment bestimmter Unternehmen etc..).
Sowohl um einen wissenschaftlichen Beirat als auch um Sanktionen für Mitgliedsstaaten bei Verfehlung der jährlichen Ziele muss das Klimaschutzgesetz unbedingt ergänzt werden!

Im europäischen Green Deal wird momentan die Prozentzahl der THG-Emissionsreduktionen bis 2030 diskutiert, welche unsere Zukunft dramatisch bestimmen werden. Weltweit bräuchten wir eine Reduktion unserer THGs um mindestens 65% bis 2030! 
Über eine Verschärfung des Emissionsreduktionsziels von derzeitigen 40% auf 50-55% soll erst im September 2020 getagt werden.
Erst im Juni 2021 soll schließlich festgelegt werden, wie EU-Gesetze verändert werden müssen, um die bis dahin festgelegte Zielmarke für THG-Reduktionen bis 2030 auch tatsächlich zu erreichen. Doch die EU muss sich schon JETZT, auf eine höheres Klimaschutzziel 2030 festlegen, um als Vorbild gegenüber anderer Weltregionen zu agieren! Die Verhandlungen dauern nicht nur zu lange, sondern behandeln außerdem viel zu geringe Zielsetzungen, um eine Vorbildrolle einzunehmen und die Pariser Ziele zu erreichen.
Auch wurden keine globalen Gerechtigkeitsaspekte in die Zielsetzungen miteinbezogen. Wir müssen im reichen, schon lange stark THG-emittierenden Europa natürlich schneller treibhausgasneutral werden als Andere. Bis 2050 muss die Welt laut IPCC klimaneutral sein – die EU müsste dies also schon viel früher sein, um Ländern des globalen Südens mehr Zeit zu geben und das 1,5°-Ziel global fair verteilt einzuhalten! Außerdem werden für Konsum in Europa große Mengen an Treibhausgasen in anderen Teilen der Welt emittiert - auch diese müssten in Ihrer Zielsetzung berücksichtigt und einem Outsourcing von Emissionen entgegen gewirkt werden.

Darum fordere ich, dass wir eine Reduktion der Treibhausgasemissionen auf Netto-Null bis 2025 für die wirtschaftsstarken EU Staaten und bis mindestens 2030 für die wirtschaftsschwächeren EU Staaten anstreben! Dabei sollen auch durch die EU verursachte Emissionen in anderen Staaten miteinbezogen werden!

Mit freundlichen Grüßen,
Julia Schatz (22, Medizinstudentin aus Erlangen)

Im "2030 Climate Target Plan" wird anerkannt, dass die Weltgemeinschaft nicht auf dem Weg ist, die Pariser Klimaziele zu erreichen. Der Plan sieht daher vor, die Klimaziele der EU zu verschärfen. Dennoch fühle mich persönlich von der Kommission und dem Vorschlag für dumm verkauft. Denn: auch die hier vorgeschlagenen Ziele sind nicht mit dem Pariser 1,5°C-Ziel vereinbar. Anstatt -50 bis -55% bis 2030 verlangt der IPCC, dessen Einschätzungen bisher stets noch zu optimistisch waren, eine Reduktion von -65% bis 2030 zur Einhaltung des 1,5°C-Ziels. Hinzu kommt, dass Europa mit die besten Voraussetzungen aller Weltregionen zur raschen Reduktion von Treibhausgasen hat. Andere Länder haben deutlich weniger Kapazitäten. Daher müssen wir - wie der Vorschlag ja auch prinzipiell anerkennt - eine echte Vorreiterrolle erfüllen. Das bedeutet aber, deutlich früher als andere die Klimaziele zu erreichen. Ich fordere daher die EU Kommission auf, offiziell das Ziel anzustreben die Netto-Treibhausgas-Emissionen der wirtschaftsstärksten EU-Länder bis zum Jahr 2025 auf Null senken, die der wirtschaftsschwächeren Staaten bis 2030. Es ist allemal klüger, am Anfang die größten Anstrengungen zu vollbringen und ggf. später Spielräume zu nutzen anstatt zu ambitionslos zu beginnen und am Ende (so wie es bisher stets gelaufen ist) die Ziele nicht erreichen zu können. 
Sollte sich die EU Kommission geringere Ziele setzen als jene, die der IPCC zur Einhaltung des 1,5°C Ziels vorschlägt, verlange ich, dass den entsprechenden Plänen klare Aussagen vergleichbar der Folgenden beigefügt werden: "Wir tun nicht genug, um nach aktuellem Stand des Wissens eine sichere Zukunft für die junge Generation und folgende Generationen zu gewährleisten. Wir nehmen eine Erhitzung des Planeten von 3°C bis zum Ende des Jahrhunderts und damit verbunden die Überschreitung fataler klimatischer Kipppunkte in Kauf. Wir wissen nicht, wie Europa und die Weltgemeinschaft mit den dann wahrscheinlich eintretenden Zusammenbrüchen umgehen können wird."

We welcome the ambition to include the contribution of all sectors of the economy and society for an increased climate target for 2030, to prepare the EU for the transition towards climate neutrality by 2050. But in the current roadmap, only maritime transport is considered while the rest of the blue economy and general seas and ocean are not considered. The ocean has taken up between 20–30% of total anthropogenic CO2 emissions since the 1980s (IPCC figures) and ocean-based mitigation options could reduce global greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions by nearly 4 billion tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent (CO2e) per annum in 2030 and by more than 11 billion tonnes per annum in 2050, relative to projected business-as-usual (BAU) emissions (Hoegh-Guldberg. O., et al. 2019). Reductions of this magnitude are larger than the emissions from all current coal fired power plants world-wide and more than China’s total emissions in 2014.

We request the inclusion of the ocean and seas, the blue economy and ocean-solutions into the EU’s 2030 Climate Target Plan, as almost half of the EU population lives less than 50 km from the sea and majority of large urban areas are concentrated along the coast (Eurostat figures). In addition, Tyedmers, et al. (2005) calculated that fishing fleets consume the same quantity of oil as the whole of the Netherlands. By limiting the action on the blue economy to maritime transport, the fisheries (or other) fleets are not considered.

The Climate Target Plan also referred to the land use sector and agriculture only for food provision, but the ocean-based food system (wild capture fisheries, aquaculture, and shifting human diets towards food from the sea) should be considered for climate action as well. The EU Maritime Spatial Planning Directive (2014/89/EU) provides a unique opportunity to address climate action at European coasts. Effective Maritime Spatial Planning integrates many activities affecting ocean and coastal areas, and prioritization of renewable energy and nature conservation can be explored.

Nature conservation is not highlighted in the Roadmap, but referred to as “natural sink”, even though nature remains the biggest ally to store carbon from the atmosphere. Restoration of vegetated coastal ecosystems, such as tidal marshes and seagrass meadows (coastal ‘blue carbon’ ecosystems), could provide climate change mitigation through increased carbon uptake and storage of around 0.5% of current global emissions annually (IPCC). The paper by Duarte et al. (2020) shows the key opportunities of saltmarsh, seagrass, kelp and oyster reef restoration all pointing to the importance of Blue Carbon and coastal defenses as well as water quality improvement and coastal protection, which will be important in the future. There are guidelines on how to include coastal wetlands in a country’s greenhouse gas inventory, which remain voluntary to adopt (Guidelines on The 2013 Supplement to the 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories: Wetlands (Wetlands Supplement)), but should be made more explicit in this Plan.

Climate change is a trans-boundary problem, but the actions and solutions has to be enforced at national and local level. The Roadmap should refer to which mechanisms will be in place to follow up and support implementation at EU Member State level.

Finally, an assessment on the society readiness to implement this higher level of ambition is crucial for the success of the 2030 Climate Target Plan, especially as investment by households and businesses are expected to rise the most. Developing a communication strategy to EU citizens will be needed, and lessons could be learned from the COVID-19 crisis, as citizens were able to accept difficult decisions with regard to their social life and ability to work, for the larger goal of sparing the health system.

Mit der Vereinbarung von Paris hat sich die internationale Staatengemeinschaft verpflichtet, auf mehreren Ebenen die Erderwärmung einzudämmen. Die nachhaltige Waldbewirtschaftung ist in der Vereinbarung von Paris explizit als eine der Tätigkeiten aufgeführt, die dem Klimawandel entgegenwirken. Die Europäische Union ist als Vertragspartner der UNFCCC aufgefordert, ihren Beitrag zur Erreichung der globalen Klimaziele zu leisten. Das kann nur dann erfolgreich und nachhaltig umgesetzt werden, wenn zum einen das Potential der nachhaltigen Waldbewirtschaftung ausgeschöpft und zum anderen die Substitutionsleistung des nachwachsenden Werk- und Rohstoffes Holz auf allen Ebenen genutzt wird. Wissenschaftliche Untersuchungen belegen, dass nachhaltig bewirtschaftete Wälder dauerhaft eine höhere CO2 Aufnahmekapazität aufweisen als nicht bewirtschaftete Wälder. Holz und Holzwerkstoffe spielen in der stofflichen und energetischen Verwendung eine wichtige Rolle beim Ersatz fossiler Materialien durch biobasierte Produkte. Der verstärkte Einsatz von Holz und Holzwerkstoffen in allen Bereichen der Bioökonomie, im Baugewerbe, in der Textilverarbeitung und als Teil eines nachhaltigen Energiemixes sind unverzichtbare Wege, um einen wichtigen Beitrag zur Erreichung der Klimaziele zu leisten. 
Eine wichtige Voraussetzung zum Erreichen der Pariser Klimaziele ist der Aufbau und Erhalt klimastabiler Wälder. Hierzu ist der notwendige Waldumbau konsequent weiter zu verfolgen und die Waldbesitzer sind dabei zu unterstützen. Eine einseitige Bewertung des Holzvorrates ist hierbei nicht zielführend.

Sie sprechen davon, das 1,5 Grad Ziel einzuhalten und hierfür eine Führungsrolle zu übernehmen. Dann tun sie dies auch bitte. Zeigen sie der Welt, wie die EU gemeinsam diese Ziele erreichen kann und nicht durch Kompensationen, indem wir Wälder in anderen Ländern aufforsten. Die EU ist eine Verbindung aus den höchsttechnologisierten Ländern der Welt, warum verwenden wir diese Wissen nicht um die Alternativen, die bereits vorhanden sind (Wasserstoff als Treibstoff, Wind und Solarenergie als Standard-Energie und einen einheitlichen Gebäude-Sanierungs-Standard und Neubau-Standard, der auf einem Null-Emmisionshaus aufbaut, warum werden in den unterschiedlichen Ländern nicht die Baumethoden des Holzbaues stark gefördert, obwohl man mittlerweile sehr viele Studien dafür hat, dass auch Hochhäuser daraus gebaut werden können und sie den Feuerschutzstandards in jedenm Land entsprechen können u.v.m.). Warum kann man nicht ein verstärktes Augenmerk auf die Bildung legen, die dafür sorgt, das die zukünftigen Generationen auch in allen Bereichen Nachhaltig handeln. Warum kann man die Subventionen für Gas, Benzin und andere Fossile Brennstoffe nicht auf die von erneuerbaren Ressourcen umschwenken, dann würden sich die fossilen Brennstoffe sehr schnell nicht mehr rentieren. 
Kann man Frimen nicht dazu bringen, dass sie nachhaltiger werden und wenn sie dies nicht sind sehr hohe Strafzahlungen und zusätzliche Kompensationen aufweisen müssen? Warum gibt es keinen Leitfaden, oder sogar Gesetze, der für jedes Land angepasst ist, das in unserer Gemeinschaft ist, damit wir zusammen so gut es geht Nachhaltiger werden. 
Warum wurde keine Klimagerechtigkeit mit in die Ziele mit einbezogen? Wir müssen viel schneller Treibhausgase verringern. Wir haben das Geld dafür und können dadurch die Vorbildfunktion wieder einnehmen. Laut IPCC muss die Welt bis 2050 klimaneutral sein. Die EU müsste also, um 
Ländern des globalen Südens mehr Zeit zu geben, viel früher klimaneutral sein. 
Sie erwähnen in Ihrem Papier, dass Sie einen "ausbalancierteren" Weg bis dahin wollen. Dabei wird nicht berücksichtigt, dass es am Anfang leichter ist Emissionen einzusparen, hinterher wird es schwieriger. Für einen ausbalancierten Weg müsste also am Anfang viel mehr eingespart werden als am Ende, damit es immer mit ähnlichen Anstrengungen verbunden ist. 

Dazu haben sie einmal gesagt, dass sie Alles tun würden (whatever it takes) um klimaneutral zu werden. Warum wird das dann nicht getan? Stehen sie nun zu ihrem Wort und setzen sie sich bitte durch, um auch weiterhin alle Grundrechte der Bürger der EU aufrecht zu erhalten.
